webTitle: Foot and mouth: let there be life

fields.headline: Let there be life
fields.standfirst: For  Jean  and  Nick Armstrong , as for so many who live on the land, Easter has been the time of rebirth and renewal. But not this year. The disease they feared struck earlier this month. Yet, even as Jean writes to friends from their silent, lifeless farm, she holds on to the belief that their faith and experience will kindle hope from the ashes of the pyres
fields.trailText: For  Jean  and  Nick Armstrong , as for so many who live on the land, Easter has been the time of rebirth and renewal. But not this year. The disease they feared struck earlier this month.
fields.body:
These last few days seem to have gone by in a sort of daze. The foot and mouth disease we all dreaded has hit the valley, with Nick and I being the first confirmed case on Tuesday morning. Keith Benn was confirmed Wednesday and no doubt there will be others.

Nick noticed on Monday morning when he fed the 60 ewes in the 2nd Croft that one old girl didn't come. He went to look for her and as he approached she ran with a limp to the food. He mentioned his concern for her at lunchtime and said she would need to be examined. After lunch, he went back to the field; although she seemed fine, he decided he would still catch her. On examination, he found two small cuts on her upper gums but nothing on her feet. He brought her home and called me to have a look.

Although it wasn't an obvious case, we felt we had to let the Ministry of Agriculture know. Vet arrived at 6.30pm, an American girl, drafted over with five others to help with the crisis. It was her first case so was very unsure. We went to look at the others in the field, caught a sheep we were suspicious of; it showed no clinical signs, but decided to bring her home too. By 9.30pm, Ellen, the vet, said she would have to get a second opinion and would come the next morning with a senior vet. Nick and I slept very little and at 4am decided to get up and go and see the two sheep. They seemed to be fine and certainly no worse. We milked the cows and did all the necessary routine work in the yard, feeding young stock etc. When I went to feed the calves and sheep over the road, I put some sheep rolls into the trough of the two isolated ewes. They ate immediately, so naturally I was very optimistic.

Ellen arrived around 10.30am with the more experienced vet. It was Richard, my nephew, and we could not have asked for anyone better; he was absolutely wonderful. After diagnosing the ewe as foot and mouth, and picking out four more from the flock of 60 she was running with, he rang London to confirm. Nick and I were devastated and for about 10 minutes Nick just went to pieces. Thankfully, Richard took over and organised everything; by 1pm, he had the ministry man, the valuers, the slaughter men and the sergeant from the Army in the yard.

I had expressed to Richard that Nick did not want his beloved cows burned on a pyre. He and Chris, the Army man, decided it needed to be a swift departure because they could easily become a hazard to the sheep on the fell that wandered about the roads encroaching upon the farm. This was a real blessing as some farmers have their animals lying dead and rotting around them for up to nine days before they are disposed of. Nick helped to pen the sheep because he was the only one who could work a dog. He then came into the house and we closed the curtains and stayed in. They were all slaughtered by 6pm.

Shortly after we came into the house, the telephone began to ring and we had a constant flow of family, neighbours and friends ringing with comforting words. Some knew what we were going through because they had already been through it, but all had a bond of unity and love. Richard stayed until around 9pm, long after the others had been fed and left. He sorted out signs on gates and disinfected footbaths and sprayed the dead animals with disinfectant. He then gave us both a hug and told us we would be all right because we still had each other. The phone went silent at around 11.15pm. We went to bed exhausted.

Next morning (Wednesday) was very weird. We awoke as usual at 5.30, both with shocking bad heads caused by the tension from the previous day. After taking a couple of Paracetamols each we got back into bed! In the 32 years we have been at Mosedale End we have never had a lie-in except when we have been ill. There were no sounds from the yard, no ewes bleating, no cows blaring or munching at the silage outside our bedroom window; we felt a real sadness at the silence.

We didn't go back to sleep but we did talk things through. What were our options? Where do we go from here? All Nick wanted to do the previous day was to sell the remaining implements and retire from farming. Now on reflection, especially as the grandchildren were so upset the night before at the thought of no lambs at Mosedale, Nick thought maybe we could have a flock of sheep again. The biggest problem, of course, will be hefting the sheep on the fell again. They have grazed on a certain area on the back of Skiddaw for generations; there are no fences yet they never stray from their patch. But Nick thinks with God's help, the dogs, and his experience, he can do it.

We got up around 6.30, had baths and hair washed ready for Chris and David, the ministry man, arriving at 7.30am. By 1pm, the wagons had arrived to pick up the sheep but a mix-up at the Maff offices had resulted in no wagons for the cattle. Chris was on the telephone immediately. We had a wonderful team of men working with us.

Eight-thirty on Thursday morning, the wagons for the cattle arrived, plus the men to do a preliminary disinfecting of the yards and the road through the village. Chris said we were the first in Cumbria to be diagnosed, slaughtered and the animals off the farm within 48 hours.

We can now only look to the future. I felt God gave us a great inspiration of hope on a most devastating day. As I went into the byre where the young stock were, on that Tuesday, the first swallow of spring flew in, chittered, flew around then back out again. I just felt God was saying: 'Winter is passed, here comes spring.' It gave me a real ray of hope. Even in the darkest of times, Jesus can shine His light. ('When Jesus spoke again to the people, He said, "I am the light of the world. Whoever follows me will never walk in darkness, but will have the light of life".')

The ministry have told us it will be around the end of May before anyone will be allowed back on the farm. The whole place has to be thoroughly cleaned, washed and disinfected. Everything has to be burned, straw, hay, even the sawdust. After all this has been done, we would love to have you come and stay with us for a few days.

webTitle: Major health risk as farm crisis grows

fields.headline: Major health risk as farm crisis grows
fields.standfirst:
• Leaked letter reveals fear over BSE carcass disposal
 Labour in emergency meeting over slaughter

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText:
• Leaked letter reveals fear over BSE carcass disposal
 Labour in emergency meeting over slaughter.
fields.body:
A package of emergency government measures to control the foot and mouth crisis will expose people to the potential risk of infection by the human form of mad cow disease, The Observer can reveal.

Under new guidelines to relax the rules governing the disposal of carcasses, the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food has told Britain's waste industry that it must use landfill sites across the country to dispose of cattle which might be infected with bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE).

As the Government battled yesterday to stop a political backlash over its handling of the issue, representatives of companies that operate landfill sites demanded 'unlimited indemnity' from the Government in case the infective prion which causes BSE in cattle escapes and causes human variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease in humans.

The companies fear they will be liable to law suits running into billions of pounds if the source of any new outbreak of human variant CJD is traced back to them. 'It would be a public health disaster,' said one senior source in the industry.

The move reveals the increasing concern over the public health implications of burying and burning hundreds of thousands of animal carcasses. On Friday the Government abandoned the burying of thousands of cattle at Hallburn aerodrome in Cumbria after locals complained of choking smoke, and grease-laden ash covering their houses.

The Government's Cobra task force met in emergency session yesterday and officials launched a rearguard action to stop the slaughter policy spiralling out of control. On Friday Agriculture Minister Nick Brown admitted that the Government was being overwhelmed by the number of livestock which needed to be slaughtered and then disposed of. Yesterday figures revealed that 408,000 carcasses were lying in fields waiting to be buried or burnt, and that more than 500,000 were awaiting slaughter.

William Hague, the leader of the Opposition, said that it was time for the Army to be put in operational control of the epidemic as Maff was clearly failing to cope. 'The speed of the slaughter process still needs to be speeded up further,' he said. 'In about 40 per cent of foot and mouth outbreaks, the animals aren't being slaughtered within 24 hours.'

But a letter obtained by The Observer, written by one of Britain's leading experts on waste disposal, reveals high levels of concern about the public health implications of the new policy.

The letter, written by Dirk Hazell, head of the Environmental Services Association which represents landfill companies, says: 'We are extremely concerned at any pressure exerted on our members to receive carcasses of cattle at landfill.

'Until the outbreak of foot and mouth disease, cattle carcasses over 30 months old were being sent to prescribed outlets (high temperature incineration). We are extremely concerned as to the known resilience and potential toxicity of the BSE prion. The high risk associated with the prion means that much greater caution must be exercised than with the foot and mouth virus which is much less resilient and does not damage human health.

'The order of magnitude in the difference between the prion and the virus is similar to that between Alzheimer's disease and athlete's foot.

'It was not considered safe before the outbreak to landfill carcasses of cattle aged between 30 months and 60 months and we must emphatically insist that our members must have a watertight, permanent and comprehensive indemnity.'

In Northern Ireland a cull of 4,000 cattle was ordered after the province suffered its second case of foot and mouth disease, six weeks after the first case and several weeks after Government controls were supposed to have halted the spread of the disease to new areas.

Northern Ireland Agriculture Minister, Brid Rodgers, confirmed that an emergency meeting of the Northern Ireland Executive would be held tomorrow to discuss the fresh outbreak. 'It goes without saying that this is a huge setback for our agriculture industry,' he said.

The outbreak, on a farm in Ardboe, Co Tyrone, reveals that the disease can lie dormant for weeks, or that it can be carried on the wind across large distances from the British mainland.

Maff is so concerned about a public backlash on the issue of human health that it has started offering families complaining of the smell of rotting carcasses in north Devon temporary accommodation.

webTitle: Rebuilding Wembley is 'barmy' says McAlpine boss

fields.headline: Rebuilding Wembley is 'barmy' says McAlpine boss
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of Wembley
fields.trailText: Rebuilding a national football stadium at Wembley is 'barmy' and the plan should be scrapped, says a leading construction expert.
fields.body:
Rebuilding a national football stadium at Wembley is 'barmy' and the plan should be scrapped, says a leading construction expert.

Oliver Whitehead, chief executive of building giant McAlpine, said: 'The idea of building a national stadium in a residential area of north London, where transport infrastructure is poor and can't be made much better, is barmy. Why can't we build it in a place that needs regenerating? If we have to have a national stadium in London, it should be at King's Cross, where you can build it with a convention centre. Otherwise let's take it to the Midlands.'

The criticisms come as Football Association executives have given the project two months before rethinking the entire £660 million rebuilding plan. But Sir Rodney Walker, chairman of Wembley National Stadium Limited (WNSL), the FA subsidiary overseeing the project, said: 'The only Wembley deadline is my self-imposed deadline, and provided we continue to make the progress we've made in the past few weeks I'm confident we'll hit that deadline.'

The timetable is already slipping. WNSL confirmed it will not go to the City to raise a £475m syndicated bank loan until June at the earliest. Last week it emerged that the FA is prepared simply to refurbish the existing stadium if its financing plans are rejected by the City. WNSL suffered one rejection by the banks last December. The plan relies on the stadium making a £30m annual profit.

webTitle: Disney 'meatspace' magic went rancid in cyberspace

fields.headline: Disney 'meatspace' magic went rancid in cyberspace
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: The past, someone observed, is another country. So is Disneyland, Paris. In a (shamelessly successful) attempt to earn brownie points with his children, your columnist journeyed there last week expecting to be bored and found himself instead attending a fascinating masterclass in brand management, image manipulation and the exploitation of a certain kind of intellectual property. And he came away wondering about the difference between virtual reality and its 'real' counterpart.
fields.body:
The past, someone observed, is another country. So is Disneyland, Paris. In a (shamelessly successful) attempt to earn brownie points with his children, your columnist journeyed there last week expecting to be bored and found himself instead attending a fascinating masterclass in brand management, image manipulation and the exploitation of a certain kind of intellectual property. And he came away wondering about the difference between virtual reality and its 'real' counterpart.

It's a commonplace that Disneyland is a virtual world. It is a subtly controlled, all-encompassing environment in which millions of people pay lots of money to subject themselves to sophisticated methods of crowd control. It is efficient, safe, well managed and clean. Most of the customers seemed satisfied. The most extraordinary thing was that while the majority consisted of families with young children, there were also a good many adults on their own. (The other striking thing was the number of people from Eastern Europe, for whom a trip to Disneyland clearly represented the fulfilment of a lifetime's ambition.)

Brand management was everywhere - mainly of Disney properties, but also of those of a small number of corporate 'partners', notably American Express, McDonald's, Nescafé, Kodak and IBM. When lifesize models of Tigger, Eeyore, Gepetto and other cartoon characters suddenly appeared, they were besieged by autograph hunters and amateur photographers in the kind of scrum that normally forms only around David Beckham. And although there was no overt huckstering, the marketing and selling operation parted customers from their money like a high-powered vacuum cleaner sucking up dust. Nobody, but nobody, left the Park without at least one souvenir. Many departed clutching dozens of trade-marked or copyrighted articles.

But although Disneyland is a virtual world, it is firmly rooted in the real one of rain, fences, motorways and security guards. Its success as a commercial venture demonstrates the power of American corporate culture in what John Perry Barlow calls 'meatspace'. Disneyland shows how the mass media can be used to transform customers into enthusiastic consumers of whatever Disney chooses to pump at them.

But switch to cyberspace and this aura of invincibility dissolves. Two years ago, Disney forged an online strategy which involved replicating what it does so successfully in meatspace - harnessing its brands to achieve a dominant position. To do this it created a new subsidiary, the Disney Internet Group, with the intention of eventually spinning that off. The company decided that a key requirement was to build an all-encompassing portal, and created Go.com by cobbling together assets (such as the Infoseek portal) it already owned. The idea was that Go would eventually become the parent for all of Disney's online activities.

Many analysts assumed that the traditional Disney mixture of magic and muscle would eventually make Go.com a serious rival for Yahoo! and the like. After all, Disney has rarely, if ever, failed to achieve its commercial ambitions in meatspace. But it didn't happen, and two months ago the company closed its loss-making internet subsidiary, absorbed the Disney Internet Group into the parent company and abandoned Go.com with the loss of 400 jobs.

The contrast between this humiliating reversal in cyberspace and Disney's overweening dominance in the real world is very striking. What it suggests is that consumers are less controllable online than offline and that the power of real-world brands doesn't translate on to the net with anything like the efficiency that cynics expected. Which, of course, explains why the corporate world is so baffled by the net. Long may this bafflement continue.

When lifesize models of Tigger, Eeyore, Gepetto and other cartoon characters suddenly appeared, they were besieged by autograph hunters and amateur photographers in the kind of scrum that normally forms only around David Beckham. And although there was no overt huckstering, the marketing and selling operation parted customers from their money like a high-powered vacuum cleaner sucking up dust. Nobody, but nobody, left the Park without at least one souvenir. Many departed clutching dozens of trade-marked or copyrighted articles. But although Disneyland is a virtual world, it is firmly rooted in the real one of rain, fences, motorways and security guards. Its success as a commercial venture demonstrates the power of American corporate culture in what John Perry Barlow calls 'meatspace'. Disneyland shows how the mass media can be used to transform customers into enthusiastic consumers of whatever Disney chooses to pump at them. But switch to cyberspace and this aura of invincibility dissolves. Two years ago, Disney forged an online strategy which involved replicating what it does so successfully in meatspace - harnessing its brands to achieve a dominant position. To do this it created a new subsidiary, the Disney Internet Group, with the intention of eventually spinning that off. The company decided that a key requirement was to build an all-encompassing portal, and created Go.com by cobbling together assets (such as the Infoseek portal) it already owned. The idea was that Go would eventually become the parent for all of Disney's online activities. Many analysts assumed that the traditional Disney mixture of magic and muscle would eventually make Go.com a serious rival for Yahoo! and the like. After all, Disney has rarely, if ever, failed to achieve its commercial ambitions in meatspace. But it didn't happen, and two months ago the company closed its loss-making internet subsidiary, absorbed the Disney Internet Group into the parent company and abandoned Go.com with the loss of 400 jobs. The contrast between this humiliating reversal in cyberspace and Disney's overweening dominance in the real world is very striking. What it suggests is that consumers are less controllable online than offline and that the power of real-world brands doesn't translate on to the net with anything like the efficiency that cynics expected. Which, of course, explains why the corporate world is so baffled by the net. Long may this bafflement continue. john.naughton@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Rooney reads the runes
fields.standfirst:
Former high-flier Baltimore Technologies is plotting a comeback, writes Frank Kane

More internet news
fields.trailText: Former high-flier Baltimore Technologies is plotting a comeback, writes Frank Kane
fields.body:
For a man who has just had his second controversial profits warning in a month, Fran Rooney is in a surprisingly upbeat mood.

The soft-talking chief executive of Baltimore Technologies, the Dublin-based hi-tech company that was once the darling of the stock markets, has some tricks up his sleeve. 'We have very serious plans for the company, and this market has only just started. I and the board are very committed to it.'

He will need to be committed. The shares plunged last week when he told the market that he would have to shave another £1.3 million off the expected earnings for the first quarter of the year. In the context of the great hi-tech bear market, that amount is relatively small. But the news caused Baltimore shares, which were once flying high at more then £13.50, to lose another 20 per cent, closing at 74p. That puts a value on the London and Nasdaq-quoted stock of less than £400m.

This is a humiliating fall from the levels of just a year ago, when Baltimore briefly elbowed its way into the FTSE 100 with a capitalisation of £4.5bn. But Rooney has learned to be wary of the caprices of the stock market.

The date 23 March will be forever engraved on Rooney's heart. He arranged a briefing for analysts at Chief O'Neill's hotel in Dublin's glitzy Smithfield, intended mainly to introduce the investment community to some new faces on the board. One analyst interpreted his comments to mean that Baltimore's business was slowing down, and promptly walked out to tell his clients to dump the stock. They did, and began a stampede that ended with Baltimore losing nearly a third of its value in just a few hours. No wonder last week's announcement was much better handled.

'The market is very sensitive about companies in our sector. Shareholders are keen to see where real value lies,' says Rooney. In fact, last week's announcement bears testimony to the effect of the O'Neill's débcle. The reason Rooney again had to prune forecasts was because some customers used the 23 March warning to delay signing deals with Baltimore, hoping to get a better price later on from the (supposedly) cash-strapped company.

Rooney, who has been feted as Mr New Economy by presidents and prime ministers on both sides of the Atlantic, has the chance to get his revenge on the market. He believes the clients who held back last quarter will soon sign up, on the same terms, and will boost second-quarter earnings. 'These deals are very close to being signed,' he said from New York. 'Closing big software deals takes some time. It's not as though somebody just phones you up and you send an invoice. We are currently at the letter-of-intent stage.'

Baltimore's business could not be any nearer the sharp end of the new economy. It provides security and authorisation software for banks, securities houses, and government agencies that use the internet commercially on a daily basis. His clients include the US Central Intelligence Agency, and Britain's Ministry of Defence and Metropolitan Police. None of those organisations has a reputation for welching on their debts, or for driving a particularly hard bargain.

But Rooney sees the way forward for Baltimore in the new business stream. 'There is quite a substantial pipeline of new business coming through, especially with the banks and telecoms companies. The security infrastructure of internet operations is a real growth opportunity. For example, we've just done a deal with the Australian tax office which could be the start of things to come in other countries.'

He has also recently signed deals with Nokia and Motorola to provide security systems for their growing internet access businesses, and has targeted the Japanese telecoms market for further expansion.

So, for a company supposedly in the doldrums, Baltimore is feeling reasonably optimistic. 'We have to just keep on doing the deals we're doing, and get on with the business,' says Rooney. 'It's been a distraction over the past few weeks, having to reassure the market about prospects, but now we have to carry on with the business.'

He sees scope in licensing Baltimore's services to banks and telecoms companies whose web services will be managed by Baltimore - for a substantial fee.

In terms of market share, Baltimore is doing well, albeit in a bombed-out market. It recently overtook Entrust as the market leader, and the number one ranking should win it more business.

The financial background is encouraging. Even on the reduced first-quarter figures, there is still 150 per cent growth, year on year. After a call on shareholders last year, and even allowing for the expansion spree that has seen 60 per cent of the business coming from outside Europe, the company has £130m cash in the bank. 'That's enough to keep us going for three years, even if we never make a profit,'adds Rooney.

There was once speculation that Microsoft might want to bid for Baltimore, which Rooney sarcastically turned on its head by suggesting that it was just as likely that Baltimore might take over Bill Gates's company.

Now his ambitions with the world's leading computer company are more limited, but none the less significant. 'As the internet becomes a day-to-day method of doing business, the next big thing will be the need to authenticate yourself. We are the only company in the world that provides that kind of service, especially in the field of public key infrastructure, and we see a great opportunity to co-operate with Windows 2000 on this.'

He is a firm believer in the new economy, but is also a realist. 'The internet is not going away, but the downturn will force people to look at ways of using the internet more efficiently. The priorities will be to build a web presence, and to make it secure. It's in the second part of that where we will benefit. I think we'll see less "free" access. The net will become a subscription-based service, which will require authentication. That's our speciality.'

The people who walked out of Chief O'Neill's, some of whom still have reservations about the company, will be glad to hear all this, but their immediate concern is to hear how Baltimore will tackle its comparatively high cost base. A succession of deals over the past three years has added to the company's office and administrative costs, especially in the US and Far East, where most of the expansion has taken place.

'We would have done the cost-cutting anyway,' says Rooney, 'because we had to review the operations we've taken over. It doesn't necessarily mean redundancies, because our budgets included an element of job hirings that may not be appropriate now.'

What Rooney is not going to do - at least not until much later in the year - is make any kind of financial forecast. As a major shareholder in Baltimore, he knows, from bitter experience, what that kind of thing might cost him.

fields.headline: Virgin to sue Railtrack
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Virgin is poised to sue Railtrack this week for up to £150 million to cover losses caused by disruption following last year's Hatfield crash.
fields.body:
Virgin is poised to sue Railtrack this week for up to £150 million to cover losses caused by disruption following last year's Hatfield crash.

The figure is more than twice the level of compensation offered by the rail network owner to Virgin earlier this year and could start a flood of claims from operators. Sources said that operators were privately being encouraged by the Strategic Rail Authority (SRA) to launch legal action against Railtrack to force the issue of compensation.

Railtrack chief executive Steve Marshall told The Observer that the company would 'robustly defend' claims that pushed up the £400m offered to operators in January.

Virgin's lawsuit will cover losses of up to £100m it says it has already incurred - and which prompted Virgin to put up some fares by 10 per cent earlier this month. It also wants an agreement from Railtrack to cover loss of passenger demand over the coming months as persistent delays discourage lucrative business travel - estimated at a further £50m.

Railtrack offered Virgin £60m in compensation in January but the company claims the disruption to the network has been far worse and gone on longer than anticipated.

Industry sources believe that if Railtrack loses it will have to go back to the rail regulator or the SRA to request more emergency subsidy in addition to the £1.5 billion granted earlier this month.

Marshall plans to tell the financial markets on 24 May, at the time of the annual results, what extra operating costs the company has incurred as a result of Hatfield, including extra rerailing and measures to prevent the 'gauge corner cracking' problem that led to the crash and still plagues the network.

It emerged this weekend that the SRA is considering a compromise between Virgin and GNER for the delayed East Coast passenger franchise and upgrade project.

SRA chairman Sir Alastair Morton is believed to be keen for GNER to continue running the line. But he could invite Virgin, its 49 per cent shareholder Stagecoach and construction partner Bechtel in as risk-sharing partners on the £2bn upgrade project.

The contest is being rerun and fresh bids will be submitted on Tuesday, with the industry pushing for a decision before a general election.

fields.headline: Airlines' tears at bedtime
fields.standfirst:
BA and Virgin pinned their hopes on boosting business traffic just as the US faltered, writes Joanna Walters

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: BA and Virgin pinned their hopes on boosting business traffic just as the US faltered, writes Joanna Walters
fields.body:
The Americans are not taking it lying down. Or sitting up for that matter.

British Airways and Virgin Atlantic have spent hundreds of millions of pounds fitting beds in business class. But with the US economy taking a nap, the fear is that transatlantic business travel could be decimated - and all those expensive new beds and posh seats will be left unfilled.

This summer season could see US executives staying at home and using the telephone, crossing the Atlantic less frequently or flying economy when they do travel.

At least there'll be plenty of room at the 'back of the bus', what with American holidaymakers opting for Lima or Lisbon rather than the Lake District, with its foot-and-mouth pyres and closed paths.

BA and Virgin make most of their profits in the US market, so any softening of the transatlantic business on the back of plummeting stock markets and chilly economic outlooks is particularly bad news for them.

In 1999-2000, £3 billion of BA's £9bn turnover was generated by American business, as was £308 million of its operating profit, against losses of £310m in Europe.

There is some comfort for all UK airlines this weekend as record numbers of Britons jet abroad to escape the rotten weather and the great rural roping-off. Thomas Cook has reported bookings for Easter up 7 per cent on last year. A record 570,000 travellers are expected to trek out of Heathrow and Gatwick over the four-day weekend. The summer package-holiday market is also buoyant.

But while a general exodus from the UK over the next six months will cheer airline accountants, this fillip will do little to offset the effects of a big business and leisure stay-away from the US, Canada and Continental Europe - on top of the slump in the Far East.

Andrew Light, airline analyst at Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, said last week: 'There is a lot of uncertainty, and many signs out there that business travel demand will weaken.'

The City is eagerly waiting BA's announcement of its March traffic figures on Thursday, and its comment on trading prospects. Analysts and brokers hope to glean an idea of how the twin factors of foot and mouth and economic uncertainty are affecting current business - and future bookings.

BA chief economist Andrew Sentance has already said that 'some softening' was expected in the market but that the airline's outlook was 'positive' because it is cutting capacity.

Light said: 'Capacity management is a big driver of earnings, and BA is cutting its capacity by 20 per cent between 2000 and 2002 . That is the place to be at this stage of the cycle.'

The plan to boost profit margins by eliminating seats and using smaller long-haul aircraft flying more often, with beds in business class, was devised under previous BA chief executive Bob Ayling. He lost his job last year after presiding over losses of £115m, a cabin crew strike and a drastic plunge in customer service and staff morale.

Now his successor, Rod Eddington, is reaping the benefits of this plan as the airline slowly turns finances round. Several analysts believe it is too soon to declare the strategy an unmitigated success, but the signs are good. On 22 May, Eddington is expected to announce pre-tax profits of about £225m for the financial year just ended and these are forecast to rise above £500m in 2003.

He has also made headway with the awkward problems of battered staff morale, declining levels of customer service and rising costs that plagued the airline in the late Nineties. Eddington is in the process of selling no-frills airline Go, has announced 1,000 job losses at BA and is slimming the route network from Gatwick.

Meanwhile Virgin Atlantic's pre-tax profits for 1999-2000 fell from £99m the previous year to £40m - which became just £4m on turnover of £1bn once exceptional items were stripped out. Profits for the year just ended are expected to be flat, despite turnover growing at 10-15 per cent a year.

Spokesman Paul Moore said: 'We have seen, from the US particularly, a slowdown in bookings that's been fuelled mainly by fears over foot and mouth.'

BA and the British Tourist Authority are putting on a special plane next week to fly travel industry chiefs from the US, Japan and continental Europe around Scotland and the Lake District to convince them that Britain is not entirely a tourist no-go zone.

But business travel brings in the big bucks. The CBI last week slashed its forecast for UK economic growth for this year from 2.5 per cent to 2 per cent because of foot and mouth and gloom in the US. If there is a transatlantic business-travel slump over the summer, BA and Virgin will have to fight hard to recoup their investments on the new products.

There is anecdotal evidence from City observers to back BA's claims that it is winning market share from rivals on routes where it has introduced flat beds with privacy screens in business class - routes such as London to New York, San Francisco and Hong Kong.

BA has spent £600m on first, business class and economy refurbishments and Virgin is spending £40m on beds and on-board cocktail bars.

Moore said it was important to note that BA and Virgin between them were winning business on the North Atlantic from big US rivals such as American Airlines, United, Continental and Delta, which do not offer beds. 'The two UK airlines have raised the benchmark on product, and the others have fallen behind,' he said.

Observers say the big US airlines are typically offering corporate customers discounts of 25-45 per cent on business-class fares - average price £3,000 for London-New York - and that this is damaging everyone's bottom line.

There could be a full-blown fares war before the summer is out. One City analyst said: 'If the really big US banks start downgrading to economy or restricting travel altogether, it's panic stations.'

webTitle: Sainsbury's told its healthy child range misleads

fields.headline: Sainsbury's told its healthy child range misleads
fields.standfirst: Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Supermarket chain Sainsbury's is being accused by nutrition experts of misleading parents with its new Blue Parrot Cafe range of foods targeted at children.
fields.body:
Supermarket chain Sainsbury's is being accused by nutrition experts of misleading parents with its new Blue Parrot Cafe range of foods targeted at children.

The products include everything from fish fingers and curry sauce to fresh fruit and are the result of a massive research programme by the retailer involving children, parents and food experts. But an investigation by the campaign group Focus on Food and The Observer has found that many of the most popular products compare poorly in fat content and price with their standard equivalents.

In a randomly selected basket of children's favourites, the poor performers included burgers (less protein and more fat), fish fingers (less protein and more salt and sugar) and mashed potato shapes (twice as much fat).

Fresh fruit and vegetables selected and packaged with the Blue Parrot logo were up to three times as expensive as the non-branded equivalents. In one case (organic cherry tomatoes), there was no difference at all bar the price: the children's version was three times as expensive.

Focus on Food campaign director Anita Cormac said she was concerned that the range, which promises parents a healthier option for their children, may be misleading. 'I would not say they are hoodwinking parents but I would say it is bamboozling,' she said. 'My concern is that it is not clear unless you look very carefully at the labelling whether or not these convenience foods are more advantageous. I question the whole culture of convenience foods for children.'

Lizzie Vann, the woman credited with pioneering organic baby food 10 years ago, said any range targeted at children should be entirely organic. 'One in two babies eat organic food now and the hope is that parents will carry that through to older children. We have to get to the roots of the problem. Garlic baguettes, beef lasagne and cocktail sausages contained less fat and more protein than the other ranges. Cheese spread contained less protein than the best-known brand equivalent, but it was lower in fat.

Sainsbury's said the range had been created after extensive research by its senior nutritionists and was endorsed by the Hyperactive Child Support charity. 'The range covers 180 products and was devised with the concerns of parents in mind,' said a spokesman. 'We consulted 18,000 mums and kids over six months to find out what they wanted. We believe the range offers excellent quality and nutritional value. It is not intended to be just a health food range.'

He added that parents said they hated throwing food away, so wanted packaging that allowed for smaller portions, and research showed that not all parents were concerned about the salt or sugar content of their children's food.

'We don't believe any other supermarket is offering such a well-researched range of foods for children,' he said.

fields.headline: Loyalists cancel Easter parades
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: A Bitterly contested loyalist parade has been called off because of the foot and mouth crisis.
fields.body:
A Bitterly contested loyalist parade has been called off because of the foot and mouth crisis.

The Apprentice Boys of Londonderry cancelled tomorrow's Easter Monday demonstrations, including the march on Belfast's nationalist Lower Ormeau Road which it was feared could have turned into a sectarian showdown.

The parade would have been the order's first there in two years but Alastair Simpson, the order's governor, insisted yesterday's decision had nothing to do with the row over the route.

He said: 'The Apprentice Boys have made a decision because of foot and mouth disease here, especially in the north-west. That's it. Full stop.'

The parade in south Belfast, which would have included 50 people, is one of dozens leading up to the main demonstration in Limavady, Co Londonderry.

The order was granted permission to march along the disputed section of road nine days ago by the Parades Commission, a ruling nationalist residents failed to overturn through a number of challenges, going as high as the Court of Appeal in Belfast. The verdict had been welcomed by the commission's chairman, Tony Holland.

Residents who had described the verdict as 'disappointing but not surprising' were jubilant at the turn of events yesterday.

John Gormley of the Lower Ormeau Concerned Community group said it was now calling off all counter-demonstrations. He said: 'We're assuming that it's not going to happen and in that case our protest action will not take place.'

Tommy Cheevers, spokesman for the Belfast Walker Club of the Apprentice Boys, whose 27 members were to have taken part in the Ormeau Road march, said: 'Of course we're disappointed but once again we have shown our responsibility to wider society, given the recent outbreak of foot and mouth.'

The club respected the wishes of the organisers and 'applaud them because it has been a very brave decision', he said.

But Cheevers attacked the residents' group, saying it had been intent on staging an illegal gathering - 'and God knows where that would have led to'.

webTitle: Anger at amnesty for IRA fugitives

fields.headline: Anger at amnesty for IRA fugitives
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: More than 60 fugitive IRA terrorists will be allowed to return to Northern Ireland as free men under a new government amnesty,  The Observer can reveal.
fields.body:
More than 60 fugitive IRA terrorists will be allowed to return to Northern Ireland as free men under a new government amnesty, The Observer can reveal.

The move comes just weeks after a controversial amnesty was given to Maze prison escapers. The second batch of so-called On-the-Runs could be home before the end of the summer.

Senior security sources said the fugitives included an IRA terrorist wanted for the murder of an 11-year-old boy and the deaths of several police officers along the Irish border.

Unionists last night accused the British Government of 'bending over backwards' to appease republicans by allowing the terrorists to return to the province. Earlier this year the Government dropped charges against 40 men, including several Maze escapers.

News of the second amnesty will anger relatives of the dozens of people 'expelled' from Ulster by the IRA during the Troubles. Last week, the IRA ordered the expulsion of Londonderry man Joseph McCloskey after he became involved in a pub fight with a senior republican.

Sinn Fein has handed over the 61 names to the Northern Ireland Office, which in turn has asked the RUC to determine the exact nature of the charges against each person.

A spokesman for the Northern Ireland Office said: 'We will continue this policy as we said we would last September. At the time of that announcement by Peter Mandelson that some OTRs could go back home, we said we would look at this issue again.'

The new amnesty includes some of the IRA's most ruthless and dedicated members from feared units such as its South Armagh Brigade. On the list is Lenoard 'Bap' Hardy, who served five years in an Irish jail for possessing explosives.

The RUC wants to question Hardy about an IRA car bomb explosion in Co Down in 1982 that killed an 11-year-old Protestant schoolboy.

Unionists are outraged at what they see as another 'sop' to Sinn Fein. Jeffrey Donaldson, the anti-Agreement Ulster Unionist MP, said: 'Here we have the NIO granting an amnesty to IRA terrorists while there are hundreds of people living in exile because the IRA will not let them return home.'

fields.headline: Armed vigilantes patrol 'peace lines'
fields.standfirst:
UDA gunmen take control of Belfast's streets
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: UDA gunmen take control of Belfast's streets.
fields.body:
The men were brandishing guns. One held a Browning automatic; two others had revolvers. More than 100 less prominent figures had to make do with baseball bats and sticks. Yet none of them fear the police - because there are no police to fear. Meet the new law enforcers on Belfast's streets: gangs of armed men free to do as they please.

This was Friday night in North Queen Street in the loyalist Tigers Bay area. The sight of men with guns walking through the streets has become so commonplace over the past few weeks that nobody even remarks on it anymore. The men, members of the UDA, claim to be patrolling the so-called 'peace lines' between Catholic and Protestant areas.

But there is no peace. 'Look around you,' the UDA's North Belfast commander said. 'There is hardly a peace process at all in areas like Tigers Bay. I'm in my forties and can remember when the Troubles started in the early Seventies, and this is exactly what it was like then. Men patrolling the streets, no one about the area, people living here expecting attacks.'

He defended the presence of his men on the streets: 'Look, nobody wants to be here. We'd all rather be at home with our families than out here all night. But if we weren't here the community would demand it or else people in Tigers Bay would just move out of the area for good.'

In recent weeks there have been claim and counter-claim about who was responsible for stirring up the sectarian tensions that the three-year-old Good Friday Agreement promised to help end. Sinn Fein's Gerry Kelly blames the UDA for orchestrating recent attacks on the nearby republican New Lodge during which a pensioner was savagely beaten.

But the UDA men gathered with their baseball caps pulled down over their scarves blame republicans for the attacks. The UDA commander claims the incursions are part of a wider agenda to depopulate Protestant enclaves. 'The New Lodge is supposed to be bursting at the seams and Sinn Fein wants to expand the area, so it can get more of its supporters into North Belfast. These attacks are designed to push the peaceline back further, to create more space for their own people and increase the seats Sinn Fein has in the constituency. They [IRA/Sinn Fein] are orchestrating the attacks,' he says.

What is not disputed on both sides, however, is the chronic shortfall in RUC numbers. Officers are leaving the force in droves in the wake of the Government's controversial policing re-forms. RUC commanders have been unable to deploy meaningful patrols in many areas of Belfast. The vacuum is now being filled by the gunmen on both sides.

The UDA man points to the last two houses on North Queen Street before it spills into the New Lodge. Both are empty, boarded-up shells. The third house is unoccupied because the woman living there fears for her life and those of her three children. Close to where the armed men are 'patrolling', Angela Maddison sits in her pyjamas inside her mother's house.

She claims that three weeks ago a mob from the New Lodge tried to break into her house at 5.30am. She says she would have been killed had the vigilantes not arrived on the scene so promptly. The 31-year-old mother now shares a house with five oth ers, refusing to sleep in her own home. 'If it wasn't for the UDA vigilantes in this area, I would be out of Tigers Bay for good. That's how most women feel in this area now, they want protection and the police are too slow to do anything about it,' she said.

Across North Queen Street, the UDA's North Belfast brigadier stood under a mural paying homage to the organisation's ruthless band of killers, the Ulster Freedom Fighters. Asked what would happen if the UDA patrols caught young Catholics on the wrong side of the line, the terrorist was blunt.

'This is a message to the Sinn Fein/IRA leadership: stop allowing your people to attack areas like Tigers Bay or things are just going to get worse for everyone in this part of Belfast. The danger of trouble here getting out of control can't be exaggerated, somebody will get killed. We don't want that, but we will not stand by and let Protestants be driven from their homes,' he said.

As he finished speaking, the three armed men returned. A cluster of excited young men gathered around, masks were pulled off, the three guns stuffed into a bag. The trio vanished into the night. In the distance, a police siren wailed.

fields.headline: Heaven can wait
fields.trailText: 'I'm tired of religious bods, like that vicar the other week, slagging off single parents and blaming us for the sins of the universe.'
fields.body:
Please don't be alarmed, but I'm thinking of becoming a devil worshipper. I'm aware that Easter weekend is hardly the most tasteful time to make an announcement like this. It's a bit like declaring one's decision to cease being a vegetarian on a turkey farm the night before Christmas. Thing is, I'm a bit bored with Jesus. It's all getting a bit old (man), and I'm tired of religious bods, like that vicar the other week, slagging off single parents and blaming us for the sins of the universe. I'm starting to think if I shop around a bit, I could come up with a better deal, win myself some incentives- a bit like looking for a mortgage, only this time we're putting my soul up as collateral. That's the way I'm thinking right now. What's more, I seem to be far from alone in my blasphemy.

You can tell you're getting old when the atheists start looking young. Crises of faith used to happen as part of one's college course. The realisation that God didn't exist tended to arrive at exactly the same moment as the realisation that hangovers did. These days, we'd be considered slow off the mark. The 'yoof' of today are out there, pigging out on chocolate eggs right this second, and while they could probably name the members of Atomic Kitten and Radiohead without a moment's pause, my bet is they wouldn't know the names of the disciples, or even the gospels, if you threw a Gideon bible at them. Indeed, the son of God currently seems to rank somewhat lower in juvenile awareness than Britney, Ronan, Leonardo, or any other false god one might care to mention. The harsh truth being that, compared to even the most bottom-rung celebrities, Jesus has become very small fry.

So, has Jesus lost it? By which I mean has He, the holiest of the holies, the son of the creator, who came down to earth to preach peace and joy, and who suffered and died on the cross for our sins, hit a bit of a career trough? Is Mary's son underperforming? Or, to couch it in terms even the most shallow of people could understand, has the son of God failed to have a 'hit' for some time, and consequently been struck off the great guest list in the sky? It certainly looks like it to me.

When I was young, caring about Jesus was just something you did. There was no question about it. If you didn't, you were left in no doubt that, when you died, your soul would be thrown on to a filthy lice-infested skip to be eaten by the wild dogs of hell. (And let's not even get started on the small print of Catholicism.) These days, God and Jesus, the ultimate father-and-son song and dance act, don't seem to have quite the same cachet. There was a time when Jesus Christ was regularly hailed as the first great pop star, the greatest of them all. These days, nobody calls Jesus a pop star any more - almost as if He's not fab enough to be likened to someone as important as a pop star. Indeed, the average young person's definition of eternal damnation seems to be not being allowed to stay up to watch Pop Stars.

Admittedly, times change, as do religions, as do regions. My own bout of god-bothering, from the ages of seven to 11, may have been inspired, at least in part, by the fact that I grew up in the country. Everybody believed in God in the provinces in the 70s - there was nothing else to do. Indeed, that's what Jesus had going for him in those days - vast areas of the civilised world were as bored rigid as Middle America is today. Now that drugs have hit even the sleepiest of our shires, things just aren't the same. What young person would want to sit around thinking about God when, with one pop of a pill, they can actually see Him? Saying that, if you ask me, it was when British homes started getting colour television that Jesus really started to lose His captive UK audience.

Celebrity is what screwed up Jesus Christ's demographic. When Christ, Cat Stevens and Uri Geller was all there was, everything was fine. Now that Christ has got some serious competition, He's struggling to hold our attention. Instant gratification has dulled the fear of eternal damnation (though we might think differently on our deathbeds). Most tellingly, celebrities, our false gods, seem to have caught the real God napping. As Christ himself might say: It's a bummer. One suggestion: Considering that so many celebrities like to swan around behaving like they're Christ, maybe JC could retaliate by behaving like a celebrity. Start appearing in churches and demanding decent plonk be used as His blood, that sort of thing. It couldn't hurt.

In the meantime, I'll look into this devil-worship business. Compared to most celebrities, Satan must be a pussycat.

webTitle: 'The night the tanks took my home'

fields.headline: 'The night the tanks took my home'
fields.standfirst:
Jason Burke in Rafah, Gaza, sees the human tragedy endured by a people in the grip of mounting violence

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Jason Burke  in Rafah, Gaza, sees the human tragedy endured by a people in the grip of mounting violence.
fields.body:
You hear them coming before you see them. A ragged volley of shots, then a ragged running file of young men, automatic rifles held high, the name of God on a black bandanna around foreheads.

They are Islamic Jihad, one of the most extreme groups fighting the 'intifada' (uprising or, literally, shaking off) in the Israeli-occupied Palestinian territories of the Gaza Strip and the West Bank. Here in the city of Rafah - a grey sprawl of crumbling concrete tenements and squalid, potholed roads hard against Gaza's southernmost frontier - they are the nearest to heroes anyone has.

None is older than 18. They scramble on to a makeshift stage, form a line and fire another fusillade into the air. Their shouted hopes for martyrdom in the struggle against their 'oppressors' crash out through the loudspeakers' static into the city's sabbath evening calm.

The rally - to commemorate an Islamic Jihad fighter killed in Rafah by rockets fired from an Israeli helicopter gunship 10 days before - goes on until dark. Later two gun battles break out in the city between locals and the Israeli settlers who live on the choice coastal land to its west.

Elsewhere in Gaza, an Israeli civilian is shot and injured, two bombs are defused, a mortar is fired into a Jewish settlement and seven Palestinians are hurt when Israeli troops open fire on stone-throwers. It has, all agree, been a quiet day.

Since this intifada started seven months ago 469 people - including 386 Palestinians - have died. For once that total has not been added to.

But, despite the occasional hiatus in the violence, few believe peace will come soon. In Gaza - where more than a million Palestinians are crammed into a stretch of parched land 30 miles long and five wide - they talk of a 'summer of blood'.

Only 10 miles from Rafah, hard by the brilliant blue Mediterranean, 25 Palestinian families are living in tents. Last week their homes were bulldozed by the Israeli army. In the firefight that followed, two people were killed and dozens injured.

For the first time the Israelis had launched a ground attack deep inside territory that, according to agreements signed in the ailing peace process, is under the authority of President Yasser Arafat's government. The demolition was the strongest signal yet from Ariel Sharon - the hawkish former general elected as Israeli Prime Minister in February - that he will not moderate the hardline stance that brought him to power. On election, he pledged to use language 'the Arabs would understand'. At 1am last Wednesday, the people of Khan Yunis found out what that meant.

Noor Abu Lous, a pretty, bright-eyed, seven-year-old girl, stood among the rubble of her home and told The Observer how the helicopters had woken her.

'I heard them and stopped sleeping, and when the shooting started my mummy and daddy told me not to be scared, so I wasn't because they were looking after me and there is always shooting here,' she said. 'But then the tanks came and we had to run away, and then I was frightened and when we came back our house had gone.'

The Israelis claimed Arafat's forces were using the houses as cover to fire on a settlement and army bunkers less than 500 metres away.

'Of course people were shooting. This is our land, our children,' said Majid Abdallah, 37. 'The Israelis have destroyed some houses, so now we will shoot from a new front line. Will they come and flatten that? Will they demolish the whole city?'

The answer from Israeli hardliners would be 'yes'. Last week the leader of the ultra-religious Shas party, Rabbi Ovadia Yosef, called for Arabs to be killed with missiles. After the demolition in Khan Yunis, Sharon said the Palestinians were responsible for the violence, and there could be no negotiations until they ended it. He could accept a Palestinian state on a maximum of 42 per cent of the West Bank, but would not withdraw from any settlements or make concessions on Jerusalem or other key biblical sites.

No one, least of all Sharon, believes Arafat could accept such a deal. The Palestinian leader rejected far more generous terms from Sharon's predecessor, Ehud Barak, last summer. For Sharon, every day that Israel continues to exist and thrive - however threatened - is a small victory. And he knows that for Arafat time is running out. Ask the people of Khan Yunis about the intifada and they - like the Islamic Jihad zealots in Rafah - will swear their readiness to die. Ask them about their support for Arafat, and the response is different. 'He is far away from his people now,' said Abdallah Abu Ahmed, 45. 'He is now a high jet-setter, not with us here in the dirt.'

Such sentiments are growing. The al-Aqsa intifada - named after the seventh-century mosque in Jerusalem that was the focus for the revolt - is reaching a critical point and manyquestion its direction and purpose.

Partly this is due to the economic suffering the intifada has brought. A blockade imposed by the Israelis has caused massive unemployment, inflation and shortages. The Israelis are also withholding crucial tax receipts. As a result, Arafat's fledgling Palestinian Authority is in dire difficulties.

'The public sector and the authority itself is on the verge of collapse. The intifada has been like an earthquake shattering the whole economic structure,' said Arie Arnon, professor of economics at Ben Gurion University.

One thing Arafat still shares with his people is a sense of betrayal. Though the Arab world has pledged financial support for the intifada, only a trickle has got through. Though they expect little, they also feel betrayed by the West. The new administration in Washington has made it clear it wants to stay out of the conflict.

Noor Abu Lous, standing in the rubble in her pink plastic sandals, sings to music booming from a loudspeaker set up by Hamas, one of the most radical Palestinian groups. Her father translates the lyrics: 'We are alone, we are alone, we will fight on because we are alone.'

webTitle: Necessity test is mother of Gats intervention

fields.headline: Necessity test is mother of Gats intervention
fields.standfirst: The World Trade Organisation has plans to replace that outmoded political idea: democracy
fields.trailText: The World Trade Organisation has plans to replace that outmoded political idea: democracy
fields.body:
Trade Minister Dick Caborn says 'nothing' all day, and this keeps him very, very busy. Caborn is busy reassuring the nation that nothing in the proposed General Agreement on Trade in Services (Gats) threatens Britain's environmental regulations. Nothing in Gats permits American corporate powers to overturn UK health and safety regulations. Nothing in Gats, which is part of the World Trade Organisation regime, threatens public control of the National Health Service. The official statement of what Gats doesn't do goes on for pages and pages.

So I've been perplexed by Caborn and his EU sidekick, Pascal Lamy, rushing to Geneva and Washington and God knows where else to argue over the wording of rules that do nothing, change nothing and mean nothing.

But then last week 'something' came through on my fax machine. And this confidential document from the WTO Secretariat, dated 19 March, is something indeed: a plan to create an international agency with veto power over parliamentary and regulatory decisions.

When Winston Churchill said that 'democracy is the worst form of government except all those other forms that have been tried from time to time' he simply lacked the vision to see that in March 2001, the WTO would design a system to replace democracy with something much better: Article VI.4 of Gats. And this unassuming six-page memo, now modestly hidden away in secrecy, may one day be seen as the post-democratic Magna Carta.

It begins by considering the difficult matter of how to punish nations that violate 'a balance between two potentially conflicting priorities: promoting trade expansion versus protecting the regulatory rights of governments'.

Think about that. For centuries Britain, and now almost all nations, has relied on elected parliaments, congresses, prime ministers and presidents to set the rules. It is these ungainly deliberative bodies that 'balance' the interests of citizens and businesses

Now kiss that obsolete system goodbye. Once Britain and the EU sign the Gats treaty, Article VI.4 of that treaty, the Necessity Test, will kick in. Then, as per the Secretariat's secret programme outlined in the 19 March memo, national parliaments and regulatory agencies will be demoted, in effect, to advisory bodies.

Final authority will rest with the Gats Disputes Panel to determine whether a law or regulation is, in the memo's language, 'more burdensome than necessary'. And Gats, not Parliament, will decide what is 'necessary'.

As a practical matter, this means nations will have to shape laws protecting the air you breathe, the trains you travel in and the food you chew by picking not the best or safest means for the nation, but the cheapest methods for foreign investors and merchants.

Let's get down to concrete examples. The Necessity Test has already had a trial run in North America via inclusion in Nafta, the region's free trade agreement. Recently, the state of California banned a petrol additive, MBTE, which has contaminated water supplies. A Canadian seller of the 'M' chemical in MBTE filed a complaint saying the rule failed the Necessity Test.

The Canadians assert that California could simply require all petrol stations to dig up their storage tanks and reseal them - and hire a swarm of inspectors to make sure it's done perfectly. The Canadian proposal might cost Californians a bundle and would be impossible to police. That's just too bad. The Canadian proposal is the least trade-restrictive method for protecting the water supply. 'Least trade-restrictive' is Nafta's Necessity Test.

If California does not knuckle under, the US Treasury may have to fork out $976 million in compensation to the Canadians.

The Gats' version of the the Necessity Test is Nafta on steroids. Under Gats, as proposed in the memo, national laws and regulations will be struck down if they are 'more burdensome than necessary' to business. Notice the subtle change. Suddenly the Gats treaty is not about trade at all, but a sly means to wipe away restrictions on business and industry, foreign and local.

So what 'burdensome' restrictions are sitting in the corporate cross-hairs? The US trade representative has already floated proposals on retail distribution. Want to preserve Britain's green belts? If some trees stand in the way of a Wal-Mart superstore, forget it. Even under the current, weaker, Gats, Japan was forced to tear up its own planning rules to let in the retail monster boxes.

The Government assures us that nothing threatens its right to enforce laws in the nation's public interest. Not according to the 19 March memo. The WTO reports that, in the course of the secretive multilateral negotiations, trade ministers agreed that a Gats tribunal would not accept a defence of 'safeguarding the public interest'.

In place of a public interest standard, the Secretariat proposes a deliciously Machiavellian 'efficiency principle': 'It may well be politically more acceptable to countries to accept international obligations which give primacy to economic efficiency.' This is an unsubtle invitation to load the Gats with requirements that rulers know their democratic parliaments could not otherwise accept. This would be supremely dangerous if, one day, the US elected a president who wanted to shred air pollution rules or, say, Britain elected a prime minister who had a mad desire to sell off the rest of his nation's air traffic control system.

How convenient for embattled chief executives. What elected congresses and parliaments dare not do, Gats would require. Under the post-democratic Gats regime, the Disputes Panel, those Grand Inquisitors of the free market, will decide whether a nation's law or a regulation serves what the memo calls a 'legitimate objective'.

While parliaments are lumbered with dated constitutional requirements to debate a law's legitimacy in public, with public evidence, and hearings open to citizen comment, Gats panels are far more efficient. Hearings are closed. Unions, as well as consumer, environmental and human rights groups, are barred from participating - or even knowing what is said before the panel.

Is the 19 March memo just a bit of wool-gathering by the WTO Secretariat? Hardly. The WTO was working from the proposals suggested in yet another confidential document also sent to me by my good friend, Unnamable Source. The secret memo, 'Domestic Regulation: Necessity and Transparency', dated 24 February, was drafted by the European Commission's own 'working party', in which the UK ministry claims a leading role.

In a letter to MPs, Trade Minister Caborn swears that, through the EC working party, he will ensure that Gats recognises the 'sovereign right of government to regulate services' to meet 'national policy objectives'. Yet the 24 February memo, representing the UK's official (though hidden) proposals, rejects a nation's right to remove its rules from Gats jurisdiction once a service industry is joined to the treaty.

Indeed, the EC document contains contemptuous attacks on nations claiming 'legitimate objectives' as potential 'disguised barriers' to trade liberalisation. Moreover, there is a codicil that regulation must not be 'more trade restrictive than necessary', ready for harvesting by the WTO Secretariat's free market fanatics.

Not knowing I had these documents in hand, Caborn's office this week maintained that Gats permitted nations a 'right to regulate to meet national policy objectives'.

I was not permitted to question the Trade Minister himself. However, the Caborn letter to MPs admits that his pleasant interpretation of Gats has not been 'tested in WTO jurisprudence'. This is, after all, the Minister who, with his EU counterparts, just lost a $194 million judgment to the US over the sale of bananas.

Now, I can understand how Caborn goofed that one. Europe argued that bananas were a product, but the US successfully proved that bananas were a service - try not to think about that - and therefore fall under Gats.

And that illustrates the key issue. No one in Britain should bother with what Caborn thinks. The only thing that counts is what George W Bush thinks. Or, at least, what the people who think for Bush think.

Presumably, Caborn won't sue the UK for violating the treaty. But the US may. In a way it already has. Forget Caborn's assurance - we need assurance from President Bush that he won't use Gats to help out Wal-Mart - or Citibank or Chevron Oil.

The odd thing is, despite getting serviced in the bananas case, Caborn and the Blair government have not demanded explicit language barring commerce-first decisions by a Gats panel. Instead, the secret 14 February EC paper encourages the WTO's Secretariat to use the punitive form of the Necessity Test sought by the US.

So there you have it. Rather than attack the rules by which America whipped Europe, Caborn and the EC are effectively handing George Bush a bigger whip.

webTitle: Maria Scott: Of low inflation and overblown marketing

fields.headline: Of low inflation and overblown marketing
fields.trailText: 'Big City payouts at the tail end of the boom were blamed last week for an unexpected rise in average earnings.'
fields.body:
If there was little sympathy from the salaried classes for City high-fliers facing lean times in a flattened stock market, there will be even less following news last week that City bonuses could undermine further cuts in interest rates.

Big City payouts at the tail end of the boom were blamed last week for an unexpected rise in average earnings - which could, in turn, forestall another rate cut.

Homeowners struggling to pay mortgages out of ordinary salaries - those for whom pay rises of much more than inflation are just a fond memory - will not be best pleased to learn that further relief is threatened by stratospheric earnings among bankers, stockbrokers and fund managers.

If they are also nursing losses on an individual savings account bought a year ago they will be feeling even more inclined to join the anti-capitalism protesters in London on May Day.

In time-honoured tradition, fund managers launched a slew of technology funds just as the market was peaking. As with previous similar marketing fests, investors have been hurt. The result has been disillusion and a huge drop in the sale of equities Isas in the run-up to the end of the 2001 tax year; the peak time for Isa sales.

Small investors appear to be more sanguine about market falls now than they were at the end of the Eighties, when the 1987 crash sent many rushing to sell out at the worst possible time. Statistics from the investment management industry and anecdotal evidence suggests there has been less inclination to sell this time around.

But the drop in Isa sales indicates that perhaps the most fundamental lesson of all has yet to be learnt. Fund managers launch new funds to feather their own nests, not yours. If investors have learnt to hold on during the bad times, they may be even more vulnerable to exploitation through overblown marketing in future.

The Financial Services Authority has warned us all that we have to wake up to the realities of low inflation, which includes prolonged pain in paying off debt and lower expectations for returns on investments.

The regulator's warning surely strengthens the case for it to get tough in controlling the use of past performance figures in advertisements for investment funds.

'Aaaaaaaaaaaaaagh!!!!'

My wife rushes in, thinking I must at the very least have got my testicles trapped in the door of the dishwasher, but no, I have merely opened a letter from the Halifax cheerfully advising us that our mortgage has gone up by £385 a month. It seems no further action is required on my part, except obviously to consider my fallback position of having the house seized by bailiffs and moving into something made of breeze blocks in the middle of nowhere, which I believe is called 'downsizing' and, actually, was quite the lifestyle statement of the 90s until we got fed up of reading about people who had escaped the rat race to reflect on how much quality time they can devote to talking to each other about not having any meaningless possessions or electricity.

I drive off to the barber's already mentally composing a judiciously worded letter to the customer care manager suggesting that, technically, OK, yes, that does seem to be my signature on what in the clear light of panic seems now to be a classic Mephistophelean home-loan agreement promising two carefree years of easy payments, sunny weather and naked clones of Uma Thurman relaxing in Jacuzzis full of Guinness followed by a four-year lock-in clause of eternal damnation and hellfire featuring the white-hot pitchforks of 7.5 per cent variable rate and extra wattage of Andrew Lloyd Webber for anyone trying to escape to the Bradford & Bingley, but hang on_ there is surely the small matter of our many years of devotion to the Halifax in which we have routinely forgiven them their innumerable endearing faults, not least a tendency to have the only member of staff with a key to the pencil drawer stuck on the bus somewhere when we're trying to open a savings account, or mislay vital records of our existence the moment we need £5 out of the machine for some groceries. Does loyalty count for nothing?

Bunny, my barber, has some financial advice to impart, though it seems to involve getting up early on Sunday mornings and looking for rare examples of early barometers at car-boot sales. 'Or you could cut your own hair,' he laughs, not realising that of course some people think I already do (just kidding, Bun). But I have my own ideas and soon afterwards am standing in the bookie's explaining to the man that I urgently need six winners for the Grand National. He is happy to oblige for a small handling charge.

When I get back, the phone is ringing. I leap to answer it, assuming it must be the Halifax calling to say it's all been a ghastly mistake and offering to settle any marriage counselling bills that may have accrued since this morning. But no, it's my mum ringing to tell me that Dad has a new Zimmer and keeps escaping from his chair and going off to butter his own bread in the kitchen. I'm glad he's up and about - a far cry, we agree, from the day after his stroke when the doctors were asking if they ought to wake him up or whether Mum wanted the insurance money instead.

How is the house sale going, I ask, because the last I heard she was all set to put a postcard in the newsagent's window, having already had the estate agent round to ask how much the place is worth and whether a stairlift counts as a feature. No, she says, everything is on hold owing to my brother having painted the front of the house up to the windowsills before realising how long the ladders weren't. 'It looks quite nice from the back though,' she says. I point out that prospective buyers might get a bit suspicious if they can only view from the kitchen window of the house behind. But by the time Mum has stopped bringing me up to date on modern house-selling techniques, I have forgotten about the National and turn on the TV just in time to see my six horses throwing their jockeys over the second fence, having worked out how much easier it is to slither about in the mud without someone on your back hitting you with a stick. And I think even our major high-street financial institutions can learn something from that.
