webTitle: Comment: Ask no questions and you won't hear any cover ups

fields.headline: Ask no questions...
fields.standfirst: ...and you won't hear any cover-ups. Whether it's the Falklands, arms to Iraq or the Wessex affair
fields.trailText: ...and you won't hear any cover-ups. Whether it's the Falklands, arms to Iraq or the Wessex affair.
fields.body:
It is a social error of the grossest kind to confuse the Lord Chamberlain and the Lord Great Chamberlain. Penny Russell-Smith, the Queen's PR, strongly implied that the distinction must be grasped by all who wished to shine at the best garden parties. The Lord Chamberlain was not 'that chap in tights who walks backwards at the state opening of Parliament,' as I had foolishly thought. 'No, no, no, no!' she cried. 'That's the Lord Great Chamberlain. The Lord Chamberlain appears at state banquets, not the procession to Parliament.'

The Lord Great Chamberlain has Her Majesty's gracious permission to sling a ceremonial key from his belt. He may also have the right to claim the bed slept in by the monarch on the night before a coronation - the authorities conflict on this point. The present Lord Great Chamberlain is seventh Marquess of Cholmondeley (pronounced 'Chumley'). The Chumleys were in an ancient and ugly scrap with the Earls of Ancaster and the Marquesses of Lincolnshire (both pronounced as you'd expect) over who should hold the title until 1902, when the contesting families agreed they should take turns to fill the hereditary office, reign by reign.

The Chumleys didn't know it at the time, but the power-sharing compromise - a Good Friday Agreement for the English aristocracy - was a great bargain. The lottery of biology gave them Elizabeth Windsor, whose reign began in 1952 and shows no signs of stopping. A noble personage connected to the last of the Ancasters or Lincolnshires - the titles are extinct, as I'm sure you know - will be left with the inevitably short reign of an aged Charles III as a consolation prize. The Guardian and Independent say Lord Carrington could be that personage, but my mind had been boggled by Lord Great Chamberlains by the time I dug out their reports and I had lost the will to fact check.

I did find that the completely separate Lord Chamberlain is Richard Luce. He has an ornate key of his very own, but must keep it in his hip pocket. He is 'the Firm's' chief executive officer, who vets candidates for Palace jobs and is the chairman of monthly board meetings of royal department heads. Lord Luce was appointed by and is answerable to the Queen, and it must be his duty as a courtier to work to keep the office of head of state as the irrevocable freehold of a clan of reactionary billionaires; to ensure that there is a Charles III. The most slack-jawed monarchist would find it hard to argue he has the fierce independence necessary to produce a rigorous review of royal conduct.

Buckingham Palace has argued just that. Sophie Wessex's bletherings demanded that something must be done. The Palace responded by saying Luce would hold an inquiry into how royals should behave in the business world. His career as a courtier is not the only handicap he must struggle to overcome as he tries to draw up rules for an open, modern monarchy. I can't, for example, see how he can be anything but pleased by the Wessex girl's sighs that an ignorant public had failed to see the statesmanly qualities of Willie Hague, or by her weird portrayal of Gordon Brown as a blood-sucking Bolshevik. Luce was a Tory MP from 1971 to 1992.

If he is a true monarchist as well as a loyal Conservative, he should also find it difficult to condemn her PR firm's exploitation of royal connections. Monarchy is the exploitation of connections. If you don't have a blood connection to the House of Windsor you can never be head of state, however wise or popular you may be.

In one respect, however, Luce is well-qualified for the job. His career has been a preparation for the moment when he would be called to play one of the Establishment's finest gambits: the incurious inquiry.

After Margaret Thatcher came to power in 1979, Luce became the Minister of State in the Foreign Office responsible for the Falkland Islands. (He served under the Foreign Secretary, Lord Carrington, who may yet be the next Lord Great Chamberlain.) The FO dismissed the belligerent noises coming from the Argentine military junta as typical Latin machismo. The Argentines invaded and about 1,000 servicemen (British and Argentine) died in an unnecessary war. Luce and Carrington resigned in April 1982 before the fighting had scarcely begun.

Their departures are remembered as honourable political acts. Successive Foreign Office Ministers had suggested to the Argentines that Britain was prepared to share the sovereignty of the Falklands. It wasn't a ludicrous policy then, and is a sensible one today, now that Argentina is a stable democracy. For all their other failings, Luce and Carrington didn't convince the Argentines that Britain had no interest in defending the islands by announcing that the survey ship Endurance would be withdrawn from the South Atlantic - the news came from the Ministry of Defence. Nor did they persuade Argentina that Britain cared so little for the islanders it would force them to accept second-class British citizenship - that was the Home Office.

They could scarcely be blamed for the incompetence of the intelligence services which weren't able to tell the Cabinet if enemy forces were going to invade until six hours after they had landed. Their self-sacrifice protected many backs - including the exposed back of Margaret Thatcher.

In February 1983 Luce was reappointed to his old job in the Foreign Office. His restoration was helped by the incurious official inquiry of the 77-year-old Lord Franks. Franks detailed all the blunders which had led to the invasion in his report of January 1983. But a feeling of detachment descended on him, when he had to name the someones who had blundered. It was so powerful it detached him from the evidence and compelled him to conclude that: 'We would not be justified in attaching any criticism or blame to the present Government for the Argentine junta's decision to commit its act of unprovoked aggression.'

Luce was back in the game and quickly concerned himself with arms sales to Saddam Hussein. As far as the public knew, there were no sales. Britain had declared that it would not sell 'lethal arms' to either side in the Iran-Iraq war. For reasons of commerce and diplomacy - Saddam was the favourite of the West and Saudi Arabia - military equipment was still trundled to Iraq.

Luce wanted to enforce true neutrality and proposed a tough statement that no weapons would be sold to either side. This raised what Paul Foot and Tim Laxton describe in the indispensable Private Eye pamphlet on the scandal as a 'howl of anguish' across a Whitehall fearful that huge sales to Saudi Arabia and Iraq would be lost. Luce was seduced and gradually his admirable statement of principle became what the late Alan Clark, a Minister very keen to merchandise death, called 'Cheshire Cat' guidelines.

'They were high-sounding,' said the old groper, 'combining it seemed both moral and practical considerations, and yet imprecise enough to allow real policy consideration to override. Far from being restrictive [the formula] was open to argument in every one of its elements.'

When Sir Richard Scott was called to investigate arms-to-Iraq, he was struck by Luce's determination to release the statement of policy very quietly. In a note from Luce to Geoffrey Howe, he wrote that he did not want 'a high-profile' announcement but 'careful background briefings to selected Members of Parliament and the press'.

The Scott Report remains the epitaph of the Tories. Its account of how Ministers preferred suppressing evidence which would save the innocent directors of Matrix Churchill from prison to having their dealings with Saddam exposed can leave readers never wanting to see another Conservative government. But when he had to apportion blame, even Scott became an incurious inquirer. Although he had said that Parliament and public were 'designedly' misled, he concluded that Ministers had 'not acted with any duplicitous intent'.

At least the Scott Report was published and readers can take a radically different view. Last week Buckingham Palace said the Queen may not publish the results of Luce's inquiry. Penny Russell-Smith went further and told me that the inquiry wasn't really an inquiry at all - incurious or otherwise. It was merely a 'consultation' between the Queen, her courtiers and the odd civil servant. Excluded from the list was the House of Commons.

I forgot to ask if she knew of any other modern country that would put up with an unelected head of state determining her own rules of conduct without taking instructions from elected representatives? Or with a revolving door between the Conservative Party and the palace? Or Lord Great Chumleys who scuttle backwards in the legislature?

webTitle: Girls lead the pack in new gangland violence

fields.headline: Girls lead the pack in new gangland violence
fields.trailText: They are violent, they hate women and are behind a surge in gang-related violence across Britain. Meet the latest phenomenon behind a surge in crime: lone teenage girls working with a pack of young men.
fields.body:
They are violent, they hate women and are behind a surge in gang-related violence across Britain. Meet the latest phenomenon behind a surge in crime: lone teenage girls working with a pack of young men.

A new breed of street gang, composed of teenage boys with a single female member, has been identified by criminologists after it swept across the United States to become increasingly apparent here.

Delinquent young females are rejecting the notion of 'girl power' and with it the support of members of their own sex.

Instead, they seek membership of male gangs by showing they are equally capable of violence and aggression. Once accepted, the girls often become hostile to all other females.

In extreme cases, criminologists believe the presence of a single female member can boost the levels of violence within the gang as a whole, and point out that in the past year a number of notorious crimes have been commited by groups of offenders matching this profile.

Last week detectives investigating the murder of a man who was kicked and punched to death charged eight teenage boys and a 16-year-old girl with violent disorder in relation to the killing.

The man was set upon in London last summer after going to the aid of his friend who was being robbed.

Criminologist Dr Jody Miller is the author of One Of The Guys, a new book published after a five-year study into the involvement of young women in street gangs in Britain and America. She found that the common perception of girls forming their own gangs as a form of empowerment does not necessarily hold true.

'Previous research led me to expect that when I talked with girls in gangs, they would emphasise the importance and strength of their female friendship networks and the family-like nature of these bonds.

'Instead, in many instances I found quite the contrary: many girls told me they were "like dudes in girls' bodies" who thought most girls were untrustworthy and felt they far preferred the company of young men.

'These girls found the notion of all-female gangs laughable and silly. They strongly supported the hierarchy within their gangs based on masculinist status.'

Last summer 17-year-old Toni Blankson, the sole female in a six-strong gang of petty thieves based in central London, was jailed for life for the murder of a law student.

Blankson and her friends had mugged Timothy Baxter and Gabriel Cornish, beating them unconscious. Both victims were then hurled from Hungerford Bridge into the River Thames as Blankson urged her fellow gang members on with cries of 'Do it, do it'. Cornish survived but Baxter, a 24-year-old law student, drowned.

Minutes after the attack a CCTV camera filmed Blankson kissing her 15-year-old boyfriend, then laughing and joking about what they had done. One social worker described her as 'the coldest young offender I have ever dealt with'. In February 19-year-old Emma Oates, the sole female in a Newport-based gang of four teenagers, was sentenced to life for the brutal racist murder of Indonesian-born Jan Pasalbessy. Oates, her boyfriend and two others had beaten and kicked Pasalbessy to death in the grounds of the Royal Gwent Hospital in front of his 14-year-old daughter. Oates's own child also watched the attack from her pushchair.

Last month 18-year-old Claire Marsh became the youngest female in Britain to be convicted of rape. Marsh, the sole female in a nine-strong gang known as the Drayford Crew, had held down the victim while the boys in the gang took turns to rape her.

Marsh, who was said to revel in her status as 'one of the lads', joined the gang after going out with one of its members. She fought to ensure she was the only female with whom the gang found favour.

The rape victim said that before the attack began she had felt safe because of the presence of another female. Instead, Marsh encouraged the attack. 'But by the minute our eyes met, I knew that she wouldn't help me. Her face was hard and fixed and she was laughing and pointing and saying things like "Yeah, go on, do her".'

During the past decade the number of women sentenced for violent crimes has more than doubled and the rate of increase shows no signs of slowing down.

In 1985 violence against the person accounted for only 3 per cent of recorded crime committed by girls under 14. This has now jumped to 9 per cent, almost equal to the figure for teenage boys.

The fact that women are drinking more than before is also seen as a factor, especially as alcohol contributes to more than 80 per cent of violent crimes.

The problem has become so acute that Holloway Prison has introduced an anger-management course for the 40 females aged between 15 and 20 who are held in its recently opened D-Zero young offenders' unit in a bid to reduce levels of violence.

Last week a 17-year-old girl was convicted of pimping after a week-long trial at Reading Crown Court. She had provided a 14-year-old schoolgirl who performed oral sex on a 41-year-old man and then demanded a £10 fee for the introduction.

The girl, who cannot be named for legal reasons and had a reputation as a vicious bully, told the schoolgirl she could set her up with a list of clients to 'do properly' and that she could buy expensive clothes and jewellery from the illicit earnings.

The problem has become so acute that Holloway Prison has introduced an anger-management course for the 40 females aged between 15 and 20 who are held in its recently opened D-Zero young offenders' unit in a bid to reduce levels of violence. Last week a 17-year-old girl was convicted of pimping after a week-long trial at Reading Crown Court. She had provided a 14-year-old schoolgirl who performed oral sex on a 41-year-old man and then demanded a £10 fee for the introduction. The girl, who cannot be named for legal reasons and had a reputation as a vicious bully, told the schoolgirl she could set her up with a list of clients to 'do properly' and that she could buy expensive clothes and jewellery from the illicit earnings. tony.thompson@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Pioneering circus storms across Britain
fields.trailText: In Britain, circus still means Billy Smart's big top and the obligatory square-wheeled jalopy full of clowns. Not for much longer.
fields.body:
In Britain, circus still means Billy Smart's big top and the obligatory square-wheeled jalopy full of clowns. Not for much longer.

This week sees the launch of Britain's answer to the huge success of Argentina's De La Guarda, Canada's Cirque du Soleil, France's Archaos and Australia's Circus Oz - all contemporary shows with cult followings.

Tickets for the new British touring show, Storm, are selling fast even before the first reviews are out. The cast is largely made up of youngsters who trained on Lottery cash to become aerialists and acrobats for the Millennium Dome Show. This time, though, the production has been put together on a much smaller budget of £100,000.

The show follows a day in the life of a city as a storm approaches and features breath-taking aerial stunts, and even a little singing.

'We wanted to make each moment fluid, so it's a coherent piece,' said Mark Fisher, the show's designer and the man behind the acclaimed Dome show. 'It has its own narrative, not like Cirque du Soleil or De La Guarda, which were really just a series of tableaux.'

Fisher, whose reputation rests on the large touring shows he designed for Pink Floyd, the Rolling Stones and U2, has worked on what he describes as 'a shoestring' to bring his Storm to life.

'We have developed the show inside one of two big industrial spaces at The Circus Space, a former power station in East London and we have tried to change the ambience of this functional space with lights.'

Of the cast of 26, 20 are Dome performers who were trained from scratch over two and half years by Paul Cockle, the manager of the Storm show.

'This time we have a very street look, rather than a carnival look,' said Fisher. 'It is slightly pastiche and yet raw and in your face at the same time.'

Fisher is not sure why Britain has taken so long to come up with a modern circus show.

'The performing arts here have been dominated by the Royal Shakespeare Company axis and the traditional West End musical,' he said.

After a month in London, the show will tour Manchester, Glasgow, Newcastle and Henley, before returning for a second London season and a planned European tour.

Tickets: Wed, Thu, Fri £15; Tue £12.50; Sat £17.50 (concessions available). Box Office: 020-7316 4740

webTitle: Oh, they do like to walk along the prom...

fields.headline: Oh, they do like to walk along the prom...
fields.standfirst: Cumbria's loss is Blackpool's gain as countryside crisis favours the coast - and there are attractions farther afield, too
fields.trailText: Cumbria's loss is Blackpool's gain as countryside crisis favours the coast - and there are attractions farther afield, too.
fields.body:
Britain is heading back to the seaside in record numbers - not just with buckets and spades, but kitted out with rucksacks, walking boots and bright orange cagoules.

While most of Britain's tourist industry goes up in smoke along with its livestock, seaside resorts are enjoying an unprecedented Easter bonanza as walkers and tourists are squeezed out of the countryside by mutton pyres and charcoaled beef.

Even though many of us are flying out for Easter breaks overseas, attendance at some domestic attractions is up threefold on last year. The biggest problems have been beating the traffic jams and finding a hotel room, while the only problem for seaside hoteliers yesterday was hiding their glee amid all the gloom.

Susi Madron, a rambler from Manchester, normally walks in the Peak District and Lake District. But with the paths closed, she and a group of friends took a train to Blackpool for a 17-mile walk along the coast, taking in the famous 'prom'.

'We thought the coast was a safe place to go. Astonishingly, it was quite busy - we met half a dozen groups of up to 25 people walking in the other direction. We felt ridiculous walking through Blackpool in full walking gear, and attracted a lot of comments from people.'

The ramblers startled Blackpool council. Mike Chadwick, spokesperson for tourism, said: 'Our beach patrol has reported groups of 20 or 30 ramblers walking together. The donkey lady reported a coachload of ramblers unloading, walking along the beach. I can't believe we're saying this - we normally have to make this sort of thing up.'

Attendance at Blackpool Zoo is up 5 per cent. And at Blackpool Tower it's up 14 per cent over the past two months compared with last year, with the sharpest rise over the last two weeks. Marc Etches, managing director of Leisure Parcs, owners of the Tower, said: 'Sadly, the countryside's loss is the seaside's gain. Where people would have spent one day in Blackpool and one in the Lake District, they are know spending two days in Blackpool.'

The most dramatic boost has been at Blackpool Pleasure Beach, boasting the largest rollercoaster in Europe, where attendance last week varied between 200 and 300 per cent up on the same days last year. Spokeswoman Sarah Dornford-May said things have never been so busy. 'Over the last two weekends we've seen a really sharp rise. Foot and mouth disease has been a major part of it, and people are now rediscovering Britain.'

Even the little stalls are this weekend reaping the benefits. David Gee, of souvenir shop Gifts Galore on Blackpool's promenade, said: 'I am as busy now as I normally am in June'. Colin Asplin, owner of the 10-room Wynnstay Hotel, said: 'We've been fully booked for a few weeks, whereas last year we had a couple of rooms free. Everyone says it's going to be a good year.' Overall, Blackpool tourist chiefs say hotel bookings are up 15 to 20 per cent on last year.

The devastating fall in tourists to locations such as the Lake District and Dartmoor is not just boosting Blackpool. Alton Towers and Drayford Manor theme park are both reporting business up 10 per cent. Airlines are reaping rewards as aroundtwo million people - one in 30 of the British population - have flown away for the four-day holiday.

Shopping centres such as Lakeside at Thurrock in Essex and the Trafford Centre in Manchester are also busy. The National Trust for Scotland said it had 'plenty of visitors' as people turned out to support the industry.

But it's the seaside that seems to be doing best. Peter Hampson, of the British Resorts Association, said: 'Bookings were dire two weeks ago, but they have now taken off in a big way. Certain places with a big day-trip market are doing very well indeed. There are millions of people doing things they would not normally do. Millions of people are going to places they wouldn't normally have thought of going to.'

Other resorts, from Clacton to Scarborough, are all busy, while Brighton has this weekend been clogged with traffic from displaced tourists. Julia Gallagher, marketing manager of Brighton Pier, said: 'We've had a very good start to the year, with business exceeding last year. Obviously foot and mouth disease is increasing the popularity of seaside resorts and putting people off the countryside.'

As well as tourists, conferences and craft fairs have also been relocating to Brighton from rural areas. Roger Marlowe, chair of the Brighton and Hove Hotel Association, and owner of Paskins Townhouse Hotel, confided: 'We've had calls every minute about Easter - it's wonderful. What other sort of business has that level of demand?'

But the countryside crisis isn't all good news for the seaside. Some resorts, such as Brighton, depend also on overseas visitors, whose numbers are falling sharply. One Brighton hotel has seen 20 German coach tours cancelled this year.

Amanda Shepherd, head of tourism at Brighton Council, said: 'We may be benefiting in the short term, but we are worried about Britain's image overseas.'

This week the British Tourist Authority is flying in dozens of tourist chiefs from the US, Canada and Japan to prove to them that Britain is still open.

In a lavish £100,000 tour, the BTA is taking them to the Culloden Hotel, Blackpool, Windermere and Windsor Castle, with a cocktail reception on the royal yacht Britannia, and meetings with the Duke of Edinburgh and Tony Blair pencilled in.

Back on the coast this weekend, the biggest problem is fitting in with the national mood as thousands of inland tourist businesses and farmers face ruin. 'We don't want to be seen to gloat,' insisted Shepherd of Brighton Council. Matthew Williamson, vice-president of the Eastbourne Hotels Association and owner of the York House Hotel, said: 'We've been full for some time, but we're not trying to make money out of foot and mouth, or benefit in any way from it.'

One small hotelier in Bournemouth, who had just given her last room to a woman who had tried 14 other hotels that were all full, was so worried about being seen to dance on the grave of the rest of the tourist industry that she insisted on staying anonymous. 'We are gaining from others' misfortune,' she said. 'You feel bad to be benefiting at somebody else's expense... but it's such good news!'

Additional reporting by Joanna Walters

British Tourist Authority info: www.visitbritain.com

webTitle: One in four Britons is on a diet. So why are we getting fatter?

fields.headline: One in four Britons is on a diet. So why are we getting fatter?
fields.trailText: More than a quarter of Britain's adults are today doing battle with their willpower in what a new survey suggests is now our most popular national pastime: dieting.
fields.body:
More than a quarter of Britain's adults are today doing battle with their willpower in what a new survey suggests is now our most popular national pastime: dieting.

However, despite 27 per cent of the population claiming to be on diets, we are either cheating or simply not getting the hang of it as statistics also show the British are continuing to get fatter.

A Gallup poll to be published this week will show that 12.8 million Britons - twice the population of Scotland - admit to being on a diet, while 1.7 million are 'constantly' on a diet. Of those, one in five is a serial slimmer who has been on more than 10 different diets in the past decade.

Out of 2,000 men and women questioned, about three-quarters managed to shift half a stone or more but only half kept that weight off for longer than a year, with 20 per cent piling it all back on within six months.

The message is a serious one, however, as this year's statistics from the National Audit Office showed that two-thirds of men and more than half of women are overweight or clinically obese.

The figures would seem to show we are getting the message that being fat is unhealthy but do not know how to tackle the problem. As a nation we will have an obesity problem to match that of America's - where a quarter of the population is clinically obese - within nine years.

Already 13 per cent of our teenagers suffer from obesity and two-thirds of men and half of women are either over weight or obese - a tripling of the figures from 1980.

The NAO report estimated that health problems related to being overweight, such as heart disease, diabetes and osteoarthritis, were already costing the NHS half a billion pounds a year.

The two main reasons people gave to the researchers for breaking diets were boredom and monotony. One in five said they quit their weight-loss plans because they were fed up and a further 16 per cent said they did not have the willpower to carry on.

Yet the diet industry is booming. The survey found that 60 per cent of dieters were following a specific programme but many of those people failing to keep to one celebrity or medically endorsed diet plan will often try another the next time. The more dieters fall off the wagon, the more new books and videos on the subject seem to appear.

Britain is being led into dieting by its ever-shrinking celebrities. Vanessa Feltz, Geri Halliwell, Martine McCutcheon and Carol Vorderman have all publicised their particular method. Even Kate Winslet, once a stalwart against the tyranny of dieting, has succumbed to a diet to help her shed the weight she gained in pregnancy. This was a blow to those who had taken inspiration from Winslet's refusal to starve her naturally curvy body shape and was deemed so important that it made tabloid headlines. But exercise was an important part of her plan.

Professor Kay-Tee Khaw, a nutritionist at Cambridge University, said diets failed because the rise in obesity in this country is not linked to a rise in food intake. 'While we have a changing pattern of eating, there is evidence that our calorific intake is not changing. It is our lack of physical activity that is causing the rise,' she said.

It is not only health that can be at risk by both daft dieting or being overweight. US researchers claim that crash diets can break up marriages.

Charlotte Markey, of the University of California, co-authored the survey. She believes the dieters, especially those who fail, suffer a drop in self-esteem, which, in turn, affects their relationship with their partner. Most at risk are women on 'quick fix diets', she said.

'Men tend to diet in a healthier way, they tend to eat more fruit and vegetables and increase the amount of exercise they do. Women, on the other hand, tend to abstain from eating altogether or use diet pills.

'They diet in unhealthy ways and take watching what they eat too far. This can put incredible stress on a marriage, because a woman's self-esteem falls and this has a knock-on effect.'

tracy.mcveigh@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: '99pc certain' of Caroline's killer
fields.trailText: The five-year hunt for the killer of Cornish schoolgirl Caroline Dickinson appeared near an end last night after Miami police said they were '99.9 per cent certain' of a genetic link between a suspect being held in Florida and a man wanted for questioning by French police.
fields.body:
The five-year hunt for the killer of Cornish schoolgirl Caroline Dickinson appeared near an end last night after Miami police said they were '99.9 per cent certain' of a genetic link between a suspect being held in Florida and a man wanted for questioning by French police.

Caroline, 13, was raped and suffocated by an attacker while sleeping in a dormitory at the Pleine-Fougères youth hostel in Brittany during a school trip. Yesterday, a few hours before French police were due to release results of DNA samples from the Spanish restaurant worker, a Miami-Dade police officer, Sharon Hinz, said that 'everything looks promising as far as what we are doing and what work they [the French] are doing over there'.

Miami police are holding Francisco Arce Montez, 51, who is due to appear in court on 2 July on a charge of 'lewd and lascivious' conduct after breaking into a woman's beach apartment last month and allegedly masturbating while she slept. The offence has also been linked to the earlier intrusion by a man into another Miami beach apartment occupied by four Irish girls and two other women backpackers.

A connection between the Miami case and the Pleine-Fougères murder on 18 July 1996 followed a check by a US immigration official who had read about the murder while on holiday in Britain. Montez's name was among 48 suspects wanted by the French for questioning.

Suspicions were strengthened by reports of a case two years before Caroline's death when a man, identified as Montez, was arrested after twice entering a youth hostel at Bléré in the Loire when he tried to lure a young Scottish girl into his car. After an initially bungled inquiry into the Dickinson killing, Montez's name was added to a list of itinerant workers in Brittany at the time.

Police here said that inquiries on possible further assaults would be widened as the suspect was known to have lived in Britain and Germany before travelling to the United States.

webTitle: Miss World stupid, awful and unnatural, says its boss

fields.headline: Miss World stupid, awful and unnatural, says its boss
fields.standfirst: The bottom line
fields.trailText: Julia Morley, widow of Miss World creator Eric Morley, has branded the beauty pageant she now heads as 'stupid' and 'awful'. She is reinventing the competition to make it 'more positive' for women.
fields.body:
Julia Morley, widow of Miss World creator Eric Morley, has branded the beauty pageant she now heads as 'stupid' and 'awful'. She is reinventing the competition to make it 'more positive' for women.

In an interview in today's Observer Review, the former model condemns the infamous 'swimsuit' parade, in which contestants walk around the stage in spark- ling bikinis before being interviewed by the show's presenter.

'It did seem very unnatural to me as a woman that girls should turn, turn, turn on the stage, for a start. And I didn't feel comfortable with swimsuits on stage. Not because I thought there was anything wrong with them, but I thought that you don't generally feel comfortable if someone's interviewing you in a dinner jacket and you're in a swimsuit.

'I thought it was pretty awful to see women standing there with practically nothing on, with old Aspel saying, "What did you eat for breakfast?" - it was so stupid.'

Five months after her husband's death, Julia Morley, who started working behind the scenes at Miss World in 1969, has taken full control of the organisation. She is stepping out from behind the glitter to reinvent it.

The new Miss World will be more respectful to the contestants and more positive. 'We've got a new concept for the show and we're discussing ways we can do something pretty positive towards the contestants' education, with scholarships,' she said.

She has just sold satellite television rights around the world with projected viewing figures of over two billion. She is devising an international lifestyle magazine, and wants to create a 'global network that nobody else has got, except CNN'.

'It's a lot of talking, I know. But I do know it's going to happen. It's just that I've got the reins now and it's a funny feeling being able to go down the roads that I've always dreamed of.'

Eric Morley came up with the idea for the Miss World competition 50 years ago to promote the Festival of Britain of 1951. After she married him in 1960 Julia Morley became the 'mother hen' figure behind the scenes, chaperoning the contestants and protecting them from the press.

While her husband was alive she tried to make the pageant less demeaning to women. She coined the phrase 'beauty with a purpose' and banned disclosure of the contestants' vital statistics.

'It did seem very unnatural to me as a woman that girls should turn, turn, turn on the stage, for a start. And I didn't feel comfortable with swimsuits on stage. Not because I thought there was anything wrong with them, but I thought that you don't generally feel comfortable if someone's interviewing you in a dinner jacket and you're in a swimsuit. 'I thought it was pretty awful to see women standing there with practically nothing on, with old Aspel saying, "What did you eat for breakfast?" - it was so stupid.' Five months after her husband's death, Julia Morley, who started working behind the scenes at Miss World in 1969, has taken full control of the organisation. She is stepping out from behind the glitter to reinvent it. The new Miss World will be more respectful to the contestants and more positive. 'We've got a new concept for the show and we're discussing ways we can do something pretty positive towards the contestants' education, with scholarships,' she said. She has just sold satellite television rights around the world with projected viewing figures of over two billion. She is devising an international lifestyle magazine, and wants to create a 'global network that nobody else has got, except CNN'. 'It's a lot of talking, I know. But I do know it's going to happen. It's just that I've got the reins now and it's a funny feeling being able to go down the roads that I've always dreamed of.' Eric Morley came up with the idea for the Miss World competition 50 years ago to promote the Festival of Britain of 1951. After she married him in 1960 Julia Morley became the 'mother hen' figure behind the scenes, chaperoning the contestants and protecting them from the press. While her husband was alive she tried to make the pageant less demeaning to women. She coined the phrase 'beauty with a purpose' and banned disclosure of the contestants' vital statistics.

webTitle: 'A light has gone out in our lives with the removal of a vital spirit'

fields.headline: 'A light has gone out in our lives with the removal of a vital spirit'
fields.standfirst: Prince Charles was a great admirer of Sir Harry Secombe, who died last week. Here he pays tribute to a man of irrepressible humour - and mourns the passing of a less cynical style of comedy
fields.trailText: Prince Charles was a great admirer of Sir Harry Secombe, who died last week. Here he pays tribute to a man of irrepressible humour - and mourns the passing of a less cynical style of comedy.
fields.body:
For those of us in my generation, and my father's for that matter, who grew up with the sound of Harry Secombe's inimitable voice booming at them from the wireless, this last week has seen the approaching end of an era with the passing of a truly special person and the last but one of the original Goons.

After enduring every kind of appalling suffering and illness in his later years with Job-like and indomitable faith, one of the great life-enhancers of our age has departed the stage of life trailing behind him nothing but memories of laughter, happiness and sheer goodness.

A light has quite literally gone out in our lives with the removal of such a vital spirit. Harry made a deep impression on me, in company with many others in our country, during that unforgettable period of The Goon Show when enormous efforts were made to tune into the BBC each week so as not to miss a single episode. Indeed, such was the impression made upon my young self that at a later stage my younger brothers actually believed I was one of the Goons ...

But Harry also made a deep impression on so many people for a multitude of other reasons. For his unforgettable singing voice, for his frequent television appearances and, above all, for his countless acts of kindness and irresistible, unstoppable good humour. Not one generation but two owe a huge debt to Harry for quite simply making life infinitely more worthwhile and totally hysterical.

When it is increasingly noticeable how cynical, tasteless and devoid of true wit so much of what passes for humour has now become, you begin to realise just how refreshingly, gloriously innocent and uncomplicated Harry's approach to life was.

No wonder more and more people want to watch or listen to the older programmes that bear the elegant hallmark of wit, the subtle play on words, the double intent and the sheer skill of proper farce.

Harry exemplified the enduring importance in our lives of those great and timeless traditions that are fast disappearing - unless perhaps we mark his departure by rediscovering these vital elements in our battered culture.

I often wonder how much of a role the shared suffering and constant danger of the last war played in helping to bring out the peculiarly zany humour of those former military combatants - Harry Secombe, Spike Milligan, Peter Sellers and Michael Bentine. I suspect that their experiences had a pretty profound effect and in many ways we have all been fortunate beneficiaries.

I remember Harry telling me years ago that some of the characters featured in The Goons had been inspired by eccentric figures they had come across during the war, and in wonderfully unlikely situations. Major Denis Bloodnok, for instance, must have been partly modelled on a particularly eccentric individual whose encounters with various types of curry have a faint ring of military truth.

Whatever the case, Harry Secombe's unique gift was to have been able to enrich the sum of human happiness and to have become a much-loved household name throughout the length and breadth of a land that has always thrived on laughter and on seeing the funny side of life even in the worst possible situations. He has left so many of us with a genuine feeling of sadness and loss at his departure.

The Observer has made a donation to a charity supported by Sir Harry Secombe

fields.headline: Stressed 'goddesses' cling to ladette past
fields.standfirst: Thirtysomethings under pressure to make perfect children and perfect pasta return to wild bingeing days
fields.trailText: Thirtysomethings under pressure to make perfect children and perfect pasta return to wild bingeing days.
fields.body:
It used to be twentysomething 'ladettes' who went out binge-drinking and smoking before getting married, having children and settling down. But the ladette has grown up and she is determined to enter middle age disgracefully.

Record numbers of women aged 30-45 are smoking and drinking heavily and doing no exercise, a major new health study reveals. As the number of single thirtysomethings grows and the pressure on married women to live up to the ideal of the domestic goddess increases, women are turning to alcohol and cigarettes to reward themselves and relax.

Women aged 35-44 suffer more stress than men of the same age. The number who drink and smoke regularly is increasing faster than in any other age group. Thirtysomethings are binge-drinking and nearly one in five smokes more than 10 cigarettes a day.

Women aged 35-44 are less healthy than older and younger women. Three in 10 get little or no exercise. They suffer more illness, with one in three visiting her GP regularly.

The survey by market analysts Mintel says 'ladettes' are staying single well into their thirties, prolonging their 'live-for-today' lifestyle, while those who have married and had children are using alcohol and cigarettes to handle the stress of trying to be a dynamic mother, who holds down a job, raises children, and still has time to serve up the perfect home-made pasta - an image popularised by the TV chef and author, Nigella Lawson.

Clare Smith, who co-ordinated the research, said: 'There is a sharp increase in so-called "bad behaviour" among thirtysomething women. Two types of women are behind it. On one side is a new group of women who are single or divorced, who are fed up that they cannot find a partner or have just left one and are going out and saying to hell with the whole thing and rewarding themselves with things they enjoy, including alcohol and cigarettes. It's the Bridget Jones syndrome.

'On the other side there are married women for whom the pressure of work and home life is growing all the time. They are struggling to live up to media icons like the domestic goddess who has a top career and a home life. In a time-starved world, booze and fags are a way of dealing with the troubles of the day.'

The study shows 75 per cent of women aged 35-44 suffer stress, compared with 50 per cent of men. The proportion of women who drink more than once a week has increased by almost 9 per cent in the past decade - 2 per cent more than the average for women as a whole.

Women aged 30-45 are now more likely than those in any other age group to drink more than once a week. They also 'binge drink' more than ever - cramming more than 10 units of alcohol into one or two nights.

Wealthier women drink more than less well-off women. The most popular drink is wine, which is often drunk at home rather than in pubs or bars.

The number of thirtysomething women who smoke heavily is also increasing sharply. The proportion smoking more than 10 cigarettes a day has risen from 10 per cent five years ago to 12 per cent, and the number smoking a packet or more has gone from 9 to 11 per cent.

The number of women who smoke more than 10 cigarettes a day is now, for the first time, the same as men - one in four. Heavy smokers are most common in the 35-44 age group.

Women complain of the pressures of trying to be a 'have-it-all' domestic goddess. Jane Green, a 33-year-old mother-of-two who works four days a week at a London publishing firm, said: 'Women think they have to get up early to take the children to school, make sure they look good when they get there to impress the other mums, attend board meetings all day, get home to take the children to their private tutors and swimming lessons, and still have time to make the perfect parmesan cheese straws.

'It's totally impossible. It's no wonder mums are turning to drink, cigarettes and sometimes even illegal drugs to help us cope.'

Emily Davies, 32, a divorcee who has not found a new partner, said single women were becoming more hedonistic. 'I'm not happy that my marriage did not work and I'm single again, but I'm determined I will not let it get me down. I go out and I do the things that I enjoy. I have a job, money, independence, so I think "Oh, sod it". I may not have everything but at least I can have fun.'

webTitle: Outrage as climbers bid to find Everest hero's body

fields.headline: Outrage as climbers bid to find Everest hero's body
fields.standfirst: Eric Simonson's team was accused of grave-robbing after he sold pictures of Mallory's corpse on Everest. Now he's back to find the second body, disgusting many who believe Sandy Irvine should rest in peace
fields.trailText: Eric Simonson's team was accused of grave-robbing after he sold pictures of Mallory's corpse on Everest. Now he's back to find the second body, disgusting many who believe Sandy Irvine should rest in peace.
fields.body:
Scholars, historians and armchair mountaineers have long argued over the legend surrounding the death Everest pioneer Andrew 'Sandy' Irvine. Now a bitter row has broken out over his corpse.

This week a massive expedition of top international climbers will risk their lives to scour a ridge high on Everest in an attempt to locate the young mountaineer's remains - 77 years after he and his climbing partner George Mallory disappeared only 600 feet short of the world's highest summit.

Two years ago the same team found Mallory's corpse. Now they are confident of finding Irvine's. If they do they could solve one of the greatest of mountaineering mysteries: did the pair climb Everest nearly three decades before Sir Edmund Hilary and Tenzing Norgay made their historic 1953 ascent?

But the expedition is deeply controversial. It has been opposed by Irvine's living relatives and many of Britain's mountaineering élite. They have told the climbers, who are led by veteran American guide Eric Simonson, that they would prefer the young mountaineer's body 'to be left where it has lain in peace'. Simonson has accused the family of greed and of conducting a libellous smear campaign.

The stakes are high. Pictures of Irvine's body would be worth a fortune. And the climber, who was 22 when he died, was carrying a tiny Kodak 'Vestpocket' camera containing film that, given the intense preserving cold of extreme altitude, Kodak believe could still be developed.

Photographs taken by Simonson's team of the half-naked body of Mallory were sold around the world for huge sums. Pictures from the climbers' long-lost camera - particularly if they conclusively proved that the pair were successful - would be worth far more.

In a letter to Simonson John Irvine, the nephew of the dead climber, said that the family has legal ownership of the camera and any film. He told The Observer last week that the family wanted any profits made from finding the corpse to be given to a charitable foundation set up in the Everest pioneer's name.

'We are saying we would much rather you left Sandy Irvine alone but if you have to then please behave in a sensitive way and not disinter him and flash pictures around the world. [Two years ago] Simonson was rather silly and [allowed] pictures of Mallory to be sent around the world which was very distressing for the family. We don't want that to happen.'

The family are backed by the élite of British climbing. After Simonson's team sold the pictures of Mallory's bleached corpse - tens of thousands of pounds were paid by one British tabloid newspaper - many accused them of 'grave-robbing'. Mallory's grandson, George Mallory II, told reporters that the sale had made him 'bloody angry'.

This weekend Sir Chris Bonington said he was 'appalled' by Simonson's actions. 'What they did with Mallory was disgusting,' he said. 'Now pushing ahead with the expedition to find Irvine when the family has said that he should be left alone is equally bad.'

Bonington said that in the past he had been given pictures of dead climbers on Everest who had been found and photographed by subsequent expeditions and had passed them on to family members. 'That is the act of responsible mountaineers. Simonson is totally wrong.'

The Alpine Club - one of the oldest and most respected mountaineering bodies in the world - has taken the unprecedented step of issuing an appeal to Simonson's team. In it Doug Scott, the president of the club and one of Britain's most experienced high altitude mountaineers, accuses Simonson and his team of damaging Mallory's body when searching for artefacts. John Irvine has alleged the same.

Last week Erin Simonson, the expedition leader's wife, said that accusation was 'totally unfounded'. Speaking from the United States, she said: 'There was no damage done at all. Climbers risked their lives to avoid damage and it is unfair and unsporting - and libellous - to suggest otherwise. We hoped to work amicably with the Irvines but were very disappointed,' she said.

In the next few days the affair will reach its climax. The US-led team is now installed in a series of camps above 20,000ft and are ready to begin searching the route the British 1924 expedition took towards the summit. Conditions are good. As when Mallory's remains were found, there is little snow.

Irvine's body is believed to be above the rock shelf at around 27,000ft where Mallory was found. Some believe he is frozen upright in a sitting position with his face exposed - making the issue of pictures doubly sensitive.

The pair were last seen by fellow team member Noel Odell who glimpsed them through cloud from a high camp. Odell never made it clear whether he had seen them above or below a crucial steep cliff known as the Second Step. Many climbers believe that climbing the step and reaching the summit would have been beyond the men's ability.

Simonson's climbers will search the area above the obstacle for evidence - such as oxygen cylinders - that it was successfully overcome. Dark goggles found in Mallory's pocket two years ago seem to indicate that the pair were descending in the dark when they died. But that does not help determine whether they reached the summit.

Interest in Mallory and Irvine's story appears insatiable. This autumn a £20 million feature film will start filming in the Himalayas, Canada and Britain. David Green, the producer, said Joseph Fiennes had been cast as Mallory. Much of the film centres on Mallory's intense relationship with his wife. Mallory's decision to attempt the climb with Irvine - as opposed to some other more experienced climber - will be attributed to the young mountaineer's skill with the newly developed oxygen equipment, not to homosexual attraction as rumoured in the past.

Julie Summers, Irvine's great-niece and biographer, is optimistic that the row can be resolved. 'The family have written a short funeral service to be said over Sandy's body if they do find him and the team have that and I have no doubt that they will be meticulous in complying with our wishes.'

fields.headline: Violin dealer denies £8m string sting
fields.standfirst: Normal business practice... or a giant fiddle in a scandal of classical proportions?
fields.trailText: Normal business practice... or a giant fiddle in a scandal of classical proportions?
fields.body:
The Wimbledon men's singles final of 1992 was a famous victory for Andre Agassi. But one Centre Court spectator that day was unable to enjoy the final set.

Peter Biddulph, a distinguished London violin dealer, was disturbed by a tap on his shoulder. 'At first I thought I was going to be questioned about where I got my ticket,' he recalls. 'But I was called to the telephone.'

The call was ultimately to turn his life upside down and start a chain of events that now threatens to undermine the extraordinarily profitable international violin trade. It was from a woman called Vera Farnsworth who told Biddulph that her long-time partner, Gerald Segelman, had died, aged 93. Would the violin dealer be able to help her out?

Segelman was renowned as an eccentric and voracious collector of some of the world's most expensive violins. 'Gerald was incredible,' said Biddulph. 'I met him in 1974 and he treated me like a son. I must have handled around £3.5 million of business for him in his lifetime.'

But the association has now led 54-year-old Biddulph, formerly known in the trade as The Flying Fiddle, to the edge of bankruptcy.

Although he is still used today as a top consultant by the big three auction houses, Christie's, Sotheby's and Bonham's, and has sold instruments to the most talented musicians of the day, including Nigel Kennedy and the late Yehudi Menuhin, in February this year Biddulph was in court facing accusations that he acted as a dishonest agent in handling Segelman's superb legacy, including three Stradivarius instruments estimated to be worth more than £1 million each.

He was accused of deliberately undervaluing violins and secretly keeping the difference for himself. Biddulph has now agreed to pay £3 million to the executors of Segelman's will, a sum that will go towards the £8 million he owes.

The arguments in the historic case pivoted on the apparently common practice of dealers working together privately to protect each other from losses and to share the profits from big sales.

The admissions made by Biddulph during the trial exposed a network which, at best, looks after its own with 'gentlemanly' agreements and which, at worst, is guilty of collusion on a grand scale.

'This case clearly showed how much power the dealers have. They are the main buyers at auction,' said Professor Brian Harvey, an expert in the violin trade. 'Personally, I would call it a cartel because the dealers in this case shared in the arrangements.'

In 1997 Biddulph was the subject of a rare legal order, called an Anton Piller order, which confiscated all the documents in his West End shop. The papers formed the basis of the case against him and of allegations that he boosted his allotted 5 per cent share in the sales with a series of 'secret commissions'. Biddulph last week defended these secret payments as a normal part of the international trade in top-flight instruments.

'I have never had the chance to say what happened,' he said. 'How do you arrive at a price for something so esoteric as a violin? I have conceded, in the absence of a written agreement with Segelman's executors, I should repay what I can. I don't really know why. It is a ridiculous affair. I am selling my shop and my record label.'

Biddulph said the plaintiffs had a 'huge advantage' because they were able to inspect all his papers. 'We should not feel embarrassed about trying to make a living. It is not easy to sell a violin and I am not going to feel guilty about dealing with a very small band of people.

'You might well get some money back later when a violin is sold on, but I would not get such a cut unless there was a clear arrangement with all the parties.

'I am sorry about the mess it caused everybody, but dealers do more than simply brokering, we give guarantees about authenticity and we promise to buy back instruments. It is a service for which others say a "secret commission" is paid.'

There was no question of deliberately undervaluing Segelman's instruments, he claims: 'I don't believe we sold any of those under their value. This was a unique situation, but we acted in good faith. There was so much confusion at the time, nothing was written down and I didn't know where I was.'

Even transactions worth hundreds of thousands of pounds are frequently sealed with a simple handshake in the trade. 'I have never had a written contract from any of my colleagues,' Biddulph insisted.

Timothy White, Segelman's executor, alleged in court that Biddulph had concealed a number of the instruments and bows that belonged to Segelman. Several of the missing items were alleged to have been sold on to prominent American violin dealers Bein & Fushi, who face similar accusations in relation to Segelman's property in a trial later this year in Chicago.

In a letter read out to the judge in court, Biddulph wrote to Bein & Fushi about the sale arrangements: 'I am sorry it could not be more, but there are too many flies round the honey pot.'

Another key section of the trial concerned the fate of the famous 'Dumas' Maggini viola, which had disappeared years ago and turned up unexpectedly among Segelman's possessions after his death. Biddulph valued it at £200,000, while on other occasions he has valued less well-known instruments by the same maker at £450,000 and £600,000.

Biddulph says he has been misrepresented and that he only agreed to pay his accusers because otherwise he would have been bankrupted by a long trial.

As he awaits the US trial, White said he would be 'pleased to see the end' of the litigation. 'It has been enormously burdensome. webTitle: Leading clerics to quit over remarriage

fields.headline: Leading clerics to quit over remarriage
fields.trailText: Leading Church of England traditionalists have confirmed plans for a breakaway group over the hotly disputed issue of the remarriage of divorcees.
fields.body:
Leading Church of England traditionalists have confirmed plans for a breakaway group over the hotly disputed issue of the remarriage of divorcees.

A bitter row has been fuelled this weekend by a claim from a former adviser to the Archbishop of Canterbury that up to 10,000 divorcees a year are already being remarried in church.

The senior cleric, who has advised on marriage and family life, told The Observer: 'There is widespread remarriage already taking place in our churches. No one talks about it publicly because it is a divisive issue. It is exactly like an elephant in the corner of the sitting room which everyone is trying to ignore.'

The report of a Church of England working party on remarriage was published early last year. The group, chaired by the Bishop of Winchester, the Rt Rev Michael Scott-Joynt, outlined a complicated series of tests which could be applied to divorcees wanting to remarry. It was expected to be considered by the church's General Synod later this year.

People would have to prove that their past marriage had been left behind and that when they entered it they did not realise they were making a lifelong commitment. But couples would not normally be remarried, the report suggested, if their relationship had contributed to the original divorce. The proviso would make it difficult for Britain's best-known divorcees, the Prince of Wales and Camilla Parker Bowles, to marry.

'If these plans are endorsed,' warned Margaret Brown, a leading traditionalist on the C of E Synod, 'it will open a floodgate. It will cream off a lot of people from the Church. There is no doubt that an eventual split will come if the Church keeps going down this path.'

Clergy on both sides of the argument fear a damaging division. The Rev Wendy Saunders, from Eltham, south London, admitted: 'It is already a lottery as to where you live and whether your vicar is prepared to carry out a service. Eighty per cent of the weddings I conduct involve one partner who is divorced.'

'If you are truly sorry that your marriage has failed and you have turned back to God, then you can be forgiven and have a fresh start. Often first marriages break down because people get married when they are immature.' Margaret Brown and other Synod members have already set up the Third Province Movement to promote 'orthodox' Christianity. The group wants to bar women priests and prevent divorcees becoming churchwardens or general synod members.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: British soldier on Kosovo patrol killed by anti-tank mine
fields.body:
British soldier on Kosovo patrol killed by anti-tank mine

A British soldier was killed and two others were injured when their vehicle struck an anti-tank mine on the border between Kosovo and Macedonia.

The Scorpion armoured personnel carrier was patrolling near the village of Krivenik in Kosovo on Friday night, according to the international peacekeeping force K-For. The explosion left a crater one metre deep and the vehicle, which was blown onto its side, was severely damaged.

The incident was described as an accident. The border area was the scene of clashes between ethnic Albanian guerrillas and Macedonian security forces last month, but fighting has abated over the past two weeks.

The peacekeeping force said there was no indication that Friday's incident was related to 'extremist activity' in the region.

Driveway shooting remand

Two men have been remanded in custody by Stevenage magistrates charged with the murder of Josephine Martorana, 46, who was shot in the driveway of her £600,000 home at Hoddesdon, Hertfordshire, last August, and died later in hospital. Jason Duncan James, 29, and Daniel Francis Whyte, 23, both of West Ealing, will appear at St Albans Crown Court on Friday. The men were also charged with the attempted murder of Martorana's son Stephen and his girlfriend Isabelle Agnes, and with the robbery of two Rolex watches.

Garden accidents alert

Parents have been warned that children are most likely to be involved in garden accidents over the Easter weekend. Consumer Affairs Minister Kim Howells said research shows that the number of accidents has risen by 20 per cent over five years. Children aged two and three are most at risk.

Hit and run child in coma

The parents of Phoebe Lyle, three, from Bangor, Co Down, were by her bedside last night as she lay in a coma in hospital at Ovieda, Spain. She was hit by a speeding car on a mountain road near Leon, north-west of Madrid. Her father Robert, an advertising executive, said she was showing no deterioration but no real improvement either.

Home from Holmes

Georgina Conan Doyle has unveiled a statute to her uncle Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, in Crowborough, East Sussex. The creator of the super sleuth Sherlock Holmes and a leading member of the spiritualist movement died at his home there in 1930.

Body found on roof of lorry

A lorry driver drove more than 30 miles on motorways between St Helens and Bolton, Greater Manchester, without realising there was a body on the roof of his vehicle. From notes found it was thought the man, aged between 18 and 25, committed suicide. The driver heard a thud as he was leaving but his check revealed nothing. Police said: 'It was amazing the body did not fall off.'

Warning over cheap lighters

British holidaymakers have been been warned not to bring home from Spain cheap cigarette lighters amid fears they could start fires on aircraft.

Tommy Cooper film on display

The earliest known TV footage of comedian Tommy Cooper, dating from 1950 when he was 27, has been discovered in a garden shed and will go on display at the National Museum of Photography, Film and Television in London.

Rabbits 'stifled'

In its Easter appeal the Rabbit Charity says rabbits are the most abused pets in Britain. Intelligent, social animals which need exercise and space, they are mostly confined in narrow hutches that would be considered unfit for cats, dogs or hamsters.

Unhappy note

'Old Macdonald Had A Farm' will not be sung at the mayor's annual charity concert at Ledbury, Hertfordshire, as a mark of sympathy for local farmers.

Bad call

Among frivolous 999 calls received by Staffordshire police was one asking why the London to Glasgow train was going so slowly.

Shark plea

The actor Edward Woodward has joined forces with the Marine Conservation Society to ask the public to help conserve the basking shark.

webTitle: Aldermaston woman tells secrets of our super-bomb secrets

fields.headline: Aldermaston woman tells secrets of our super-bomb secrets
fields.standfirst: It was 1955 and four British scientists suddenly had the power to start, or deflect, World War III. Now their full story has been told, reports  Kamal Ahmed
fields.trailText: It was 1955 and four British scientists suddenly had the power to start, or deflect, World War III. Now their full story has been told, reports Kamal Ahmed.
fields.body:
On a scrap of blue paper, unsigned but in the distinctive handwriting of one of Britain's leading scientists, four words reveal one of the most momentous events in the country's history. 'Looks just about OK.'

The note was written by William Penney, director of the atomic research centre at Aldermaston. He was writing about Britain's secret post-war project: the development of the hydrogen bomb, a weapon with the ability to destroy whole cities and millions of people in a flash of searing heat and light.

Penney had just worked out how to make the weapon detonate successfully. It was September 1955.

The note, and the remarkable story of Britain's nuclear weapons project, is revealed in the first officially sanctioned history of the 'superbomb project'. The book, which had to be given clearance by the Cabinet Office because the details it contains are so sensitive, has taken nearly 10 years to produce and is written by Lorna Arnold, a former departmental record officer with the Atomic Energy Authority. She was given special access to the closed files at Aldermaston which will not be handed to the Public Records Office for decades to come.

The book, Britain and the H-Bomb , to be published this week, reveals that the four men behind Britain's nuclear deterrent believed they were ambassadors for world peace, despite inventing one of the most destructive weapons known to man. Penney, along with physicists Keith Roberts and Brian Taylor, and William Cook, the deputy director of Aldermaston, thought that the full horror of the H-bomb was such that it would never be used.

'William Penney and William Cook had seen the appalling effects of years of conventional war,' Arnold said yesterday from her home in Oxford, where she has now retired. 'They believed that this weapon would mean the end of world wars.'

Arnold said she hoped the book would redress the balance of earlier histories of nuclear development which put America at the forefront. Although Robert Oppenheimer, the American scientist who ran the Los Alamos nuclear development project during the Second World War, is recognised across the globe, the names of Penney, Roberts, Taylor and Cook are unknown outside the rarefied world of nuclear science.

'None of them ever publicised their role or wrote memoirs - they had a great belief that they were simply part of a larger effort,' Arnold said. 'But they were dealing with one of the most complicated and difficult scientific challenges, and they were successful.'

Arnold, who is now 85, said the book became a 'labour of love', She began work at the Atomic Energy Authority in the 1950s, an era when the future of nuclear science held out the twin possibilities of total destruction or limitless electrical energy. At that time the nuclear industry was employing 27,000 people.

The book shows how the men who researched the H-bomb were at the forefront of theoretical science and often had to rely as much on their imagination as their practical knowledge. John Dolphin, who was head of the 'project committee' at Aldermaston, admitted his 'complete ignorance' of physics, yet he 'produced elegant drawings of strange "thermonuclear" devices - perhaps his own ingenious ideas,' Arnold writes.

As they grappled with what is widely believed to be the most significant discovery of the twentieth century - the process of nuclear fusion - the scientists often lost heart. At a meeting in December 1955 the main scientists met to pull together their ideas. 'Does anyone know how it is done?' Cook said. There was an 'embarrassed silence', Arnold says, before revealing that the moral dilemmas and problems with resources faced by the scientists almost led to the breakdown of the whole project.

Such was the exasperation at the slow progress and complicated nature of the work, Cook sent out worried instructions to his staff to 'keep it simple, stupid!'.

'The plain fact is that weapons work is unpopular and nobody wants to do it,' Penney wrote in a memo in 1954 in which he admitted to being 'terribly depressed'. He continued: 'If I have to run with just the same people that I have had for the last year or two we are going to make a mess. Even the programme which is definite is above the present capacity of the establishment to bear.'

The project was shrouded in the utmost secrecy because of fears that both the US and Russia, which were developing their own H-bombs, would seek to exclude Britain from the superpower league that was rapidly developing. The Government kept as much as much as possible from the public after concerns were raised that mass marches by the nascent Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament could derail the research.

Arnold said that many of the most important and sensitive documents were destroyed by Aldermaston during a 'reorganisation' in the 1960s.

The book reveals the huge tensions being created by the Cold War. In 1954 a committee under the command of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the leading military body in Britain, said they considered that the US could 'deliberately precipitate war with the USSR in the near future'. Any conflict would lead to the 'total destruction' of the UK, which they believed was Russia's primary target - just nine years after the two countries had been allies against Nazi Germany.

In the same year Penney, who was put under intense pressure to 'get results', wrote a report for Winston Churchill, the Prime Minister, in which he revealed the destructive capacity of the weapon. 'He described the effects of a five-megaton "true" H-bomb dropped on London,' Arnold writes. 'It would produce a fireball two miles across and a crater three-quarters of a mile wide and 150 feet deep. The Admiralty Citadel (Whitehall's emergency nerve centre) would be crushed at a distance of one mile, houses would be wrecked three miles away and badly damaged at seven miles; within a radius of two miles all habitations would catch fire.'

fields.headline: Putting my royalties to work would be music to my ears
fields.standfirst: Composer Mark Cherrie needs to fine-tune his savings, he tells  Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: Composer Mark Cherrie needs to fine-tune his savings, he tells Helen Pridham.
fields.body:
Mark Cherrie
Age 38
Lives in North-west London
Occupation Musician and music writer
Earns About £52,000
Mortgage £68,000
Debts None
Investments £3,000 in cash Isa
Pension Personal pension
Aims To invest more for the future

Mark writes music for television and has had considerable success. He has completed more than a dozen albums and had some 300 pieces of music published. His music has been used on American shows such as ER and Friends, as well as here and in other countries. He now wants to invest wisely the money he is collecting in royalties.

His life could have turned out very differently. Although he has always loved music, his parents had discouraged him from thinking of it as an occupation. He explains: 'My father was a musician and ran a steel band, but he went through some difficult times and often had to take other jobs to fill in. I don't think he wanted me to have those money worries.'

That was why Mark originally planned to become an optician. But he couldn't get on to the university course he wanted and it wasn't long before he dropped out and got a job as a litigation clerk for a credit company. He worked there for five years.

All this time he had been playing music in his spare time and in 1986 he took the bold step of giving up his day job to become a professional musician. He hasn't looked back since. In 1993, he started concentrating on writing music and has seen his income grow to its current level as his royalties have built up.

However, he realises it is possible that his income could go down again. This is why he feels he should be prudent and save money for the future.

On the advice of his accountant, he channels his income through his own limited company, Shiny Music. The company pays dividends to himself and his wife Sharon, who is also a shareholder in the company. Sharon is a health visitor but is currently doing research for her master's degree. In recent years much of the couple's income has been spent on holidays, a new car, and improvements to their home, which they bought five years ago.

They are repaying their home loan with an endowment mortgage, although they have received a letter from their endowment company, Legal & General, telling them the policy may not cover the loan. However, Mark says he is not too worried about this at the moment and has decided to defer dealing with it until they move to a bigger property in three or four years.

So far Mark has not man aged to save much and he is only paying £50 a month towards a pension. He would now like to start saving more seriously and he and his wife recently opened a mini cash Isa for £3,000 each with Smile.

The couple have two children, Elliot, seven and Corinna, five. He hopes they will go on to university and recently set up friendly society plans into which their child benefit is paid.

Adviser 1: Ian Howe

Mark's first priority should be to protect his financial health against illness, loss of income and even premature death. An income protection policy could be purchased in case of protracted illness. Mark has some life assurance but does need to ensure that he and Sharon have enough protection for the family's lifestyle to be kept should one of them die early.

With their uncertain, yet currently buoyant, financial situation, a flexible mortgage may be a good option. Intelligent Finance (IF) offers one which could fit bill. The rate is less than their present lender's variable rate, so if they kept their payments the same, they would effectively be paying off their loan early, making up for the potential endowment shortfall. If, in addition, Mark saved for future tax bills in an IF savings account, this amount could be offset against the loan, reducing the interest even further.

Saving £50 a month into a pension at age 38 simply isn't enough. Mark should consider taking advantage of the new stakeholder pensions.

But the problem with pensions is that you can't get at your savings until you're 50. So Mark and Sharon should consider saving the maximum into an Isa. They could each put £583 a month into an equity-linked Isa over the next five to 10 years.

Ian Howe works for financial adviser Towry Law Financial Services.

Adviser 2: Gordon Wilson

Mark has done well in managing his financial affairs so far. However, he does appear exposed in the event of illness or death. An income protection policy should be considered, and critical illness cover could also be looked at. As a minimum, the mortgage debt should be covered.

He needs to review his life assurance. Family income benefit provides high levels of initial cover at low cost and would pay out a guaranteed income on death. Alternatively, term assurance or whole-of-life assurance could be taken out to provide a lump sum.

Mark should not let the endowment situation run on. I would deal with the position immediately. This could involve converting part of the mortgage to repayment, reducing the debt or making savings into an Isa.

With a move to a larger house planned, I would recommend maintaining quite a liquid position so that Mark and Sharon's options are kept open. Mini cash Isas could absorb £6,000 of their savings a year.

With the introduction of stakeholder pensions, this is an opportune time to review his pension strategy. He could be paid a large salary this year: this would increase his ability to contribute and would be the basis year for five years of pension contributions.

Gordon Wilson works for financial adviser Thomson & Shepherd.

webTitle: My money: Matt Smith, radio presenter

fields.headline: Looking after our future is child's play? I wish it was
fields.standfirst: Children's TV and radio presenter Matt Smith tells Tracey Boles what made him start to make plans
fields.trailText: Children's TV and radio presenter Matt Smith tells Tracey Boles what made him start to make plans.
fields.body:
Money isn't the most important thing in life - so long as you are not in debt. That is the financial advice the presenter of Radio 4's new children's programme, Go 4 It, would give to his young audience.

'Trying to have everything now and paying for it later is a mistake,' says Matt Smith. 'Although that is hypocritical coming from me! Money management will stand you in good stead, as I have learnt the hard way.'

The new programme goes out on Sundays from 7.15pm today. Aimed at eight to 11-year-olds, Go 4 It will look at 'everything interesting' to children, from cinema to sports, events and music. Children will be asking the questions 'because that way they will get the answers they want'.

So what did they ask chart toppers Hear'Say, who are guests on the first programme? 'Kids ask the naughtiest questions,' says Smith. 'They wanted to know who was the most annoying member of the band. The band got out of it very diplomatically, saying "We all have our moments".'

Olympic gold medallist Steve Redgrave is quizzed in the first programme by a group of junior rowers. 'He was good at talking to the kids at their level without talking down to them,' says Smith, 33. 'They could relate to the fact that he is not flash but solid and dependable.'

Future programmes will look at subjects as diverse as the new Thunderbirds film and writing your own poetry.

Go 4 It represents a change from sport for Smith, one which has taken him from childhood and its wide-eyed enthusiasm. He is also a presenter on BBC1's children's programme Football Fever. Smith started at the BBC in 1994 as a reporter on breakfast news. From there he went on to national news, but made the leap to sport in 1996 because it was 'less depressing'.

He has a freelance contract with the BBC, which gives him just the right amount of flexibility and security. 'I would not be confident about paying the bills from month to month if I worked totally on a freelance basis, especially as my wife is giving up teaching.'

Having a baby has 'concentrated my mind' as far as family finances are concerned. Smith admits his father-in-law, a former bank director, used to be 'disgusted' by the way he and his wife, Fiona, handled money, but he thinks things improved with the arrival of their daughter, Meg, two-and-a-half. He says: 'We have to think about making provision for her. Although we are not considering private education, just the fact of having a child is expensive - an expensive joy.'

The couple have set up savings accounts and a Tessa in her name.

'We are gradually getting organised when it comes to money. I have learnt that when you do things little by little you can keep on top of them, otherwise you end up in crisis.' He has also learnt the importance of saving for retirement. 'I have seen relations who have made no arrangements entering their twilight years and having to scale down their standard of living.'

So how does he think we can get these messages across to children as personal finance enters the curriculum for the first time? 'Make it as interesting as possible, otherwise it goes in one ear and out the other.'
