fields.headline: Loyal savers 'losing out'
fields.standfirst: Some lenders face disciplinary action for measly rates, writes  Tracey Boles
fields.trailText: Some lenders face disciplinary action for measly rates, writes Tracey Boles.
fields.body:
Several banks and building societies are facing disciplinary action for paying their existing customers measly rates on savings accounts. This comes as savings rates head for some of their lowest levels ever following last week's cut in the base rate to 5.5 per cent.

The Banking Code Standards Board is considering disciplinary action against the banks and building societies for apparently breaching the code's rule on superseded accounts - those no longer open or promoted to new customers.

The institutions, which cannot be named until the investigation is complete, face compensation bills and even expulsion for paying long-standing customers less than new ones. The BCSB had been investigating all superseded accounts paying less than 3 per cent interest on balances of more than £5,000.

Interest rates on traditional instant-access accounts are at an all-time low, according to analysts at financial magazine Moneyfacts. They currently average just 1.27 per cent before tax, even on balances as high as £5,000. For higher-rate taxpayers that means after-tax rates of below 1 per cent.

Some accounts, particularly those operated by phone or over the internet, are paying much higher rates, but many savers with old-style passbook accounts will be receiving the paltry returns calculated by Moneyfacts.

Banks and building societies were keen to emphasise how the Bank of England's latest 0.25 per cent reduction was good news for borrowers, with Halifax trumpeting the fact that mortgage rates are now at their lowest for 36 years. But the flipside is lower savings rates as lenders attempt to balance their books.

Many banks and building societies have yet to announce the savings rate cuts. But when they come, they will impact on many more people than the mortgage rates do - savers outnumber borrowers by seven to one.Some accounts may come down by as much as 0.5 per cent. And with City experts expecting base rates to fall further, even as early as next month, the outlook is not rosy for savers.

But what can they do? Change their expectations, advises the Financial Services Authority. Last week the City's watchdog warned that consumers need to adjust their financial expectations to Britain's new low-inflation era. The days of double-digit returns are gone.

Headline inflation during the Nineties fell to rates last seen in the Sixties and is expected to remain at around the Government's target rate of 2.5 per cent for the foreseeable future. The FSA says consumers should be wary of any product offering the kind of returns seen during the Eighties and Nineties.

Another solution is being offered by Which?, the Consumers' Association magazine. It advises investors stuck in low-paying savings accounts to move their money elsewhere.

Its researchers recently found that banks and building societies were paying loyal savers a pittance while offering new customers better rates on savings accounts. It named Abbey National, Bristol & West and Woolwich as the worst offenders. All have 'live' easy-access accounts that pay 1 per cent or less on balances of £2,500. Which? compares this with Nationwide's Invest Direct account, which pays 5.20 per cent on balances of just £500.

Some notice accounts also offer meagre returns, although restricted access is generally rewarded. Abbey National, NatWest and Woolwich offer accounts that pay savers less than 2.5 per cent on balances of £5,000. By contrast, Yorkshire Building Society's notice account now pays 5.4 per cent.

Moneyfacts compiles charts of savings accounts rates on the personal finance sections of Ceefax or Skytext or on the Moneyfacts website. Which? also publishes the rates in its monthly savings monitor.

The savings rate will depend on how much you have to invest and the type of access you choose, Moneyfacts says.

Branch-based accounts tend to pay lower rates than those with postal, phone or internet access. Those with notice accounts may have to wait until the notice period is up before they can switch accounts.

Remember that just because an account offers a competitive rate today, it doesn't mean it always will. Unless you keep a close eye on it you could find the rate has tumbled, and that other savers are getting better rates on newer accounts.

webTitle: Where there's a will there's reward points

fields.headline: Where there's a will there's reward points
fields.standfirst: Children can inherit your Air Miles too, says  Andrew Bibby
fields.trailText: Children can inherit your Air Miles too, says Andrew Bibby.
fields.body:
The idea that children will automatically be loyal to the same companies and banks as their parents seems an antique concept today. However, there is one sense in which loyalty can still be passed down between the generations: The accumulated value from loyalty schemes such as Air Miles or reward cards doesn't necessarily disappear when someone dies. In theory, you could write your will so that your children inherit both your silverware and your Sainsbury's Reward points.

David Owen, a local government manager from Manchester, contacted Air Miles after the death of his father and arranged to take over the 900-odd miles credited to his father's account. As David says, it was cer tainly not the first thing he and his family thought about after the death. Nevertheless, there was a good reason for eventually taking the trouble. 'My son was about to go to Germany, and I wanted him to have the benefit of them. My mum was never going to use them. I had around 600 Air Miles myself, which I added in,' he says.

Air Miles, which are collected by about 6 million British people, are not normally transferable, though the scheme's published terms and conditions specify that they can be bequeathed in a will. The company normally requires to see a copy of the will and the death certificate before agreeing to a transfer. Where there is no will, Air Miles will act on the advice of a solicitor.

'In 2000 we dealt with more than 5,000 such accounts, and the number of miles transferred a year is in the millions,' says Air Miles' Sophie Blanc. Boots says it also allows its Advantage card points to be bequeathed and that it 'occasionally' gets a request to do so. 'We would cancel the card of the person who has died and issue a voucher for points to be loaded in one of our shops to another card. We could also arrange for the points to be given to a charity, though this hasn't arisen yet,' says a company spokesman.

Other companies claim that they try to take a sensitive approach to this issue. 'As long as the legal representative for the estate gets in touch with us, it is a simple procedure,' says a spokesman for Sainsbury's, adding: 'People don't tend to request it.'

The arrangement with credit card loyalty schemes is more complicated, since would-be beneficiaries may find that there are credit card debts that need to be paid off first. In practice, many credit card accounts are taken over (together with loyalty points) by a remaining spouse or partner, who may already have been a second cardholder.

David Owen says it took five months for his father's Air Miles to be correctly credited to his existing account, after the company inadvertently tried to transfer them into a new account. The process required several letters to sort out.

In the end, however, his son did get his free flight to Germany.

webTitle: Motorists driven into negative equity by  car dealers

fields.headline: Motorists driven into negative equity by  car dealers
fields.standfirst: With prices at rock bottom, dealers are increasingly relying on the commission from finance deals to make money, writes  Maria Scott
fields.trailText: With prices at rock bottom, dealers are increasingly relying on the commission from finance deals to make money, writes Maria Scott.
fields.body:
Steer clear of car finance deals that look cheap because of low monthly repayments. You could end up in the motorists' version of negative equity: a car worth less than you owe.

Many motorists have been stung by the negative equity trap over the past year as car prices have plummeted. The risk was worsened by the proliferation of car finance deals offering low deposits, deferred payments or long repayment periods. The less the debt paid off, the bigger the potential difficulties when car owners want to trade up or sell.

An index of car prices set in July 1999 by Alliance & Leicester bank and What Car? magazine shows that new car prices fell, on average, by 10.4 per cent over 18 months to the end of 2000. Prices for used cars (three-year-old vehicles) fell by an average of 4.5 per cent over that period, although that figure represents the begin ning of a recovery in used car prices towards the end of last year. Between August 1999 and August 2000 prices fell by 21.7 per cent on average.

A&L spokesman Geoff Seymour says: 'It was at that point that people were finding themselves in negative equity. They hadn't got the value in the car any more.'

Some of the worst affected cars have been 'people carriers' such as the Renault Scenic, Ford Galaxy and Vauxhall Frontera.

CAP Motor Research, which publishes guides to car prices, says negative equity has been a particular problem for people who bought on traditional hire-purchase agreements. If you have a personal loan from a bank, you own the car from the outset, and although you may get less for the car than you owe, at least you can sell.

With hire-purchase you do not own the car until the loan has been repaid. Buyers who wanted to swap to a new car part-way through a deal would normally expect to get back enough to repay their existing finance and put down a deposit on another car. But in the recent market, trading up has not been an option.

Simon Goldtharp, an editor of CAP's Black Book , a guide to used car prices explains: 'If the car is worth £2,000 and you owe £3000 you end up giving the dealer money to clear it off.'

However, consumer law allows buyers to hand back a car when they have repaid half the capital without being blacklisted for credit. CAP says dealers are losing out heavily on these deals because customers are doing just that.

Negative equity is also a problem with contract purchase agreements, deals that have been marketed heavily by manufacturers and dealers in recent years. These require deposits of around 20 per cent and lower monthly payments than would be required on a normal finance agreement.

As with hire purchase, you do not own the car, but at the end of a set term you must pay the balance owed, trade it in for a new model or hand it back. But trade-in values have been proving so poor that owners have not been able to trade up to a new car.

Like high street shops, car dealers have been relying increasingly on the selling of finance to supplement their income, according to Goldtharp at CAP. 'In a lot of cases they have pretty much relied on finance and sold cars at a loss.'

Most dealers will have a specialist to sell finance deals to customers and, although commission varies, the dealer might get £100 to £150 for each deal sold.

'They will take as much out of the customer as they can,' says Goldtharp.

In addition to loans for the cars, the sales specialist will probably also try to sell insurance to cover loans against illness or redundancy and this 'gives an extra commission again'.

Problems with negative equity are beginning to subside because car prices have begun to stabilise. Nevertheless CAP recently warned that car owners should still be wary of low-deposit finance deals.

Goldtharp points out that the prices of cars rarely go up, even in a buoyant market, and that conditions can change.

He says: 'Imagine buying something last September that you won't pay off until the next Olympics.'

Prices for used cars (three-year-old vehicles) fell by an average of 4.5 per cent over that period, although that figure represents the begin ning of a recovery in used car prices towards the end of last year. Between August 1999 and August 2000 prices fell by 21.7 per cent on average. A&L spokesman Geoff Seymour says: 'It was at that point that people were finding themselves in negative equity. They hadn't got the value in the car any more.' Some of the worst affected cars have been 'people carriers' such as the Renault Scenic, Ford Galaxy and Vauxhall Frontera. CAP Motor Research, which publishes guides to car prices, says negative equity has been a particular problem for people who bought on traditional hire-purchase agreements. If you have a personal loan from a bank, you own the car from the outset, and although you may get less for the car than you owe, at least you can sell. With hire-purchase you do not own the car until the loan has been repaid. Buyers who wanted to swap to a new car part-way through a deal would normally expect to get back enough to repay their existing finance and put down a deposit on another car. But in the recent market, trading up has not been an option. Simon Goldtharp, an editor of CAP's Black Book , a guide to used car prices explains: 'If the car is worth £2,000 and you owe £3000 you end up giving the dealer money to clear it off.' However, consumer law allows buyers to hand back a car when they have repaid half the capital without being blacklisted for credit. CAP says dealers are losing out heavily on these deals because customers are doing just that. Negative equity is also a problem with contract purchase agreements, deals that have been marketed heavily by manufacturers and dealers in recent years. These require deposits of around 20 per cent and lower monthly payments than would be required on a normal finance agreement. As with hire purchase, you do not own the car, but at the end of a set term you must pay the balance owed, trade it in for a new model or hand it back. But trade-in values have been proving so poor that owners have not been able to trade up to a new car. Like high street shops, car dealers have been relying increasingly on the selling of finance to supplement their income, according to Goldtharp at CAP. 'In a lot of cases they have pretty much relied on finance and sold cars at a loss.' Most dealers will have a specialist to sell finance deals to customers and, although commission varies, the dealer might get £100 to £150 for each deal sold. 'They will take as much out of the customer as they can,' says Goldtharp. In addition to loans for the cars, the sales specialist will probably also try to sell insurance to cover loans against illness or redundancy and this 'gives an extra commission again'. Problems with negative equity are beginning to subside because car prices have begun to stabilise. Nevertheless CAP recently warned that car owners should still be wary of low-deposit finance deals. Goldtharp points out that the prices of cars rarely go up, even in a buoyant market, and that conditions can change. He says: 'Imagine buying something last September that you won't pay off until the next Olympics.'

fields.headline: It's not as complicated as it seems...
fields.standfirst: But do research your needs well, reports  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: But do research your needs well, reports Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
How do you choose a stakeholder pension when more than 40 companies have entered this new market? Many may be daunted by the prospect.

But take comfort from the experts: choosing could become much simpler once you have thought through a few of the issues. For a start, if you are an employee without a pension arrangement, first look to the scheme set up by your employer, says Tom McPhail, of independent financial adviser Torquil Clark.

'It's a pretty good rule of thumb that the deal your employer offers is likely to be as good as anything you'll get elsewhere.' This is because many employers are expected to contribute to the stakeholder scheme they set up. Many will be able to negotiate reductions on charges, cutting the management charge from the maximum 1 per cent to 0.8 per cent.

Employers of five people or more have until 8 October to put a stakeholder plan in place for their workforce unless they already have an occupational scheme. If they do run an occupational scheme, you should seriously consider joining it, not least because most employers make significant contributions into these schemes.

But if you are going to take out your own stakeholder plan, you need to consider various issues, principally the charges, the investment choice in the scheme, the track record and strength of the provider, and the accessibility of the plan.

Charges are tightly controlled. There are no initial charges, the maximum annual management charge is 1 per cent and penalty charges, for transfers in or out, or for people stopping, starting or changing their contribution levels, are banned. Most providers are charging a 1 per cent annual management fee, but some, such as Legal & General and Royal Bank of Scotland, are reducing this when the fund gets to a certain size. L&G will charge 0.8 per cent on funds of £25,000.

Some intermediaries, such as Torquil Clark (0800 056 1836) and Direct Life & Pensions (0808 107 2000) are offering to rebate some of their commission to stakeholder investors and have negotiated some charge reductions.

If you are young and going to take an interest in your pension, you will want to be able to move your investment easily between funds. You will be able to tolerate international risk on your money in your twenties, because your investment will have decades to recover from market turbulence; this would be very unwise for a 55-year-old.

If you do not want to think about your investments, you could go for a 'lifestyle' option, where your plan is automatically moved into safer funds the closer you get to retirement.

Scottish Widows, NPI and Friends Provident are highlighted by both Torquil Clark and adviser the Massow Rainbow Group as large, strong product providers with a range of funds and an acceptable record.

In a review of the stakeholder market, accountant PricewaterhouseCoopers

notes that the Government has 'driven a hard bargain' on the terms product providers must offer.

It hints that some providers will find it difficult to compete in the long term. This should not be a disaster for anyone who held funds with them, but it could be an inconvenience and a worry. Very few stakeholder funds have been set up as 'with-profits funds', the vehicle that caused such problems at Equitable Life, so investors should not be put off by that.

If you visit the post office regularly, you may be attracted to Standard Life's plan, which is available there. Others will want to run their account through the internet.

People earning more than £30,000 and paying into an occupational scheme already are barred from a stakeholder; everyone else can participate in this new arrangement, which lets you invest £3,600 (£2,808 net of basic-rate tax) a year.

We will be exploring complexities of the stakeholder in future issues.

Next week: should you switch your personal pension to a stakeholder?

fields.headline: 'Lost' cheque could cost you dear
fields.standfirst: Lenders don't make it easy to meet their deadlines
fields.trailText: Lenders don't make it easy to meet their deadlines.
fields.body:
Many shoppers who sign up for an interest-free deal are caught out by the small print. The deal they agree to is that no interest will be paid as long as the entire balance is paid off by a certain date. But paying it off is not as easy as it sounds.

Customers have found that when they try to pay, the finance firm asks for payment by cheque.

In some cases the cheque is then lost or delayed - and the finance firms insist on claiming huge amounts of interest according to the let ter of the contract. Some contracts even have small print saying that payment must reach the company five days before the deadline.

The National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux is so concerned it has issued a warning to consumers to ask for the final deadline before they sign the deal and to find out how the payment must be made.

The Finance and Leasing Association is also troubled by the growing number of people caught in this situation. It has issued new guide lines to lenders saying reminders should be sent out a month before the deadline and that leeway must be given if a payment is a little late.

Clerical assistant Jenny Justice (above) bought a television for £379 from Powerhouse in Southampton on six months' interest-free credit last June, paying a deposit of £50. The balance had to be paid in full by 17 December.

Jenny has had similar deals in the past and has always paid up on time. In her case if the balance was not paid off by that date, the deal would no longer be interest-free. She would then be switched to an interest-bearing deal over three-and-a-half years. When Jenny signed the deal she had to fill out direct debit forms.

That was so that if she did not make the 17 December deadline, the company would start taking direct debits each month. In the first week of December, Jenny realised she had not been sent instructions as to how to pay off the balance.

She phoned the finance company First National Tricity, owned by Abbey National Bank, and was told to send a cheque. Jenny posted this cheque on 9 December.

She did not check her bank statements until mid-January and discovered that the finance company had taken two direct debit payments of £16.57 - as well as cashing her cheque for the full £329.

Jenny, of Romsey, Hampshire, said: 'I phoned them to point out the error, expecting the whole thing to be very quickly sorted out. Instead, they insisted that I had not paid off the amount on time. They claimed my cheque had not arrived with them until 27 December. They said the cheque was cashed on 29 December.'

This meant Jenny was no longer on an interest-free deal. Instead, she would have to pay the £16.57 every month for 42 months until the balance was paid off.

That is at an APR (annual percentage rate) of 34.2 per cent. In total, she would have to pay £695.44. Her cheque for £329 would be counted towards the final sum.

Jenny was told her best bet was to agree a settlement figure, which meant she would pay some but not all of the interest. She was sent a proposed settlement fee. First National Tricity were offering to end the agreement for a payment of £104.84. It claimed she owed £227.97. That included £189.10 interest and £38.87 for insurance. Jenny claims she told the sales assistant she did not want insurance, but says that the assistant filled in the paperwork.

Jenny said: 'I rang again to query this. I was told during the conversation that I could pay the settlement figure by Switch. So why did they not suggest that when I first phoned them? If they had suggested I pay by Switch then this would never have happened.'

We put Jenny's questions to First National Tricity, which said: 'Cheque payment is the method preferred by the company. If a customer inquires about other methods of payment our customer service staff will always offer options.

'During December 2000 we were aware of delays to the post that resulted in customers' cheques not reaching their accounts within the deferred period. A company decision was therefore made to allow extra days' grace on customers' accounts.

'We fully accept Mrs Justice intended to settle her account before the due date and all interest charges have been removed.'

NACAB is dealing with seven other cases of people who have been caught out in the same way. But they say this is 'the tip of the iceberg'.

A spokeswoman said these are just the cases reported to head office, but there will be many more dealt with at branch level, and many more again not reported to the CAB.

She said: 'The problem these companies have got with 0 per cent finance deals, is - what happens if everyone pays up on time?

'The companies tend to be very fussy about payment dates and that is where many people run into difficulties.

NACAB has produced a checklist for shoppers:

 Do not let a sales assistant fill in the application for you.

 Take time to understand the offer.

 Make sure you know the final deadline for payment.

 Ask how payment can be made.

 If a direct debit is set up, check the account regularly to see what transactions have been made.

 Check that what you are told by sales staff is written down in the agreement.

 When you are told about credit terms, ask the assistant to point out where they appear in the agreement.

Storing up trouble for the future

Shoppers paying for goods on store card credit may be paying interest as high as 32 per cent - nearly six times the bank base rate, writes Maria Scott .

Store cards are notoriously expensive for people who rack up debt. The rates rarely change and even now, with the base rate at 5.5 per cent, lenders show little sign of budging. There are some cheaper cards in the market (see table) but generally store cards are one of the most expensive ways to borrow. Some shave off a percentage point or so for payment by direct debit, but borrowers who pay off just the minimum pay huge charges.

Retailers promote store cards with discounts and other offers. Borrowers canny enough to use the cards for the perks may find them worthwhile since they do not charge annual fees and can provide up to two months' free credit. But borrow long term and you pay up to three times what you would on conventional credit cards.

A spokeswoman for Timecard, the storecard for Comet, B&Q, Woolworths and Superdrug, said 60 per cent of its customers always paid their bills in full.

webTitle: Work: It's the end of the road

fields.headline: It's the end of the road
fields.standfirst:
New tax rules could signal a farewell to the flash comapny car, writes Alexander Garrett

Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: New tax rules could signal a farewell to the flash comapny car, writes Alexander Garrett
fields.body:
Poor old sales reps. They spend their week racing up and down motorways, listening to more drive-time radio than any human being should decently have to, and pausing only to check in for their overnight stay at a Travelodge.

And nobody even respects them for it: they are blamed for most of the sins of the road, whether it be hogging the fast lane, talking on their mobiles, or eating that overfilled baguette at the wheel. Until now, the one solace the long-distance sales rep had was his (or her) company car: the fabled Mondeo or, if lucky, BMW Series 5 that was as much an office as a mode of transport, and which placed them in their own eyes a cut above the wage-slaves back at base.

But now even that is going to be taken away from them. From next April, the tax treatment of company cars is going to be turned upside down and many will be forced to give up their dream machine in favour of a clean machine. Until now, you could reduce the tax you paid on the benefit of your company vehicle by clocking up the maximum number of business miles each year; from next April, the tax will be calculated on the basis of how environmentally 'clean' the car is judged to be in terms of its emissions, and the number of miles driven will be irrelevant. The idea is to get people driving greener cars, but in practice, that is usually synonymous with smaller cars, since the amount of pollution you produce is largely dependent on the size of the engine.

Those who spend most time in their cars will be hit hardest; currently, if you drive more than 18,000 business miles a year, you pay tax on just 15 per cent of the value of the car; but somebody driving a gas-guzzler like a Mercedes will see that shoot up to 35 per cent of the car's value, more than doubling their tax bill. The liability of a 2.2 litre Vauxhall Vectra will be set at 22 per cent of its value from next April, but a ratchet effect will make the liability of each model go up progressively after that, as the emissions threshold is lowered.

Next April may seem a long way off, but Alison Chapman, a tax partner at accountant Deloitte & Touche, says company car drivers should be thinking about it now. 'The average replacement cycle for a company car is three to four years,' she says. 'So if you change your car this year, you may end up driving it for three years under the new tax regime.'

She says that many people with company cars will find it hard to accept the idea of downgrading to a smaller vehicle. 'If you spend a huge amount of time in your car, say you're doing 20,000 miles plus, then you are going to feel you need a comfortable car. A lot of salespeople need extra space to carry samples and other goods,' she points out.

Chapman says she believes that employees will also find it hard to accept a lower value car than they are entitled to. 'I don't think many companies are going to say that if you choose a cheaper car, we'll give you some extra money and, psychologically, people will feel that they're losing out,' she says. Even more of a thorny issue is the status symbol that the company car has come to represent in the UK workplace, and the loss of status that would be implied by downsizing. Swap my Passat for a Polo? You've got to be joking.

John Manion, a principal at remuneration consultants Towers Perrin, says the car's importance as a status symbol varies from company to company and industry to industry. 'It's partly a question of visibility; in London, nobody has a clue what car you drive,' he says. 'But if you're a firm in Yorkshire where everyone drives to work and passes you in the car park, it's a different matter.'

The pecking order of company cars is particularly important in sectors such as pharmaceuticals and consumer goods, he says, but less so in IT, where the car culture doesn't have such a long tradition. For the salesman the perception is particularly acute. 'If you drive up to your customer's gate in a flashy car, then people are likely to think you're a better salesman.'

Alison Chapman has experienced at first hand how your company car can affect colleagues' perception of you. She says that when she became a partner at Deloitte & Touche, she had to surrender the company BMW and buy her own car. 'I wasn't going to pay for a BMW myself, so I ended up with a third-hand Hyundai Sonata, and people said 'poor you', assuming I'd been demoted,' she says.

She believes that many high-mileage company car drivers who face the prospect of downgrading will prefer to pay the higher tax, or even opt out of their company car for the first time and take the cash alternative. One advantage of doing so is that you have more choice over the car you choose and you can even opt to spend the money on something else, like a conservatory. She also predicts that some low-mileage 'perk' drivers who gave up their company car for cash will opt back in, as they will no longer be penalised for their low business miles.

However, many in the motor industry believe that the change of taxation will have the desired effect in making many people opt for less polluting cars. In last year's Lex Vehicle Leasing Report on Company Motoring, some 42 per cent said they would 'get a car with lower emissions' as a result of the new tax regime, while only 18 per cent said they would give up having a company car.

John Stanley, spokesman for the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders, says: 'There has been a general trend in car registrations towards smaller vehicles, and that is not just among private buyers but also among fleets. We are seeing "super-minis", such as the Corsa, the Polo and the Fiesta, which are now as refined and well equipped as larger vehicles, with features like ABS, multiple airbags and CD players fitted as standard.'

Manufacturers have improved the safety of smaller cars, as well as providing much more headroom and window surface - all of which should go some way to assuage the disgruntlement of the long-distance sales rep.

It is left to the British Vehicle Rental and Leasing Association's spokeswoman to put in a kind word for this embattled species: 'These people are part of the lifeblood of the economy,' she says. 'Nobody drives 18,000 miles-plus a year for pleasure. If they have to downsize from a Mondeo to a Focus that might not mean sacrificing too much in terms of comfort, so it becomes more of an image thing. But I don't think you're going to get these people pounding up and down the motorway in a super-mini.'

The idea is to get people driving greener cars, but in practice, that is usually synonymous with smaller cars, since the amount of pollution you produce is largely dependent on the size of the engine. Those who spend most time in their cars will be hit hardest; currently, if you drive more than 18,000 business miles a year, you pay tax on just 15 per cent of the value of the car; but somebody driving a gas-guzzler like a Mercedes will see that shoot up to 35 per cent of the car's value, more than doubling their tax bill. The liability of a 2.2 litre Vauxhall Vectra will be set at 22 per cent of its value from next April, but a ratchet effect will make the liability of each model go up progressively after that, as the emissions threshold is lowered. Next April may seem a long way off, but Alison Chapman, a tax partner at accountant Deloitte & Touche, says company car drivers should be thinking about it now. 'The average replacement cycle for a company car is three to four years,' she says. 'So if you change your car this year, you may end up driving it for three years under the new tax regime.' She says that many people with company cars will find it hard to accept the idea of downgrading to a smaller vehicle. 'If you spend a huge amount of time in your car, say you're doing 20,000 miles plus, then you are going to feel you need a comfortable car. A lot of salespeople need extra space to carry samples and other goods,' she points out. Chapman says she believes that employees will also find it hard to accept a lower value car than they are entitled to. 'I don't think many companies are going to say that if you choose a cheaper car, we'll give you some extra money and, psychologically, people will feel that they're losing out,' she says. Even more of a thorny issue is the status symbol that the company car has come to represent in the UK workplace, and the loss of status that would be implied by downsizing. Swap my Passat for a Polo? You've got to be joking. John Manion, a principal at remuneration consultants Towers Perrin, says the car's importance as a status symbol varies from company to company and industry to industry. 'It's partly a question of visibility; in London, nobody has a clue what car you drive,' he says. 'But if you're a firm in Yorkshire where everyone drives to work and passes you in the car park, it's a different matter.' The pecking order of company cars is particularly important in sectors such as pharmaceuticals and consumer goods, he says, but less so in IT, where the car culture doesn't have such a long tradition. For the salesman the perception is particularly acute. 'If you drive up to your customer's gate in a flashy car, then people are likely to think you're a better salesman.' Alison Chapman has experienced at first hand how your company car can affect colleagues' perception of you. She says that when she became a partner at Deloitte & Touche, she had to surrender the company BMW and buy her own car. 'I wasn't going to pay for a BMW myself, so I ended up with a third-hand Hyundai Sonata, and people said 'poor you', assuming I'd been demoted,' she says. She believes that many high-mileage company car drivers who face the prospect of downgrading will prefer to pay the higher tax, or even opt out of their company car for the first time and take the cash alternative. One advantage of doing so is that you have more choice over the car you choose and you can even opt to spend the money on something else, like a conservatory. She also predicts that some low-mileage 'perk' drivers who gave up their company car for cash will opt back in, as they will no longer be penalised for their low business miles. However, many in the motor industry believe that the change of taxation will have the desired effect in making many people opt for less polluting cars. In last year's Lex Vehicle Leasing Report on Company Motoring, some 42 per cent said they would 'get a car with lower emissions' as a result of the new tax regime, while only 18 per cent said they would give up having a company car. John Stanley, spokesman for the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders, says: 'There has been a general trend in car registrations towards smaller vehicles, and that is not just among private buyers but also among fleets. We are seeing "super-minis", such as the Corsa, the Polo and the Fiesta, which are now as refined and well equipped as larger vehicles, with features like ABS, multiple airbags and CD players fitted as standard.' Manufacturers have improved the safety of smaller cars, as well as providing much more headroom and window surface - all of which should go some way to assuage the disgruntlement of the long-distance sales rep. It is left to the British Vehicle Rental and Leasing Association's spokeswoman to put in a kind word for this embattled species: 'These people are part of the lifeblood of the economy,' she says. 'Nobody drives 18,000 miles-plus a year for pleasure. If they have to downsize from a Mondeo to a Focus that might not mean sacrificing too much in terms of comfort, so it becomes more of an image thing. But I don't think you're going to get these people pounding up and down the motorway in a super-mini.'

webTitle: Find your way through the credit maze

fields.headline: Find your way through the credit maze
fields.standfirst: Can't afford to buy that telly outright? Beware. Retailers will gamble on you having difficulty repaying the debt
fields.trailText: Can't afford to buy that telly outright? Beware. Retailers will gamble on you having difficulty repaying the debt.
fields.body:
Many high street firms now offer 0 per cent finance, but finance companies do not lend at 0 per cent. They buy the money they lend at about 3.5 per cent, so will not be lending it for nothing.

At jeweller Ernest Jones, any item of jewellery costing over £200 is available on interest-free credit.

If you choose a ring that costs £300, say, finance company GE Capital Bank will, if it approves you, lend you the £300. But the lender will want back not £300 but £300 plus interest, and this is paid by the retailer.

In the used car trade, a common scam is to offer 0 per cent finance in large adverts just to bring people in. Those who respond find the offer is restricted to one or two expensive cars - and then only if they pay a 50 per cent deposit, which no one who buys on finance can afford.

So are high street shops now employing the same tactics as the less scrupulous elements of the used car trade?

The Observer asked Paul Witts, of advertising agency The Creative, which specialises in the finance-led retail market, to explain how some of the deals on the market operate.

Ernest Jones

The jeweller offers interest-free credit on items over £200. On £200 you pay a 10 per cent deposit and get six months to pay. On £500 you pay 20 per cent and get nine months' credit. On anything over £1,000 you also pay 20 per cent but get 12 months to pay. If you pay this amount in the time given, there is no interest charged.

Verdict

This is a genuine offer, not like the car trade scams. The customer gets credit over a short term and does not pay interest. The vendors pay the interest themselves. So they are in fact taking a price cut on the goods.

The finance will not be as expensive for the vendors as it would for you or me - especially if they bring the finance firm a lot of work. The vendors will be borrowing at a cheap rate and will get a commission on the deal, or a cheaper rate still. But though it is not as easy to jack up prices for jewellery as it is in the car trade, it would be surprising if the vendor's price list did not include a margin for this.

The law does not allow the vendor to offer an alternative to 0 per cent finance. So a customer can't point out that the offer amounts to a price cut and get a lower price for cash.

You will probably find jewellers are keen to sell you a warranty or some kind of insurance to get back some of the amount by which they are subsidising your deal.

Dixons

Typical deals include a stereo for £199 or a Bosch television for £649 on six months' interest-free credit.

There are two options on offer. One is an interest-free option where you pay nothing for six months then pay the balance or go into a finance deal at 29 per cent over 48 months.

Or you can choose to make monthly interest-free payments over six months. After six months you can pay the balance or go into a deal at 19.8 per cent.

If you decide not to pay the balance you will just carry on making monthly payments until the account is settled. Dixons uses two finance companies, HFC Bank and GE Capital Bank.

Verdict

Again, this is a genuine offer of a subsidised finance deal. But if the balance is not paid off, the customer automatically switches to another agreement with a high rate of interest. The second offer, at 19.8 per cent, is a better deal, but the rate is still high.

In both cases the store is gambling on people not paying off the entire sum in six months.

John Lewis

Customers are offered 'extended' credit on larger items such as furniture and carpets over a longer period of time.

You take out a deal over nine, 12, 18, 24, 30 or 36 months. On each you pay a minimum deposit of 10 per cent. The typical APR (annual percentage rate of interest) is 13 per cent. A three-seater sofa for £1,850 would cost £2,189.48 over 36 months. That's £339.48 interest. The John Lewis company provides its own finance.

Verdict

As always, buying on credit costs more. But at least in this case it is quite clear from the start how much more. An interest rate of 13 per cent is realistic and is the standard for this sort of deal.

Most companies will not be able to do a deal at less than about 13 per cent, including a profit, because of the cost to them of buying in the money they lend. So if you see rates lower than this, beware: you often pay more in the end.

For its its part, Dixons denies that its finance deals could confuse people and says credit gives customers more freedom of choice.

A spokeswoman said: 'We offer credit as a way of giving extra choice to customers. A detailed credit check is carried out before an interest-free option is offered, so only customers in a stable situation will be given these deals.

'Our staff are trained to explain agreements carefully. In the case of interest-free options, a clear reminder is always sent out one month before the end of the interest-free period. We are simply offering the customer an alternative method of paying.'

The fact that stores are not allowed to offer an alternative to a 0 per cent finance deal is helping to establish this as a high street selling tool. If the standard rate of finance is 13 per cent, which is about what a bank loan would cost, the customer appears to be getting a 13 per cent discount. In fact, the store is subsidising the deal by much less than that because it gets finance at a far lower rate.

The more 0 per cent finance deals a retailer does, the cheaper that finance gets. Not only does it appear to offer a big discount, but it can sell to people who do not have any money.

Once the deal is signed, the finance company pays the store for the goods - less the interest on the deal - and the store gets its money on the spot. If the customer has trouble paying, that the finance firm's problem.

But Witts believes 0 per cent finance can have its upside for customers: 'As long as you pay it off on time, it is free credit.'

webTitle: How to climb your way up the greasy pole

fields.headline: How to climb your way up the greasy pole
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: 1 Understand that your ability to cope with the stresses of your given field could be the determining factor of your success. Many outstanding players are better at handling certain types of pressures than rivals - athletes who train harder than competitors, for instance, managers who work longer hours, academics who publish more books, and writers who cope well with deadlines.
fields.body:
1 Understand that your ability to cope with the stresses of your given field could be the determining factor of your success. Many outstanding players are better at handling certain types of pressures than rivals - athletes who train harder than competitors, for instance, managers who work longer hours, academics who publish more books, and writers who cope well with deadlines.

2 Watch the leaders in your field and try to work out the stresses they face and the way they cope. Perhaps they are capable of sitting through five-hour meetings, able to cope with endless moaning from colleagues, and do not want to spend much time with their partner or family.

3 Decide whether you want to carry on liking yourself. It is often easier to rise if you trample on others. Unfeeling types will be untroubled by decisions which give sleepless nights to others. Middle managers have to decide if they will sacrifice underdogs to appease senior managers.

4 Keep notching up achievements if you want to progress. You need to demonstrate why you should be promoted. Bureaucrats could be impressed if your section wins a kitemark, Investors in People award, or some other supposed testimony. Signs of increased productivity will appeal to bosses in more commercial roles.

5 Don't let the developing ruthless side of your nature get you into trouble. If you are discovered fiddling your tax, tape-recorded slagging off your boss or suspected of taking brown envelopes, you could find your promising career is over. Many high-fliers do these things and worse - but their biggest skill is ensuring they do not get caught.

6 Recognise that the unpleasant side of your nature will need to be balanced by something which resembles principle or affability. You will need allies. Many military generals have been seen eating with their men and wandering around near the front line, occupations which imply that they still care. But this camaraderie should not run too deep: true egalitarians are seen as lacking ruthlessness.

7 Understand that you probably need to take calculated risks to mark yourself out. Entrepreneurs such as Sir Richard Branson are constantly taking risks and frequently lose out as a result. But they make sure they win more than they lose - and, whatever happens, pay a lot of attention to maintaining the confidence of people around them.

webTitle: Redundant but still entitled to a fair deal

fields.headline: Redundant but still entitled to a fair deal
fields.trailText: I have been offered a redundancy payment on my short-term contract. I used to be an employee of the business, but some of us agreed to go on short-term contracts. I was originally told that my redundancy and pension top-up would be made up to the end of the contract in June - but then received a letter stating that these payments would be enhanced to cover another three months of service.
fields.body:
I have been offered a redundancy payment on my short-term contract. I used to be an employee of the business, but some of us agreed to go on short-term contracts. I was originally told that my redundancy and pension top-up would be made up to the end of the contract in June - but then received a letter stating that these payments would be enhanced to cover another three months of service.

A further letter said that a mistake had been made and that we would just get the original amounts.

Can I hold them to the enhanced terms?

There are two ways you could try to hold them to the enhanced terms.

First, you would need to show that the enhancement was part of a contract. To prove this, you would have to demonstrate that you had given something in exchange - agreeing to work for a longer period, for instance.

If you cannot do this, you could try the more difficult second route. On this road -'estoppel' - you would need to show that you had relied on the enhanced offer and would suffer detriment if you did not get it. For instance, you might have agreed to take out a larger mortgage. But this is complicated and difficult to prove. It may well be that you simply have to accept the original offer.

webTitle: Rough deals: who'd have credited it?

fields.headline: Rough deals: who'd have credited it?
fields.standfirst: The boom in 'free' finance on the high street is luring millions into debt, write  Mike Bull and  Diane Halligan
fields.trailText: The boom in 'free' finance on the high street is luring millions into debt, write Mike Bull and Diane Halligan.
fields.body:
The 'have now, pay later' culture has started a trend in the High Street that could drag millions of consumers into debt.

If you go into a jeweller, electrical store, a furniture shop - just about any shop at all - the sales staff may be as eager to sell a finance deal as to sell a product. Virtually every big store offers credit deals and in many cases the company makes more from these than from the sale of its products. The product has become almost incidental in the whole transaction.

The mini-boom we have been enjoying for the past few years is the result of people spending more. But experts warn that booms built on credit are the most likely to go bust. The National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux has been sounding warnings since the autumn that Britain's credit problem is spiralling out of control. The number of people with serious financial problems has rocketed by 34 per cent in two years. NACAB blames the easy availability of credit.

There has been a massive explosion in the sale of credit agreements with consumer goods since the mid-1990s. Lending through retailers, excluding store credit cards, grew by 40 per cent in 1996. It has since levelled out, but is still running at substantial levels. In the year to February £7.7 billion of new retail credit agreements were recorded by the Finance and Leasing Association.

It is easy to get credit in the high street. On a shopping trip we were offered finance deals at The Link, Dixons, Habitat, Ernest Jones, John Lewis and just about everywhere else we tried.

Paul Witts, head of The Creative, an advertising agency that works for lenders, says retailers are eager for the commission on finance deals. 'For every customer they can sign up to a finance deal, they will receive a commission from the finance company,' he says.

'That commission is often more than they make on the sale of the product. Especially if they can also sell you an extended warranty, insurance - the works.

'The mark-up on many high street goods is small because competition is so fierce. So everyone's playing the finance game.' Witts added: 'It's also easier to sell if people do not have to part with any money. A good salesman will break the price down to a small monthly payment. And, because the customer wants to be persuaded so he or she can get their hands on the sofa or TV, no one does the sums.

'In fact, customers are paying far more for products in the long run. You have bought a finance deal - not just a product - and that finance will cost you money.'

Witts adds: 'My advice would be to take a step back before signing the deal. Do the sums. Multiply the monthly figure by the number of months of the deal. If you have agreed to warranties, insurance etc and you see the final figure, with interest added, you will realise how much you are paying. Shop around to see if that is a good price for the item you are after.'

Every company that generates business for a finance company will be repaid, either with commissions or with cheaper lending rates.

Typical commission is 10 per cent of the interest payable on the money borrowed.

When it all breaks down

If you pay cash for a television and it breaks soon after you get it home you can take it back and ask for a refund, claiming breach of contract. But what if your TV breaks and you are still paying for it?

The 1974 Consumer Credit Act says that both the finance company and the retailer are responsible for the quality of the goods if there is a pre-existing arrangement between them. But in practice, the joint liability of the deal simply serves to cloud the issue.

Susan Marks, social policy officer at the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux, said: 'We get people coming to us who have been pushed to and fro. Part of the problem is that the finance company does not know the goods. They may ask you to show the goods to the retailer so the retailer can decide whether they are faulty.'

But this tactic is often used to fob customers off. Marks said that if you have bought goods on credit and believe them to be faulty, you should write to both the retailer and the finance company stating that you wish to rescind the contract.

If the retailer wishes to examine the goods, you should ask for a receipt stating that you have submitted them for 'examination purposes only'. It should stipulate that the retailer must not attempt to repair the item without your approval. This is so that any claim you have for a full refund of your money is not affected.

But if you wish to rescind the contract on the basis of the goods being faulty, you must prove they were not of saleable quality . That may mean paying independent bodies to report on the state of the goods.

And in many cases, the required legal standard is low. The used car business offers the most obvious example: it is difficult to determine what constitutes 'saleable quality'. In the past, courts have ruled that a car is fit for sale 'if it can be driven off the forecourt'.

Direct Car Finance, which features comedian Jim Davidson in its ads, specialises in selling cars to people with a bad credit history and deals only in used cars. Customers buy the vehicles through deals set up by sales staff with Welcome Finance.

A spokesman for Welcome Finance said: 'We must decide if a vehicle was in a saleable condition when bought. If it was, our agreement is still enforceable. But we do try to take a sympathetic view. We commission reports into the state of the vehicles; these should be paid for by the customer, but we quite often pay towards the cost.

'The trouble for us is that some people will buy a car and drive it for six months and then, when it breaks down, try to claim that it was not of saleable quality in the first place.'

The law may change soon. An EC directive currently in consultation (1999/44/EC) is considering changing the rules so consumers do not have to prove that goods are at fault.

One suggestion being considered is that no proof at all be required within the first six months. However, retailers would probably be allowed to repair or replace rather than offer a full refund.

Every company that generates business for a finance company will be repaid, either with commissions or with cheaper lending rates. Typical commission is 10 per cent of the interest payable on the money borrowed. When it all breaks down If you pay cash for a television and it breaks soon after you get it home you can take it back and ask for a refund, claiming breach of contract. But what if your TV breaks and you are still paying for it? The 1974 Consumer Credit Act says that both the finance company and the retailer are responsible for the quality of the goods if there is a pre-existing arrangement between them. But in practice, the joint liability of the deal simply serves to cloud the issue. Susan Marks, social policy officer at the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux, said: 'We get people coming to us who have been pushed to and fro. Part of the problem is that the finance company does not know the goods. They may ask you to show the goods to the retailer so the retailer can decide whether they are faulty.' But this tactic is often used to fob customers off. Marks said that if you have bought goods on credit and believe them to be faulty, you should write to both the retailer and the finance company stating that you wish to rescind the contract. If the retailer wishes to examine the goods, you should ask for a receipt stating that you have submitted them for 'examination purposes only'. It should stipulate that the retailer must not attempt to repair the item without your approval. This is so that any claim you have for a full refund of your money is not affected. But if you wish to rescind the contract on the basis of the goods being faulty, you must prove they were not of saleable quality . That may mean paying independent bodies to report on the state of the goods. And in many cases, the required legal standard is low. The used car business offers the most obvious example: it is difficult to determine what constitutes 'saleable quality'. In the past, courts have ruled that a car is fit for sale 'if it can be driven off the forecourt'. Direct Car Finance, which features comedian Jim Davidson in its ads, specialises in selling cars to people with a bad credit history and deals only in used cars. Customers buy the vehicles through deals set up by sales staff with Welcome Finance. A spokesman for Welcome Finance said: 'We must decide if a vehicle was in a saleable condition when bought. If it was, our agreement is still enforceable. But we do try to take a sympathetic view. We commission reports into the state of the vehicles; these should be paid for by the customer, but we quite often pay towards the cost. 'The trouble for us is that some people will buy a car and drive it for six months and then, when it breaks down, try to claim that it was not of saleable quality in the first place.' The law may change soon. An EC directive currently in consultation (1999/44/EC) is considering changing the rules so consumers do not have to prove that goods are at fault. One suggestion being considered is that no proof at all be required within the first six months. However, retailers would probably be allowed to repair or replace rather than offer a full refund.

fields.headline: Where innovation flowers
fields.standfirst: Dutch horticultural prowess is down to a lack of resources and cheap labour, writes  Simon Caulkin
fields.trailText: Dutch horticultural prowess is down to a lack of resources and cheap labour, writes Simon Caulkin
fields.body:
So much for a business school education. If President Bush really does bin the Kyoto treaty on reducing greenhouse gases, he will have scored a business own goal unmatched since IBM handed responsibility for the operating system of its new PC to a brash young software company called Microsoft.

Leave aside for a moment the evident truth that - the economy being a wholly owned subsidiary of the environment (as a more enlightened US politician put it) - the argument that Kyoto 'would damage our economy and hurt our workers' is as challenged economically as some of Bush's election pronouncements were semantically.

Put away also righteous anger that the immediate beneficiaries of such a decision would be the stock-option stashes of Bush's buddies in big oil, some of the least needy and least deserving cases on earth.

Consider instead the poetic justice by which this act of political expediency will end up undermining the competitiveness, and hurting many more jobs, of the very companies it is designed to favour.

Way back in 1990, Harvard academic Michael Porter, author of standard textbooks and adviser to governments on competition, published a massive tome entitled The Competitive Advantage of Nations. This showed how transient (and treacherous) was the advantage based on natural resources such as cheap labour and raw materials such as oil and coal. Such factors are easy to substitute or circumvent by the use of brainpower - a much more dynamic and enduring defence of strategic position. One of Porter's most striking examples of advantage created from lack rather than abundance of natural resources is the Dutch flower industry. An extraordinary indirect legacy of the great tulip bubble, Dutch horticulture maintains a lock on 65 per cent of the world's trade in cut flowers.

What makes Dutch flowers bloom is not natural resources but self-reinforcing rounds of management innovation which give them impregnable advantage over less sophisticated competitors. Plant husbandry is just part of it: Dutch horticulture is an evolving high-tech industry based on science, supported by specialised equipment, auction and distribution systems that whizz delicate cargos from bulbfields to market in hours.

Counterintuitively, it was the shortage of basic inputs that was the trigger for Dutch success, obliging growers to innovate to compete. In contrast, cautions Porter, 'an abundance of labour and natural resources or a lack of environmental pressure may lead a country's companies to spend the national resources unproductively'. (Can anyone think what North Sea oil bought us, apart from time?)

'Competing based on cheap inputs, which could be used with less productivity, was sufficient in a more insular, less global, economy. Today, when emerging nations with even cheaper labour and raw materials are part of the global economy, the old strategy is unsustainable.'

Note Porter's reference to 'environmental pressure'. In a subsequent article in Harvard Business Review (from which the above quote was taken), he developed his argument further. Wisely applied, he claimed, environmental standards could not only prod companies to speed up innovation; in so far as those innovations increased overall resource productivity, they had the potential to reduce rather than raise costs.

There is a strong parallel here with the quality movement. Quality showed that by eliminating waste, designing quality in ('right first time') was always less expensive than correcting mistakes after the event. Pollution is waste. Treating it 'end-of-pipe' is undeniably costly. Preventing it happening in the first place may also be costly in one-off terms - but it is far cheaper in whole-system costs, and even in investment terms the payback is often a matter of months.

Since, on the above definition, between a quarter and half of the world's output is waste, there is a massive commercial opportunity for companies to develop and sell clean technology that also benefits the environment.

But here's the rub. Porter's other important observation was that under regulatory pressure, fast-moving companies could often be seen to innovate their way to an unassailable competitive advantage over slower, or lazier, rivals. Dutch flower growers are a good example.

Now reframe Bush's Kyoto decision in this light. By making life easier for US fossil-fuel burners and producers, he is turning down the pressure to innovate. Far from doing them a favour, reducing the pressure to innovate makes it much more likely that they will fall behind their European and Japanese competitors in technology and in appeal to customers. They will miss out on markets for cleaner technology.

This has already happened once in the car industry. It is also happening in other combustion areas, such as heating, where European companies, driven by relatively high fuel prices and stricter regulation, lead their US counterparts by decades.

Now there is a growing divergence in oil. When BP broke with the rest of the oil majors four years ago and came out in support of the precautionary principle in environmental matters, it set off a spurt of internal innovation that it is only just beginning to tap. By adopting its own emissions trading scheme and implementing hundreds of process improvements, it claims it has already reduced its own emissions over 1990 levels by 5 per cent.

Although BP won't comment on Bush's Kyoto statement, it says it has no intention of altering its own stance. Why would it, when it knows that in the longer term its technological and trading experience could give it a real advantage over rivals in meeting tighter customer requirements, attracting dedicated managers and securing loyal financial capital?

The world badly needs more big corporations to turn their attention to devising solutions rather than denying the problem. That this is possible is shown in a modest way by BP, among mainstream companies, and the burgeoning 'natural capitalism' movement, espoused by Bill Clinton. But only if government plays its part with intelligent standard-setting and regulation. And that means resisting business's special pleading for the easy solution. As always in management, the only thing gained from a free lunch is indigestion.

fields.headline: Jimmy Logan
fields.standfirst: Scots comedian whose warmth and sincerity shone through his performances on stage and screen
fields.trailText: Scots comedian whose warmth and sincerity shone through his performances on stage and screen.
fields.body:
The comedian, actor and impresario Jimmy Logan, who has died of cancer aged 74, was a legend, one of the first Scots entertainers to make the transition to television stardom in the 1950s, and a quietly intelligent performer who was ahead of his time. An accomplished stand-up and sketch comedian, he favoured chat, insight and observation over gags.

Yet his roots were deeply buried in old-style entertainment, and in recent years he was regarded as an encyclopaedia of Scottish popular theatre, his speciality being Sir Harry Lauder, whom he met as a child. In turn, Logan influenced others: Billy Connolly decided to become an entertainer after seeing him in pantomime.

Based in Glasgow, he was one of five children of a famous family. His parents, Jack Short and May Dalziel, were a Glasgow music-hall double act. His aunt, Ella Logan, was a Broadway singer who starred in the original Finian's Rainbow, and his sister, Annabelle, is jazz singer Annie Ross, of Lambert, Hendricks and Ross.

Logan began work as a child, selling programmes at his parents' shows. He left school at 14 and became assistant manager of Paisley's Victory Theatre. By the mid-1940s he was featuring in his parents' show, Ma and Pa Logan, at Glasgow's Metropole, and at 19 was principal comedian at the Metropole.

As a young man he modelled himself on the Scottish matinee idol and song and dance star of the 1930s and 40s Jack Buchanan, who had made a good living playing languid Englishmen. Logan devised a series of sophisticated revues, Five Past Eight, that drew Scotland-wide audiences to Glasgow's Alhambra Theatre. He also did around 150 radio shows with his friend Stanley Baxter.

Logan's stage act included character-based sketches, and these transferred well to the British television of the 1950s. He starred in Saturday Showtime, written by Eric Sykes, for ITV in 1956, and from 1957 to 1961 in BBC TV's Jimmy Logan Show - much of it written by himself.

His Scots accent, though broad, was not indecipherable to English viewers, although he was happy to lay the doric on with a trowel much later in his career as Rab C Nesbitt's father-in-law in the successful comedy TV series of the 1990s.

In Scotland, and occasionally elsewhere in Britain, Jimmy Logan appeared in 35 pantomimes, usually as the dame, and when variety went into decline he switched with ease to straight acting. He appeared in Scotland and England in Harvey, The Entertainer, Death of a Salesman, Comedians, Uncle Vanya and many other stage plays.

In the 1986, at the behest of Frank Dunlop, he took his one-man show about Sir Harry Lauder to the Edinburgh Festival, playing, not inappropriately, at the town hall in nearby Portobello, where the tang of the sea wafted in on the performance. He toured the show extensively, dancing and working his way through 36 Lauder songs. In 1993 came a follow-up at the festival. The Fabulous Fifties was a nostalgic evocation of Scottish variety's last gasp.

Earlier he had tried his hand at business by buying the Metropole, but it was not a success. The theatre closed and Logan lost a lot of money.

Logan's warmth and sincerity shone through his performances. The story is told of a disastrous production of Sinbad the Sailor at the Alhambra in the 1960s, when a burst pipe caused the safety curtain to fall, halting proceedings. Logan ad-libbed in front of the curtain to the 2,000-strong audience for a while and then asked the orchestra leader to find the theatre carpenter, who had worked there all his life and was about to retire. The bemused carpenter suddenly found himself on stage with Logan doing a This is Your Life on him, and soon the audience was spellbound by the old man's stories of the great music hall stars he had known. It was quite a disappointment when the pantomime was able to recommence.

That night at the Alhambra was an example not only of Logan's quick-wittedness but of his humanity and respect for the unsung people of the theatre. Even as a young man, he campaigned at Equity meetings for the rights of chorus girls and smaller acts.

He had made his credited film debut at 21 in the Clydebank drama Floodtide (1949), with Gordon Jackson and Rona Anderson, but a cinema career did not follow, although there were a trickle of roles and he appeared in Carry on Abroad (1972) and Carry on Girls (1973).

In 1990 his services to Scottish entertainment, and to charity, led to Logan being awarded an OBE. One of his last major dramatic roles was something of a tribute from an old admirer, appearing alongside Billy Connolly in Anthony Neilson's The Debt Collector (1998). His memoir, It's a Funny Life, was published in 1998. He is survived by his second wife, Angela, and 15-year-old twins Robert and Annabelle.

 Jimmy Logan (James Short), entertainer, born April 4 1927; died April 13 2001

fields.headline: Website of the week
fields.standfirst: Public Transport Information
fields.trailText: Public Transport Information
fields.body:
Public Transport Information? Doesn't sound a very exciting place to spend my lunch break.

Probably not, unless you're planning a holiday in Britain and don't own a car. Or you need to find out which airlines fly to Teesside. Or you can never remember to bookmark all the different railway company sites, and the trainline.com has ground to a halt on a Monday lunchtime.

Hang on. You can't say that. One of their PRs is on the phone and wants to fax over some site reliability statistics.

Maybe she can explain why the ticket clerks at Euston had no knowledge of my last online booking. ("Sometimes they go astray, but I can't do anything about it.") But if we have to talk about train journeys, let's explore some of the tiny services you can find here -the Great Little Trains of Wales, or the Strathspey steam railway in Aviemore.

Or the Hadrian's Wall bus service

Exactly. The site is designed to look like a card file, and finding out about rail, air, ferry or bus services is a matter of choosing the Local section and picking a spot on the map of the UK.

Who's behind it?

The little-known Institute of Logistics and Transport, which sets down standards for the sites listed. It isn't the most memorable of sites, but for that very reason it's well worth bookmarking.

fields.headline: Living La Vida Loca
fields.standfirst: The end of Holy Week tomorrow signals the start of Spain's party season. From dancing horses to  running the bulls, David Clement-Davies rounds up the most colourful and exuberant celebrations
fields.trailText: The end of Holy Week tomorrow signals the start of Spain's party season. From dancing horses to running the bulls, David Clement-Davies rounds up the most colourful and exuberant celebrations
fields.body:
Spain is blazing with poppies, orchids and wild flowers at the moment, but with Semana Santa, Holy Week, and Easter upon us, a riot of human colour is also erupting across the country. During Holy Week, processions sway and thump through towns and villages decked out in the full regalia of church and Inquisition. Semana Santa (April 8-15 this year) heralds the approach of Spain's fiestas and ferias (local fairs), and the start of the bull-fighting season. There is hardly any time of year when a village or hamlet is without some feast or other, but May to July sees some of the most beautiful and dramatic, especially in the south. Prices go up dramatically during Feria and it is always advisable to book a hotel well in advance. Then again, you may not go to bed at all.

Seville (April 29-May 7)

The best way to irritate a rural Andalucian is to tell them that nobody parties like they do in Seville. The Holy Week pageants are some of Spain's most moving and Sevillians will certainly claim their April Feria is the best. From the moment the lights go on in the Real de La Feria, the city hardly sleeps for a week. Not that Sevillians are very good at getting to bed at any time of the year, but the Feria is their chance to prove their stamina.

Whole families emerge from their houses dressed like a picaresque tableau, with even the tiniest children done up like pocket Carmens. But then Seville is the home of the cigarette factory that inspired Bizet's best tunes. Round a corner you will hear clapping and be confronted by the spectacle of a spontaneous Sevilliana, the local dance that is quick to pick up and essential if you want to enjoy the party. In the afternoons, the Sevillian horses clip-clop under the orange and lemon trees, often more brightly attired than their riders. The city plays host to several funfairs, too, and the best flamenco bars are to be found along the Calle Vetis.

 For further information, visit: www.sevilla.org. Tourist Office: Avda de la Constitucion, 21b. Tel: 00 34 954221404.

Granada Cruces De Mayo (May 2 and 3); Summer Fair of Corpus Christi, (June 14-21); International Music and Dance Festival (June 22-July 8)

Granada, home of the Alhambra, bursts into colour during Cruces De Mayo, on May 2 and 3, when windows, balconies and patios are adorned with floral crosses. This is followed by the Feria of Corpus Christi, which is given much of its flavour by the fact that Granada is a university town, and young as well as old dress up in traditional garb. The city has the added attraction of the gypsy caves at Sacramonte, where you can see flamenco most days of the year. But be warned, the place has become very touristy and exploitative and it is always best to make friends of a local who can show you the more authentic spots. This year is the 50th anniversary of Granada's annual International Festival of Music and Dance (June 22-July 8).

 For information and booking, visit www.granadafestival.org, Tourist Office: Corral del Carbon. Tel: 00 34 958225990

Jerez Feria De Caballo (May 13-20)

For my pesetas, Jerez has the finest feria of all. It centres around the park Gonzalez Hontoria and for a week under the jacaranda trees, this elegant, wealthy town - home of sherry, bull breeding, flamenco and the Spanish Riding School - becomes a vignette of old España. It is a true horse fair and they do things in style. Here you will see some of the finest examples of Andalucia's famous dancing horses alongside almost every equine breed under the sun, while there are riding competitions and the grand parade of riders and carriages.

Couples in traditional Traje (polka dot dresses for the women and gaucho hats, chaps and waistcoats for the men) really indulge in the Spanish talent for flirting and display. The paseo, the evening stroll, is raised to a fine art in Jerez. Casetas - bars-cum-restaurants -pump, the death rides at the fun fair spin the pretty doñas like bunches of wild carnations and the caballeros strut their equestrian stuff.

 For further information, visit: www.jerez.org. Tourist Office: Calle Larga 39. Tel: 00 34 956331150

Cordoba Cruces de Mayo (May 1-3); Festival de los Patios Cordobeses (May 4-16); Nuestra Senora de Salud (May 20-28)

As in Seville, beautiful Cordoba makes much of Semana Santa. But its feria, of Nuestra Señora de Salud, is gentler than Seville's and is at its most entrancing when the Juderia, the old, labyrinthine Jewish quarter along the side of the Mesquita (mosque) begins to jostle with costumes and dancers. For a very unusual festival, visit the Festival de Patios Cordobeses a week before. The city will probably be less full and accommodation easier to find for the ensuing party. The Spanish patio has its roots both in Roman and Arabic culture and families unlock a floral and architectural treasury, hidden for the rest of the year behind sturdy iron grates, as they compete to delight visitors and win prizes. Cordoba also hosts a flamenco festival every two years, this year April 27-May 12, and a festival of guitar in the first two weeks of July.

 For further information, visit: www.ayuncordoba.es. Tourist Office, 10 Palacio de Congreso. Tel: 00 34 957471235

Madrid Fiesta De San Isidro (May 15 for two weeks)

It's entirely appropriate that stolid, grandiose Madrid should begin its biggest fiesta, dedicated to the city's patron saint, San Isidore, with a speech. The Pregon is delivered by the mayor on the day of the saint, even if no one's listening, and then the games begin. The capital may have little of the intimacy of, say, Jerez or Cordoba, but it has its own attractions and the Fiesta of San Isidro is especially significant as it heralds the start of the capital's bullfighting season, and for bull and matador alike all roads lead to Madrid.
