Huelva Virgen del Rocío (June 1-4)

If a foreigner tells a Spaniard he is a 'Rociero', he'll probably be met by a slightly resentful grimace at such impertinence. The pilgrimage - or romería - is not for tourists and to follow the Camino (the way) through the Cota Donana National Park, you really need to be invited along by one of the Brotherhoods, semi-religious guilds that set out in full costume from villages right across Spain. They converge on the little town of El Rocio, following their local virgins in flower-decked carriages pulled by oxen. There, after days of ecstatic partying, the young men of the mountain town of Almonte, and only they, literally fight for the right to manhandle a huge silver Madonna around town. "The Paloma Blanca", or White Dove, as she is called, is said to be the source of many a miraculous cure, and to take "the promise" to join the pilgrimage is probably the Andalucian equivalent of going to Mecca, rivalled only by the more sober northern route of Santiago del La Compostela. Part religious festival, part pagan rite, all the traditions, prejudices and superstitions of Andalucia converge at the little town.

It is possible at least to watch the start, and one of the best places is Sanlucar de Barrameda, from where Columbus set sail in 1492. The procession that leads the virgin is splendid and there is little to compare with the sight of army landing craft carrying the horses and pilgrims across the Guadalquivir river and into the national park. Sanlucar also hosts a sherry festival in early April, flamenco, jazz and music festivals and its famous beachfront horse races in August.

 Further information from the Sanlucar Tourist Office, Calzada del Ejercito. Tel: 00 34 956366110.

Pamplona The Running of The Bulls (July 6-14)

Spain's most famous fiesta. Immortalised by Hemingway in The Sun Also Rises, a novel slimmer than a cape, the festival of San Fermin is when the young men run with the bulls, someone invariably gets badly hurt or even killed, and the tabloids start running their campaigns about Spanish cruelty to animals. The fiesta itself is a feast of fireworks, music and processions, rich in tradition and spoilt perhaps only by the sheer weight of visitors. The dangerous bit, for humans at least, is when the bulls are let loose every morning from the Coralillos of Santo Domingo to run the course to the town's ring, where the daily fights take place. To take part, you will have to be at the start before 8am when rockets signal the beginning of the mayhem. Pamplona can be one of Spain's most exciting and most upsetting fiesta, but one of its nicest moments is when it winds up on July 14 with a candle-lit procession.

 Tourist Office: Calle de Duque de Ahumada 3. Tel: 00 34 948220741

As if in penance for the extremities of their coastline, the Malagans celebrate Semana Santa with more solemnity and gravitas than anyone else. The thrones carrying the holy images through the faded grandeur of Malaga's streets need up to 200 people to bear them along. But Malagans have always known how to have a good time and their feria is one of the most exuberant.

In the day, the fun takes place in the streets and bars across the city and at night switches to the Cortijo de Torres on the edge of town. It is also a place to see two unique dances, Verdiales and Malequenas.

fields.bodyText: Spain is blazing with poppies, orchids and wild flowers at the moment, but with Semana Santa, Holy Week, and Easter upon us, a riot of human colour is also erupting across the country. During Holy Week, processions sway and thump through towns and villages decked out in the full regalia of church and Inquisition. Semana Santa (April 8-15 this year) heralds the approach of Spain's fiestas and ferias (local fairs), and the start of the bull-fighting season. There is hardly any time of year when a village or hamlet is without some feast or other, but May to July sees some of the most beautiful and dramatic, especially in the south. Prices go up dramatically during Feria and it is always advisable to book a hotel well in advance. Then again, you may not go to bed at all. Seville (April 29-May 7) The best way to irritate a rural Andalucian is to tell them that nobody parties like they do in Seville. The Holy Week pageants are some of Spain's most moving and Sevillians will certainly claim their April Feria is the best. From the moment the lights go on in the Real de La Feria, the city hardly sleeps for a week. Not that Sevillians are very good at getting to bed at any time of the year, but the Feria is their chance to prove their stamina. Whole families emerge from their houses dressed like a picaresque tableau, with even the tiniest children done up like pocket Carmens. But then Seville is the home of the cigarette factory that inspired Bizet's best tunes. Round a corner you will hear clapping and be confronted by the spectacle of a spontaneous Sevilliana, the local dance that is quick to pick up and essential if you want to enjoy the party. In the afternoons, the Sevillian horses clip-clop under the orange and lemon trees, often more brightly attired than their riders. The city plays host to several funfairs, too, and the best flamenco bars are to be found along the Calle Vetis.  For further information, visit: www.sevilla.org. This is followed by the Feria of Corpus Christi, which is given much of its flavour by the fact that Granada is a university town, and young as well as old dress up in traditional garb. The city has the added attraction of the gypsy caves at Sacramonte, where you can see flamenco most days of the year. But be warned, the place has become very touristy and exploitative and it is always best to make friends of a local who can show you the more authentic spots. This year is the 50th anniversary of Granada's annual International Festival of Music and Dance (June 22-July 8).  For information and booking, visit www.granadafestival.org, Tourist Office: Corral del Carbon. Tel: 00 34 958225990 Jerez Feria De Caballo (May 13-20) For my pesetas, Jerez has the finest feria of all. Here you will see some of the finest examples of Andalucia's famous dancing horses alongside almost every equine breed under the sun, while there are riding competitions and the grand parade of riders and carriages. webTitle: The sculpture trail of Yorkshire brass

fields.headline: Bronze and brass
fields.standfirst: For 200 years, Yorkshire brass has attracted a wealth of artistic talent from Moore to Hirst. Martin Wainwright walks the sculpture trail
fields.trailText: For 200 years, Yorkshire brass has attracted a wealth of artistic talent from Moore to Hirst. Martin Wainwright walks the sculpture trail
fields.body:
The centre of Leeds is a terrible place for pedestrian-on-pedestrian bumps, on account of the number of distracting cherubs, owls and bare-breasted ladies cavorting on the buildings above. Every other facade in the square mile of largely traffic-free streets is Victorian or Edwardian, and no good merchant prince in those days thought that plain pediments and lintels were enough to get passers-by tilting their admiring heads.

The resulting, rampant friezes and bas-reliefs would be a half-day preoccupation in themselves, but they are only a backdrop to more than 40 pieces of free-standing sculptures or statues. Famous, or notorious, for claiming the title of "Britain's Barcelona" because of its nightclubs and dry climate, Leeds has genuinely better reason to aim for a European sculptural crown.

It is not just a matter of the finest ensemble of Victorian statuary outside London, in the flamboyant collection of nymphs, worthies and the Black Prince on his vast charger in City Square. The city is also a place where an exceptional number of sculptors have been born, studied or turned teacher themselves, almost always interacting with the work of their predecessors.

Ralph Brown RA, son of a Leeds school caretaker, used to admire the nymphs' curving bottoms when he changed trams in City Square. So did Kenneth Armitage, Barbara Hepworth and Henry Moore. The illustrious roll-call suggests something in the water, people say, or more probably the stone; but there is actually nothing mysterious about the wealth of talent.

From the early 18th century, when the Moot Hall statue of Queen Anne had an inscription emphasising that it was "distinguished far beyond the one in St Paul's, London" , civic pride and local money led to plenty of commissions in Leeds and places for plinths. The patronage was then given an edge by the arrival in Leeds of a series of cultured academics, especially once the Yorkshire College became Leeds University in 1905.

One of the first vice-chancellors, Sir Michael Sadler, caused (and enjoyed) a series of tremendous rows which foreshadowed the Tate bricks controversy. His attempt to fill Leeds' sacred Town Hall with modern frescoes ended in glorious failure, but he got an Eric Gill tablet of Christ scourging some Yorkshire-looking moneylenders bolted to a university wall. His successor tried to cover it with ivy, but was always foiled by a modernist gardener, who snipped away the tendrils, saying doggedly that that he was paid to keep the place tidy. Frederick Gregory, who was head of the high-quality Bradford printing firm Lund Humphries, then used his money to seal Sir Michael's victory for ever. His Gregory Fellowships have brought just about every major post-war British sculptor to Leeds for a spell, many of them leaving reminders of their stay in bronze, marble or - in Austin Wright's case - concrete encased in aluminium.

Their talent was also drawn by the mighty examples of Moore and Hepworth who both studied at Leeds School of Art (still a thriving alma mater which most recently produced Damien Hirst); and by their classmate Sir Herbert Read, the outstanding authority on 20th- century sculpture, whose son Benedict (the outstanding authority on Victorian sculpture) now teaches at Leeds University.

This tremendous history means that the city's predictable (but notably fine) collection of figurative statues has a strong 20th-century counterbalance; and the commissions are still coming in. A playful bronze tribute to petanque by Roger Burnett - a Yorkshire family watching a Frenchman aiming at the cochonnet in Leeds' central boules park - was installed in October. A 17ft-high sculpture by Graham Ibbeson, creator of Eric Morecambe's eternally sunshine dance in Morecambe, was unveiled on March 24.

These form two points on the serpentine Leeds Sculpture Trail, whose statues are complemented by an accompanying booklet and a series of links on the BBC's Leeds Online website.

There are breathtaking moments for those who believe that everything was dour and hard-headed in a 19th-century northern city. Alfred Drury's Circe, waving her wand (now sadly lost) above hogs that were secretly meant to represent Leeds aldermen, is thoroughly erotic and the eight nymphs - also by Drury and strictly speaking called Morn and Eve - are nubile, too. When they were last cleaned, the workmen insisted on screens to hide the heavy-duty buffing of bosom and buttock involved.

And then there are the owls - the civic symbol of Leeds. They are everywhere, modestly topping iron railings or hugely prominent, doubling as lightning conductors on Leeds Civic Hall and keeping an eye on the new £12 million Millennium Square.

This is about to see the city's third and fourth sculpture unveilings in six months, when Both Arms by Kenneth Armitage (another Leeds-born RA) and a vast rugby ball by Richard Wilson are put in place. Nelson Mandela will open a new garden in the square on April 30. The installations will be complemented by an exhibition at the final stop on the trail, Leeds city art gallery and the linked Henry Moore Institute, which have Rodins, Flaxmans and Moores a-plenty, plus the usual good and startlingly-cheap Yorkshire caff.

Leeds Statues Trail by Melanie Hall follows two tours and is available from Leeds Civic Trust, LS2 7EQ £2.50 (but does not include sculpture later than 1995). www.bbc.co.uk/leeds has an up-to-the-minute tour of "the city's silent observers" and many useful links

Cast of major players

1 The collection in City Square of eminent Victorians, plus the Black Prince, has recently been joined by a graceful eddy of gulls and a beady-eyed pigeon, the work of Lorne McKeane. The prince was so vast that no British foundry could cast him, and he came in a barge from Belgium, just avoiding bridges over the Aire and Calder navigation from Hull.

2 Graham Ibbeson sculpted Arthur Aaron VC, after the war hero won a city-wide vote last year for the subject of a Millennium Sculpture, beating more obvious candidates such as Joshua Tetley of beer fame, Don Revie of Leeds United and Henry Moore.

3 Robert Peel by William Behnes was the first of 26 statues of the politician, erected after his death in a riding accident in 1850 which triggered "Peelmania" . The statue was the first bronze figure in Britain to be cast in one piece, and one of the first to show a statesman in contemporary dress rather than classical drapery.

4 Leeds Town Hall lions have been consistently popular since they were installed in 1867, partly because of William Keyworth's endearingly friendly (though noble) carving but more because they cost £550 compared with the £11,000 paid for their counterparts in Trafalgar Square. Keyworth never visited Africa but spent a lot of time at Regent's Park zoo.

5 Hermes at Leeds University is enjoying a second life and change of name. He was salvaged from the former Midland Bank in Park Row when the building was demolished. When originally commissioned from William Chattaway in 1970, he was called "The Spirit of Free Enterprise".

fields.headline: Dune roaming
fields.standfirst: This summer, flights and packages are being offered for the first time to Brazil's northern resorts, opening up a spectacular stretch of unspoilt coastline to British tourists. Sarah Barrell checks it out
fields.trailText: This summer, flights and packages are being offered for the first time to Brazil's northern resorts, opening up a spectacular stretch of unspoilt coastline to British tourists. Sarah Barrell checks it out
fields.body:
Several climate and time zones away from Rio's celebrated Copacabana, the beaches of Brazil's north-east are largely unknown to British travellers. And this is not surprising as until now they could only be reached by a 10-hour flight from London to São Paulo followed by a three-hour internal flight north. Add on several thumb-twiddling hours waiting for connections, and you've got a dog-tired start to a beach holiday. But from May 1, Airtours will fly direct to Salvador and from August 31, Unijet will fly direct once a week to the main north-eastern hubs of Recife and Natal, cutting the journey time to a manageable nine hours.

And only 45 minutes south of Recife's shimmering skyscrapers is the sleepy cape of Santo Agostinho, a protected conservation area. In early morning, beyond the Blue Tree Park Hotel's private beach, the locals go about their morning's business of unscrambling nets and hammering small boats into submission.

Hidden in the mossy green hills above are the char-black remains of a Dutch chapel where, in the mid-1600s guerrilla troops finally bought a fiery end to a short but intense couple of decades of Dutch occupation. Beyond similarly-barbecued shells is the point where, a century before the Dutch fled the coast, Spanish conquistador Yanez Piñon was blown ashore on his way to the Caribbean and unwittingly "discovered" Brazil. A couple of months of beachfront camping later, he left, and Brazil's colonial fate fell to Portuguese explorer Pedro Alves Cabral.

Busy gazing up at these now silent hills, I all but tripped over a beached fish - a 6ft-long silver beauty that had escaped the net too late and regarded me with opaque eyes and half a tail. A small girl ran over to me and brazenly flipped it over with a foot no bigger than the fish's head. She said something in singsong Brazilian Portuguese, grinned, wiped her face on the hem of her skirt and skittled off up the beach. Back on the hotel beach, my own red face incurred hoots of laughter from the lifeguard who had now taken up position on his watchtower. He urged me to get in the water before I "cook".

Until now, tourism in this part Brazil has been almost exclusively domestic. The things that you usually have to escape a resort to find - authentic food, language, music - are within reach of the end of your sun-lounger.

I was happy to eat tapióca (manioc-flour pancakes) for breakfast and to be surrounded by the wind-down chatter of holidaying bankers from São Paulo. It's as close to a genuine travel experience as you are likely to get within the cloistered walls of resort.

Though perfect for those seeking beach retreat, Santo Agostinho is pretty remote. Any excursion, to Recife and its picture-perfect colonial satellite, Olinda, or to beaches north or south, is at least half a day's undertaking. Perhaps better for beach and local bar culture is Porto de Galinhas, a lively pastel-painted village euphemistically named "Port of the Chickens"; what was traded here until the late 19th century were slaves. Regardless of the grim heritage, happy chickens abound as municipal art, moulded from the upturned roots of palm trees, and ships leaving the harbour today contain only snorkel-capped tourists heading for the deep aquamarine rock pools in the reef wall.

With hotels going up quicker than you can say "deluxe-room with air-con", Porto Galinhas is in danger of becoming over-developed. But for now, the three-street intersection remains a charmingly-overgrown fishing harbour retaining the odd hammock-slung pousada (traditional guest house), lively beach bar nightlife and exquisite stretch after stretch of mangrove-backed coastline, accessed for the most part by surf board-stuffed beach buggies running roughshod over long sandy tracks.

I spent a night among a rowdy crowd of freshman students who were downing ele e ela (a shot of black-bean soup and a shot of white rum that translates as "he and she") as a chaser to every beer. But I stuck to the Brazilian national drink, caipirinha. This cocktail of fresh lime, sugar and cachaça (white rum) has to be the greatest non-footballing expression of Brazilian ebullience. Or at least that's what it feels like at the time of consumption. After the fact, count on a headache the size of Ronaldo's fan club.

It was in this top-heavy state that I made the journey north by plane to Natal. A matter of millimetres on my map, the journey takes 90 minutes by plane. Make the journey inland from Recife to the western border with Peru, and you're travelling the equivalent of London to Moscow. After a couple of "short hops", you begin to understand that when Brazilians call their country a continent they aren't far off.

One stride closer to the equator, we had left the sugarcane state of Pernambuco for Rio Grande Do Norte, where the green sugar belt is replaced by undulating expanses of sand dune, and palm-backed beaches by the vast wild fringes of the sertão. Inland life, often drought-stricken, is unforgiving.

If at all possible, the pace of life here slows even more. This is Brazil's major fruit-growing region, with mango, papaya and passion fruit the most easily-recognisable foodstuff to be found on stalls that appear on the roadside more frequently than bus stops.

Unlike the colonial towns of Bahia and Pernambuco further south, there is little in Natal to pack into a sightseeing itinerary.

Lurking among local tourist board rhetoric are the spurious superlatives usually to be found in a destination short on international accolades: the cleanest air in the world (according to NASA), the largest cashew tree in the world (according to the Guinness Book of Records - actually quite a spectacle). Then, of course, there are those sand dunes; and with stretches of coastline as glorious as these, who needs quirky USPs?

Again, I found myself cachaça-fuelled, only this time (and perhaps quite sensibly) the rum was being used to power my transport for the day; a banana-yellow, low-slung beach buggy. A fleet of us took off in a roller-coaster convoy from our hotel at Ponta Negra (a flawless stretch of sheltered beach considered the best in the north east) to Genipabu, the region's premier dune park.

Here for around $100 (split between four passengers), you can watch your life, and the stunning Natal coastline, flash before your eyes. The bugeiros (buggy drivers), sporting wrap-around shades and boy-racer confidence, drive their charges as if mortality has never crossed their minds. Later, I tried dune surfing (throwing yourself down a sandy mound on a climate-adapted "snowboard") and found it tame by comparison.

Further north along the coast, where schools of black dolphins summersault in the surf and heat haze makes spaghetti out of the Atlantic highway, I took a fresh-fish lunch and a freshwater swim at one of the many lagoons that appear like oases between the sand dunes.

Pitangui Beach, with $13 million of investment planned over the next five years, seems to symbolise the future of the north-east. Alongside this massive development in tourist infrastructure, the word "Eco" is handed out with the ease of a croupier dealing cards. It has all the making of the new Cuba.
fields.bodyText: Several climate and time zones away from Rio's celebrated Copacabana, the beaches of Brazil's north-east are largely unknown to British travellers. And this is not surprising as until now they could only be reached by a 10-hour flight from London to São Paulo followed by a three-hour internal flight north. Add on several thumb-twiddling hours waiting for connections, and you've got a dog-tired start to a beach holiday. But from May 1, Airtours will fly direct to Salvador and from August 31, Unijet will fly direct once a week to the main north-eastern hubs of Recife and Natal, cutting the journey time to a manageable nine hours. And only 45 minutes south of Recife's shimmering skyscrapers is the sleepy cape of Santo Agostinho, a protected conservation area. In early morning, beyond the Blue Tree Park Hotel's private beach, the locals go about their morning's business of unscrambling nets and hammering small boats into submission. Hidden in the mossy green hills above are the char-black remains of a Dutch chapel where, in the mid-1600s guerrilla troops finally bought a fiery end to a short but intense couple of decades of Dutch occupation. Beyond similarly-barbecued shells is the point where, a century before the Dutch fled the coast, Spanish conquistador Yanez Piñon was blown ashore on his way to the Caribbean and unwittingly "discovered" Brazil. A couple of months of beachfront camping later, he left, and Brazil's colonial fate fell to Portuguese explorer Pedro Alves Cabral. Busy gazing up at these now silent hills, I all but tripped over a beached fish - a 6ft-long silver beauty that had escaped the net too late and regarded me with opaque eyes and half a tail. A small girl ran over to me and brazenly flipped it over with a foot no bigger than the fish's head. She said something in singsong Brazilian Portuguese, grinned, wiped her face on the hem of her skirt and skittled off up the beach. Back on the hotel beach, my own red face incurred hoots of laughter from the lifeguard who had now taken up position on his watchtower. He urged me to get in the water before I "cook". The things that you usually have to escape a resort to find - authentic food, language, music - are within reach of the end of your sun-lounger. Any excursion, to Recife and its picture-perfect colonial satellite, Olinda, or to beaches north or south, is at least half a day's undertaking. fields.headline: Playing away
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor, net nanny, runs the rule over children's activity holiday websites
fields.body:
Before you pack your offspring off to a children's camp, make sure it is a member of the British Activity Holiday Association, which sets safety standards and minimum requirements for accommodation and staff training. Members are listed here. A community website for expatriates in London also posts a list of camps with comments from parents.

PGL
By far the best and most comprehensive of the sites visited. PGL is big enough to offer plenty of specialist holidays; those who choose to go to France can opt to train as a lifeguard, lie on the beach all afternoon or learn French. Also runs 14 multi-activity holidays around Britain.

Sealyham
Another for the PE-loving child, Sealyham is based in Pembrokeshire and offers three different activities each day, including "muddy experiences", campfires and raft building.

The AquaSports Company
For children aged between eight and 16 at a lakeside centre in Surrey. Children must have already completed a beginner's course in dinghy sailing, windsurfing or canoeing. The courses, which last five days, also take in treasure hunts and barbecues. Accommodation is in tents.

CampPage
Sending your child to the US or Canada does have drawbacks; the cost of the airfare, the possible homesickness, and the difficulty in vetting camps. But if your child likes the idea, then a number of the centres listed here accept children from abroad.

Pré Fleuri
Pré Fleuri is an international school in the Swiss Alps for four- to 12-year-olds. It combines language learning, sport and a belief in the creative potential of every child.

EF Language Travel
Pupils learn Spanish, German or French during the morning and try to speak it in the afternoon. Unfortunately, prices are frequently missing and the information is bland and rather unconvincing.

Cross Keys
Cross Keys camps allow children more freedom to choose which activities they want to pursue and encourage them to relax and express themselves. Unusually, the site includes a section for the children themselves.

Camp Beaumont
Runs nine day camps, four residential camps (one in France) and specialist holidays based on the US model. For children as young as six.

fields.headline: Somewhere in Britain
fields.trailText:
Cold comfort

Taste chocolate as it would have been drunk, cold, at the time of William III. Hampton Court Palace is opening up what was then the country's first chocolate kitchen, where chefs in traditional costume will recreate recipes. A special trail sets out the history of chocolate. Open 9.30am (Monday 10.15am) - 6pm. £10.80 adults. £7.20 children, £8.30 senior citizens, £32.20 families. Tel: 020-8781 9500.

Taste chocolate as it would have been drunk, cold, at the time of William III. Hampton Court Palace is opening up what was then the country's first chocolate kitchen, where chefs in traditional costume will recreate recipes. A special trail sets out the history of chocolate. Open 9.30am (Monday 10.15am) - 6pm. £10.80 adults. £7.20 children, £8.30 senior citizens, £32.20 families. Tel: 020-8781 9500.

Warp factor

Spinning and weaving demonstrations using wool from Cumbria's threatened Herdwick sheep take place at the Georgian town house in Cockermouth where William Wordsworth was born in 1770. Plus an Easter egg hunt on Monday. Free to National Trust members, otherwise £3 adults, £1.50 children. Open today and Monday (closed tomorrow) 10.30am-4.30pm. Tel: 01900 824805.

Top attractions

A circus workshop where you can learn to juggle is one of the weekend attractions at Leeds Castle, near Maidstone in Kent. Also Easter bonnet-making demonstrations and Punch and Judy shows. Open from 10am, last admissions 5pm. £8.50 adults, £5.20 children, £24 families. Tel: 01622 765400.

Golden opportunity

Hunt for treasure at the Dolaucothi Gold Mine in Carmathenshire. Not the real thing, sadly - only gold-wrapped chocolate coins and Easter eggs. Pumpsaint, Llamwyrda, Carmarthenshire. Tomorrow and all week. 30p for the hunt. Adult tickets for the site and underground mine tour £6.20, children £3.10, families £14.50. 10am-6pm last tour 4.40pm. Tel: 01558 650359.

Let us prey

Go peregrine falcon spotting with a ranger from the Falls of Clyde Visitor Centre in New Lanark. Walks are at 10am and 1pm today and tomorrow. Adults £2.50. Children free. Tel: 01555 665262.

Social engineering

For all who have fiddled with flanges and cursed at dropped screws, in the attempt to build a crane on the living-room carpet, Durham's Beamish Open Air Museum stages an exhibition on the history of Meccano this weekend. Open 10am-5pm. Admission to museum including exhibition : £12 adults, £9 for over 60s, £6 for children Today, tomorrow and Monday. Tel: 0191-370 4000.

Old scores

A medieval battle and an English Civil War duel will be re-fought as Warwick Castle, celebrates 1,000 years of history. Today, tomorrow and Monday. 10am - 6pm, £10.25 adults, £7.35 senior citizens, £6.25 children 4 -16, family £29. 0870 4422000.

webTitle: Man With a Pipe, Paul Cézanne (c1892-5)

fields.headline: Man With a Pipe, Paul Cézanne (c1892-5)
fields.trailText: · View the work online
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artist: Paul Cézanne (1839-1906), who was born and died in Aix-en-Provence in southern France, near Montagne Saint- Victoire, the subject to which he returned time and again. Cézanne's father insisted he study law but Cézanne abandoned his studies in 1861 and moved to Paris. By 1863 he was exhibiting alongside Manet. Cézanne's attempts to establish himself as an avant-garde artist competed with his tendency to withdraw, resolving itself in a fascination with landscape, which he started to explore while staying at a house his mother owned at l'Estaque, near Marseille. He had his first one-man show in 1895, at the age of 56. The radical authority of his art, a hard southern sun burning away Monet's soft reveries, made him a modern hero.

Subject: A local gardener, named le père Alexandre. He appears in the same hat, smoking the same pipe, concealing his cards from a fellow peasant in Cézanne's The Card Players (c1892-5).

Distinguishing features: This is a poker-faced portrait, a picture of a man giving nothing away. You don't know if his blank expression conceals depths of rural wisdom or if he is genuinely vacant. It's the same as looking

at Cézanne's paintings of the Montagne Sainte-Victoire. The mountain oscillates in the afternoon heat, its rock faces registering as planes of blue and gold; in the foreground are square slices of houses, floating green fields; there is a sense of anticipation, but no clue as to what's happening down in the fields, or why the mountain is significant.

Landscape painting had always included people, and told mythic stories, until Cézanne evacuated them and hinted at desires and horrors in a house glimpsed through trees, a blur at the end of an avenue.

In The Card Players, le père Alexandre sits upright, puffing on this same pipe as he faces down his opponent. Here too he seems a canny country character, a village star. There's a cool authority to the way he stands. You feel he was a man who always dressed the same, behaved the same, and so acquired style. He's all tubes; his tall round hat, long face, sleeves, all have a mathematical roundness, making him the human equivalent of a Cézanne landscape - like the rocks, he's burned down to geometry.

He is as ancient as the scenery, a golem made of Provençal dirt; the surface of the painting is mottled, rough-hewn. He's brown, from his dungy hat to his thick clothes. You can't take your eyes off those collar wings folded over so strongly. While his dead-on presentation makes his wide-shouldered body astonishingly flat, Cézanne allows individual features - collar, shiny pipe, folds of the jacket - to have an almost trompe-l'oeil lift. This is in contrast to a portrait by, say, Holbein, who models the human figure according to the laws of perspective. Cézanne paints as a succession of glances with no mastering single point of perspective. His paintings are flatter and rougher-surfaced than painting tended to be since the Renaissance. This made him an icon for the Cubists.

Inspirations and influences: "Cézanne's anxiety is what interests us," said Picasso. You see echoes of his "anxiety" from Picasso's Cubism to Robert Rauschenberg's collages.

Where is it? The Courtauld Gallery, Somerset House, Strand, London WC2 (020-7848 2526).

fields.headline: Making an exhibition
fields.standfirst: Ben West takes in 10 museums where learning goes hand in hand with having a good time
fields.trailText: Ben West takes in 10 museums where learning goes hand in hand with having a good time
fields.body:
The museum world has been transformed in recent years, creating interactive, innovative and exciting exhibitions guaranteed to prise even the most Nintendo-obsessed youth away from his GameBoy and Pokemon set. Here are 10 places not to miss.

Eureka!

Eureka! is Britain's first and only interactive museum designed specifically for three- to 12-year-olds, although all ages will be absorbed by the hundreds of exhibits and activities.

It presents a fun, hands-on approach to learning, providing thousands of buttons, levers, gadgets and tools to operate. Visitors are encouraged to touch, look, smell, listen and role play. The only problem is fitting it all in.

The four main exhibition areas are Me and My Body, Living and Working Together, Invent, Create and Communicate, andThings.

Eureka!, Discovery Road, Halifax, West Yorkshire (01426 983191). Open daily 10am-5pm. Adults and children over three, £5.50; a £25 saver ticket admits up to five people.

Thackray Medical Museum

Established in 1997 in a former workhouse building adjacent to St James' Hospital, this interactive museum explains how people's lives have changed over the past 150 years as a result of improvements in medicine and healthcare. It looks at how improved living conditions and medical advances help us to live around 50 years longer than we did in 1840. In "Pain, Pus and Blood", you get an insight into surgery without anaesthetics. At BodyWorks, you enter a giant gut to explore the human body.

Thackray Medical Museum, Beckett Street, Leeds (0113 2444343). Open Tues-Sun 10am-5pm. Adults £4.40; children (5-16) £3.30; concessions £3.60; family ticket (two adults and up to 3 children) £14.

Catalyst, the Museum of the Chemical Industry

Catalyst is Europe's only museum to explore the science and technology behind the chemical industry and its impact on our lives through hands-on exhibits, activities and demonstrations. There are plenty of interactive puzzles and computers, archive film footage and displays.

Scientrific explores how modern materials and chemicals are made. The Observatory explores environmental issues while Birth of an Industry allows visitors to explore the chemical industry from ancient times, using lifelike reconstructions and audio-visual programmes. Catalyst, Mersey Road, Widnes, Cheshire (0151-420 1121). Open Tues-Fri, most Mons during school holidays 10am-5pm; Sat/Sun 11am-5pm. Adults £4; children £3.40; concessions £3.95; family ticket (2 adults, 2 children/1 adult, 3 children) £13.95.

The Earth Centre

A Millennium Project transformed two disused collieries into this, the world's first green theme park offering an interactive tour, indoor and outdoor exhibitions, attractions, gardens, play areas, theatres and events focusing on sustainable living. It aims to help people be environmentally aware and look after the planet.

The Earth Centre, Denaby Main, Doncaster (01709 513933). Open for pre-booked guided tours from May 26 -November 4, daily 10am-6pm. Adults £3.95; children 5-16, concessions £2.95.

Life Interactive World

Exploring DNA, genetics and the origins of life, a visit here begins with a trip through four billion years of evolution to meet the ancestors. There are various interactive attractions and virtual games, a live show explaining what we have in common with other living things and a multimedia display in a theatre resembling a huge brain.

The Tunnel of Love is a light-hearted look at what attracts living creatures to each other, the Sensory Zoo teaches about the whole range of senses while in Cell City you get to see what makes you unique, and kill germs and fight diseases using interactives.

Life Interactive World, Times Square, Scotswood Road, Newcastle upon Tyne (0191-243 8210). Open daily 10am-5pm. Adults £6.95; children £4.50; family ticket £19.95.

Royal Navy Submarine Museum

Although relatively small compared with the other featured days out, this museum boasts a number of hands-on exhibits including the "Globe Probe" diving bell and a view of the panorama of Portsmouth Harbour through working periscopes of HMS Conqueror, used in the Falklands War.

Royal Navy Submarine Museum, Halsar Jetty Road, Gosport, Hampshire (023 9252 9217). Open daily April-Oct 10am-5.30pm, Nov-Mar 10am-4.30pm. Adults £4; senior citizens £2.75; children (5-16) £2.75; family ticket (2 adults, 4 children) £11.

Museum of Science and Industry in Manchester

Colourful displays and hands-on exhibitions reflect the region's cultural heritage. The Power Hall houses the world's largest collection of working steam mill engines, while the Air and Space Gallery is packed with aeroplanes.

Manchester's textile industry is explored in Fibres, Fabrics and Fashion, where you experience the sight and sound of historic working mill machinery while the history and the future of leading-edge technologies are covered in The Futures exhibition. The centrepiece of this gallery is a re-build of "The Baby", the world's first stored program computer.

Museum of Science and Industry in Manchester, Liverpool Road, Castlefield, Manchester (0161-832 1830). Open daily 10am-5pm. Adults £6.50; Concessions £3.50; Children/young people (5-18) free to permanent galleries, £2 for special exhibitions.

The Science Museum

The collections at the Science Museum cover the history of western science, technology and medicine. Although many of the displays are still from the traditional school, more and more are becoming interactive and now there are over 800 "hands-on" exhibits encouraging visitor participation.

Last summer saw the opening of Making the Modern World, a chronological display of 1,800 objects that changed the world, and the Wellcome Wing, which features exhibitions covering key current scientific topics including genetics, digital technology, bio-medicine and artificial intelligence.

The Science Museum, Exhibition Road, London SW7 (0870 8704771). Open daily 10am-6pm. Adults £7.95 from 10am-4.30pm; students £4.95 from 10am-4.30pm; Children, concessions free; free for all after 4.30pm; Extra charge for special exhibitions.

The Eden Projeect

Having opened in March, the £80 million Eden Project's mission is to promote understanding of the relationship between plants, people and resources, leading towards sustainability.

Its principal attraction is a vast plant collection, housed inside and outside two state-of-the-art, architecturally triumphant giant conservatories. One conservatory contains plants from the humid tropics (rainforests and oceanic islands), while the other holds ones from the warm temperate regions such as the Mediterranean, South Africa and California.

Sculpture, animation, automata, puppetry, live music and performance are all being used to enhance appreciation and the educational value of the collections.

The Eden Project, Bodelva, St Austell, Cornwall (01726 811911) Open daily 10am-6pm, and until 8pm over Easter to Easter Monday. Adults £9.50, children (5-15) £4, seniors (60yrs+) £7.50, students £5.

As well as more than 150 interactive puzzles and experiments, there are regular special events and multi-media presentations exploring the scientific issues of the day.

You can play a giant keyboard, create your shadow in colour, launch a hot-air balloon, fire a rocket and, in the Planetarium, take a voyage to outer space.

Techniquest, Stuart Street, Cardiff (029 20 475475). Open Mon-Fri 9.30am-4.30pm; Sat, Sun 10.30am-5pm; school holidays 9.30am-5pm. Adults £6; children (5-16), concessions £4; family ticket (2 adults, 3 children) £16.50; Planetarium 75p extra, Discovery Room 50p extra.

webTitle: Neil Hagerty: American cigarettes | A rosary | A mojo bag

fields.headline: Neil Hagerty never travels without...
fields.trailText: A necessity: American cigarettes. I find they leave the filthiest burns.
fields.body:
A necessity: American cigarettes. I find they leave the filthiest burns.

A lucky charm: When my father was dying, he had a rosary blessed at Lourdes, so I always take that with me.

A memento: I carry what I think you people in the old world would call a mojo bag. It contains hotel light switches, coins, matchbooks, the teeth of the concierge - stuff like that. I've also got a remnant or two of every trip I've taken dating back to 1974 when I went to Puerto Rico. Does that seem obsessive?

If only: If I was going hitchhiking, I'd like a travelling companion with me on my journey. I can't be too specific, though. You've seen it happen where someone travels alone at first but doesn't stay that way . . .

 Neil Hagerty's solo album, Neil Michael Hagerty, is released on Domino records on April 9

 The Cumbrian Tourist Board has announced that more than 70 footpaths have been re-opened. For details of other open Cumbrian attractions, visit www.cumbria-online.co.uk

 In Devon, 140 routes, including about 25% of the coastal path network, have been opened, although the majority of local paths remain closed. Detailed information is available on www.devon.gov.uk and the public rights of way helpline on 01392 382550.

 The British Association of Leisure Parks, Piers and Attractions has a website, www.balppa.org, where details of its members' opening times, events and prices can be found as well as links to their own websites.

 Across the Channel, the Normandy Tourist Board (0117 9860386, normandy-tourism.org) has said there are no restrictions for tourists except that horse riding is banned.

 A leaflet called Great Attractions in Pennine Yorkshire, with information on 30 attractions, is available from the Hebden Bridge Tourist Centre (01422 843831, hebdenbridge@ytbtic.co.uk). It has information on what is open and closed.

fields.headline: He wrote the poem, you see the sights
fields.standfirst:
Byron didn't get it wrong - the Rhineland really is a land of fairytale castles and fine wines. Will Hodgkinson goes with the flow
plus, Stephen Moss on the places that put the romance in poets' hearts
fields.trailText: Byron didn't get it wrong - the Rhineland really is a land of fairytale castles and fine wines. Will Hodgkinson goes with the flow
fields.body:
There are two images of the Rhineland embedded into the popular consciousness. The first is of a fairytale land filled with gothic castles, fine wines, angry dragons, benign Teutonic maidens and lush green pastures. The second is of a popular destination for coachloads of tourists.

In the 18th century, however, before mass tourism was ever thought of, the former image reigned supreme, and the Rhineland was as remote and romantic as Venice or the Orient. It was Lord Byron's epic poem Childe Harold's Pilgrimage that described a place where the gallant young man of the title "gazes on a work divine/A blending of all beauties, streams and dells/Fruit, foliage, crag, wood, cornfield, mountain, vine."

Byron travelled extensively through the Rhineland after exiling himself from England, and it was his words that were to inspire countless young men to include the area as part of their Grand Tour of Europe, and dream of having their hearts broken by feckless peasant girls on the banks of the great river while they were at it.

With this in mind, I ventured on a tour of my own, retracing the steps of the great poet, adding the odd destination for the sake of convenience, and dodging anyone with an American accent who wore socks with their sandals.

Hamburg seemed as good a place as any to start a Romantic journey: although Byron never made it this far north. Lord Nelson did, and found love here while his poetic contemporary fled from an unhappy affair further south. It's also likely that Byron would have approved of the attitude to life here. Germany's most famous port brings with it sin, colour and open-mindedness: the infamous Reeperbahn offers every kind of sexual peccadillo known to mankind, including some new ones made possible by the wonders of medical science. The St Pauli port area retains a sense of well-mannered bohemianism: everyone cycles, the waterside bars and restaurants keep going throughout the night, and the Sunday morning Fischmarkt is like a medieval fayre, with traders of every description trying to out-shout one another in order to hawk their disparate wares.

Little of the Hamburg of Byron's time remains - a great fire in 1842 and British bombs in 1943 razed the city twice over - but it has been reconstructed in a variety of neos - romanesque, gothic, classical - and now has a traditionalism infused with an embracing of the modern age. From the baroque splendour of the Hotel Atlantic by the Alstadt lake to the proud industrial harshness of the warehouse district, a trade area that has been Customs exempt from 1189, Hamburg has the kind of civilised eclecticism that Byron fled to Europe to immerse himself in.

It was time to retrace the steps of Childe Harold.

The first mention of the Rhineland in the epic poem is "The Castle Crag of Drachenfells" that "frowns oe'r the wide and winding Rhine". Drachenfells turned out to be just outside Konigswinter, an unremarkable town with a thriving tourist trade and a large Turkish population whose men work on the river. Beyond the over-stylised bierkellers and the international tourist tat of the high street - anything from bratwurst to batik - lie the beautiful Sibengerberge mountains, of which Drachenfells tops one of seven. A funicular railway from Konigswinter takes you up to the cloud-blanketed castle remains.

Moss-encrusted turrets and crumbling ramparts rise out of black, brooding rock, supposedly once inhabited by a dragon who was thought to have been slain by the great German hero Siegfried.

A walk through the forest back down to the town takes you past Hansel & Gretel-like houses, woodcutters' shacks, and the macabre, gothic Drachenberg castle, with turrets thin enough and wrought-iron gates imposing enough to make a Grimm's Fairy Tale villain feel at home.

From Konigswinter, Childe Harold travelled downstream to stay awhile at Koblenz. The city where the Rhine meets the Mosel river has small cobbled passageways that connect square after square, long flights of steps leading to oval gateways, and streets that are so quiet at night they are reminiscent of the Vienna depicted in Carol Reed's The Third Man. It was to inspire painters like Turner and Stansfield, who, like Byron, came here for the serene yet untamed landscape, the vibrant working life centred around the river, and the abundance of wine that comes from the Riesling grape grown on the area's slate-covered vineyards.

The town, which was founded by the Romans in 9BC, was destroyed by the French in 1801 and again by the Allied Forces in 1943, but some of the old world survives: at the corner of land where the two rivers meet is the Bleumenhof flower garden, once home to Koblenz's own group of the Order of Teutonic Knights, and it still houses the Basilika St Kastor, a church built in 836 that once saw Edward I sell his crown when he was strapped for cash.

The church was first used by Luis Pius, grandson of Charlemagne, who failed to live up to his name when it was discovered that he had an illegitimate daughter, Rizza, whose image now resides on one of the church's stained-glass windows.

Byron was particularly taken by the brutal military might of the fortress Ehrenbreitstein, just across the river from the town and high up on a hill that is traversed by a chairlift.

What he referred to as "A Tower of Victory" has been used in a military capacity from the time of its construction in the 10th century by the knight Erembert until the second world war: these days it has the slightly emasculated role of being a centre for summer operas.

Koblenz still has the romantic spirit that so inspired Byron. It's a quiet town, and the squares are filled with cafés, bars and middle-aged women with cropped red hair and old men in caps. There are old-style taverns popular with the ubiquitous elderly American tourists. The baroque four-roomed Weindorf Rest is ideal for sampling the local riesling.

Newer restaurants like the Café Mijoo are favoured by a young local crowd. There are also local stories remembered and celebrated, like the one about Luther of Koburn, a 15th-century robber who stuck out his tongue at the archbishop just as his head was chopped off, only to be found innocent 100 years later. In the town square of Jesuitenplatz, a grimacing figure sticks his tongue out as the clock strikes the hour. And there are no bridges to take you from one tree-lined bank of the river to another, only ferries, including one run by an old man who charges 80 pfennigs for the journey.

The most romantic journey of all, which Byron himself undertook, is the river trip from Koblenz to Rudesheim, known as the Rhine Gorge. It is so fairytale, it is ridiculous - all that is missing is a flaxen-haired damsel singing lullabies to her fair knight, who has probably just been eaten by the dragon at Drachenfells.

These days, the journey takes four hours, and the best way to travel is on the Goethe paddle steamer. The steamer chugs past the mighty Burg Katz castle, before arriving at Lorelei, the narrowest part of the river and a watery grave for many an unfortunate sailor. Legend has it that this rocky promontory is inhabited by a beautiful woman who lures boats to their doom by singing sweet harmonies; these days the rock is topped by a rather chipped statue of said lady, who looks more like an Essex girl on a night up West than the beguiling Teuton of legend

Medieval robber barons once occupied the many castles that the steamer passes from there until Rudesheim, as well as villains like Archbishop Hatto of Meinz, who once lived in the Mauseturm customs tower at Bingen. He was eaten alive by mice after burning all the local beggars for fuel during one particularly harsh medieval winter. The journey ends at Rudesheim, and from there it's a short train journey to Frankfurt, and back into the reality of the modern age.

At the end of my own mini-Grand Tour, I had not managed to fall in love with any peasant girls with deep blue eyes, or slay any dragons in their foreboding castles, but I was still suffused with the romantic spirit enough to walk along the great river's banks and imagine Lord Byron finding solace from an unhappy love affair in the great beauty and ancient mystery of the land around him.

The Rhine may not be as elegant as the Seine, or as sacred as the Ganges, but it isn't as dirty as the Thames. And it is, as the great poet himself put it in Childe Harold's Pilgrimage, "Wild but not rude, awful yet not austere/It is to the mellow earth as autumn is to the year."

Way to go
Lufthansa (0845 7737747) flies to Hamburg from Heathrow £162.90pp return inc taxes.
Hotels: Kempinksi Hotel Atlantic, An Der Alster 72-79, 20099 Hamburg (+49 40 24 71 29), doubles from £140 a night.
Maritim, Rheinalee 3, 53639 Konigswinter (+49 22 23 70 70) doubles £120. Hotel An Der Mosel, Pastor-Klein Strasse 11, 56073 Koblenz-Rauental (+49 26 14 06 50). Doubles £59.
Restaurants: UIl Porto, Grosse Elbstrasse 100 (next to Fishmarket), 22767 Hamburg (+49 40 38 72 31), £13 a head with wine.
Weindorf-Rest, Julius Wegsler Str 2, Konigswinter, £10-£13 a head with wine. Cafe Miljoo, Gemusegasse 8, 56068 Koblenz (+49 26 11 42 37) £6.50-£10.
Riverboat trip: paddle steamer from Koblenz to Rudesheim, The Goethe, c/o KD (+49 22 12 08 83 18) costs £14.50.

With this in mind, I ventured on a tour of my own, retracing the steps of the great poet, adding the odd destination for the sake of convenience, and dodging anyone with an American accent who wore socks with their sandals. Hamburg seemed as good a place as any to start a Romantic journey: although Byron never made it this far north. Lord Nelson did, and found love here while his poetic contemporary fled from an unhappy affair further south. It's also likely that Byron would have approved of the attitude to life here. Germany's most famous port brings with it sin, colour and open-mindedness: the infamous Reeperbahn offers every kind of sexual peccadillo known to mankind, including some new ones made possible by the wonders of medical science. The St Pauli port area retains a sense of well-mannered bohemianism: everyone cycles, the waterside bars and restaurants keep going throughout the night, and the Sunday morning Fischmarkt is like a medieval fayre, with traders of every description trying to out-shout one another in order to hawk their disparate wares. Little of the Hamburg of Byron's time remains - a great fire in 1842 and British bombs in 1943 razed the city twice over - but it has been reconstructed in a variety of neos - romanesque, gothic, classical - and now has a traditionalism infused with an embracing of the modern age. From the baroque splendour of the Hotel Atlantic by the Alstadt lake to the proud industrial harshness of the warehouse district, a trade area that has been Customs exempt from 1189, Hamburg has the kind of civilised eclecticism that Byron fled to Europe to immerse himself in. It was time to retrace the steps of Childe Harold. The first mention of the Rhineland in the epic poem is "The Castle Crag of Drachenfells" that "frowns oe'r the wide and winding Rhine". Drachenfells turned out to be just outside Konigswinter, an unremarkable town with a thriving tourist trade and a large Turkish population whose men work on the river. Beyond the over-stylised bierkellers and the international tourist tat of the high street - anything from bratwurst to batik - lie the beautiful Sibengerberge mountains, of which Drachenfells tops one of seven. A funicular railway from Konigswinter takes you up to the cloud-blanketed castle remains. Moss-encrusted turrets and crumbling ramparts rise out of black, brooding rock, supposedly once inhabited by a dragon who was thought to have been slain by the great German hero Siegfried. A walk through the forest back down to the town takes you past Hansel & Gretel-like houses, woodcutters' shacks, and the macabre, gothic Drachenberg castle, with turrets thin enough and wrought-iron gates imposing enough to make a Grimm's Fairy Tale villain feel at home. From Konigswinter, Childe Harold travelled downstream to stay awhile at Koblenz. The city where the Rhine meets the Mosel river has small cobbled passageways that connect square after square, long flights of steps leading to oval gateways, and streets that are so quiet at night they are reminiscent of the Vienna depicted in Carol Reed's The Third Man. It was to inspire painters like Turner and Stansfield, who, like Byron, came here for the serene yet untamed landscape, the vibrant working life centred around the river, and the abundance of wine that comes from the Riesling grape grown on the area's slate-covered vineyards. The town, which was founded by the Romans in 9BC, was destroyed by the French in 1801 and again by the Allied Forces in 1943, but some of the old world survives: at the corner of land where the two rivers meet is the Bleumenhof flower garden, once home to Koblenz's own group of the Order of Teutonic Knights, and it still houses the Basilika St Kastor, a church built in 836 that once saw Edward I sell his crown when he was strapped for cash. The church was first used by Luis Pius, grandson of Charlemagne, who failed to live up to his name when it was discovered that he had an illegitimate daughter, Rizza, whose image now resides on one of the church's stained-glass windows. Byron was particularly taken by the brutal military might of the fortress Ehrenbreitstein, just across the river from the town and high up on a hill that is traversed by a chairlift. What he referred to as "A Tower of Victory" has been used in a military capacity from the time of its construction in the 10th century by the knight Erembert until the second world war: these days it has the slightly emasculated role of being a centre for summer operas. Koblenz still has the romantic spirit that so inspired Byron. It's a quiet town, and the squares are filled with cafés, bars and middle-aged women with cropped red hair and old men in caps. There are old-style taverns popular with the ubiquitous elderly American tourists. The baroque four-roomed Weindorf Rest is ideal for sampling the local riesling. Newer restaurants like the Café Mijoo are favoured by a young local crowd. There are also local stories remembered and celebrated, like the one about Luther of Koburn, a 15th-century robber who stuck out his tongue at the archbishop just as his head was chopped off, only to be found innocent 100 years later. In the town square of Jesuitenplatz, a grimacing figure sticks his tongue out as the clock strikes the hour. And there are no bridges to take you from one tree-lined bank of the river to another, only ferries, including one run by an old man who charges 80 pfennigs for the journey. The most romantic journey of all, which Byron himself undertook, is the river trip from Koblenz to Rudesheim, known as the Rhine Gorge. It is so fairytale, it is ridiculous - all that is missing is a flaxen-haired damsel singing lullabies to her fair knight, who has probably just been eaten by the dragon at Drachenfells. These days, the journey takes four hours, and the best way to travel is on the Goethe paddle steamer. The steamer chugs past the mighty Burg Katz castle, before arriving at Lorelei, the narrowest part of the river and a watery grave for many an unfortunate sailor. Legend has it that this rocky promontory is inhabited by a beautiful woman who lures boats to their doom by singing sweet harmonies; these days the rock is topped by a rather chipped statue of said lady, who looks more like an Essex girl on a night up West than the beguiling Teuton of legend Medieval robber barons once occupied the many castles that the steamer passes from there until Rudesheim, as well as villains like Archbishop Hatto of Meinz, who once lived in the Mauseturm customs tower at Bingen. He was eaten alive by mice after burning all the local beggars for fuel during one particularly harsh medieval winter. The journey ends at Rudesheim, and from there it's a short train journey to Frankfurt, and back into the reality of the modern age. At the end of my own mini-Grand Tour, I had not managed to fall in love with any peasant girls with deep blue eyes, or slay any dragons in their foreboding castles, but I was still suffused with the romantic spirit enough to walk along the great river's banks and imagine Lord Byron finding solace from an unhappy love affair in the great beauty and ancient mystery of the land around him. The Rhine may not be as elegant as the Seine, or as sacred as the Ganges, but it isn't as dirty as the Thames. And it is, as the great poet himself put it in Childe Harold's Pilgrimage, "Wild but not rude, awful yet not austere/It is to the mellow earth as autumn is to the year." Restaurants: UIl Porto, Grosse Elbstrasse 100 (next to Fishmarket), 22767 Hamburg (+49 40 38 72 31), £13 a head with wine. Weindorf-Rest, Julius Wegsler Str 2, Konigswinter, £10-£13 a head with wine. fields.headline: Far from the madding shroud
fields.standfirst: The world's most famous relic is usually kept under wraps, but Andy Pietrasik uncovers all the ingredients for a perfect weekend
fields.trailText: The world's most famous relic is usually kept under wraps, but Andy Pietrasik uncovers all the ingredients for a perfect weekend
fields.body:
Business before pleasure. That's the reputation Turin has earned with its industry over the years. Milan has couture, Florence culture, Venice canals and Turin has, well, cars and a shroud.

But it shouldn't take a leap of faith to believe that you can have a good time in Turin - it's an Italian city after all, and so well versed in the finer things in life. In fact, it wouldn't be an exaggeration to say that Turin has made pleasure its business. And because of that, it's the perfect place for an indulgent weekend.

A quick glance at a menu will tell you that many of the ingredients are local: barolo, barbera and barbaresco wine, porcini mushrooms and truffles. The aperitif was born here with vermouth (Martini and Cinzano are made nearby), the breadstick (grissino) was invented here, as was zabaglione, ice cream on a stick and a gourmet chocolate they call giandujotto.

There's no shortage of places in which to indulge yourself either - 800 restaurants to be precise, ranging from the gilt-laden Ristorante del Cambio to the city's famous art-deco cafés and pastry shops, elegant confections of marble, iron and glass such as Baratti & Milano.

An espresso will cost 50p standing at the bar; a nice lunch with a glass of local wine will set you back less than a tenner; a double scoop of gelato around 70p; an aperitif £2, which comes with free canapes (stuzzichini) during the cocktail hour (7.30pm-8.30pm); and dinner weighs in at anything from £15 to £40 a head. It's enough to tempt a saint.

Of course, anyone who's seen the cult Michael Caine film The Italian Job will also know that the city centre is no eyesore despite the Fiat Group producing Fiat, Lancia and Alfa Romeo cars in Turin. The Italian Alps lend an unexpected drama that's echoed in the grandeur of the buildings. Take the lift to the observation deck of the imposing Mole Antonelliana tower, and you'll see a city laid out before you on a grid system that's easy on the eye and easy to explore by foot. Its broad squares are lined with fine baroque and art-nouveau architecture, and the long, arcaded walkways of Via Po and Via Roma are wide enough to drive a Mini down.

In the late 60s, when The Italian Job was filmed, the amount of traffic clogging the Piazza Castello, the main square and the hub of the city, was enough to inspire the plot of "a smash-and-grab raid and $4 million through a traffic jam". These days, it is pedestrianised and much of the city is being restored in preparation for when Turin hosts the Olympic Winter Games in 2006, and those long-awaited tourists finally start to arrive.

Even the old Fiat factory, a couple of miles out of the centre at Lingotto, has been transformed - award-winning architect Renzo Piano converting the 20s site into a hotel, Le Meridien Lingotto, a conference centre, shopping arcade and an auditorium.

At night, you can catch a classical concert there or an opera at Teatro Regio. And you can snatch glimpses of frescoed ceilings through half-drawn curtains as you wend your way down to the fashionable Murazzi district to enjoy an aperitif and a romantic meal overlooking the river Po.

At times, it can be like walking through a living museum. There's Palazzo Reale, the Royal House of Savoy, built when Turin was the first capital after the unification of Italy in 1861. And the monumental Palazzo Carignano and Palazzo Madama. Classic stuff. Then there's Guarino Guarini's Chapel of the Holy Shroud in the baroque Duomo di San Giovanni, which houses one of the most talked about pieces of cloth in history. Actually, the chapel's still undergoing restoration after a fire in 1997. And the Holy Shroud has only been seen by the public five times since it arrived in the city in 1694; the one that's on permanent display is a photographic copy, because prolonged exposure to light would damage the original image of a man's body, believed to be Christ's.

After the shroud, the second most popular attraction in Turin is, bizarrely, the Egyptian Museum, which claims to have the most complete collection of artefacts outside Cairo. A further claim is that the Italian film industry was born here, and the recently-restored Mole Antonelliana - originally conceived as a synagogue - is now a shrine to the silver screen in the form of the National Museum of the Cinema.

And let's not forget that the Federazione Italiana del Football was founded in Turin on March 15 1898. Since then the city's two teams, Torino and Juventus, who share the ultra-modern Stadio Delle Alpi, have enjoyed varying fortunes, Juve now being the Serie A draw. It was here, on July 4 1990, that England went out to Germany on penalties in the semi-final of the World Cup. But try not to hold that against Turin.

Where to eat
The city is rightly famed for its ornate and elegant cafés, and these are the best places to lunch on local dishes such as agnolotti - a ravioli-like pasta filled with meat and red wine sauce; risotto allarneis with wine sauce; bagnacauda, a version of fondue (vegetables are dipped in a sauce of garlic, anchovies, butter and milk); and hazelnut, chocolate and vanilla gelati.
 Baratti & Milano, Piazza Castello 29
Art-nouveau jewel set in the stunning Galleria Subalpina, an iron- and glass-roofed arcade. All wood panelling, big mirrors and chandeliers. There's a bar laden with jars of giandujotto chocolates and crystallised violets.
 Caffé Torino, Piazza San Carlo 204
In the portico of the square known as the "living room" of Turin because everybody passes through it. Favourite of Ava Gardner, James Stewart and Brigitte Bardot when they were in town. An ode to good taste.
 Caffé Platti, Corso Vittorio Emanuele II, 72
Magnificent interior and good local Langhe salad of mixed leaves, toma cheese, celery, walnuts, olive oil and lemon for £4. Also good house aperitif, Platti Rosa. Once the haunt of Giovanni Agnelli, founder of Fiat.
 Ristorante Del Cambio, Piazza Carignano 2 Classic Piedmontese cuisine in a baroque setting. Crimson velvet drapes, chandeliers and gilt mirrors. Established 1757. £40 a head with wine.
 Caffé Tabac, Murazzi del Po 3
In one of the arches of Murazzi along the banks of the Po, with a terrace for alfresco dining.

Aperitifs
 Mulassano, Piazza Castello 15
Art-nouveau bar with marble, wood and bronze fittings and a tooled leather ceiling. Favourite of actors, directors and singers from nearby Teatro Regio and a good pre- or post-theatre bet.
 Caffé Roberto, Via Po 5
Good for snacks and happy hour.
 Achille Caffé, Via Carlo Alberto 12
Good buffet of free canapes and reasonable aperitifs for £2.

Late-night bar
Societe Lutèce Bar, Piazza Carlo Emanuele
Hip little bar in renovated area, where a margarita will set you back £4.

Coffee houses
 San Tomasso, Via San Tomasso 10
Open 8.30am-3pm, 8pm-midnight. Lavazza coffee was created here in 1895. Restored in the deco style, it reopened four years ago with classic advertising memorabilia, including posters from the latest Lavazza campaign with Bond girl, Maria Grazia Cucinotta.
Al Bicerin, Piazza della Consolata 5
Opened in 1763, a single, snug room with wooden walls and white marble tables that sells bicerin - a thick, sweet drink with the consistency of bitumen but actually made from hot coffee and drinking chocolate with a topping of cream. Regulars were Nietzsche and writer Italo Calvino.

Chocolates
Laboratorio Artigianale del Giandujotto, Via Cagliari 15A, Tel: + 39 11 2476245
Like Willy Wonka's Chocolate Factory; you can buy seven types of the famous giandujotto chocolates much cheaper (500g of the classic variety for £5; at the airport, 300g will set you back £8), and, if you phone in advance, you can watch them being made in traditional machines with stone grinders for the famous local tonda gentile delle Langhe hazelnut.

Ice cream
You can't go to Italy and not have an ice cream.
Gelati Pepino, Piazza Carignano 8
The most famous parlour in Turin. Twenty flavours, but the classic is pinguino: white ice cream covered with chocolate.

Shopping
 Porto Palazza, Piazza della Repubblica
Europe's biggest open-air market. Open all morning on weekdays and all day Saturday, you can pick up handfuls of fresh basil for a song, porcini mushrooms for a fraction of the UK price. I bought a lump of parmegiano reggiano for £2.50 and a cool coffee percolator for £13. Just behind is the Balôn flea market and, on the second Sunday of every month, the Gran Balôn ideals in curios and antiques.
Under the portico of Via Roma for designer clothes (Hermès, Fendi), and Galleria San Federico (Versace); more affordable options in Via Garibaldi; boutiques, delis and curiosities in Via Mercanti and the surrounding streets.

Football
 Stadio Delle Alpi, Strada Altessano 131, Torino, tel: +39 011 3290088.
Designed and built for the 1990 World Cup.
 Juventus. Ticket line: +39 011 65631 (juventus.com). Ticket prices from £13-£80.
 Torino. Ticket line: +39 011 8396670, (toro.it).
For Juventus, call a week in advance to check ticket availability and you can pay over the phone with a credit card. Alternatively, Travelscene specialist sales (020-8861 6566) can organise tickets for Juventus and Torino football matches.

Museums
The Torino Card costs L21,000 (£7) lasts two days and allows free entry to some of Turin's 38 museums and reduced ticket prices to a number of musical shows and plays. It also offers 48 hours of free travel on the ATM public transport system. The card can be bought from Turin Tourism (+39 011 535181/ 535901), Piazza Castello 161, Porta Nuova railway station and at a number of hotels. Further information: Italian State Tourist Board (020-7408 1254).

Way to go
Andy Pietrasik travelled to Turin with Travelscene (020-8424 9648) and stayed at the four-star Grand Hotel Sitea. Travelscene two-night breaks in Turin start from £346pp including three-star B&B accommodation and Meridiana flights from Gatwick. Includes free Target Guides book to Turin. Travelscene also offers three-for-two-night weekend breaks at the four-star Le Meridien Lingotto from £365pp, saving £63pp. Travelscene specialist sales (020-8861 6566) can organise opera and theatre tickets at Teatro Regio and the Auditorium Giovanni Agnelli. Ryanair ( www.ryanair.com, 0870 156 9569) is offering flights to Turin from £14 one-way plus tax.

fields.headline: Somewhere for later
fields.trailText: Europe
fields.body:
Europe

UK: The Grand Touring Club (01449 737774, www.grand touringclub.co.uk) offers self-drive breaks in a choice of seven classic cars, including an Aston Martin DB6, Jaguar E-Type Roadster and a Ferrari Dino. Prices start at £360pp for a three-night break mid-week and include car hire, half-board accommodation, motor insurance, 24-hour breakdown cover, advice line and area route books.

fields.headline: Pocket Gym
fields.trailText:
The more I have to squeeze myself into airline seats, the more concerned I get about long-haul flights and deep vein thrombosis.
Why not try the Pocket Gym, which you can use in your seat to help stimulate blood circulation during long periods of inactivity?
fields.body:
The more I have to squeeze myself into airline seats, the more concerned I get about long-haul flights and deep vein thrombosis.
Why not try the Pocket Gym, which you can use in your seat to help stimulate blood circulation during long periods of inactivity?

Won't I look like a complete wally?
Quite possibly, but this ingenious invention offers a full body work-out and is completely portable. It only weighs 300g has a resistance of up to 5kg and comes with a comprehensive range of 30 exercises.

How does it work?
It comes in five parts in a convenient travel case. You just fit it together to get something that looks and feels a bit like a bicycle pump but offers enough resistance to get the blood going.

What sort of exercises can you do in your airline seat?
There are 20 upper-body, mid-body and lower-body fitness training exercises that you can do in your seat and several others that might be better to try when you reach your destination.

Does it really work?
It's been endorsed by Mark Green, currently medical director of Gatwick Airport and one of the UK's leading experts in aviation medicine.

The Pocket Gym Lite costs £17.95, but is available at airports' tax-free stores for £14.95. For more details, call 0800 0720898 or visit www.pocket-gym.com. There are three other Pocket Gyms offering more resistance depending on your fitness requirements.
