fields.headline: Unknown Chekhov
fields.standfirst: He is renowned for his poignant and exquisitely crafted plays. But his early, experimental stories, published here in English for the first time, reveal a delight in the absurd, writes  Peter Constantine
fields.trailText: He is renowned for his poignant and exquisitely crafted plays. But his early, experimental stories, published here in English for the first time, reveal a delight in the absurd, writes Peter Constantine
fields.body:
'Write as much as you can!! Write, write, write till your fingers break!" This advice, which Anton Chekhov sent to Maria Kiselyova in a letter in 1886, was the motto by which he lived and worked. He was 26, and had already published over 400 short stories and vignettes in popular magazines, as well as two books of stories, with a third in the making. He had written his first series of plays including Fatherlessness, Diamond Cut Diamond, The Scythe Struck the Stone, The Clean-Shaven Secretary With the Pistol and The Nobleman (none of which have come down to us) and Platonov and On the High Road, and he was about to begin writing Ivanov, his first major theatrical success.

Throughout this period Chekhov was also energetically studying medicine at Moscow University, from which he graduated in June 1884. The nameplate on the Chekhov family's door now read "Dr AP Chekhov".

The stories and vignettes in my book, The Undiscovered Chekhov, are from this period, the most prolific of Chekhov's life. They are some of the works that helped make him a literary star and contributed to his receiving the Pushkin prize in 1888. The seven stories and vignettes that follow have never before been translated into English.

For Chekhov, these early years were extremely difficult. The Russian literary giants of the 19th century - Tolstoy, Pushkin, Gogol, Turgenev and Dostoevsky - had all come from the nobility. Chekhov was the grandson of a serf. His father had run a ramshackle grocery store in Taganrog in southern Russia. When Chekhov was 16, his father went bankrupt and left town in a hurry. He took the whole family, including the two elder sons, with him to Moscow - everyone except young Anton, who was left destitute and penniless to fend for himself in Taganrog.

As Chekhov wrote to his friend and publisher Suvorin many years later: "What the aristocrat writers get for free from nature, intellectuals of lower birth have to pay for with their youth. Write a story of how a young man, the son of a serf, a former shopboy, choirboy, schoolboy and student, brought up to respect rank, to kiss priests' hands, and worship the thoughts of others, thankful for every piece of bread, whipped time and again, having to give lessons without galoshes, brawling, torturing animals, loving to eat at rich relatives' houses, needlessly hypocritical before God and man, merely from a sense of his own insignificance - write a story about how this young man squeezes the serf out of himself, drop by drop, and how waking up one bright morning this young man feels that in his veins there no longer flows the blood of a slave, but the blood of a real man."

By the time the 19-year-old Chekhov rejoined his parents in Moscow three years later, having secured a scholarship to study at the university, the family was living in utter poverty in grimy basement lodgings in Grachyovka, one of Moscow's red-light districts. Anton immediately took charge and became the head and chief support of the family, a position he was to keep till the end of his life. His family nicknamed him "Papa Antosha". He was determined to succeed, and despite the harsh reality of his situation wrote to his cousin: "I will make a fortune... that is as certain as that two and two make four."

Chekhov began making his fortune by writing stories and vignettes for popular magazines in Moscow and St Petersburg. According to his younger brother, Michael, the moment the first instalment of Anton's scholarship arrived from Taganrog, he bought up all the magazines he could lay his hands on. He meticulously read through them to see what they were publishing, and then went to work. He sent in sharp, witty, innovative pieces which were published during 1881 in the Moscow humorous magazine Zritel (Spectator) and In Svet i Teni (Light and Shade).

Chekhov's pieces came as a surprise to readers of the time, for whom a story was supposed to deal with significant issues and have a clear beginning, middle and end. It was also supposed to impart the author's ideals. Chekhov's stories veered from this norm. He signed his pieces "Antosha", "Antosha Ch", "My brother's brother", "A man without a spleen" and "Chekhonte" - the last a nickname coined for him by his former religion teacher at school, Father Pokrovsky.

Chekhov's contemporaries described him roaming the streets, markets, taverns and brothels of Moscow, absorbing the colour and commotion of the city and working it into quick, vivid prose. His friend and fellow writer Vladimir Korolenko wrote in his memoirs that when asked how he wrote his stories, Chekhov laughed, snatched up the nearest object - an ashtray - and said that if Korolenko wanted a story called The Ashtray, he could have it the next morning.

Soon Chekhov was writing at such a pace that he was paying family and friends 10 kopecks for story ideas and 20 kopecks for plot outlines. But making ends meet remained a major problem for him throughout the 1880s, and in letters to friends, he constantly laments his lack of money. In a letter to Suvorin in 1888, Chekhov wrote: "I was terribly corrupted by the fact that I was born, grew up, studied, and began to write in a milieu in which money played a shockingly large role."

As money began trickling in from the publication of his work, Chekhov managed to move his family to better lodgings - they were to move almost a dozen times during his student years. But as he had to share his cramped living space with his parents, siblings, lodgers, and a constant flow of visiting relatives, Chekhov's living and working conditions remained very difficult.

"In front of me sits my non- literary work, banging mercilessly at my conscience. In the next room a visiting relative's fledgling is bawling; in the other room, father is reading The Sealed Angel out loud to mother. Someone has wound up the phonograph, and La Belle Hélène is playing. I want to escape to the country, but it's one in the morning. Can you imagine more vile circumstances for a man of letters?"

Chekhov wrote this to his new friend and publisher, Nicholas Leikin, in August 1883. Leikin was the owner and editor of the popular humorous St Petersburg magazine Oskolki (Splinters), for which Chekhov was to write 162 pieces over the next couple of years. Leikin had been searching for an energetic writer who had a wild sense of humour and an innovative style - and, most importantly, who was a master of brevity. Chekhov was the ideal candidate. Oskolki had a strict editorial limit of 100 lines, which forced Chekhov to develop an inventive style concise enough to carry ideas within an extremely restrictive framework. He complained bitterly that he had to "squeeze the very pith and essence" out of his plots, but he readily complied, sending Leikin some of the most original writing of the time. Oskolki published everything from anecdotes, witty riddles and cartoons to intricate vignettes and stories. Chekhov took these forms and expanded them into new literary genres. In an early piece in Oskolki, The Cross (published in February 1883), Chekhov pokes a daring jab at the oppressive state censorship which had just been granted greater power after the assassination of Tsar Alexander II in March 1881.

In The Cross, a poet enters a drawing room: " 'Well,' the hostess says turning to him, 'how did your dear little poem do?' " The guests hover about him, amazed and impressed that a poet should be awarded a cross for a poem. The angry poet holds up his manuscript for all to see, and the startled guests realise that the cross he was awarded is "not the kind of cross you can pin on your lapel" - it is the red ink cross of the state censor. His poem has been rejected.

Like many of his contemporaries, Chekhov put a good deal of effort into eluding the censor. It was always uncertain what would manage to slip through and what would be prohibited. Almost a century has passed since Chekhov's death, and it is surprising that many of these early masterpieces have not been translated into English. As Chekhov specialist Julie de Sherbinin has pointed out: "The gaps in English translation of his early work can be attributed to various factors: these stories were long considered products of an 'immature' writer, they are rich in colloquialisms and wordplay and thus are hard to translate, and they often depend on cultural context for their humour."

Since Chekhov's death in 1904, there have been many translations of his other prose pieces. During the Bloomsbury years, Constance Garnett established his position as an international literary figure by publishing 17 volumes of her Chekhov translations - 201 stories. The quantity of Chekhov's work was so great that Garnett had to make a selection, and her selections have subsequently remained largely uncontested. Consecutive generations of Chekhov translators have not veered far from her choice of stories, only occasionally introducing new, untranslated material.

In many of his letters throughout his life, Chekhov downplayed his stories, calling them "little trifles", even "literary excrements" that were written "half-consciously". He playfully confided that he wrote things off the cuff, as if he were eating blini [Russian pancakes]. "I don't love money sufficiently for medicine, and I don't have enough passion, that is, talent, for literature." Chekhov's natural self-deprecation in talking about his work misled many who knew him and later most of his biographers; but there is evidence that behind closed doors, he was always a painstakingly careful writer. His friend Nikolai Yozhov, for instance, was both shocked and amazed to catch him one day transcribing a story by Tolstoy. Chekhov told him that he often did this, that it was just an exercise - he was rewriting the story, editing it down. (Yozhov was outraged.) Chekhov wrote in an earnest letter of advice to his older brother, Alexander, also a writer: "Most important of all: keep watch, observe, huff and puff, rewrite everything five times, condensing and so on, always remembering that all of Petersburg follows the work of the Chekhov brothers!"

It is a widely accepted myth that Chekhov initially saw writing as the road to a quick rouble, that he spent the first part of his career as a hack writer for the gutter press, and that it was only in midlife that he miraculously found literature. A closer look at the quality of his early work refutes this.

Thomas Mann, in an essay published in Sinn und Form (Sense and Form) in 1954, commemorating the 50th anniversary of Chekhov's death, was one of the first to point out that Chekhov's diffident public attitude towards his writing had misled subsequent generations into a distorted view of his work. "In my eyes," Mann wrote, "the reason Chekhov has to a large extent been undervalued in Europe and even in Russia is due to his extremely sober, critical, and sceptical stance towards himself, and the dissatisfaction with which he regarded his accomplishments - in short, his modesty.

This modesty was an extremely appealing trait, but it was not designed to exact respect from the world and, one could say that it set the world a bad example. For, the view we have of ourselves is not without influence on the image that people have of us, and can taint that image and possibly adulterate it. Chekhov the short-story writer was convinced for far too long of his artistic unworthiness and the insignificance of his capabilities. It was only slowly and with great difficulty that he gained a modicum of belief in himself - the belief that is essential if others are to believe in us. To the end of his life, he showed no trace of the literary grand seigneur, and even less of the sage and prophet."

Another important factor that led earlier generations of scholars to deprecate Chekhov's early work was his own selection of stories for the 10-volume Sobranie Sochinenii (Collected Works, 1899-1902). It was felt that the pieces Chekhov chose not to include were in his eyes not up to par. And until quite recently, general scholarly opinion agreed with him. Stories told in minimalist telegrams? Absurdist vignettes? How could one compare these wild pieces with the multilayered style of The Cherry Orchard or The Lady with the Lap Dog, a style that has served as a model for many writers of the 20th century?

Scholars today are taking a broader view in assessing the scope of Chekhov's early work. Pieces until recently dismissed as "scurrilous sketches" and "impenetrably vacuous balderdash" are now viewed as important experimental works. Thomas Venclova, for instance, discusses Chekhov's early prose as a major precursor of the Russian absurdist writers of the late 1920s and Eugène Ionesco.

My work on this book began two years ago in the Slavic and Baltic division of the New York public library. I was looking through a heavy bound volume of Budilnik issues from 1880. The magazines had a very progressive, almost late-Edwardian look, much like early issues of the British magazine Punch. The drawings were coloured, which surprised me, and after the middle of 1880, the lettering on the title pages was flushed with gold. Just as I was wondering how a fin-de-siècle printer could have managed that, I noticed a short story signed "A Chekhov" - Alexander Chekhov, Anton's older brother. In the next few issues there were more "A Chekhov" signatures, and quite a few "Arteopod," an alias Alexander often used.

And then came the first stories by "Antosha Chekhonte" - Anton Chekhov. To my surprise, the New York Public Library has all the Moscow and St Petersburg magazines in which Chekhov was first published: Budilnik ( Alarm Clock ) , Strekoza (Dragonfly) and Oskolki. As I began reading Chekhov's early stories in context, a very different image of him jumped off the page. The initial picture in my mind of the sedate literary elder with monocle and cane (the picture of Chekhov used on most book covers) disappeared, and a younger, livelier, more energetic image of the writer took its place.

I soon found that the New York public library has one of the world's best collections of turn-of-the-century and earlier Russian material. Some of its rare books are not even available in the Russian state library. It houses almost 400,000 books, manuscripts and periodicals, including volumes from the libraries of 26 members of the Romanov dynasty - some items dating back to the 14th century. Avrahm Yarmolinsky, a Chekhov scholar and translator, who served as head of the Slavic and Baltic division, had travelled to Russia during the 1920s and 30s, buying up the libraries of the Romanovs and the former aristocracy. It was quite an experience working on this book, surrounded by such imperial Russian treasures.

The Undiscovered Chekhov brings to English-speaking readers a new body of Chekhov's work that deserves a wider audience. I chose these stories as representative pieces out of the large body of Chekhov's writing spanning the period from 1880 to 1887. His work from that time is largely unknown outside Russia. Without it, a full picture of Chekhov as a writer is impossible. In The Undiscovered Chekhov, exuberance and energy, but also the technique of a young writer of genius, are apparent. These are the stories that made Chekhov famous in his day.

The Collection
A few days ago I went to visit my friend, a journalist by the name of Misha Kovrov. I found him sitting on the sofa, cleaning his nails and drinking tea. He offered me a cup.

"I never drink tea without some bread to chase it down with," I said. "Will you give me some?"

"Never! Were you a sworn enemy, I might serve you some bread, but a friend - never!

"That is odd. Why?"

"I'll tell you why. Come over here."

Misha took me over to his desk and pulled out a drawer.

"Take a look!"

I looked inside, but could not see anything worth mentioning. "There's nothing in there. Just some dirt . . . nails, bits of rag, and a few odds and ends."

"That is precisely what I want you to take a look at! It has taken me 10 years to collect these nails, and bits of rag and string! This is a collection of extreme importance!"

Misha scooped up the rubbish and poured it on to a sheet of newspaper.

"Do you see this burnt match?" he asked, pointing at an ordinary, slightly charred match end. "This is a very interesting match. I came upon it last year in a bread roll, which I had bought at Sevastyanov's. I almost choked. Luckily my wife was at home and pounded my back till I spat it out, or else the match might well have stayed lodged in my throat. And take a look at this fingernail, or is it a toenail, do you think? Three years ago I found it in a sponge cake I had bought at Filippov's.

Armless and legless though the sponge cake was, it did have nails - one of those tricks of nature! Ah, and this green piece of rag here I found five years ago in a sausage I bought at one of Moscow's best butchers. This dried-up cockroach was swimming in some cabbage soup I was eating at a railroad station buffet, and this nail I found in the meatball I was eating at that same buffet. That rat tail and this strip of morocco leather were both in the same loaf of bread I bought at Filippov's. This herring, of which now only the bone is left, my wife found in a cake that she was given on her name day. And this beast here, that goes by the name of bedbug, was brought to me in a mug of beer at a German beer hall. Ah, and this bird dropping I almost swallowed at a tavern while eating a fish pie. And so on, my dear fellow."

"What an extraordinary collection!"

"Indeed. It only weighs about a pound and a half, and does not contain all the items that I have inadvertently swallowed and digested. I would say that I have swallowed a good five, six pounds' worth."

Misha carefully picked up the newspaper, peered tenderly at his collection for a good minute, and then poured it back into the drawer. I picked up the cup, sipped at my tea, and refrained from asking him a second time to bring me some bread.

No more fires! The anti-combustion ointments of Babayev & Gardyen are the glory of our times. The following data serves as proof of their ideal fire-inhibiting qualities. Lapshin, the matchstick magnate, has rubbed the ointment on his "Swedish" matches, which now, as we are all aware, will not light even when held over a burning flame. The wicks of Pushkarevsky lanterns are also dipped in this ointment. Theatre brokers, loan sharks, barristers from Iversk never light up with shame, and this only because they have been dipped in the Babayev & Gardyen ointment. But please do not take us merely at our word. We encourage our readers to purchase this newest of products and to smear it on:

 Fiery men and women.
 Entrepreneurs whose business is about to go up in flames.
 Men in whose hearts love is all too easily kindled.
 Combustible daughters and flaming mothers.
 The hot heads of young provincial officials.
 Bureaucrats who sizzle with so much zeal that it can only lead to no good.

Goat or Scoundrel
A sultry afternoon. A young lady of about 18 is reclining on a couch in the drawing room. Flies are wandering over her face, an open book is lying at her feet, her mouth is slightly ajar, and her breath is light and even. She is asleep.

A small, elderly man of the Gogolian old-lecher genre enters the drawing room. Seeing the young lady asleep on the couch, he grins and tiptoes over to her.

"Oh_ how lovely she is!" he whispers, smacking his lips. "Ho, ho_ a sleeping beauty. What a pity I am not an artist! Just look at that head, that little arm!"

The old man bends over the girl's hand, caresses it with his gnarled fingers, and plants a kiss on it. The girl sighs deeply, opens her eyes, and looks at the old man in bewilderment.

"Oh_ is that you, mon prince ?" she mutters, struggling to wake up. "Forgive me, but I seem to have fallen asleep."

"Yes, indeed, you were asleep," the prince croons. "And you are still fast asleep, yes, and dreaming of me, yes, seeing me in your dreams_ sleep, sleep_ I am but a dream."

The girl believes him and closes her eyes.

"How sad," she whispers, as she drifts back to sleep. "All I ever see in my dreams are goats or scoundrels."

The prince, somewhat rattled, tiptoes off.

Trickery: an extremely ancient joke

In England, in olden times, criminals sentenced to death were given the right to sell their bodies while they were still alive to anatomists and physiologists. The criminals could give the money they received from this sale to their families, or they could spend it on drink. One criminal, guilty of a terrible crime, called over a renowned medical man, and after much haggling sold him his body for two guineas. No sooner had the criminal received the money than he burst into peals of laughter.

"What are you laughing at, my good man?" the astonished anatomist asked.

"You've bought me as a man who's to be hanged, y'r honour," the criminal guffawed. "But I tricked you, I did! You see, y'r honour, I am to be burned at the stake. Ho ho ho!"

The Height of Gullibility
In the town of T the other day, K, a local landowner, bigwig and wealthy family man, shot himself. The bullet was discharged into the mouth and lodged itself in the brain. The following letter was found in the unfortunate man's pocket:

"I have just read in the almanac that we are to expect a bad harvest this year. For me a bad harvest means bankruptcy. As I do not wish to live to see such shame come upon me, I prefer to take my own life, and wish that nobody be held responsible for my death."

The Height of Inattentiveness
It has been reported as a substantiated fact that the other day the following regrettable incident took place: Dr M, a celebrated surgeon, during an amputation in which both legs of a railroad switchman were to be removed, due to inattentiveness amputated one of his own legs, and that of his assistant. Both men received immediate medical treatment.

The Height of Civility
I am the son of a long line of highly esteemed civil servants, I read The Civilian every day, I dress in a civil fashion, and my darling Anyuta and I are bound together in a civil marriage.

The Height of Loyalty
We have been informed that recently one of the contributing editors of the Kiev Tattler, a certain Mr T, after reading some Moscow newspapers, began to doubt his political allegiance and carried out a search of his own premises. Not coming upon anything incriminating, he nevertheless decided to escort himself down to his local police station.
fields.bodyText: 'Write as much as you can!! Write, write, write till your fingers break!" This advice, which Anton Chekhov sent to Maria Kiselyova in a letter in 1886, was the motto by which he lived and worked. He was 26, and had already published over 400 short stories and vignettes in popular magazines, as well as two books of stories, with a third in the making. He had written his first series of plays including Fatherlessness, Diamond Cut Diamond, The Scythe Struck the Stone, The Clean-Shaven Secretary With the Pistol and The Nobleman (none of which have come down to us) and Platonov and On the High Road, and he was about to begin writing Ivanov, his first major theatrical success. Throughout this period Chekhov was also energetically studying medicine at Moscow University, from which he graduated in June 1884. The nameplate on the Chekhov family's door now read "Dr AP Chekhov". The stories and vignettes in my book, The Undiscovered Chekhov, are from this period, the most prolific of Chekhov's life. They are some of the works that helped make him a literary star and contributed to his receiving the Pushkin prize in 1888. The seven stories and vignettes that follow have never before been translated into English. For Chekhov, these early years were extremely difficult. The Russian literary giants of the 19th century - Tolstoy, Pushkin, Gogol, Turgenev and Dostoevsky - had all come from the nobility. Chekhov was the grandson of a serf. His father had run a ramshackle grocery store in Taganrog in southern Russia. When Chekhov was 16, his father went bankrupt and left town in a hurry. He took the whole family, including the two elder sons, with him to Moscow - everyone except young Anton, who was left destitute and penniless to fend for himself in Taganrog. As Chekhov wrote to his friend and publisher Suvorin many years later: "What the aristocrat writers get for free from nature, intellectuals of lower birth have to pay for with their youth. Write a story of how a young man, the son of a serf, a former shopboy, choirboy, schoolboy and student, brought up to respect rank, to kiss priests' hands, and worship the thoughts of others, thankful for every piece of bread, whipped time and again, having to give lessons without galoshes, brawling, torturing animals, loving to eat at rich relatives' houses, needlessly hypocritical before God and man, merely from a sense of his own insignificance - write a story about how this young man squeezes the serf out of himself, drop by drop, and how waking up one bright morning this young man feels that in his veins there no longer flows the blood of a slave, but the blood of a real man." By the time the 19-year-old Chekhov rejoined his parents in Moscow three years later, having secured a scholarship to study at the university, the family was living in utter poverty in grimy basement lodgings in Grachyovka, one of Moscow's red-light districts. Anton immediately took charge and became the head and chief support of the family, a position he was to keep till the end of his life. His family nicknamed him "Papa Antosha". He was determined to succeed, and despite the harsh reality of his situation wrote to his cousin: "I will make a fortune... that is as certain as that two and two make four." Chekhov began making his fortune by writing stories and vignettes for popular magazines in Moscow and St Petersburg. According to his younger brother, Michael, the moment the first instalment of Anton's scholarship arrived from Taganrog, he bought up all the magazines he could lay his hands on. He meticulously read through them to see what they were publishing, and then went to work. He sent in sharp, witty, innovative pieces which were published during 1881 in the Moscow humorous magazine Zritel (Spectator) and In Svet i Teni (Light and Shade). Chekhov's pieces came as a surprise to readers of the time, for whom a story was supposed to deal with significant issues and have a clear beginning, middle and end. It was also supposed to impart the author's ideals. Chekhov's stories veered from this norm. He signed his pieces "Antosha", "Antosha Ch", "My brother's brother", "A man without a spleen" and "Chekhonte" - the last a nickname coined for him by his former religion teacher at school, Father Pokrovsky. Chekhov's contemporaries described him roaming the streets, markets, taverns and brothels of Moscow, absorbing the colour and commotion of the city and working it into quick, vivid prose. His friend and fellow writer Vladimir Korolenko wrote in his memoirs that when asked how he wrote his stories, Chekhov laughed, snatched up the nearest object - an ashtray - and said that if Korolenko wanted a story called The Ashtray, he could have it the next morning. Soon Chekhov was writing at such a pace that he was paying family and friends 10 kopecks for story ideas and 20 kopecks for plot outlines. But making ends meet remained a major problem for him throughout the 1880s, and in letters to friends, he constantly laments his lack of money. In a letter to Suvorin in 1888, Chekhov wrote: "I was terribly corrupted by the fact that I was born, grew up, studied, and began to write in a milieu in which money played a shockingly large role." As money began trickling in from the publication of his work, Chekhov managed to move his family to better lodgings - they were to move almost a dozen times during his student years. But as he had to share his cramped living space with his parents, siblings, lodgers, and a constant flow of visiting relatives, Chekhov's living and working conditions remained very difficult. "In front of me sits my non- literary work, banging mercilessly at my conscience. In the next room a visiting relative's fledgling is bawling; in the other room, father is reading The Sealed Angel out loud to mother. Someone has wound up the phonograph, and La Belle Hélène is playing. I want to escape to the country, but it's one in the morning. Can you imagine more vile circumstances for a man of letters?" Chekhov wrote this to his new friend and publisher, Nicholas Leikin, in August 1883. Leikin was the owner and editor of the popular humorous St Petersburg magazine Oskolki (Splinters), for which Chekhov was to write 162 pieces over the next couple of years. Leikin had been searching for an energetic writer who had a wild sense of humour and an innovative style - and, most importantly, who was a master of brevity. Chekhov was the ideal candidate. Oskolki had a strict editorial limit of 100 lines, which forced Chekhov to develop an inventive style concise enough to carry ideas within an extremely restrictive framework. He complained bitterly that he had to "squeeze the very pith and essence" out of his plots, but he readily complied, sending Leikin some of the most original writing of the time. Oskolki published everything from anecdotes, witty riddles and cartoons to intricate vignettes and stories. Chekhov took these forms and expanded them into new literary genres. In an early piece in Oskolki, The Cross (published in February 1883), Chekhov pokes a daring jab at the oppressive state censorship which had just been granted greater power after the assassination of Tsar Alexander II in March 1881. In The Cross, a poet enters a drawing room: " 'Well,' the hostess says turning to him, 'how did your dear little poem do?' " The guests hover about him, amazed and impressed that a poet should be awarded a cross for a poem. The angry poet holds up his manuscript for all to see, and the startled guests realise that the cross he was awarded is "not the kind of cross you can pin on your lapel" - it is the red ink cross of the state censor. His poem has been rejected. Like many of his contemporaries, Chekhov put a good deal of effort into eluding the censor. It was always uncertain what would manage to slip through and what would be prohibited. Almost a century has passed since Chekhov's death, and it is surprising that many of these early masterpieces have not been translated into English. As Chekhov specialist Julie de Sherbinin has pointed out: "The gaps in English translation of his early work can be attributed to various factors: these stories were long considered products of an 'immature' writer, they are rich in colloquialisms and wordplay and thus are hard to translate, and they often depend on cultural context for their humour." Since Chekhov's death in 1904, there have been many translations of his other prose pieces. During the Bloomsbury years, Constance Garnett established his position as an international literary figure by publishing 17 volumes of her Chekhov translations - 201 stories. The quantity of Chekhov's work was so great that Garnett had to make a selection, and her selections have subsequently remained largely uncontested. Consecutive generations of Chekhov translators have not veered far from her choice of stories, only occasionally introducing new, untranslated material. In many of his letters throughout his life, Chekhov downplayed his stories, calling them "little trifles", even "literary excrements" that were written "half-consciously". He playfully confided that he wrote things off the cuff, as if he were eating blini [Russian pancakes]. "I don't love money sufficiently for medicine, and I don't have enough passion, that is, talent, for literature." Chekhov's natural self-deprecation in talking about his work misled many who knew him and later most of his biographers; but there is evidence that behind closed doors, he was always a painstakingly careful writer. His friend Nikolai Yozhov, for instance, was both shocked and amazed to catch him one day transcribing a story by Tolstoy. Chekhov told him that he often did this, that it was just an exercise - he was rewriting the story, editing it down. (Yozhov was outraged.) Chekhov wrote in an earnest letter of advice to his older brother, Alexander, also a writer: "Most important of all: keep watch, observe, huff and puff, rewrite everything five times, condensing and so on, always remembering that all of Petersburg follows the work of the Chekhov brothers!" It is a widely accepted myth that Chekhov initially saw writing as the road to a quick rouble, that he spent the first part of his career as a hack writer for the gutter press, and that it was only in midlife that he miraculously found literature. A closer look at the quality of his early work refutes this. Thomas Mann, in an essay published in Sinn und Form (Sense and Form) in 1954, commemorating the 50th anniversary of Chekhov's death, was one of the first to point out that Chekhov's diffident public attitude towards his writing had misled subsequent generations into a distorted view of his work. "In my eyes," Mann wrote, "the reason Chekhov has to a large extent been undervalued in Europe and even in Russia is due to his extremely sober, critical, and sceptical stance towards himself, and the dissatisfaction with which he regarded his accomplishments - in short, his modesty. This modesty was an extremely appealing trait, but it was not designed to exact respect from the world and, one could say that it set the world a bad example. For, the view we have of ourselves is not without influence on the image that people have of us, and can taint that image and possibly adulterate it. Chekhov the short-story writer was convinced for far too long of his artistic unworthiness and the insignificance of his capabilities. It was only slowly and with great difficulty that he gained a modicum of belief in himself - the belief that is essential if others are to believe in us. To the end of his life, he showed no trace of the literary grand seigneur, and even less of the sage and prophet." Another important factor that led earlier generations of scholars to deprecate Chekhov's early work was his own selection of stories for the 10-volume Sobranie Sochinenii (Collected Works, 1899-1902). It was felt that the pieces Chekhov chose not to include were in his eyes not up to par. And until quite recently, general scholarly opinion agreed with him. Stories told in minimalist telegrams? Absurdist vignettes? How could one compare these wild pieces with the multilayered style of The Cherry Orchard or The Lady with the Lap Dog, a style that has served as a model for many writers of the 20th century? Scholars today are taking a broader view in assessing the scope of Chekhov's early work. Pieces until recently dismissed as "scurrilous sketches" and "impenetrably vacuous balderdash" are now viewed as important experimental works. Thomas Venclova, for instance, discusses Chekhov's early prose as a major precursor of the Russian absurdist writers of the late 1920s and Eugène Ionesco. My work on this book began two years ago in the Slavic and Baltic division of the New York public library. I was looking through a heavy bound volume of Budilnik issues from 1880. The magazines had a very progressive, almost late-Edwardian look, much like early issues of the British magazine Punch. The drawings were coloured, which surprised me, and after the middle of 1880, the lettering on the title pages was flushed with gold. Just as I was wondering how a fin-de-siècle printer could have managed that, I noticed a short story signed "A Chekhov" - Alexander Chekhov, Anton's older brother. In the next few issues there were more "A Chekhov" signatures, and quite a few "Arteopod," an alias Alexander often used. And then came the first stories by "Antosha Chekhonte" - Anton Chekhov. To my surprise, the New York Public Library has all the Moscow and St Petersburg magazines in which Chekhov was first published: Budilnik ( Alarm Clock ) , Strekoza (Dragonfly) and Oskolki. fields.headline: Ask a fellow traveller
fields.trailText: Frances Carey wants advice on driving to St Petersburg.
fields.body:
Frances Carey wants advice on driving to St Petersburg.

 I frequently travel independently to Russia. I always begin by asking friends in St Petersburg for an invitation, about six months in advance of the trip; then a visa from the Russian Embassy in London is available by post in about two weeks. I have driven there three times: the easiest route is by Scandinavian Seaways ferry to Gothenburg in Sweden and Silja Line ferry from Stockholm to Turku in Finland. You need separate car nsurance for Russia, arranged in advance from the Russian insurance company, Ingostrakh (their office in Helsinki is convenient for this, since they speak English and fax to Finland is more reliable than to Russia).

If going there without friends to issue an invitation, you need to book with a company like Intourist who can get you into a hotel, motel or campsite. The Olgino motel/campsite is on the Finnish side of St Petersburg on the main road in.

The roads from the border to St Petersburg are fairly good but they can be very rough within the city, especially when crossing tramlines.

If flying, a cheaper alternative than going directly to St Petersburg is to fly Buzz to Helsinki (for about £90 return) and then take the train (about £60 return). Book a Buzz flight on the internet and train tickets are available in advance from Helsinki railway station, by telephone. Your arrival station Finlyandski Voksal has its own station for the metro - a very efficient way of getting around this beautiful city.
Terry Coles

 My advice is to think very carefully about this. We travelled Fred Olsen line, Harwich to Oslo, and then drove across to Stockholm (easy in a full day) through very pleasant countryside and caught an overnight ferry to Turku. From there, we drove via Helsinki to the Russian border at Vyborg. Once through, it is a reasonable drive to St Petersburg (Turku to St Petersburg in one day, but don't stop in Helsinki if you want to arrive in daylight). Ferries also go direct to Sweden or you could drive from Calais via Denmark. However, ferry fares will be quite expensive. Independent travel in Russia, unless things have changed since our trip, is not easy. You will need special insurance, and petrol stations are few and far between - we were given a map with them marked out. Intourist caters for independent travellers. The border crossing was tricky; we had to empty the car of every item of luggage which was all searched and the car itself was examined in detail. This took two hours.

But the reason why I would not attempt this trip now is crime. The road from the border to St Petersberg is notorious for robberies and on arrival at your destination your car will need to be in secure accommodation at all times - you cannot walk away from it unless it is guarded or in a special compound (western cars are a prime target, but even Russians remove their windscreen wipers and place them inside the car). It may be worth flying with your daughter to help carry the extra luggage needed and to settle her in, which may be a more practical solution than driving.
Gerry Mewton

Manju wants to know how he can meet like-minded people to travel with this summer as most of his friends cannot take the time off.

 I travelled in Iran in 1999 with an Australian guy I "met" via the Lonely Planet website ( thorntree.lonelyplanet.com), and I wouldn't hesitate to do it again. Make sure you advertise well in advance so you have the chance to get to know the person a bit before the actual trip - you don't want any nasty surprises far from home.
Candi Bain

 Try the Rough Guide website, www.travel.roughguides.com. It has a designated noticeboard for people looking for travel partners.
Amy Richardson

 Don't be put off the idea of heading off alone because you're bound to meet people "going the same way" all the time. Everyone is really friendly because they are all in the same boat.
Dave Terrington

This week's questions

 I am returning from New Zealand via Singapore this summer and have planned to spend two weeks in Malaysia, possibly around Tioman Island. But I have recently become aware that travelling alone as a single female can be dangerous in Malaysia. I was hoping to combine visits to the jungle, snorkelling and cultural activities. Does anyone have any advice about making my visit safely?

And we want to be able to get to beautiful wild areas without spending the whole day and all our energy walking there and back (we are too old to be back-packers and camp out). That was the disadvantage of the Odessa area of the Pyrenees last year. Any ideas for good areas to head for?

fields.bodyText: Frances Carey wants advice on driving to St Petersburg.  I frequently travel independently to Russia. I always begin by asking friends in St Petersburg for an invitation, about six months in advance of the trip; then a visa from the Russian Embassy in London is available by post in about two weeks. I have driven there three times: the easiest route is by Scandinavian Seaways ferry to Gothenburg in Sweden and Silja Line ferry from Stockholm to Turku in Finland. You need separate car nsurance for Russia, arranged in advance from the Russian insurance company, Ingostrakh (their office in Helsinki is convenient for this, since they speak English and fax to Finland is more reliable than to Russia). If going there without friends to issue an invitation, you need to book with a company like Intourist who can get you into a hotel, motel or campsite. The Olgino motel/campsite is on the Finnish side of St Petersburg on the main road in. The roads from the border to St Petersburg are fairly good but they can be very rough within the city, especially when crossing tramlines. If flying, a cheaper alternative than going directly to St Petersburg is to fly Buzz to Helsinki (for about £90 return) and then take the train (about £60 return). Book a Buzz flight on the internet and train tickets are available in advance from Helsinki railway station, by telephone. Your arrival station Finlyandski Voksal has its own station for the metro - a very efficient way of getting around this beautiful city. Terry Coles  My advice is to think very carefully about this. We travelled Fred Olsen line, Harwich to Oslo, and then drove across to Stockholm (easy in a full day) through very pleasant countryside and caught an overnight ferry to Turku. From there, we drove via Helsinki to the Russian border at Vyborg. Once through, it is a reasonable drive to St Petersburg (Turku to St Petersburg in one day, but don't stop in Helsinki if you want to arrive in daylight). Ferries also go direct to Sweden or you could drive from Calais via Denmark. However, ferry fares will be quite expensive. fields.headline: Well versed and well travelled
fields.standfirst: Stephen Moss charts the places that put the romance in the soul of Britain's poets
fields.trailText:
Stephen Moss charts the places that put the romance in the soul of Britain's poets
Plus, Byron's Rhineland
fields.body:
Before the Romantics, poets rarely referred to their journeyings in their work. Chaucer, Marvell and Milton all spent long periods on the Continent and absorbed European influences, but the impact on their writing was subtle. It was the Romantics, with their love of nature, emotional response to place and sense of life as a journey, who first treated travel as an end in itself. But even they were less camera than psychoanalyst's couch.

Wordsworth travelled widely in France, Germany and Switzerland in his twenties, and those experiences - as well, of course, as his Lakeland childhood - were transmuted into the works by which he is remembered. His wanderings left a residue which his poetic imagination could later mould, as he explains in his description of the Alps in The Prelude:
"Like a breeze
Or sunbeam over your domain I passed
In motion without pause; but ye have left
Your beauty with me, an impassioned sight
Of colours and of forms, whose power is sweet."

As well as a stock of memories and images, travel also provided perspective.
"I travelled among unknown Men,
In Lands beyond the Sea;
Nor England! did I know till then
What love I bore to thee."

If Wordsworth, the youthful radical, was for a decade an emotional exile, Shelley was for the last decade of his short life an actual one, living first in Switzerland and then in Italy, which in Julian and Maddalo (an account of his friendship with Byron), he called a "paradise of exiles". He spent the summer of 1816 with Byron at Lake Geneva, where he wrote Mont Blanc, with its pantheistic sense of the power and unity of nature.
"The secret Strength of things
Which governs thought, and to the infinite dome
Of Heaven is as a law, inhabits thee!

The way Shelley is moved by Mont Blanc to a rumination on the invisible forces at work in nature is typically Romantic. He is not describing the scene, but exploring the emotions it evoked.

Don't be misled by the success of WH Auden and Louis MacNeice's jaunty Letters From Iceland. Poets are thoroughly unreliable travellers. Robert Browning, widely travelled and much influenced by Shelley, settled in Florence in the 1850s but wrote virtually nothing while there. DH Lawrence undertook his own "savage pilgrimage" to Italy, Ceylon, Australia and New Mexico, but was more interested in sensuousness than scenery. In Italy, he was chiefly fascinated by the luxuriance (and sexual suggestiveness) of fruit, and contrasts the loveliness of pomegranates with the listlessness of Venice,
"Abhorrent, green, slippery city
Whose Doges were old, and had ancient eyes."

As for TS Eliot in The Waste Land, all cities seemed the same:
Jerusalem Athens Alexandria Vienna London Unreal."

Some poets are explicitly doubtful about the benefits of travel. The resolutely immobile Philip Larkin once expressed an interest in visiting China, but only if he could come back the same day. Travel broadens the mind, but great poetry is often the product of narrow obsession, the neurotic cultivation of a tiny plot.

Plus, Byron's Rhineland

fields.headline: Sex is not everything
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 34.
fields.trailText: Against my better judgment, I rang Pamela and asked her to accompany me to Nigel's official coming-out party. I could not risk being mistaken for a single gay man.
fields.body:
Friday, April 6, Arthur Askey Way, Ashby-de-la-Zouch

A belated birthday card from Pamela Pigg. On the front, a picture of a middle-aged git, sitting at a rustic table outside a thatched pub. A black labrador lies at the git's feet, next to a wicker basket from which protrude several fishing rods, nets, etc. The git is wearing a green waxed jacket and a deerstalker, and is raising a foaming tankard to his self-satisfied lips. In the background is a vintage car, presumably owned by the git.

For how long did Pamela shop for this card? And when she found it, did she exclaim, "At last! This is the perfect card for Adrian Mole"? She must know by now that I hate thatch, dogs, tankards, fishing, tweed - in fact, almost everything to do with the countryside. I am urbane to my very fingertips. Inside, Pamela had written: "Adrian, Mon Amour, let's try again. Sex is not everything, Love Piglet."

Query: do I want to try again with Pamela? Most of our trysts seem to end in tears, snot and recriminations. She is ludicrously oversensitive: last autumn, when we were walking in the woods, she wept because the leaves were leaving "their mothers" (the trees).

Saturday, April 7

Against my better judgment, I rang Pamela and asked her to accompany me to Nigel's official coming-out party. I could not risk being mistaken for a single gay man. I regretted my invitation as soon as I saw her outfit. No woman over 17 should wear a sequinned boob tube, in my opinion. And her comedy earrings were not at all amusing. Nigel's parents looked shell-shocked - his mother still thinks his homosexuality is a "silly phrase [sic] he is going through".

That night, after yet another failed attempt at sexual congress (her fault, not mine), Pamela turned her back on me and began to weep piteously. I longed for sleep, but felt compelled to offer her comfort. Unfortunately, she was still there in the morning, naked, apart from the comedy earrings. When William barged into my bedroom, he said, disapprovingly, "You will have to get married now, Dad." He has never seen me in bed with a woman before, not even his mother.

Sunday, April 8

Pamela suggested that we go out for lunch "en famille". She recommended Ye Olde Carvery in Frisby-On- The-Wreake. Glenn and William were excited - they rarely eat out. On the way, in the car, I explained that Frisby-On-The-Wreake was a notorious centre for paganism. Pamela contradicted me violently, saying that Frisby had won best-kept hanging basket prize for three years running. I pointed out that the two could easily co-exist, and Glenn said diplomatically, "Yeah, a witch can 'ave 'an 'anging basket."

Ye Olde Carvery was full of wax-jacketed gits talking in loud voices about the poor cow who'd put her foot in it. I assumed they were banging on about foot and mouth, but Pamela had picked up a copy of the Mail On Sunday and told me the Countess of Wessex had been entrapped by a reporter dressed as an Arab sheikh into calling John Major "wooden", William Hague "a puppet", and foxes "vermin".

The carvery did not cater for vegetarians. Indeed, a glance at the trays of ye olde foode congealing behind the bar told me that Ye Olde Carvery did not cater for any person with a normal appetite, tastebuds, etc. On the way out, one of the gits laughed at Pamela's comedy earrings. I could hardly object.

Wednesday, April 11

Awake all night with irritating dry cough. Sweated profusely.

Thursday, April 12

TB has broken out only two kilometres from my door! And I have all the symptoms. Dr Ng was summoned. He angrily removed a red sequin from the back of my throat.

webTitle: Fast-track inquiry plan for accused teachers

fields.headline: Fast-track inquiry plan for accused teachers
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: A new group of officials are to be appointed to speed up investigations into allegations of abuse by teachers in an attempt to give staff more protection from false accusations.
fields.body:
A new group of officials are to be appointed to speed up investigations into allegations of abuse by teachers in an attempt to give staff more protection from false accusations.

The move will be announced by David Blunkett, the education secretary, at the National Union of Teachers' conference in Cardiff today. He will also meet Marjorie Evans, the headteacher cleared of slapping a pupil after 18 months.

Mr Blunkett is to appoint 25 coordinators in England at a cost of £1.4m. They will start work in September.

The officials will have no investigatory powers but will liaise with local education authorities, child protection committees, schools and governors to hurry cases along. They will offer advice but not take decisions on inquiries into abuse.

The education secretary will also review the guidance given to governors about abuse cases. But he has ruled out giving accused teachers anonymity while their case is investigated - a demand to be made in a motion to the NUT conference tomorrow backed by Mrs Evans. "We don't think that is a practical way forward," an education department spokesman said.

Mr Blunkett wants the time taken to deal with abuse allegations to be reduced from around nine months to three months in all but the most complicated cases. He accepts some cases will take longer.

"We must protect innocent teachers as well as children and to do so we need cases to be dealt with quickly, fairly and consistently," he will say.

"A balance must be struck between protecting pupils and ensuring teachers do not have their careers smeared or damaged by false accusations. It is our duty to make sure that allegations are dealt with quickly so that innocent teachers can return to the classroom swiftly where they belong.

"Dealing with cases more quickly can benefit the victims of genuine abuse too as their anguished wait for justice is reduced." The advisers will be involved in all allegations of physical and sexual abuse.

The National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers said it had dealt with 1,289 cases where pupils had accused staff of abuse over the past decade. Only 52 resulted in convictions against teachers. The number of allegations rose from 42 in 1991 to 159 in 2000. The NUT dealt with 160 cases of teachers being accused of abuse last year and the Association of Teachers and Lecturers an estimated 60-80.

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the NUT, said last night: "Teachers around the country will be delighted at the prospect of any investigation being contained within three months. It would have prevented the nightmare Marj Evans went through."

Mrs Evans went through two police investigations, a court case, and a long-running inquiry by school governors at St Mary's junior, Caldicot, Monmouthshire, before it was found that there was no case to answer. She returned to school on March 21. An education department spokesman said Mr Blunkett was pleased that her ordeal was over. The Welsh assembly has launched an inquiry into the case.

The NUT, the largest teachers' union, is one of the bodies consulted by the government about protection for teachers.

Yesterday Mr McAvoy backed the call to be made in tomorrow's motion for the pupil as well as the teacher to be suspended when an abuse allegation was made. The situation would be similar to workplace cases when both accuser and accused are suspended when allegations are made.

 The NUT leadership last night urged leftwingers not to sabotage its united front against the government on working conditions. Its conference will tomorrow debate a joint motion agreed with three other teachers' bodies which demands an inquiry into pay and conditions.

webTitle: Tories on course for row with teacher unions

fields.headline: Tories on course for row with teacher unions
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: The Tories will today provoke a major confrontation with Britain's teachers when the shadow education secretary, Theresa May, tells the National Union of Teachers that it has become the "last bastion of unreconstructed trade unionism".
fields.body:
The Tories will today provoke a major confrontation with Britain's teachers when the shadow education secretary, Theresa May, tells the National Union of Teachers that it has become the "last bastion of unreconstructed trade unionism".

A year after she was barracked by NUT members, Mrs May will infuriate teachers again by claiming that threats of industrial action have inflicted "incalculable damage" to the reputation of teachers.

Referring to the NUT's plan to stage a work-to-rule, which was abandoned on Thursday night, Mrs May will tell the union's annual conference in Cardiff today: "There are too many times when teaching seems to be the last bastion of unreconstructed trade unionism. I believe images of teaching unions calling for 'civil disobedience' and threatening industrial action over a a 35-hour week does nothing to tackle the real problems in teaching today and does incalculable damage to the reputation of the teaching profession."

Mrs May's remarks, which will be made within hours of a speech by the education secretary, David Blunkett, announcing measures to speed up investigations into allegations of abuse by teachers, will enrage the NUT leadership, which will say that it deserves credit for the way it has averted industrial action over staff shortages.

Mrs May will make clear that a future Tory government would not tolerate even the threat of such action because she will insist that the profession must move away from old-style industrial confrontations.

"When I visit classrooms I see committed, hardworking professionals," she will tell the conference. "But that is not the image witnessed by so many people when they see teachers walking out or barracking government ministers on the television news or when all they read about in the newspapers is industrial actions and strikes."

The speech will be seen as a highly provocative intervention at a sensitive moment during negotiations over teacher shortages. Tory officials insisted last night that Mrs May was not trying to provoke trouble, but merely wanted to make clear to teachers that they have a key role to play in ending the crisis in education.

Mrs May will set out a four-point plan to "reprofessionalise" teachers. She will say a Tory government would:

 Reduce bureaucracy, paperwork and directives from the education department. As a first step, the Tories would remove central targets for how many pupils can be excluded from school, allowing heads to make their own decisions.

 Fund schools directly from Whitehall, ending the "bureaucratic" role played by local education authorities, and saving millions of pounds. The Tories' "free schools concept" would give an extra £540 to every pupil in the country which heads could spend as they saw fit.

 Simplify the national curriculum to allow teachers a greater say in what they teach.

 Provide greater protection for teachers who are accused of misconduct by pupils, a senstive subject that will form one of the main themes of Mr Blunkett's speech today.

He will announce measures to speed up investigations into allegations of abuse by teachers in an attempt to give staff more protection from false accusations. He is to appoint 25 coordinators in England at a cost of £1.4m. They will start work in September.

Mr Blunkett, who will meet Marjorie Evans, the headteacher cleared after 18 months of inquiries, wants the time taken to deal with abuse allegations to be reduced from around nine months to three months in all but the most complicated cases.

fields.headline: Marks of distinction
fields.standfirst: Far from being an act of vandalism, the age-old practice of writing in the margins of books enhances the reading experience, argues  HJ Jackson
fields.trailText: Far from being an act of vandalism, the age-old practice of writing in the margins of books enhances the reading experience, argues HJ Jackson
fields.body:
We all know the reader- annotated book of the present day, and we prefer not to think about it. It's a scruffy thing. Somebody has used a yellow highlighter to mark significant passages - most of the text, it seems. Perhaps it was the same person who scribbled some page numbers in ballpoint pen inside the back cover, with the odd word to show what subject the page numbers refer to, or who wrote a disparaging comment on the title page under the author's name. If it is a library book, there will be no way of telling who marked it up, but if it is private property, the owner's name will almost certainly be on the first blank page inside the cover. If it is left on a bus, nobody will carry it off: it is unlovable and unsaleable.

On the other hand, the British Library in 1998 proudly announced the acquisition of its second copy of Galileo's work on sunspots, Istoria e Dimostrazioni Intorno alle Macchie Solari (Rome, 1613). A publicity leaflet describes it as follows:

"The special interest of this copy lies in the copious annotations in Italian which have been written in the margins throughout the book. While it is not known who wrote the annotations, there appear to be three different hands, all dating from the early 17th century. The annotations have not been transcribed or studied in any detail, but it is clear that they were written by contemporary readers who were interested in recent developments in astronomy and were competent enough to comment in detail on Galileo's observations and findings. These annotations are important evidence for the impact of Galileo's ideas on his contemporaries and give a glimpse of the excited interest and polemical discussion which Galileo's work often provoked."

In this case, apparently, reader's notes increase the market value of the book. The library did not need another copy of that edition, rare and valuable though it might be. The notes are not Galileo's, nor does it contain even his autograph. The notes were written, so far as we know, not by some other famous person but by unidentified contemporaries of no guaranteed authority. In fact the notes have not been "studied in any detail", so we don't actually know yet what they contain, and it is possible that they are not original, perhaps not directly relevant to the text at hand.

Nevertheless, they are valued as a contemporary response, and may be valued all the more, nowadays, for being the work of nameless readers. The same criteria could be applied to the book on the bus, but its annotations have negative value. How do we explain the discrepancy between worthless notes and priceless ones?

About the time that the British Library displayed its Galileo, I picked through a batch of books rejected from a college book sale. There I found a paperback copy of a book by Joseph Fletcher called Situation Ethics: The New Morality (Philadelphia, 1966). All markings are in ballpoint ink. Inside the front cover are an address and two owners' names; the notes were written by the second of them. On the first page,the half-title, she has written, "Criticism in bookstore by Ramsey" - a reference for further reading. The first note occurs on page 19, where the word "casuistry" is underlined and a definition is given in the margin: "study of right and wrong". The reader, a student, appears to be conscientious enough to look up unfamiliar terms. At page 41, she begins cautiously to express her own opinions in reaction to the developing argument: "Good", she says. At page 55, she first registers disagreement, underlining the sentence, "For the situationist there are no rules - none at all," and commenting, "Don't agree. Should have some rules or could screw it all up."

So the response continues, the comments being generally brief and, to be honest, banal. At the end of the index, the annotator sums up the volume in her own words: "nothing is no-no - everything is relative in face of love - must love neighbour - only one absolute - love - idea of 'Summon bonum' - higher good - says must do things for the good - and could turn out bad as long as the goal is good then it's OK - the means to the end - feels there should be no laws - how could you bring children up that way?"

We have no way of knowing whether the notes in the Galileo are any more sophisticated than these. It is quite likely that they, too, are student's notes, and if we were in a position to compare them, we might be able to say something about changes in educational methods and results over time. This copy of Situation Ethics is not as uninformative as the book that contains nothing but underlining, nor as thrilling as a copy that provides privileged information or significant criticism. But it repays attention, and as time goes by its kind of record is likely to increase in value, if not in commercial terms, then at least in terms of potential use by the sociologist and cultural historian.

Though the annotator herself can hardly have been aware of the fact, her annotations are consistent with centuries of tradition reaching back far beyond the birth of print, through the ages of manuscript culture. Methods of annotation are culturally transmitted by the usual mysterious means - for example, prohibition, or word of mouth. They are taken for granted as part of the common reading experience, and it looks as though they will continue to do so. Interactivity is in its heyday and the proponents of the electronic book seem to be keen to accommodate the desire of readers to be involved through annotation.

The student copy of Situation Ethics illustrates a fact that many serious readers deplore: even when less invasive alternatives are available, people go on disfiguring books. Those same serious readers might be prepared to make an exception, though for marginalia associated with public figures. They would be stirred by the sight of the copy of Shakespeare that circulated among the prisoners at Robben Island in South Africa when Nelson Mandela was there. (The prisoners' custom was to sign their names at their favourite passages, and in 1977 Mandela chose Julius Caesar II ii 32-37: "Cowards die many times before their deaths", et seq.) They would understand the buzz over Marilyn Monroe's books in 1999, when some of her personal effects came up for sale. (The most telling was a copy of The Little Engine That Could containing "childish pencil scrawls at the end", possibly hers.)

Books with marginalia often turn out to be a record of affection. Thomas Hardy and Mrs Hennicker exchanged notes in a book, and Mark Twain seems to have started off as a writer of marginalia by writing in books to amuse his fiancee. In the 1960s Philip Larkin, a librarian as well as a poet, enjoyed bawdily altering books with his companion, the academic Monica Jones, and Joe Orton and Kenneth Halliwell were convicted of defacing library books.

Among writers known for their marginalia are Blake, Darwin, Macaulay and Walpole. It was as the editor of marginalia by ST Coleridge, who is associated with the popularisation of the genre, that I began to notice other reader's comments in books, and to collect them. Coleridge's friends encouraged his habit of writing comments in the margins of books. (He well understood the sentimental value of his notes. In Charles Lamb's copy of the plays of Beaumont and Fletcher, he wrote, "I will not be long here, Charles! - & gone you will not mind my having spoiled a book in order to leave a relic.") From roughly 1807, when Coleridge was 35, the number of books that he freely annotated grew until he began to see this library as a marketable resource. One of Charles Lamb's best-known essays celebrated his skills as an annotator. Thomas De Quincy published some of the notes that Coleridge had written in books of his. In November 1819, Coleridge himself, under cover of an editorial fiction, published his "marginalia" on Sir Thomas Browne in Blackwoods' Magazine, bringing the word marginalia from Latin into English.

Ultimately, the future of marginalia rests with readers, and to readers I say (with William Blake): throw off the mind-forged manacles and take a pencil to your books. It is difficult to think of any value attached to books that is not increased by the addition of notes. If it is only by the souvenir value of a presentation inscription, notes personalise our books. (A surprising but charming case is the copy of Kenneth Burke's Grammar of Motives in the Beinecke Library, autographed in ballpoint by Burke and a group of friends to celebrate a party in August 1965. One of them, Robert Osborn, added a drawing with a caption, " The man who, at that splendid luncheon party, juggled 8 balls including his own").

Methodical dating and indexing can create a convenient reading record and filing system. Minute criticism in the margins at the very least allows a reader to let off steam; at its best, it is a vital part of the process by which the reader works out an independent position. For my money, annotating books is more profitable and less narcissistic exercise than keeping a diary. And it increases our satisfaction in our books if we know that they contain useful supplementary materials and better or fuller information than that found in other copies.

fields.headline: Apes who gaze at the stars
fields.standfirst: John Gribbin tells Nicholas Wroe why we should take an interest in science
fields.trailText: John Gribbin tells Nicholas Wroe why we should take an interest in science
fields.body:
It is now a commonplace that some time during the 19th century, the study of science became so complex and specialised that the interested general reader has been effectively excluded from its debates ever since. But no one seems to have told John Gribbin. In the last 30 years he has produced more than 50 books and thousands of articles on cutting-edge contemporary science, all written in a language that the fabled interested general reader has at least an even chance of understanding.

While Gribbin does have a scientific background, he says: "I'm not a scientist who writes. I regard myself as a writer who happens to write about science." He takes the Isaac Asimov definition of an expert - "I'm an expert in only one thing: sounding like an expert" - and on this basis has plunged into the latest developments in the studies of climatic change, the search for extra-terrestrial life, quantum mechanics, string theory and the search for human origins. Books like Almost Everyone's Guide to Science and his Companion to the Cosmos have provided lucid overviews, while the likes of In Search of Schrödinger's Cat have dug pretty deeply into more specialised fields, in that case quantum physics.

Gribbin says that the recent boom in science publishing was launched by the success of Stephen Hawking's A Brief History of Time but might now have passed its peak. "I suspect history has taken over in the last year or so." But he knows there is still a large market out there keen for news from the lab, and he thanks the British education system for giving him the skills to be able to speak to it.

"In the 1950s and 1960s you would learn a lot about some subject and then sit down and do an exam. I was very good at this sort of précis, and my writing career since has been similar in that I often write short things about other people's work and try to boil quite complex things down to their essence."

After leaving school, his maths wasn't good enough for him to be a physicist, so he enrolled as one of the first students on the MSc astronomy course at Sussex university, where he is now a visiting fellow. "Astronomy is probably the most general area of science that it is possible to work in," he says. After completing his PhD at Cambridge, he hoped to get a job in the discipline, "but things were very tight at the beginning of the 1970s and I got into writing." A fellow PhD student had been writing for New Scientist and suggested Gribbin should do the same. "I ended up entirely funding the last year of my PhD from journalism, and so it was the obvious place to go as a second-choice career. I've never sat down and said 'I want to be a writer', but equally I can never remember a time when I wasn't one."

As a journalist he wrote five or six science news stories a week, "on every topic under the sun", and then naturally gravitated into books. His most recent entirely new work was last year's Stardust , in which he dealt with the cosmic aspects of human origins. He points out that the four most common elements that actually react to anything in the universe - carbon, hydrogen , oxygen and nitrogen - are also the four most common elements of our bodies. "The analogy I use is that in the polar regions people make houses out of ice, and in warmer parts of the world they use mud because that is what is available. Life is made of these four elements because that is what is available, which leads me to say that it is very likely that life is common. Of course, that doesn't mean there is intelligent life elsewhere. That is another big step and is an unresolved question."

While his work in this area is strictly scientifically accurate, he has also dabbled in science fiction. "I always preferred hard SF writers like Arthur Clarke and Asimov, who dealt with real science extrapolated to the future, rather than fantasy." His fiction career ended when "suddenly people stopped buying the books. So I thought: 'Sod that, I'll go back to what I know will sell.' My agent was delighted because he always thought it was a waste of time, but it was immensely valuable to my development as a non-fiction writer. I learned about characterisation and plot development and building to some sort of climax and all that. My non-fiction writing did improve."

His latest book, The First Chimpanzee , is a good example of his approach to topical scientific developments. It is an update of his 1982 book, The Monkey Puzzle , written with Jeremy Cherfas. Gribbin was intrigued by research that implied our relationship to chimpanzees and gorillas was closer than had been previously thought. The scientific establishment was dismissive, but as time has gone on Gribbin says the new view, "while not exactly becoming respectable, did become less disreputable". Then, a couple of years ago, "some superb and very rigorous research was done in Australia which produced some rock-solid data. This time it got headlines, so it was time to bring the story up to date."

Is there an evangelical impulse to his work? "I think so," he says. "I do care about people being informed and encouraged to take an interest in science. It's important. One of the really nice things about my career is that people who have done degrees have come to me and said that they started doing physics or something because they read one of my books. That is a fantastic sense of achievement."
