webTitle: Review: Just Capital: The Liberal Economy by Adair Turner

fields.headline: Just capital
fields.standfirst: Howard Davies reviews Just Capital: The Liberal Economy by Adair Turner
fields.trailText: Howard Davies reviews Just Capital: The Liberal Economy by Adair Turner
fields.body:
Just Capital: The Liberal Economy
Adair Turner
400pp, Macmillan
£20
Buy it at a discount at BOL

On the second page of the first part of Just Capital , Adair Turner makes a shaming admission. It is decorously relegated to a footnote in six-point type, but will be read with glee by his detractors. People familiar with the Confederation of British Industry, he says, "will wonder, in reading this chapter, whether I am not attacking some of the very language which was used by it when I was its Director-General".

Indeed they might. The first third of the book is a sustained polemic against the myth of competitiveness when applied to the nation state. The arguments that lie behind the notion that nation states compete with each other, and that Europe is suffering from a failure of competitiveness vis-à-vis the United States, are "confused in theory, wrong in empirical description of the world economy, and wrong in their description of the causes of European unemployment". Apart from that, the competitiveness industry has a lot going for it.

As the man who handed the CBI to Turner in 1995 when, he ambiguously acknowledges, it "had carved out a name for itself as an advocate of competitiveness", I take a personal interest in this recantation. And I am forced to accept that he makes his case powerfully against the strong-form exponents of competitiveness theory. It is economic nonsense to suggest that nations are engaged in a kind of mercantilist fight to the death. The argument that, faced with the imperatives of globalisation, countries have no choice but to cut spending, taxes and all forms of labour-market regulation is evidently untrue. So is the notion that the US strain of capitalism is unambiguously superior to all others.

My own defence of the use of competitiveness as a policy lever - half-shared by Turner - is that it can help to force otherwise desirable measures of liberalisation and fiscal discipline. Domingo Cavallo introduced a so-called competitiveness package recently in Argentina, designed to achieve just the sort of macro-economic stability that is the underpinning of all the policy prescriptions in Just Capital . And while Turner cannot resist taking aim at those, like William Hague and the Eurosceptic press, who harness bogus competition arguments to their cause, his principal objective is altogether grander. He aims first to assess the reasons for the different economic records of different brands of capitalism; North American, Rhineland and Lombard Street. Then, heroically, he tries to articulate his own model of the liberal economy.

This a high ambition for a book targeted at the general reader. Yet it is no exaggeration to say that he succeeds triumphantly. I have read no better assessment of the relative performance of the UK, continental Europe and the US. Turner demonstrates that while the US record of absolute growth and employment creation has been superior in recent years, European productivity per hour remains appreciably higher. While the UK has caught up a little with France and Germany over the last two decades, the catch-up has been slow: a superior per capita growth rate of only around 0.15% a year.

Turner convincingly demonstrates that there is no relationship whatsoever between the level of taxation and public spending, and economic growth. His key message is that governments, and their electors, still have important choices to make, and that there is no inevitability about lower taxes and lower public expenditure. Tax systems need to be constructed with care, and some forms of labour-market regulation (notably high minimum wages) are dangerous. But if a developed country wishes to spend more on education, healthcare or the transport infrastructure, it is able to do so without seeing its productive base float offshore.

There are, however, some policy prescriptions that are unambiguously positive: macro-economic stability with low inflation, a robust domestic competition regime, and as much exposure to external competition as possible. He sees the UK's major post-war policy error as our delayed decision to join the common market. And the single currency now scores highly as a measure that would improve the micro-economy and promote macro-stability.

Turner's muscular style will win him few friends among those at whose confused thinking he takes aim. His last chapter is particularly pungent. In it he explores the dangerous vacuities of stakeholder capitalism and the paradox of the third way - "an unwillingness to say bluntly that one purpose of taxes is to support redistribution, matched by fuzzy talk of communities, stakeholders and social responsibility". Why not, instead, straightforwardly espouse a policy of "redistributive market liberalism", which at least benefits from a clear intellectual rationale, persuasively set out here?

As politicians of all parties, and the pundits who follow them, contemplate a month of phony war before the real hostilities begin, they could usefully spend a day or two with Just Capital . No other book would do so much to improve the quality of debate on the economic and social questions at issue in the next election.
fields.bodyText: Just Capital: The Liberal Economy Adair Turner 400pp, Macmillan £20 Buy it at a discount at BOL On the second page of the first part of Just Capital , Adair Turner makes a shaming admission. It is decorously relegated to a footnote in six-point type, but will be read with glee by his detractors. People familiar with the Confederation of British Industry, he says, "will wonder, in reading this chapter, whether I am not attacking some of the very language which was used by it when I was its Director-General". Indeed they might. The first third of the book is a sustained polemic against the myth of competitiveness when applied to the nation state. The arguments that lie behind the notion that nation states compete with each other, and that Europe is suffering from a failure of competitiveness vis-à-vis the United States, are "confused in theory, wrong in empirical description of the world economy, and wrong in their description of the causes of European unemployment". Apart from that, the competitiveness industry has a lot going for it. As the man who handed the CBI to Turner in 1995 when, he ambiguously acknowledges, it "had carved out a name for itself as an advocate of competitiveness", I take a personal interest in this recantation. And I am forced to accept that he makes his case powerfully against the strong-form exponents of competitiveness theory. It is economic nonsense to suggest that nations are engaged in a kind of mercantilist fight to the death. The argument that, faced with the imperatives of globalisation, countries have no choice but to cut spending, taxes and all forms of labour-market regulation is evidently untrue. So is the notion that the US strain of capitalism is unambiguously superior to all others. My own defence of the use of competitiveness as a policy lever - half-shared by Turner - is that it can help to force otherwise desirable measures of liberalisation and fiscal discipline. Domingo Cavallo introduced a so-called competitiveness package recently in Argentina, designed to achieve just the sort of macro-economic stability that is the underpinning of all the policy prescriptions in Just Capital . And while Turner cannot resist taking aim at those, like William Hague and the Eurosceptic press, who harness bogus competition arguments to their cause, his principal objective is altogether grander. He aims first to assess the reasons for the different economic records of different brands of capitalism; North American, Rhineland and Lombard Street. Then, heroically, he tries to articulate his own model of the liberal economy. This a high ambition for a book targeted at the general reader. Yet it is no exaggeration to say that he succeeds triumphantly. I have read no better assessment of the relative performance of the UK, continental Europe and the US. Turner demonstrates that while the US record of absolute growth and employment creation has been superior in recent years, European productivity per hour remains appreciably higher. While the UK has caught up a little with France and Germany over the last two decades, the catch-up has been slow: a superior per capita growth rate of only around 0.15% a year. Turner convincingly demonstrates that there is no relationship whatsoever between the level of taxation and public spending, and economic growth. His key message is that governments, and their electors, still have important choices to make, and that there is no inevitability about lower taxes and lower public expenditure. Tax systems need to be constructed with care, and some forms of labour-market regulation (notably high minimum wages) are dangerous. But if a developed country wishes to spend more on education, healthcare or the transport infrastructure, it is able to do so without seeing its productive base float offshore. There are, however, some policy prescriptions that are unambiguously positive: macro-economic stability with low inflation, a robust domestic competition regime, and as much exposure to external competition as possible. He sees the UK's major post-war policy error as our delayed decision to join the common market. And the single currency now scores highly as a measure that would improve the micro-economy and promote macro-stability. Turner's muscular style will win him few friends among those at whose confused thinking he takes aim. His last chapter is particularly pungent. In it he explores the dangerous vacuities of stakeholder capitalism and the paradox of the third way - "an unwillingness to say bluntly that one purpose of taxes is to support redistribution, matched by fuzzy talk of communities, stakeholders and social responsibility". Why not, instead, straightforwardly espouse a policy of "redistributive market liberalism", which at least benefits from a clear intellectual rationale, persuasively set out here? As politicians of all parties, and the pundits who follow them, contemplate a month of phony war before the real hostilities begin, they could usefully spend a day or two with Just Capital . No other book would do so much to improve the quality of debate on the economic and social questions at issue in the next election.

fields.headline: Castle House, Hereford
fields.trailText: The rooms were light, bright, fresh and modern without being minimalist or cliched English 'country house'.
fields.body:
Castle Street, Hereford.
Tel: 01432 356321.
Fax: 01432 365909.
email: info@castlehse.co.uk website: www.castlehse.co.uk

First impressions: Completely refurbished Georgian villa in the centre of the city overlooking the cathedral. Quiet, calm, refined decor in semi-formal north-European style. Friendly, open, enthusiastic local staff working with teams of spiffy top-drawer French and Dutch hoteliers and restaurateurs. Maximum attention to detail. AA's hotel of the year 2001.

The rooms: Light, bright, fresh and modern without being minimalist or cliched English "country house". Ten generous-sized suites, one double and four singles. Furnishings all new. Fabrics spectacular. Tapestries, paintings and flowers abound.

The bed test: Immense and unparalleled luxury. Extremely easy to get into, but hard to get out of.

The bathroom test: Marble and woods, telephone, robes, views, smells and top soaps.

Restaurant: Small gourmet menu heading for awards. Supplied by its own farm and overseen by former Savoy chef Stuart McLeod. Regional bias, international standards. Low on vegetarian offerings, high on details, spectacularly presented and very reasonably priced. Immense, well-chosen wine list.

The lounge: Small, relaxed and cheerful, but hardly needed because the suites are of similar size and quality

What is there to see within walking distance: The medieval cathedral with its Mappa Mundi and chained library is next door. Nell Gwynn's birthplace 100 yards.

How much a night? Suites £165-210. Double £155. Single £90.

fields.headline: Women want lights, camera, action
fields.standfirst: For discrimination in key jobs, say the Guerrilla Girls, Hollywood is even worse than US Senate
fields.trailText: For discrimination in key jobs, say the Guerrilla Girls, Hollywood is even worse than US Senate
fields.body:
Pamela Anderson is to star as the feminist campaigner Gloria Steinem while Catherine Zeta-Jones plays a veteran politician in a supposed new film, The Birth of Feminism. Or so says a mock poster demanding "Equality now!" by a protest group called the Guerrilla Girls who this week have stepped up their campaign to highlight the lack of women behind the cameras in the film business.

The Guerrilla Girls, who describe themselves as "culture's favourite masked avengers", have been plastering stickers across Los Angeles and New York complaining at the scarcity of female directors, producers, cinematographers and screenwriters. According to the stickers, no woman has ever won an Oscar for feature film direction, cinematography or sound, and 94% of the writing awards have gone to men.

The stickers also say that a range of major production companies - Miramax, New Line, Artisan, Sony, Screen Gems, Paramount Classics, Fine Line, Dimension, USA Films and the Shooting Gallery - released no more than one film directed by a woman last year. In some cases, it was none.Only four of last year's top-grossing 100 films were directed by women, reads another sticker - "even the US Senate", the sticker says, is "more progressive than Hollywood". The group's film statistics are taken mainly from research done at San Diego State university.

The Guerrilla Girls were founded in 1985 as a reaction to an exhibition at New York's Museum of Modern Art which featured the work of 169 artists of whom only 13 were woman.

Discrimination

Since then, wearing gorilla masks and calling themselves "your cultural conscience", they have staged stunts on the issue of discrimination against women and minorities in the arts.

To maintain anonymity, they use the names of dead women in the arts such as the painters Frida Kahlo of Mexico and Georgia O'Keeffe of the US, and the French writer Anais Nin. They say they are feminist counterparts of the Lone Ranger and Robin Hood. "We could be anyone," they say on their website, guerrillagirls.com.

They have produced around 70 posters on different themes, the latest being the mock film poster for The Birth of Feminism which shows Pamela Anderson, Halle Berry and Catherine Zeta-Jones in bikinis with the slogan: "They made women's rights look good. Really good!"

Anderson is billed as playing Gloria Steinem and Berry and Zeta-Jones as feminist politicians Flo Kennedy and Bella Abzug. The Guerrilla Girls said of the poster: "Women producers have been trying for years, without luck, to convince movie and television studios to make a film about the feminist movement of the 1960s and 70s. We think they're lucky Hollywood hasn't gone for it."

The film statistics on the stickers are backed up by a new study carried out at San Diego State university which analyses the jobs women did in production of the 250 top grossing films in the US. Looking at all executive producers, producers, directors, writers, cinematographers and editors of the films released in 1999, the study found that 17% were women. For cinematographers specifically, the figure was 4%; for executive producers, 15%; and for writers it was 12%.

"It is impossible to look at these numbers and claim that discrimination is a thing of the past," said Martha Lauzen, a professor at the university's School of Communication where the latest survey was compiled.

A key reason for this imbalance, she argued yesterday, was the film industry's ignorance of its extent: "I don't think this is part of a grand conspiracy," Professor Lauzen said. "I don't think all the men in the business get together once a year and say 'let's not hire any women'. It's more of a lack of awarenesss."

But she did not believe hiring decisions would change without pressure. She cited the campaigns run by the National Association for the Advancement of Coloured People which protested last year at the shortage of parts for actors from ethnic minorities in prime time television.

"The reason we don't see more women speaking out is that they want to go to work next morning," Prof Lauzen said. "It's great that the Guerrilla Girls are doing what they're doing."

Fear of open protest

The study also looked at television where 40% of all prime time characters are female; for those behind the scenes the figure is 23%. Women fared best as producers and worst as cinematographers.

One box office success last year, What Women Want, starring Mel Gibson and Helen Hunt, was directed by a woman, Nancy Meyers. It told the story of a man who was able to read women's minds, clearly not a skill that Hollywood's male studio executives have yet acquired.

webTitle: Classic Stories of the New Testament, read by Martin Jarvis and Rosalind Ayres

fields.headline: Classic Stories of the New Testament, read by Martin Jarvis and Rosalind Ayres
fields.standfirst: (CSA Telltapes, £8.99, 180mn)
fields.trailText: A pet is not just for Christmas. Likewise, this selection is not just for Easter. It's like getting a year's worth of Sunday readings in one go.
fields.body: A pet is not just for Christmas. Likewise, this selection is not just for Easter. But the most important festival for Christians is a logical marketing peg and a grand time to renew acquaintance with the New Testament, or discover it. The selection of epistle-size chunks concentrates on the four Gospels, beginning naturally with John 1, running through Christ's life, death and resurrection, and signing off with a gobbet from Revelation. It's like getting a year's worth of Sunday readings in one go. For those brought up to believe that the scriptures must be read plainly, the deliveries may prove a wee bit too expressive - for example, Ayres's little gasp in Mary's Annunciation inquiry about not knowing a man. For others, the husband-and-wife team turn in a crisp, well-paced performance.

fields.headline: Let's get finical
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... the importance of being a stickler
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... the importance of being a stickler
fields.body:
In a theatre review earlier this week, one of our critics wrote: "The play has an edgy, enervated quality that is always interesting." Publication of the review was closely followed by an email from a reader: "Enervated means lacking in energy. [Your critic] probably meant 'nervous'." Indeed she did.

Usually when the word is misused in the Guardian we find that what was intended was the exact opposite of its actual meaning. We used it, for example, when we wanted to say, by way of a compliment, that a certain building energised the city centre. Imagine the dismay of the architect to read that his work, on the contrary, drained its environment of all vitality.

Some of you take a relaxed view of this kind of thing and recommend acquiescence, arguing that resistance or protest is futile. A reader suggests that "flaunt" in place of flout, "refute" for deny, "appraise" for apprise are all in what he calls "the uncertain stage", by which he means as certain of their future in a new form as my tadpoles.

"It takes time," he says, "for a word to acquire a new usage and meaning. At first, the new usage is straightforwardly wrong. Then there is a stage of ambiguity and uncertainty. Finally, the new usage becomes correct - recognised and accepted by almost everyone. For example, in my own lifetime, the use of 'disinterested' to mean 'uninterested' has passed through all these stages."

Not here, it hasn't. It may be that the day is not far off when all resistance to the misuse of the word refute is abandoned. In the case of refute and deny we are talking about matters of degree. Between deny and refute is rebut, and I belong to the apparently dwindling band of people who think the words represent distinctions worth making.

I do not think the Guardian should be ready to make concessions on any of the other examples put forward by this reader. Disinterested signifies impartial, and is remote in meaning from uninterested. We flout the rules of intelligent discourse in flaunting these illiteracies. And on appraise and apprise, even the dictionary to which the Guardian turns, Collins Millennium - a dictionary not slow to recognise new meanings - stands firm here. It offers the following note on usage: "Appraise is sometimes wrongly used where apprise is meant: they had been apprised (not appraised) of my arrival." Appraise means to assess the worth or value of something; apprise means to make aware or inform. This is too familiar ground.

To return to the reader: "We really need a touchstone more sensitive and up to date than dictionaries. May I commend to you the one I myself employ? It is the way words are used in the Guardian." Good God! There, if I ever heard one, is an argument for newspapers to be conservative in conceding change.

At the opposite end of the scale to this reader are most of the rest of you, who write to me about Guardian English, chastising us for being too sloppy and me in particular for not being nearly hard enough on offenders who break the rigid set of rules you would like to see applied. For example, "I want to tell you how disappointed I was that the crass homophones you set... should be thought taxing enough to form the basis of a quiz in our beloved Guardian." This letter continued: "Your astonishing statement that a score of 35 [out of 40] was 'good by our standards' suggests that you feel too much emphasis on this subject is pedantic, but I disagree profoundly."

Ah, the dangers of irony. Some of you write to me about bad - well, let us say appalling - constructions such as the following, which appeared on the front page recently: "Although outwardly supportive, the countess was privately being censured by officials ..."

Mail about Guardian English - on the misuse and misspelling of words and errors in basic grammar - far outweighs that about any other aspect of the paper. Some of you really do want bacterium to remain the singular of bacteria, and media to be recognised as a plural noun. A reader pointing out the phrase "the media is restrained" in a leader this week, ended a terse email with the even terser: "See Guardian Style guide under M." He had done what increasing numbers of you are doing before writing, and visited www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/styleguide .

My colleague, the editor of the style guide, is drawing up a list of things we constantly get wrong. This is where he is so far: 1. defuse/diffuse; 2. bored of; 3. compare to/compare with; 4. prodigal (does not mean returned wanderer); 5. like/as if; 6. protester, adviser (not protestor, advisor); 7. London's Oxford Street, etc (should be Oxford Street, London); 8. Chancellor Gordon Brown (should be Gordon Brown, the chancellor); 9. convince/ persuade; 10. bacterium/bacteria.

You have made a contribution. Don't stop.

 Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning 020-7239 9589 between 11am and 5pm, Tuesday to Friday. Mail to Readers' editor, The Guardian, 119, Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Fax 020-7239 9897.

webTitle: In search of bricks and mortarboards

fields.headline: In search of bricks and mortarboards
fields.standfirst: When students start to look for a new home their parents must do a few sums themselves. Is it cheaper to buy them a place of their own rather than pay rent? Patrick Collinson investigates
fields.trailText: When students start to look for a new home their parents must do a few sums themselves. Is it cheaper to buy them a place of their own rather than pay rent? Patrick Collinson investigates.
fields.body:
Spring is the time when students start to look for the home that will see them through the next academic year, and when more affluent parents start doing their maths: does it pay to buy a house for their son or daughter rather than shelling out rent money?

Parents don't even need to be that affluent; lenders which only five years ago were hostile to the lettings market are now falling over themselves to hand out buy-to-let mortgages, some on rates as low as 6% with only small deposits demanded.

But is it worth it, especially after the steep increase in property prices over the past three years? Jobs & Money this week carried out a snapshot survey in the big university cities and found that in many cases the answer is yes, although sky-high prices in London, Brighton, Oxford and Cambridge are making the equation far less comfortable than before.

All the estate agents we contacted reported a surge in parents asking for details on property - usually three- or four-bed terraces and semis - for their son or daughter to share with friends, with Nottingham seeing the most activity.

The agents say it is also the time of the year when they see their unlikeliest customers. Minutes after nipping in to Poundstretcher to pick up a £2 saucepan, the Oxfam and Firetrap-clad student nervously steps through the doors of an estate agency and asks for details on £100,000 houses.

"In the past couple of weeks we have had them pouring in," says Nottingham estate agent Jennifer Will of Paul Davey & Co.

Competition from professional landlords combined with the surge in student numbers has sent prices spiralling in what were previously undesirable student areas. Lenton in Nottingham, Jesmond in Newcastle, Headingley in Leeds and the Unthank Road area in Norwich have all seen the price of terraced housing jump through the £100,000 barrier, deterring most parental buyers.

Estate agents say they have to continuously deflate the price expectations of parents from the south of England, who have read too many property stories about £10,000 terraces in places such as Salford.

In Sheffield, estate agent Nicola Spencer says: "Londoners have no idea about house prices in the north. They ring up and say they want a three-bed house in a good area for £30,000. They come up here all wanting a bargain and want to get something as cheap as chips." Most are let down when she tells them typical three-bed houses in Sheffield sell for £85,000-£125,000.

Competition for property close to universities is fierce. Ms Spencer recently saw 11 buyers compete for a two-bed flat minutes from Sheffield University put on the market for £57,950; it sold last week to a parent who paid £70,000 in cash.

Other areas are witnessing over-supply, as landlords lured by big yields - often 10% or more - have invested heavily in property at the same time as some universities and housing associations have constructed new student accommodation blocks. Connell Estate Agents in Exeter says over-supply has resulted in rental properties further out of town remaining empty, while in Sheffield new student accommodation is making students picky about going more than a mile out of the city centre in search of housing. Yet the figures still stack up for most big northern cities. The threshold is broadly where the annual income on the property (the yield) is more than 7%-8% of the property's value. Yields of 15% can still be found in cities such as Leeds and Manchester, but in Oxford, Cambridge and Brighton they are 5% or below. In London they are even lower, and require that parents take on colossal loans. It is also partly due to the fact that student rents only poorly reflect house price variations; student rents in Brighton are only a quarter higher than Manchester, but house prices are double.

webTitle: Estate agent contracts: Caught in sole agent trap

fields.headline: Caught in sole agent trap
fields.standfirst: When does 16 weeks equal nine months? When you have signed a contract which reactivates itself if the sale of your house falls through. Elizabeth Langton looks at some surprising small print
fields.trailText: When does 16 weeks equal nine months? When you have signed a contract which reactivates itself if the sale of your house falls through. Elizabeth Langton looks at some surprising small print.
fields.body:
For most of us, selling our home means striking up a relationship with a local estate agent - a relationship we expect to last for a maximum of three months. For Doreen Jansen, of Croydon, Surrey, it meant being tied to the same agent for nearly nine months.

Signing on the dotted line to put her home on the market resulted in a bond that lasted from June last year to March this year, when she finally broke free from Cubitt & West in Shirley.

Although the agency hadn't broken any laws, Ms Jansen and her solicitor felt she had been locked into an unfair contract. But the agents were not members of the ombudsman for estate agents scheme so she could not turn to that for help.

As Jobs and Money reported last week, there is mounting frustration about the failure of estate agents to join the voluntary ombudsman scheme. Nearly two-thirds of estate agent firms have refused to join the scheme, which is the only avenue of redress available to the public without going to court.

In response to the article, consumer affairs minister Kim Howells issued a warning to agents who refuse to join. "I am very concerned by the reports that the majority of estate agents have still to join the ombudsman scheme, especially as my department has been very active in encouraging estate agents to join the scheme," he said.

"By joining, businesses are proving their commitment to putting the needs of their customers at the heart of their business success. I want to remind all estate agents to join the scheme as soon as possible. As I have said previously, statutory legislation remains a serious option if they fail to sign up," he added.

Ms Jansen would welcome statutory regulation of estate agents, as her experience has left her feeling cheated. In June last year, Ms Jansen signed what she thought was a straightforward sole agency contract for 16 weeks with a two week notice period. "As I understood it the contract was for 16 weeks, during which time if another agent sold the house, I would have to pay multiple agency fees," she said.

But as ever, the small print contained an extra condition. The 16 week period which started from the date the contract was signed, would be "suspended as soon as the sale is agreed and restarts in the event of the sale falling through".

The property was put on the market in June and a sale was agreed in August, when the contract had only been in operation for seven weeks and six days. By January, the sale had fallen through. Ms Jansen, who was unhappy with the service she had received from the agency, decided to terminate the contract after giving notice.

However, the agency pointed to the fact that the contract had been suspended after the offer had been made and was reactivated when the sale fell through. In practice this meant the contract had another eight weeks and one day to run before it expired at the end of March.

She was informed that should another agent sell the property before the sole agency period had expired, she would have to stump up the cash for their fee.

Her solicitor agreed that, although the contract was un fair, the agents would be within their rights to take proceedings against her. Trading standards officers also confirmed that the length of the agreement was classed as a core term of the contract and therefore could not be challenged under the Unfair Terms in Consumer Contracts regulations that came into force in October 1999.

Brian Mathews, of Arun Estates, Cubitt & West's parent company, denied the contract was unfair: "Our agreements have trading standards' approval. It's important to us not to breach any trading standards regulations."

The consumer contract regulations, introduced to combat rip-off Britain, say that a consumer is not bound by a standard term in a contract with a seller or supplier if that term is unfair. Unfairness is defined as creating a significant imbalance in the parties' rights and obligations under the contract, to the detriment of the consumer and in favour of the business.

Ms Jansen didn't feel able to risk being forced to pay fees to two sets of agents, so she gave notice and waited for the contract to run out before placing the property with another agent.

Hugh Dunsmore-Hardy, chief executive of the National Association of Estate Agents, said agents' contracts vary widely and homeowners should ensure they understand every aspect of what they're being asked to sign.

A sole agency contract is one where the agent expects to be the only one with the right to sell your property. This means you may have to pay the agent even if another agent finds you a buyer.

Sole selling rights is the same as sole agency except you have to pay the estate agent even if you find your own purchaser, such as a friend. Multiple agency agree ments allow you to market the property with several agents and, as a result of the extra competition for buyers, agents charge higher fees.

Straightforward enough on the surface, but contracts are frequently a source of contention. Last year, high profile agents FPD Savills came under fire from the Consumers' Association following the case of a couple who faced estate agency charges of almost £9,500 by FPD Savills, even though their flat remained unsold after negotiations fell through.

Their contract meant that even vendors who were forced to withdraw due to circumstances beyond their control, were liable to pay fees.

The Consumers' Association used its powers to enforce Unfair Contract Terms Regulations, and wrote asking FPD Savills to rewrite its contract. FPD Savills responded by amending its contracts to make them clearer and fairer to the consumer.

Ms Jansen warns vendors to look closely at their contracts and seek the advice of a solicitor if in doubt. Moving house is rarely a smooth process; delays and hiccups are frequent. Some sellers see out several abortive sales before exchanging contracts and, in theory, the kind of contract Ms Jansen signed could go on being suspended and reactivated for a long time.

Her property is now being marketed with another estate agent who offered her a straightforward sole agency period of 12 weeks with a 14 day notice period. And a sale is on the point of being secured.

Ms Jansen wants to see estate agents subjected to statutory regulation and the introduction of standard contracts to protect sellers like herself. "It was a nightmare not being able to remarket the property with a more suitable estate agent," she says.

Until the government moves to change the law, it is up to sellers to make their own checks on estate agents. Kim Howells urges all consumers to check before they employ the services of an estate agent to ensure they are a member of the ombudsman scheme.

fields.headline: Moves in the right direction
fields.trailText: Housemovers and first-time buyers may be cheering at the news that mortgages are the cheapest they have been for more than 30 years, but they'll be less thrilled to hear that the cost of moving is going up.
fields.body:
Housemovers and first-time buyers may be cheering at the news that mortgages are the cheapest they have been for more than 30 years, but they'll be less thrilled to hear that the cost of moving is going up.

The overall costs of moving have increased since last year across all price ranges, with properties in lower price brackets hardest hit, according to this year's annual Woolwich Cost of Moving Survey. It now costs an average £4,449 to upgrade from your £100,000 property to a £150,000 one - an increase of £75.

But the good news for anyone both selling and buying is that it actually costs less to move home in 2001 than it did five years ago. Moving from a £100,000 property to a £150,000 one costs nearly 5% less than it did in 1996. Underlying these changes is a fall in estate agent fees - although irrelevant to first-time buyers - while conveyancing charges have risen for both.

Since last year, solicitors' fees have gone up by an average 8% for properties up to £200,000, compared to 6% for those costing more. So cheaper properties are hardest hit. And two in three solicitors no longer offer discounts for acting for both sale and purchase.

Estate agents, on the other hand, are charging 18% less to sell a £150,000 property than they were five years ago, though fees have not gone down as much on cheaper properties - by 6.4% for sales of £50,000 homes, for example.

Location counts. Selling a £100,000 property in the South East would cost £2,303 in solicitor and estate fees (£184 more than the national average) compared with £1,655 in Humberside.

Wealthier buyers have been hit by stamp duty rises. Since March 2000, duty has been 1% on properties over £60,000, 3% over £250,000 and 4% over £500,000.

www.houseweb.co.uk one of the most comprehensive property websites, offers a handy guide to costs.

fields.headline: Mandarin Kitchen, London
fields.standfirst: You'd be hard pressed to beat the seafood on offer at Mandarin Kitchen, says Matthew Fort. Although the sea cucumber is very definitely an acquired taste
fields.trailText: You'd be hard pressed to beat the seafood on offer at Mandarin Kitchen, says Matthew Fort. Although the sea cucumber is very definitely an acquired taste.
fields.body:
Why can't razor clams appear more regularly on menus? They are the essence of cooked shellfish, the distillation of marine munchability. True, they can be a bit rude to look at, and, if not cooked very carefully, can feel as if you've put a peculiarly dense rubbery toy in your mouth. When treated with care, however, they have an unmatched sweetness and a forceful tenderness. And when that sweetness is matched against garlic soya sauce, well, then you know what a perfect marriage is all about.

Pimlott and I were lunching at Mandarin Kitchen when we came across these razor clams with garlic soya sauce. We rejoiced. Mandarin Kitchen won the Asian section of the Moët et Chandon London Restaurant Awards last week, for which I was a judge. So why bother with a review, you may ask - surely, if you helped vote it a winner, you must have eaten there before and never thought to mention it to us. All true. I have eaten there several times, and thought highly of it, but I thought it a good idea to remind myself just why.

Mandarin Kitchen certainly did not get the award for its decor, which is far removed from the high-concept, designer dream world that is now part of the eating experience. It would be kind to call the place utilitarian in its approach to visual display, though more accurate to say that it resembles a generously proportioned, white-painted tube tunnel with windows. But looks aren't everything. Indeed, they may not be anything. Mandarin Kitchen rates as one of the more difficult restaurants in west London in which to find a seat come dinner time, partly because discerning and curious London chefs love to eat there.

Why? In a word, fish. It isn't just the best Chinese fish restaurant in town. It's possibly the best fish restaurant of any national denomination. It is said to sell more lobster than any other place in London, but we weren't there for that. We wanted the marine exotica that you rarely see on other menus: the aforementioned clams, roast baby squid with chilli and garlic, sea cucumber pot, monkfish in ginger sauce and, by way of contrast, spicy beef shin from a section on the menu delightfully named "cold toss". In fact, the thought of the sea cucumber really set Pimlott slavering, but we'll come to that.

I've already extolled the virtues of the clams, and similar accuracy in cooking technique meant that another potentially dentally challenging shellfish, squid, was as resistant to the tooth as a rose petal. A toothless old crone could have eaten these squid and, equally remarkable, tasted them. Let's face it, squid isn't one of Dame Nature's heavy hitters. Texture, great; taste, the weak link - unless it's been squidding about until a few hours before hitting the pan. These, like all the fish at Mandarin Kitchen, obviously had been, so held their own with the garlic and chilli.

I set about demolishing the honorary meat dish virtually singlehanded - Pimlott, wisely as it turned out, was reserving his fire for the sea cucumber pot - and, given the generous nature of the portion, eating the lot was quite an undertaking. Nevertheless, I managed it. Shin of beef is another ingredient that we see far too little of on contemporary menus. The European way is to braise it for hours and hours until the meat turns gently and silkily fibrous. The Chinese way is to braise it with spices - notably, in this case, star anise - for not nearly so long, let it cool, slice it thinly and then relish the interplay between the dense meat, and the cores of gelatine and connective tissue running through it.

The monkfish was anonymous after these kitchen curiosities, partly because the ginger was not its usual cheerful, challenging self. It was unusually self-effacing, and the dish suffered as a result. But one dish's disappointment is another's opportunity, and in came the sea cucumber pot. You may not be familiar with sea cucumber. You are not alone in this. They figure prominently in photographs of coral reefs in National Geographic, but rather less frequently on fishmongers' slabs. They aren't vegetables at all, but curious creatures, kind of marine cleaners, hoovering up all the stuff that other denizens of the deep won't touch. What came out of the braising pot and into our bowls were short sections of what appeared to be draught excluder of almost supernatural slipperiness, and was a severe test of chopstick technique. As for flavour, I would say that sea cucumber rates slightly lower than phlegm, the texture of which it closely resembles. But then, that's the point. The braising medium, stock and shitake mushrooms contributed the flavour, the sea cucumber variations on jelly, which is so appreciated by the Chinese and so unrecognised by most of the rest of us.

I withdrew from the contest after a couple of exploratory mouthfuls, but Pimlott ploughed his way through the lot, cooing cheerfully as he went. It was a majestic performance, helped by a bottle of Pinot Grigio from a rather well-appointed wine list. It worked exceptionally well, and made but a modest contribution to our bill of £70.40. And £70.40 seems remarkably little to pay for superlative fish and shellfish that is handled with supreme assurance, not to mention the rare opportunity to come to grips with a sea cucumber. Although, on reflection, "grips" may not be quite the right word

As for flavour, I would say that sea cucumber rates slightly lower than phlegm, the texture of which it closely resembles. But then, that's the point. The braising medium, stock and shitake mushrooms contributed the flavour, the sea cucumber variations on jelly, which is so appreciated by the Chinese and so unrecognised by most of the rest of us. I withdrew from the contest after a couple of exploratory mouthfuls, but Pimlott ploughed his way through the lot, cooing cheerfully as he went. It was a majestic performance, helped by a bottle of Pinot Grigio from a rather well-appointed wine list. It worked exceptionally well, and made but a modest contribution to our bill of £70.40. And £70.40 seems remarkably little to pay for superlative fish and shellfish that is handled with supreme assurance, not to mention the rare opportunity to come to grips with a sea cucumber. Although, on reflection, "grips" may not be quite the right word

webTitle: Roads clear as Britons fly off

fields.headline: Roads clear as Britons fly off
fields.trailText: Nearly a million people had flown abroad for the bank holiday weekend by last night, with another 500,000 heading for the Channel tunnel and ferry ports, ignoring government pleas to spend time in the countryside to help a tourism industry beleaguered by the foot and mouth crisis.
fields.body:
Nearly a million people had flown abroad for the bank holiday weekend by last night, with another 500,000 heading for the Channel tunnel and ferry ports, ignoring government pleas to spend time in the countryside to help a tourism industry beleaguered by the foot and mouth crisis.

The total number leaving the country this Easter is expected to reach a record 1.75m. Foot and mouth and weather more winter than spring have contributed to an expected 15% rise in overseas holidays compared with last Easter.

Newhaven port in East Sussex reported a 26% rise - and a 60% plunge in numbers coming into the country.

About 330,000 people were flying from Heathrow, 240,000 from Gatwick, 200,000 from Stansted, 80,000 from Manchester and 35,000 from Luton.

Those staying began the weekend at shopping centres, amusement parks and city centre attractions.

Motoring organisations reported an absence of holiday gridlock on the roads.

A highways agency spokesman said: "There has not been as much traffic as we expected. Some roads are busy, but there have been no hold-ups anywhere, and coastal areas have had no real problems."

Avon, Somerset, Gloucestershire, Wiltshire, Devon, Dorset and Cornwall all reported about 90-95% of normal business, according to Malcolm Bell, chief executive of South West Tourism.

Coastal paths have begun to reopen, helping tourism particularly in Devon, Dorset and Cornwall, but the industry will still lose about £25m as up to 150,000 fewer people travel to the south-west.

The Lake District was enjoying only a "moderately busy" time, in stark contrast to previous Easters, said David Hewkin, manager of Windermere tourist information centre, despite footpaths being open.

On Brighton seafront, traders said the many sunseekers came as a welcome break from their "disastrous" spring season so far.

In Blackpool, Katherine O'Connor, deputy head of tourism, said an upturn in business was expected as people walked along the coast instead of in the countryside.

The weather offered little to raise the spirits of those staying put. Nick Ricketts of the meteorological office said most of Britain would have rain or drizzle today, with a chilly north-westerly wind.

This would clear in many parts by tomorrow evening, with sunny spells in most places on Monday. Temperatures would range from 6°C in Scotland tomorrow to 13°C in the south-west.

webTitle: Leader: Shayler is doing what Straw wanted

fields.headline: A welcome test case
fields.standfirst:
Shayler is doing what Straw wanted

Special report: David Shayler
Guardian Unlimited Politics
fields.trailText: The prosecution of David Shayler has taken on a legal life of its own. Before he can be tried for breaching official secrecy by publishing allegations about the security and secret intelligence services, it must be determined whether our baggy, catch-all secrecy laws are abusive in terms of the Human Rights Act.
fields.body:
The prosecution of David Shayler has taken on a legal life of its own. Before he can be tried for breaching official secrecy by publishing allegations about the security and secret intelligence services (that they kept files on such notorious reds as Jack Straw and Peter Mandelson, for instance), it must be determined whether our baggy, catch-all secrecy laws are abusive in terms of the Human Rights Act. This trial before a trial - due to begin the week after next - may well lead to the eventual quiet dropping of the Shayler prosecution. But before that happens, this testing of the Official Secrets Act ought to be eagerly applauded. And not just by us. It is, after all, what Mr Straw himself always wanted.

Intellectually, the home secretary is one of the Blair government's brighter sparks. A qualified lawyer, he knew well in advance of the incorporation of the European convention into UK law (still one of the Blair government's great achievements) that a dynamic process of comparison was being set in train. Existing state practice was going to be examined in the light of ideal rights. The home secretary welcomed the HRA as a means of improving governance by testing the fairness of government action. Including, of course, its use of the apparatus for covering up the doings of its spies and security operatives. In that spirit he ought to welcome these preliminaries to the Shayler case.

The European convention is not incompatible with official secrecy or even raison d'état. What it emphasises is justification by public interest. Breaches of its protection of freedom of expression - as in the Shayler case - need to be defended by a convincing exposition that the public's welfare would be damaged by disclosure. That is going to take a lot more than Mr Straw or Robin Cook appending their names to discredited "public interest immunity certificates".

These ministers' attitudes are one of the Blair era's great puzzles. They cooled their heels so long in opposition, watching the Tories succumb to the temptation of abuse of power, yet so quickly embraced the culture of secrecy when they took office. Now they squander political capital protecting the security and intelligence services, despite the evidence - David Shayler's for example - of mismanagement, inefficiency and unaccountability; and despite the fact that spies will never love the left, even in its milk-and-water dilution.

webTitle: How Maff's masterplan went up in smoke

fields.headline: How Maff's masterplan went up in smoke
fields.standfirst:
Special report: foot and mouth
Guardian Unlimited Politics
fields.trailText: On the face of it, the most reviled government department in Britain had at last got something right. A week ago the Ministry of Agriculture and the army identified a disused Cumbrian airfield as the perfect site for a purpose-built incinerator to burn the backlog of animals killed during the foot and mouth epidemic.
fields.body:
On the face of it, the most reviled government department in Britain had at last got something right. A week ago the Ministry of Agriculture and the army identified a disused Cumbrian airfield as the perfect site for a purpose-built incinerator to burn the backlog of animals killed during the foot and mouth epidemic.

Work started last Saturday; by Sunday an access road was in place; by Monday a 500 metre pyre was built, ready to burn 3,000 diseased carcasses every day - for a year if necessary. Wagons carrying slaughtered cattle from all over northern Britain began converging on the aerodrome; on Thursday night someone counted 83 lorries. This was to be Britain's biggest animal crematorium.

Its rapid construction was, at last, the display of fast-moving efficiency for which the nation had been waiting. It was probably a re-enactment of the kind of wartime effort that built the airfield in the first place.

Unfortunately, though, this was under the control of Maff, an organisation so hapless that if it began selling umbrellas, the rain would cease. Yesterday it was obliged to close the site for at least a week. It may never reopen. And unless there is a dramatic change of mood, it may have to do so over the prone bodies of local residents. With amazing crassness officials had chosen Hallburn aerodrome - less than a mile from the centre of Longtown, the small town outside Carlisle which has attained a sort of infamy as the foot and mouth capital of the world.

Longtown has been surrounded - and sometimes covered - by choking smoke for the past five weeks. On the six-mile drive between here and Carlisle there is not an animal left alive in the fields. Throughout that time the first view of the town for anyone driving north from Carlisle has been the pyre of burning sheep at Howend Farm. It is still alight; local gossip is that officials chose such cheap coal that the carcasses have never burned properly.

Hallburn was supposed to solve these problems, and do the job properly. Special low-sulphur coal was being imported from Colombia to replace the stuff from Workington. Steel girders were used to hold the carcasses off the ground and ensure a proper up-draught. It was, said Ian Pearson, the regional disposals manager for Maff, "a new-technology burn: a faster, efficient, higher-temperature burn".

But it would still burn over Longtown, and Longtown fought back - the mouse that roared. At an astonishing public meeting this week about half the population turned up at the town's community centre and routed a group of ill-briefed officials - from Maff, local councils, the army and the environment agency - who had been sent to reassure them that there was no danger to their health.

Fury

The officials appeared to imagine this was a routine meeting of hayseeds; the army sent just a fresh-faced lieutenant. Nothing in the panel's lives of decent obscurity could have prepared them for the fury that would follow. It was, in that sense, a microcosm of the way this epidemic has overwhelmed thousands of other well-meaning public servants, up to and including the minister of agriculture himself.

They were in trouble from the moment North Cumbria's director of public health, Peter Tiplady, was over-smugly announcing that the chances of BSE spreading from the pyres was "one in a million". A voice cried out: "You don't give a shit. You're just happy to come to Longtown and set fire to it." This was wildly applauded.

The best-researched, and most decisive intervention came from James Bell, son of a retired Longtown vet, who announced himself as "research and technical director for a company which is a recognised world leader in carbon chain degradation" and said he had 13 questions. As soon as he mentioned "polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons" the panel had a problem.

At one point the chairman tried to wrestle the microphone from him, which was a mistake. But long before question 11 ("Are you aware of the EU R45 requirements instanced in 75/552/EEC and 67/548/EEC?") they had all slumped defeated into their seats.

The only question they probably even grasped was the last: "Is there anything that can be said that will stop the burn at Hallburn?"

Surprisingly, there was. Other speakers gave less technical but equally forceful testimony. "My garden and my window are smothered with globules from the burning," said a lady from Chapelknowe. "It's like a resin. Even a woman knows that what goes up must come down."

Longtown was unanimous. And Nick Utting, the area NFU secretary, eventually took the microphone. He told Ian Pearson: "I'm afraid, sir, that you cannot expect Longtown to take any more. The people have had enough." Pearson meekly agreed and said he would recommend that the site, in which more than £2m is thought to have been invested, close at once.

Bell calculated that the smoke would contain eight carcinogens, dioxin, mustard gas and - even with the low-sulphur coal - 9,000 tons of sulphur dioxide. No one has yet emerged to counter his claims or to answer the obvious question about whether the smoke contains foot and mouth germs. The wind would carry the flames either over the town or towards the Lyne Valley, the one part of the Longtown area which has remained relatively disease-free, with 11 farms still uncontaminated.

Blood

The Lyne Valley was also the route chosen for the wagons to carry the diseased bodies to the site. "They're supposed to be sealed," said farmer John Armstrong, "but I know that at least one of them has had blood dripping." His neighbour, Sam Alexander, a pig-farmer forced into retirement several agricultural crises ago, said: "The drivers have got no consideration whatever. They're going so fast along these narrow roads they're going to kill someone."

All these issues are now being discussed at meetings between Maff officials and Arthuret parish council, which covers Longtown. Other councillors and vociferous opponents were being excluded from the talks. But Karen Johnson, the council clerk, was still insisting yesterday: "We don't intend to compromise. As far as we're concerned, Hallburn will stay closed."

There is still talk of protesters lying down in front of the lorries, on the off-chance that the drivers would notice.

The issue has at least given Longtown a new focus, a rallying-point after six weeks that have brought nothing but despair and dissension.

"It's been setting farmer against farmer, neighbour against neighbour," a resident said. The sheep mart, once Longtown's biggest business, remains firmly padlocked, although the yard has been taken over by the diggers used to construct the pyres. Trade remains appalling: even the barber is said to have lost half his trade now the farmers no longer come to town.

The church, at least, has been doing better business and John Smith, the priest, continues to preach hope. The congregation will be singing Oh God, Our Help in Ages Past tomorrow, as they have done ever since the crisis started. But the help has been a long time coming. Except for the fortress of the Lyne Valley, there is hardly a sheep or cow left alive round Longtown. Normally, by now, the fields would be alive with gambolling and baa-ing lambs. There is nothing: it is Silent Spring.

Margaret Armstrong, a haulier's wife (no relation to John), was musing over coffee about these strange times: "I phoned a friend and said 'Jean, what did we do before foot and mouth?' I can't remember what we talked about. People used to say what a lovely life we had up here. I can't ever see it being normal again now.

"It seems just like snakes and ladders. Sometimes you seem to be up a bit and things are getting a bit better. Then suddenly you hit another snake and you're down again. But, no matter what, you never get back where you were."

webTitle: Interview Chris Green, chief executive Virgin Trains

fields.headline: The railwayman's lament
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Chris Green, the despairing and widely criticised man at the centre of the Virgin Trains fares row, bemoans the fact that the rail industry lacks a single, powerful leader. Split into more than 100 parts, he believes it needs cohesion, but there is nobody with the skill and the authority to develop it.
fields.body:
Chris Green, the despairing and widely criticised man at the centre of the Virgin Trains fares row, bemoans the fact that the rail industry lacks a single, powerful leader. Split into more than 100 parts, he believes it needs cohesion, but there is nobody with the skill and the authority to develop it.

It cannot be Green. He is probably the best-known railwayman in Britain, having served a long apprenticeship with British Rail before taking over "this most exciting job" as chief executive of Virgin Trains, which has a record of being one of Britain's most unreliable companies.

He does not want to lead the industry, but he knows somebody who should, or to put it more accurately, he knows the job description. The job title is chairman of the Strategic Rail Authority, at present occupied by Sir Alastair Morton, but while Mr Green acknowledges Sir Alastair's contribution, he finds that he has been "a reluctant bride".

The leader Green is looking for must stand between the customer and Railtrack - the person who must decide "whether we want low fares and high subsidies or the other way around". The successful candidate would act like an "admiral of a flotilla of ships, directing their passage to make sure that they come safely through to the harbour".

By saying this, Green is joining the growing debate within the industry and government that Sir Alastair has not been fulfilling his role and may have to move on if he fails to satisfy their expectations.

Green said: "If Sir Alastair does not accept the role of leadership and strategy, our industry will not be able to progress satisfactorily." In making these comments this week, Green was sticking his neck out. He is at present looking to the SRA for succour over his plan to increase Virgin's fares by up to 10% from May 21, a decision which cannot be revoked. Green would like to impose a fares freeze if he could get a deal with the SRA, the government's official industry arm. If not, he does not rule out further fare rises later this year.

Understandably, passengers have been reluctant to accept Virgin's hard luck story. But, according to Green, it must be put down to the appalling impact of the Hatfield rail disaster on the industry. Six months on, the issue is who is going to pay for the unpredictable effects of Hatfield. Like foot and mouth, the financial implications of the crisis are far beyond the means of any single owner.

In BR days, the government would have carried the insurance risk of last resort and would no doubt have slowed down some investment to balance the books. Virgin is one of the worst hit of the train operators, although Great North Eastern Railway has almost certainly been decimated by Hatfield, followed last month by the Selby rail crash, but is not saying so as graphically as Virgin. Green said that, although traffic was now only 10% below what it was before Hatfield, Virgin lost £100m in income in just 12 months and would lose a further £50m this year unless it put up its fares.

He maintained he had received only £30m in compensation from Railtrack - which has accepted direct responsibility for Hatfield - and like other rail companies, is planning to claim more through the courts.

Green continued: "Virgin is the first to agree that big fare increases are unfair to rail users, but it has run out of options, short of slowing down investment or handing back the keys.

"We have had to watch government give Railtrack £1.5bn of extra subsidy to tide it through a crisis of its own making, while we face months of judicial action to extract our rightful compensation." Better late and safe

You might think Green has almost reached the end of his tether in trying to run a high profile rail company owned by Britain's most controversial entrepreneur, Sir Richard Branson.

Having put his name to some old rolling stock on a clapped-out railway, Sir Richard was obviously prepared to take the brickbats, but these have been slung at him for almost four years, and passengers have noticed little improvement. Indeed in the months since Hatfield, things have got noticeably worse. Green makes no bones about the reasons - he said recently: "If safer trains mean later trains, then so be it."

But Green, a professional railwayman since 1965, when BR made him a junior manager and he lived above the shop - in a small flat while Birmingham New Street station was being noisily renovated - has always been an optimist. "The positive side to all this is that £7.5bn has been invested in the upgrade of the west coast main line and new rolling stock, and I will soon be taking delivery of 840 coaches, the last by 2003, for the west coast main line and for our cross-country services between Inverness and Cornwall. This is far bigger than anything under nationalisation, and shows the commitment of the private sector to this potentially exciting industry."

Green was born in the leafy suburb of Richmond in Surrey, developing a love of the railway - "not as an anorak" - as he made his way to school every day on the District line. He subsequently found himself at Oxford at the time Dr Beeching was writing his two reports. The first and best remembered brought about huge cuts on rural services. The second was a plan to upgrade long distance lines and increase speeds. Beeching also proposed the concept of inter-City services - which 30 years later Green turned into a profit of almost £100m.

Green climbed quickly up BR's oily, stained greasy pole, stopping off to perform increasingly important jobs in Nottingham, Hull and Edinburgh. He brought together BR's shambolic southern commuter network before heading off to Scotland to run ScotRail in the dying days of the state-run industry. He was never an advocate of John Major's type of privatisation, but kept his mouth shut. "My view is that the industry should have been been kept intact and privatised as one unit. Tearing it apart was doomed to failure, and we have been picking up the pieces ever since."

After a brief unhappy period as chief executive of English Heritage, where he skirmished with its chairman, Sir Jocelyn Stevens, over his personal expenses, Green started out again as a railway consultant before being snapped up by Sir Richard. "His philosophy is simple. In this increasingly congested island, there must be a place for a dynamic rail system."

In his quieter moments, Green takes to the canals or goes hill walking in the Lakes. "On the canals, you just go at three miles an hour and there are no roads and certainly no trains. Only pleasant waterside pubs. It gives you a remarkably new perspective of what a beautiful country we live in."

Green is a stern opponent of throwing up the bricks and starting again. His "single leader" would work towards delivering a "joined up railway" helped by the 25 train companies. Petty commercial differences have kept them apart in the first few years of privatisation, preventing them from making sensible progress.

Now, said Green, they should act together and produce a joint marketing strategy and fares structure. The wide discrepancies on unregulated fares make this an urgent issue. John Prescott's call for the SRA to investigate the "grey area" of unregulated fares sounds impressive, but the government is in a helpless position without the cooperation of the train companies.

Lost art

Green's most important criticism of the railway is that it has lost "the art of delivery". He said that the industry had thrown away "the sergeant major of the track", the dedicated railwaymen who daily used to inspect a 10-mile length of track, and knew what was wrong. These men have gradually left the industry, disillusioned and forgotten. They have been replaced by "clever technology", dismissed by Green as "hardly out of the university experimental stage which are thrown at projects without being thoroughly tested".

The last week has been difficult for everyone at Virgin. Members of the government have gone on the offensive. Transport minister Lord Macdonald went as far as suggesting that passengers should boycott the company by switching to alternative means of transport: "It's really for passengers to look at it and say, 'well, can we get to Manchester more quickly by air or by coach or by car'." Green blamed "rail cancer" for the rises of up to 10%, and he sees little prospect of a quick fix. He is willing to listen to ideas - he is one of the leaders of Operation Rising Sun, a rail industry initiative to learn from the success of Japan's hi-tech network.

Anything to cure what he diagnosed last year as a "nervous breakdown" in the rail network, at the peak of Railtrack's post-Hatfield speed restrictions.

Virgin's public image was hardly helped by its bust-up with the Football Association over transport to last week's FA Cup semi-final between Arsenal and Spurs. The game was played at Old Trafford, which meant 67,000 Londoners wanted to make the trip north, but Virgin maintained it could only schedule one train, carrying 500 people. At the time, he accused the FA of failing to consult with the railway industry: "This really is a bad idea. The west coast main line is currently undergoing massive engineering works."

View from the ground

Green does his best to get a view from the ground - he recently ended up running the buffet while travelling on one Virgin train because of a shortage of catering staff. In a self-depreciating account of the experience, he told a newspaper that he had scalded himself and suffered a panic attack with mental arithmetic.

Mixing with the passengers is likely to be a bruising experience for the foreseeable future, with cheerful customers difficult to find. In November, Green predicted that it would take a year for the railway industry to recover from the crisis which followed the Hatfield train crash. He remarked: "If we can't get our act together, we deserve shooting at the end of this."

He insists that the industry cannot go on making mistakes indefinitely. His "single leader" - a sort of British Rail chairman mark two model - would knock heads together and, by using his knowledge and expertise, point the way to the sunnier uplands.

If this does not happen, Virgin would start cutting services and eventually staff. Ultimately the government would have to start running the industry again, once the private sector failed to achieve adequate returns. Green put it like this: "Being realistic, shareholders cannot be expected to pour money into a cash hole without understanding the solution."

Family Married with two children

Home Berkhamsted in Hertfordshire, from where he commutes by train to his office in Euston station

fields.headline: States of confusion
fields.trailText: • I'm just back from the States. They are very worried about foot and mouth there. At Denver airport I was subjected to a rigorous grilling by the immigration officer. "Have you been anywhere near a farm?" he asked, his eyes searching my face for scraps of straw, cow pats, sinister lesions, etc. "No!" I replied, quite honestly as it happened, though what would have occurred if I'd replied that I had spent the last few weeks having sex with infected sheep, I don't know. One young man who admitted to having been recently in the countryside was ushered into another room, possibly to be shot, or at least isolated for a month. It can't have encouraged people to be frank.
fields.body:
 I'm just back from the States. They are very worried about foot and mouth there. At Denver airport I was subjected to a rigorous grilling by the immigration officer. "Have you been anywhere near a farm?" he asked, his eyes searching my face for scraps of straw, cow pats, sinister lesions, etc. "No!" I replied, quite honestly as it happened, though what would have occurred if I'd replied that I had spent the last few weeks having sex with infected sheep, I don't know. One young man who admitted to having been recently in the countryside was ushered into another room, possibly to be shot, or at least isolated for a month. It can't have encouraged people to be frank.

Most Americans seem under the impression that our whole land is infested with a terrible, lethal plague and that normal life has become impossible for everyone. Meat, I kept being told, costs a fortune now, and the milk is too dangerous to drink. There's little point in telling them that this is not true, because people always prefer to believe what they read in the newspapers - thank heavens, as we newspaper people say.

Even the San Francisco Chronicle, which had an upbeat article saying that this was a good time to visit Britain, implied that a thick, stinking, greasy pall of smoke from burning animals covered the entire countryside. "Must be nice for you guys to eat beef," mused one man, as I tucked into some beef. He was the director of a leading international thinktank, so what the ordinary Joe in the street thinks I cannot imagine - though of course we should always remember that the average American doesn't think about Britain at all from the end of one decade to the next.

 The downturn in the stockmarket after the boom years is awfully noticeable. People are saving their money. The knick-knack shops where visitors like me go to buy useless but beautiful presents, such as a $6.99 (£4.85) miniature "tornado in a bottle", tend to be empty. There are more beggars now, and they are more demanding. Instead of the mournful cry of "Goddany cha-a-a-nge?", you get people saying crisply, "Hey, buddy, give me five dollars to buy food?" America is still stupefyingly rich, or at least a lot of Americans are, but there is a spooky chill at their backs, a whisper that the good times could vanish like steam from a subway grating. In Boulder, Colorado, the big row is over a vast Borders bookshop that has opened only a hundred yards away from the much loved Boulder Bookstore, and removed a small ice-rink that was in the way. There was a time when people would have mourned the loss of a bookshop to make way for an ice-rink, but these days chain bookshops are seen as just another corporate enemy, like Exxon or Nike.

 Everyone predicted that amazon.com would do away with all bookshops, and owners reported seeing customers who spent hours in their shops browsing, before going home to order a dozen volumes cut-price on the web. No longer. Bookshops sweep all before them. As with Starbucks, one suspects they will proliferate until there is one on every corner. Whether anyone reads the books is a different matter.

 On our last day in Colorado (I was with a colleague from the BBC making a couple of radio programmes about the grandiosely titled Conference on World Affairs, which is actually a marvellous piss-up interrupted by speeches - catch it on Radio 4 tomorrow at 10.45pm) a freak blizzard hit Denver airport, which is an all-weather airport in the sense that the Titanic was an unsinkable ship. Screaming gales landed a foot and a half of snow on the runways in twenty minutes, or so we were told. Our flight was due out in the late afternoon, but meanwhile the news got worse and worse. A note of panic crept in. This kind of thing is not supposed to happen in the States. "They're re-assessing at 12 o'clock and they might open the airport then," someone said. News came of drivers stuck for hours since wrecked cars were stopping the snow ploughs getting in. Someone reported that the local TV station said the airport would be closed all day. It was, I imagined, rather like Paris when the Wehrmacht was advancing, except that there was no way of getting out.

Though I badly needed to get home, a tiny corner of me rejoiced that even the hyper-efficient Americans can screw up now and again on a heroically British scale. Finally we made a run for the airport, which was almost deserted, except for the brisk and friendly BA staff who told us our incoming flight had arrived without any problems. We returned to Gatwick 20 minutes early.

 One panel I appeared on at the conference was called Books That Have Changed My Life, which I thought rather pompous, because it implies that one is the kind of person whose life is changed by books. (One of the other panellists was Roger Ebert, now America's leading film critic, who told us, apropos of nothing, that at the Cannes festival once he had asked a waiter in a fancy restaurant where the bathroom was. "Monsieur," the man expostulated, "ah have only one pair of hands.")

I told the audience the topic reminded me slightly of Desert Island Discs, which all British people want to appear on so that we can demonstrate our wide-ranging and eclectic tastes, from Beethoven to Van Morrison. My fantasy has always been that Sue Lawley says, "Simon, after your single-handed ascent of Mount Everest, you returned to England and discovered a cure for lung cancer."

"Yes, and a record which meant a great deal to me at this time, Sue, was Nellie the Elephant ... "

"Next you became special adviser to the Treasury, and you are credited with ending Britain's economic malaise and halving unemployment."

"Those were difficult times, Sue, but my wife and I were able to draw wonderful consolation from the work of Sheb Wooley. I'd like to hear once again that marvellous seminal work, The Purple People Eater ... "
