webTitle: Maff fails to meet slaughter targets

fields.headline: Maff fails to meet slaughter targets
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The government admitted for the first time last night that the slaughter programme to prevent the spread of foot and mouth is not working fast enough to meet its targets.
fields.body:
The government admitted for the first time last night that the slaughter programme to prevent the spread of foot and mouth is not working fast enough to meet its targets.

Figures released yesterday showed that the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food (Maff) was failing to keep up with the sheer weight of numbers involved. There were still 541,000 animals waiting to be killed and 408,000 carcasses waiting to be disposed of, the largest number since the beginning of the crisis and an increase of around 20,000 over the past week. So far 1.58m animals have been slaughtered or identified for slaughter.

The minister of agriculture, Nick Brown, admitted that although infected animals were being slaughtered within 24 hours of the disease being reported, the weight of numbers meant it was difficult to cull those on neighbouring farms within the required 48 hours. The secondary culling - crucial to create firebreaks - was happening only about 70% of the time.

Mr Brown told BBC Radio 4's The World at One: "One problem we have is that, although we are often able to make a start on it within the 48 hours, it is often very difficult to see it through to a conclusion because of the sheer volume of work."

Epidemiologists have based their most optimistic estimates of controlling the spread of the disease on all infected animals being killed within 24 hours and those on adjoining premises within 48 hours. Scientists from Imperial College, London, yesterday said nearly a third of British farms could be infected unless the firebreak culling of healthy cattle near infected sites was intensified.

"The 48 hour timescale is extremely difficult to achieve," a Maff official said yesterday. "There are a lot of difficulties meeting the targets. It would be astonishing if Devon, for instance, where there have been hundreds of contiguous cases in the past few days, was coming close to meeting the targets."

The battle against foot and mouth disease has become Britain's biggest combined civil and military exercise in more than 30 years, Brigadier Malcolm Wood, second in command of the operation to kill and bury millions of animals, said yesterday. "Nothing I have been involved with, including the Gulf war and Bosnia, compares to this. The scale is enormous," he added.

Almost 2,000 military personnel are involved in the fight against the disease, working alongside 1,700 vets.

Maff officials said the average daily number of confirmed foot and mouth cases fell by a quarter last week. In the seven-day period ending April 8, there was an average of 32 new cases each day compared with 43 in the previous week.

The government is finding it increasingly difficult to find new sites for disposal of animals. "We're not on top of the disposal," Maff admitted last night. Preparation work on a giant burial pit for animal carcasses is continuing in Devon over the weekend. The site at Ash Moor, near Petrockstowe, will be capable of taking more than 430,000 sheep carcasses.

Meanwhile the RSPCA was yesterday investigating a marksman's attempts to kill sheep as part of the cull in south Wales. Amateur video footage showed the local authority marksman taking potshots at the animals in a field and failing to kill at least one after several attempts.

The RSPCA said the video had "shocked and appalled" its officers and it might prosecute. "Yes, there is a crisis in the countryside, but it is not a licence for cruelty. No vet was present at this culling to ensure the animals did not suffer."

Mr Brown yesterday gave the strongest signal yet that he favours a limited vaccination programme, and has serious doubts about the scale of the culling and the continuing outbreaks. "The strategy I am attracted to is one which uses vaccination in order to ensure that the high value animals, the cattle, live on rather than are culled out, but vaccination is not a way of defeating the disease once it has occurred," he told Radio 4.

Potentially more damaging news came when a suspected case of swine fever was identified at a pig fattening unit, the Ministry of Agriculture said last night. The site in Ardleigh, near Colchester, Essex, has been sealed off and officials haveimposed movement restrictions, a spokeswoman said.

If tests on samples prove positive for classical swine fever, all animals at the unit will be slaughtered. More than 36,000 pigs were slaughtered after an outbreak of the infectious disease last August, the first in Britain for 14 years.

webTitle: Tourism minister flies into a storm

fields.headline: Tourism minister flies into a storm
fields.standfirst:
Special report: foot and mouth
Guardian Unlimited Politics
fields.trailText: Scotland's tourism minister last night flew back from Italy into a storm of protest over his holiday plans.
fields.body:
Scotland's tourism minister last night flew back from Italy into a storm of protest over his holiday plans.

Alasdair Morrison's trip to the continent has been attacked as grossly insensitive by opposition politicians and tourism officials at a time when the tourist industry and farming community are in crisis.

Mr Morrison, who had arranged the family break before the foot and mouth outbreak started, has expressed regret that his trip might have caused upset, but said he had done everything he could to help the tourist trade. He said he was returning home early to be with his father-in-law, who was seriously ill in hospital.

"If I have caused any offence to people working in tourism, then I certainly regret that," he said.

Last month, Mr Morrison told the Scottish parliament that he planned to spend his summer holidays in Skye and in Dumfries and Galloway, the region worst hit by foot and mouth.

He made no mention of the trip to Italy at Easter.

In America last week, he joined first minister Henry McLeish in urging US holiday makers to come to Scotland.

It has also emerged that a senior civil servant at the Scottish executive responsible for tourism and enterprise has been spending his Easter holidays at Euro Disney.

The Scottish National Party said Mr Morrison had shown "gross insensitivity" in going ahead with his Italian holiday.

Duncan Dewar, chief executive of the Fife-based tourist operations Days Away and Best of Scotland's Holidays, said Mr Morrison's decision was disgraceful.

"I think that it's extremely insensitive for a politician to do that. He's made a real gaffe," he said.

"It is ill-thought at a time when businesses are struggling to survive. I think he should sit down and give himself a long time to think about what he has done."

Scotland's tourist trade, which was in crisis even before the foot and mouth outbreak with a serious decline in overseas visitors, has been bracing itself for a further downturn since the start of the epidemic.

The tourism body Visitscotland said it estimated the outbreak would cost the industry north of the border £25m over the Easter fortnight and it projected there would be 80,000 fewer visitors than for the same period last year.

webTitle: Blair fails to convince on food safety

fields.headline: Blair fails to convince on food safety
fields.standfirst: 72% of public distrusts cajoling
fields.trailText: 72% of public distrusts cajoling.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is losing the battle to reassure voters about British produce, according to a new poll which reveals that three-quarters of the nation no longer trusts the government on the crucial issue of food safety.

Last year's exposure of the mass Whitehall BSE cover-up, together with vast public opposition to GM foods and anxiety about the foot and mouth crisis, has led 72% of the public - and 57% of Labour voters - to disregard ministers' blandishments, the ICM research suggests.

The findings, which appear in the Ecologist magazine, are likely to make uncomfortable reading for the prime minister, already aware of the cynicism surrounding "spin" and the levels of distrust surrounding farming methods, in the immediate run-up to the election campaign.

The research, conducted three and a half weeks ago as the foot and mouth epidemic escalated dramatically, also reveals the public are sceptical of the prime minister's claims to be "green" - despite him promising five weeks ago to make Britain a leading player in "the coming green industrial revolution". Mr Blair announced £100m of new money to support wind and solar power and pledged to ratify the Kyoto protocol before the end of next year.

Sixty-five per cent of the public believe Labour has done nothing to improve the environment since it came to power, mirroring the cries of opposition parties, which point to the fact Mr Blair made no speech on the environment for his first three and a half years in office.

The figures also reflect the words of his own chief environmental adviser, Jonathan Porritt, who last September accused the prime minister of "downgrading" green issues, despite promising in Labour's manifesto to put them "at the heart of government".

Two-thirds think there should be more emphasis on organic research - rather than GM foods, which gain 13 times as much government funding - and almost half (45%) believe there should be a ban on importing and testing GM crops in Britain.

In a further embarrassment for the government, three-quarters of those surveyed believe Britain's beleaguered railway should be re-nationalised. Support is cross-party, with two-thirds of Tory voters calling for privatisation to be reversed, despite the Thatcher government having introduced it.

But, with Railtrack due to bring havoc today with its most extensive Easter engineering programme "for decades", ministers are adamant re-nationalisation is not an option.

"The government has always said it would be too expensive and the money is better spent on priorities such as health and education," said a Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions spokeswoman last night.

Commenting on the survey of 1,000 adults, Charles Secrett, director of Friends of the Earth, said: "Labour ignores this poll result at its peril." The magazine's editor, Zac Goldsmith, added: "This is a picture of a public which cares a lot about issues that don't even appear on the radar screens of most politicians."

Last night opposition parties were quick to capitalise on the government's perceived lack of delivery on environmental issues. "The environment's always been seen as an add-on by the government, a luxury," claimed Damian Green, the shadow environment minister.

"What we've seen is a pattern of three and a half years of doing nothing about the environment followed by six months of intense action and these days people are a bit too cynical to accept that. It's seen as too little, too late."

"They've achieved some things but fallen very far of their original claim to put the environment at the heart of their government," said Don Foster, the environment spokesman for the Liberal Democrats.

A Labour party spokesman said: "We don't comment on polls but, as the prime minister's recent speech [to the [WWF] shows, he is fully committed to environmental protection and environmental policies."

webTitle: Monarchy: Common touch and lack of flummery  keep sleaze and scandal at bay

fields.headline: Common touch and lack of flummery  keep sleaze and scandal at bay
fields.standfirst:
Other monarchies may have more power and money than ours, but they have adapted better

Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Other monarchies may have more power and money than ours, but they have adapted better
fields.body:
Royal families are thicker on the ground in Europe than anywhere else in the world. Seven of the 15 states of the European Union are monarchies, if you include the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg. And then there are Norway and Monaco, not to mention the claimants to the ancient thrones of much of eastern Europe.

None of them, however, are quite as pretentious as Britain's royal family - and none are anywhere near as uneasy in their crowns.

When the Prince of Wales once remarked that the Scandinavian monarchies were "grander and more pompous" than the house of Windsor, their royal families were somewhat surprised, to put it mildly. Britain's royals do tend to look down on their continental cousins. Only this week a Buckingham Palace official mused: "You can't compare our royal family with Norway's. They have only got 4m people and we've also got the Commonwealth."

But although some continental monarchies have more powers than ours, some even receive per capita more money, and none endures the same obsessive, intrusive media scrutiny, theirs have been much more successful in keeping up with the temper of the times.

Younger sons may serve in the armed forces, as Prince Andrew has, but many of them retreat into private business. And royal dynasties in Europe are confined to the immediate family - spouses, sons and daughters. There is no equivalent of Prince and Princess Michael of Kent, who, the Guardian disclosed yesterday, have undertaken 20 trips in the past 15 months in pursuit of their private and commercial activities, receiving VIP airport treatment.

Nor do foreign palaces tend to be made over to relatives of the royal family in the way that Kensington Palace has become what was once described as "a subsidised chalet for redundant royals".

Other European royal families do not insist on the flummery and deference of Britain's royals.

The king of Norway can be seen queueing to get into the cinema; no king of Sweden has gone through a coronation since the mid-19th century; the king of Spain has the use of eight palaces, but owns none of them.

Through a mixture of good fortune and common sense, the monarchies of Europe are much more popular with their populations than Britain's is.

They have pulled off the trick of appearing to be just regular folks, even if they are richer even than our royal family (Queen Beatrix is estimated to be worth more than £3bn) or have privileges such as those enjoyed by the Danes, who are still exempt from taxation and have a taxpayer-subsidised yacht.

European royal families do not have business guidelines, such as Britain's are drawing up. But their powers are controlled by written constitutions - Belgium's king is nominally selected by parliament and, although he signs all laws they also have to be countersigned by ministers.

They even abdicate when they feel themselves getting too old these days, too - as Grand Duke Jean of Luxembourg did last year.

Their children these days generally go to state schools and marry commoners, and most expect to work for a living.

The expectations of their subjects are more relaxed and less frenetic than ours, too: when Crown Prince Haakon of Norway moved in with his ex-drug-taking, waitress girlfriend and her three-year-old son, no one turned a hair. Imagine what the News of the World would have made of that.

webTitle: Mr Euro on schedule for date with destiny

fields.headline: Mr Euro on schedule for date with destiny
fields.standfirst:
Single currency sceptics rebuffed

Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Single currency sceptics rebuffed.
fields.body:
This time next year, the French franc and 10 other mainstream European currencies will be history, usurped by 15bn euro banknotes and 56bn euro coins. For all the hype, the changeover is likely to be unspectacular. But for Belgium's elfin finance minister, Didier Reynders, it will be the culmination of a year's work and the realisation of a dream.

Reynders, chairman of the increasingly powerful 12-nation euro group, has already started digging the graves of the drachma and the German mark.

Wim Duisenberg, the wild-looking president of the European Central Bank, and Pedro Solbes, the whispering commissioner for monetary affairs, can also lay claim to the epithet of Mr Euro. But the tough-talking Belgian wins hands down for he, more than the other two, is the single currency's proselytiser-in-chief.

Reynders breathes and sleeps the euro and has travelled the world singing its praises and explaining how it will work - to the Czechs, the Turks, the Hungarians and anyone else who will listen.

On the stroke of one o'clock every day he consults the euro's exchange rate on his flash mobile phone and checks the price of oil. He's keen.

One of his ideas - to give the euro group political clout to counterbalance the ECB in Frankfurt - has set alarm bells ringing in Britain.

Treasury mandarins and some of Gordon Brown's closest advisers fear that giving more power to the euro 12 will inevitably be at the expense of the "outs". But, Reynders argues, the euro is not a closed shop.

"All those who want to join the euro can do so provided they meet the necessary economic criteria." The real step change, when the "outs" are jilted and left stand ing in a lay-by will, he hints, not happen for a year or two.

He makes no secret of the fact that there will be a definite cut-off point. "There is a limit and the moment will come when we need to know what the organisation [of the euro zone] will be. "We're convinced it will allow us to better integrate the EU."

When it comes to Brussels micro-managing countries' budgets to ensure that they stay in line with special EU guidelines, Reynders is also a big fan.

"This was not a case of the EU imposing its will on a small country.

"Every member state agreed to this approach when they signed up to the broad economic guidelines. Different countries' budgets should, ideally, be debated [by euro group finance ministers] before any national decision is taken."

Reynders has a reputation as being "brilliant but glacial" and he talks with authority about what the future holds for the euro. He is not, however, remotely glacial, although it is true that he does not mince his words.

Duisenberg, the ECB supremo, discovered this to his cost last year when he missed an informal meeting of finance ministers in Versailles at a time when the euro was in free fall and in desperate need of some kind of verbal support.

Reynders was the only European finance minister to publicly criticise him. He called Duisenberg's absence "unacceptable" - and earned himself a reputation as a tough talker.

That Reynders, a lawyer by training, finds himself in such an influential position is perhaps not surprising. For years he has been Belgium's homegrown wunderkind, the one who at 27 found himself in the top job at the national rail company SNCB/NMBS. After that, he held the top slot at national airline, Sabena, and he has presided over his own party, the PRL (francophone liberals).

Coming from one of the world's most federal states, Reynders is unashamedly federalist in his outlook. He happily chats about his ideas for further EU integration: a directly elected president of the European commission, a single, EU-wide tax to fund the institutions in Brussels and some kind of vague political authority for his own beloved euro group are among the ideas he defends.

"The tax would be for financing the EU institutions. It is natural for the European institutions to have tax-raising powers since when you have political power you must have fiscal powers. Otherwise it looks like Europe decides policy but member states foot the bill for it."

Such a system would not, he stresses, replace national taxes but complement them.

A lover of red wine, golf, the cinema and books, Reynders relaxes by staying at a farmhouse he owns in the rolling hills of French-speaking Wallonia. Married to a lawyer, Bernadette, with whom he he has four children.

If managing the launch of the euro was not enough to keep him up at night, he is also working on a radical overhaul of the Belgian tax system. Friends say he wants to be the only Belgian finance minister in living memory to have cut taxes.

But for Reynders it is clear that the euro is his inspiration - and come E-day on January 1, 2002, he will be toasting the single currency with a glass of his favourite Bordeaux.

webTitle: Fluffies on the run as spikies win battle of the streets

fields.headline: Fluffies on the run as spikies win battle of the streets
fields.standfirst:
May Day mayhem? Threats of violence deter peaceful protesters

Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: May Day mayhem?  After bitter feuding between "fluffies" and "spikies" (pro-peaceful and pro-violent) over tactics and ideology, a winner seems to have emerged.
fields.body:
The seeds of mass dissent were planted in vibrant road protests and squats, in opposition to GM foods and concern about quality of life in cities. They grew in giant carnival-style events in busy shopping streets and on motorways around the UK. They flourished around the world. They peaked in anti-globalisation demonstrations in Washington, Seattle and Prague, but the British anti-capitalist movement has been poisoned so deeply by hardliners intent on violence that it may never recover its popular appeal.

Now, after bitter feuding between "fluffies" and "spikies" (pro-peaceful and pro-violent) over tactics and ideology, a winner seems to have emerged. "The party's over," says one north London man who has been deeply involved in organising events, thought of himself as a moderate but will not take part in this year's May Day events in London.

Hijacked by thugs

According to many people involved in last May Day's digging up of Parliament Square by Reclaim the Streets to plant vegetables, and the later demonstrations in Trafalgar Square, the organisation of mass protest against third world debt, globalisation and the banking system has finally been hijacked by "thugs" who only want to attract peaceful protesters as a front for their destruction of property and confrontations with the police.

Reclaim the Streets (RTS) is now divided, with many of its leading thinkers and most experienced organisers disaffected, and hundreds of people who might have come to London on May 1 have been deterred by the change in direction.

Two additional factors suggest that this year's May Day event will not attract such large numbers as before. There is a widespread fear of oppressive policing: Scotland Yard announced on Thursday a high-risk "zero tolerance" approach to troublemakers. And untested legislation that could class protesters against ideological issues as terrorists will also drastically reduce the numbers involved.

With police and potential protesters themselves deeply unclear as to what will happen on May Day, the best estimates so far are that fewer than 2,000 people will take to the streets for a series of actions billed widely as "May Day Monopoly". Police believe at least half of them intend to cause chaos. In previous years up to 15,000 people have come from all over the country.

Through websites and a detailed pamphlet, people are being encouraged to take "autonomous" DIY actions against symbols of capitalism around London, with a showdown expected in Oxford Street in the afternoon of the Tuesday bank holiday. Without being an explicit call to arms, the subtext is clear. Every potential target is named - from McDonald's to the Royal Opera House.

Alienation

The shift has alienated hundreds of people who would have come to demonstrate peacefully. "There's been a virtual war between the fluffies and the spikies," said one man who was arrested but not charged in last year's May Day disturbances. "The spikies have won. I have sympathised completely with the protests so far. They have been fun and made good political points, but now they seem to want to get straight in.It has been taken over by the thugs".

Others agree, angry that mass protest organisers do not want to talk to the press or communicate their message more widely.

"The carnival is over. We're going back to old class war and fringe anarchist days. I went to a meeting a few weeks ago and the bottom line was just destroy property," said Chris Turnbull, a north Londoner who used to be involved with Reclaim the Streets.

"I am totally disillusioned. They've lost their focus, their sense of play and vision. The only ideology now seems to be destruction. The only images they want are ones of violence."

Several people who worked with RTS have in effect been excommunicated from the loosely knit organisation that in the past seven years has been responsible for a number of huge street parties and demonstrations.

"There has been a witch hunt. People have been pilloried for standing up, just talking to the press or trying to explain to the public why people were demonstrating. The real organisation has become internecine, secret, exclusive and authoritarian," said one woman. "They talk about equality and justice, but the reality is that there has been a pogrom."

The deliberate lack of structure is deeply confusing to the police. "Basically anyone who wants to organise something on May Day can call themselves what they want and do it," says Dave, who has been involved in radical street politics for seven years. "In the past people have gone under the umbrella term of Reclaim the Streets, but this is changing, too. They're advertising it as a fun day out, but I wouldn't take my family as I did last year."

RTS was never a formal organisation, one reason why the police, with their strict ranks and layers of bureaucracy, found it so hard to comprehend. But since the mayhem in Westminster last year, which led to the prime minister declaring that such behaviour must never happen again, undercover special branch officers have been desperately trying to gather more reliable intelligence, even asking disaffected RTS people to grass on their former friends. They have given no information.

Some of what the police have discovered chimes with the views of the veteran demonstrators. "We know we're not dealing with Reclaim the Streets any more," said one senior officer. "We seem to have a new, tougher breed on our hands.

"Their aim is violence against property and police officers because that is the best way to get media attention. Some people who were encouraging violence within RTS have fanned out and started their own loosely knit organisations, but we don't know what support, if any, they have."

Special branch has been taking a long, hard look at the Anarchist Federation, Solidarity Federation, the Birmingham Section 26 Collective and the Urban Alliance. Two weeks ago, the Met raided an empty factory in Brixton, south-west London, which was supposedly a secret training camp for another radical group, the Wombles - "White Overall Movement Building Liberation Through Effective Struggle".

Wombles

The Wombles style themselves on Ya Basta!, a highly disciplined and principled non-violent direct action Italian support group for the Zapatista rebels in Mexico. Wearing all white and using water pistols and mock weapons, Ya Basta! march with foam battering rams to pass through police lines.

Prominent in Prague at the IMF/World Bank conference, they impressed many British activists who are thought to have have copied the idea. The British version of Ya Basta! has no formal connection with the Zapatistas.

In one sense, the discovery was a coup for Scotland Yard. But although one white overall was found, and some graffiti ("Smash Police Skull"), there was little else to suggest it was a current training camp.

The Wombles, whoever they are, had moved on. One protester, who claimed to be a Womble, was withering about the police raid. "If we wanted violence, we wouldn't be marching on May Day with water pistols, inflatable hammers and a 50ft inflatable Uncle Bulgaria," the protester said.

"Even our name was a piss-take, but the fact that they are taking us so seriously is a joke on them. When they talk about sinister hardcore paramilitary Wombles, they look ridiculous."

The police are not giving too much away at this stage. They have "an intelligence picture", built up by covert operations led by Special Branch and MI5, but do not know how accurate or clear it is.

The Met's assistant commissioner Mike Todd, who is in overall charge of May Day policing this year, was candid enough to admit this week that none of the ringleaders of last year's trouble had been caught.

There is concern that the protests that have been heavily flagged on the internet and in the May Day Monopoly game guide pamphlet will not be the focus of any trouble.

"Is there a hidden agenda?", said an officer. "We don't think so. But we cannot be sure."

By sabre-rattling at this stage, the police are hoping to make trouble-makers think twice before coming at all.

"We have intelligence on certain individuals who we think are pulling the strings behind the scenes, but we do not have evidence," said one officer.

"We think we know who they are. Intelligence can help us prepare, but it won't get someone arrested. Intelligence can also be wrong. We won't really know what we're dealing with until the day."

On the road to violence

May 14 1995 500 anti-road protesters take over a half-mile stretch of Camden High Street in north London for a giant open-air party as part of a campaign to reclaim the streets for pedestrians and cyclists. Police arrest three people for public order offences

July 23 1995 A lunchtime protest takes over Upper Street, Islington, one of north London's busiest roads. By early evening riot police move in to clear the road and sporadic fights break out as the 200 protesters are driven towards King's Cross station. Windows are smashed and bottles and cans are thrown at police as the protesters flee the area

July 13 1996 Thousands of road protesters create traffic chaos in west London by holding a mass street party on the M41 at Shepherd's Bush. Activists set up 20ft-high steel tripods to block approaches to the M41 from the A40 Westway into central London

August 24 1996 Eighty people are arrested as hundreds of police in riot gear clash with anti-road protesters on the Brighton seafront. Police foil an attempt by Reclaim the Streets to hold a street party in the middle of the East Sussex seaside town, seizing sound equipment, a van full of scaffolding poles, and an uninflated bouncy castle

June 18 1999 Violence flares in the heart of the City of London as 4,000 protesters descend for the "carnival against capitalism". Police are attacked with bricks and concrete blocks and £2m worth of damage is caused to shops and offices. Eight demonstrators enter Lloyds Bank in Cheapside and some chain themselves inside

May 1 2000 Five thousand people attend a largely peaceful "guerrilla gardening" event in central London, planting flowers and building ponds in Parliament Square. Violence erupts when anarchist protesters attack a McDonald's restaurant and there are sporadic clashes with riot police across the city. Churchill's statue is daubed with red paint and a mohican "haircut" of turf is placed on the wartime leader's head

Laura Milne

webTitle: White's week: Jim White tracks down Tim Henman's former coach

fields.headline: White's week
fields.standfirst: Jim White tracks down Tim Henman's former coach
fields.trailText: Jim White tracks down Tim Henman's former coach
fields.body:
As weeks go, this last one has not been David Felgate's best. For nine years he was involved at the top of tennis, at its very pinnacle, his every moment dedicated to the preparation of Britain's No1 player Tim Henman. Together they celebrated seven titles as the player Felgate had spotted as a teenager became the most significant British performer for a generation.

Then, last Monday, it was announced that Henman and he were parting company. He was now an ex-coach. Thus this week, instead of handing out advice and bananas at the side of the court, he has found himself on the sofa at home, flicking through Teletext to check on how the player he had once thought of as his boy was performing. The words "by mutual consent" were used in the announcement of their split - a euphemism, we can only assume.

"Not at all," says Felgate when I tracked him down to his home this week, where he was presumably hoping for a more exciting phone call than one from a nosy journalist. "We felt it was the right decision for everyone."

Which, as an assessment from someone who has effectively received his P45, veers on the manic side of positive.

"Have you ever had that feeling in the stomach when you know something's right?" he adds. "Well, it was like that. Look, Tim and I got on really, really well. Still do. It is a very intense relationship between a tennis player and a coach; we probably saw more of each other than we did of our wives. But we had been talking for more than six months and, although the subject of a break wasn't actually raised, we knew that was what was on each other's minds. It was right."

And so, on Sunday, after Great Britain's Davis Cup match with Portugal, they split. But while the parting may have been amicable, it was by no means equitable. Henman carried on playing, winning his first match without a coach at the Estoril Open on Tuesday. For Felgate everything was different. He was unemployed.

"I'm sure he will have found it strange too, without me at the courtside," Felgate says. "But you have to remember that it is just tennis. Yes, of course it was an emotional relationship, intense, all those things. But I still have my health and my marriage."

Still, how does Felgate feel about those within tennis who thought the split was not before time? John McEnroe, for instance, after Henman had lost in the first round of the US Open in 1999, was unequivocal in his advice: if the player wanted to go on and dominate tournaments, he was going to have to ditch Felgate. And, if he could not dismiss a man who was his oldest friend in tennis, then the coach should recognise his shortcomings, do the honourable thing and walk away.

"Most people are good at criticising when a match has been lost," he says, volleying the McEnroe verbal forehand. "I've always been a firm believer that coaches coach and players play. I wasn't much of a player. John was a great. But then he didn't have huge success as America's Davis Cup coach, did he? No, people are entitled to opinions. I only get upset when they get the facts wrong."

Felgate seems remarkably chipper, a commercial for the advice he always gave his player: think positive. The hard times, though, may be to come. Henman might go on to win Wimbledon. And the first thing a thousand commentators will suggest is that McEnroe's advice was bang on target: the player won because he ditched his coach.

"And they'd be right," says Felgate. "As I say, I prefer facts. And, if he wins Wimbledon, it would be a fact that he made the right decision to break with me."

And if he does not?

"Well, it wouldn't mean he made the wrong one. There are many factors involved."

Whatever Henman does in the future - win, lose or lose again - he knows where he is going: back on court. For Felgate, his long-time partner on the line, things are less clear.

"I've had some offers," he says. "But it has to be right. The relationship between a player and his coach is so delicate, you have to be sure."

And, if he needs any help finding someone else to nurture, Felgate could always seek the assistance of his wife, Jan. She is a players' agent, though one of her clients may not be of much use right now. It is Tim Henman.

webTitle: US claims crew's story shows China was at fault

fields.headline: US claims crew's story shows China was at fault
fields.standfirst:
Special report: China
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The United States adopted a markedly more aggressive stance towards China yesterday over the circumstances of the mid-air spy plane collision and future Sino-US ties following the 11-day standoff.
fields.body:
The United States adopted a markedly more aggressive stance towards China yesterday over the circumstances of the mid-air spy plane collision and future Sino-US ties following the 11-day standoff.

With the 24 crew members now back in the US - they fly to Washington state later today for a reunion with their relatives - American officials began to give a very different version of the incident from the one put out by Beijing.

The defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, said yesterday that the spy plane was flying straight and level until a Chinese fighter pilot, "manoeuvring aggressively" in the skies above the South China sea, struck the US aircraft from below. He said Chinese pilots had been buzzing US planes for months.

Contradicting Chinese reports, Mr Rumsfeld said the crew attempted to issue 25-30 Mayday signals and landed in distress. He said the crew was greeted by armed Chinese troops.

"The Chinese pilots have been manoeuvring aggressively against our pilots for months," he said, citing 44 recent cases. "The F-8 pilot clearly put at risk the lives of 24 Americans."

Mr Rumsfeld also said a major portion of the sensitive data and equipment on board had been destroyed by the US crew, as they are trained to do.

He added that Chinese officials were armed when they "invited the crew off the aircraft". Showing some diplomacy, Mr Rumsfeld said: "I don't know that their guns were even taken out of the holsters."

The US decision to challenge the Chinese version of events so promptly came after President George Bush, in remarks at the White House on Thursday, adopted an abrasive tone largely rejected by the US while the crew remained in China.

The dispute did "not advance a constructive relationship" between the two countries, Mr Bush said. Detaining the crew was "inconsistent" with a positive relationship between the US and China.

Both countries now had to make "a determined choice to have a productive relationship".

The two sides are due to meet to discuss the details of the April 1 incident and its implications on Wednesday.

Claiming to speak on the basis of early debriefings with the returned crew, an official told the Washington Post that a Chinese fighter had caused the accident by clipping an engine on the EP-3 spy plane.

The US plane very nearly plunged into the South China sea, the official said. The Chinese fighter was less fortunate.

The US officials said that they were now "more convinced than before that the Chinese pilot caused the accident. The US plane was flying on autopilot at the time of the clash and was on a straight and level course in clear visibility".

China contends that the US plane veered to the left, colliding with the Chinese F-8 jet.

"There was no sudden turn," a Pentagon official said. Instead the F-8 made two passes of the spy plane, coming within three to five feet of its left wing.

"On the third pass, he came in too fast. He tried to decelerate by bringing up his nose, which would bleed off speed. But when that happened, he lost some fine control and his tail came up under the No 1 propeller."

The collision with the propellor broke the F-8 into two pieces and debris smashed into the nose of the EP-3, causing the cone to break off and hit a second propeller on the right wing. These incidents tipped the EP-3 on its side for a period until the pilot regained control and landed on Hainan island.

"Our assessment is this wasn't a deliberate act in any way of coming out to try to ram the EP-3, it was a rendezvous that was not accomplished very well," said a US diplomat in Beijing yesterday.

China has repeatedly said that the crippled plane had violated its airspace by landing on Hainan without permission.

But the diplomat said that the pilot had sent out distress calls on frequencies used by all aircraft. "Aircraft and towers are supposed to monitor the guard frequencies all the time to listen up for aircraft in distress," the diplomat said.

fields.headline: Japanese gloom deepens
fields.standfirst:
Declining exports and threat of further bankruptcies signal fresh downturn

Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: Declining exports and threat of further bankruptcies signal fresh downturn.
fields.body:
The Japanese government issued its gloomiest assessment yet on the state of its ailing economy yesterday, warning that exports are contracting fast and that a fresh downturn is now a real possibility.

Downgrading its assessment on everything from housing to business sentiment for the third consecutive month, the report on the world's second-largest economy used the word "weakening" for the first time in almost six years.

"Japanese exports have faltered, resulting in a decline in production," the government said, adding that in February, export growth slowed to just 1.3% from a year earlier, while imports were up 11.5%.

"The economy is weakening, reflecting the slowdown of the US economy."

Unemployment is running at 4.7%, just below a record 4.9%, and worries of further contraction in the jobs market have been fuelled by fresh news that capital spending by companies is falling fast.

The government's assessment coincided with a report from a local research company, Teikoku Databank, which said that debts from companies which have collapsed over the past year have soared to a post-war record of 26 trillion yen (£146bn) - up 130% in 12 months.

These include catastrophic failures such as the insurance company Kyoei Life in October, which by then had run up liabilities of ¥4.5 trillion.

Teikoku predicted that any further contraction of the economy would lead to a fresh wave of bankruptcies as Japan's teetering banking sector came under renewed pressure to call in underperforming loans.

Last week, the government announced a package aimed at helping banks to tackle their long-standing bad loan problem.

This included a plan to reduce the vulnerability of banks to stock market fluctuations by setting up a fund to buy part of their vast shareholdings.

As expected, the Bank of Japan announced it was leaving its monetary policy unchanged yesterday, following last month's decision to cut interest rates to zero.

Yet the effective abolition of borrowing costs has not had any discernable effect on economic activity.

Japan's money supply fell 0.4% in March month on month after surging 6.1% in February. At the same time, the central bank promised to pump more money into the system if there were any further signs of instability on Tokyo's financial markets.

Analysts have noted that the Bank of Japan has all but exhausted its monetary tools and that only fiscal measures are likely to have any real impact from here.

Meanwhile, the central bank has become increasingly vocal in its calls for the government to adopt a much more aggressive approach towards structural reform.

Economics minister Taro Aso tacitly admitted that a slide back into recession was a real possibility.

"If the economy worsens rapidly due to US economic conditions, and there are signs it could contract, we should not hesitate to carry out an extra budget," he was quoted as saying, indicating that Japan may held an emergency budget if conditions continue to deteriorate.

Mr Aso is one of four men vying for the leadership of the ruling liberal democratic party and to take over from Yoshiro Miro as prime minister.

The economy is the main election battleground.

fields.headline: Water tests halt sheep burials
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Transport of sheep carcasses to a burial trench 1,000ft up a Welsh mountain has been halted following the threat of an injunction from a group concerned about possible river pollution.
fields.body:
Transport of sheep carcasses to a burial trench 1,000ft up a Welsh mountain has been halted following the threat of an injunction from a group concerned about possible river pollution.

Truck movements to the site on the Epynt military range at Trecastle, near Brecon, will not begin again until Tuesday at the earliest.

More than 6,000 sheep carcasses have already been dumped in a huge burial trench. But tests carried out this week, just five days after the burials began, showed traces of ammonia.

The contamination was discussed at an emergency meeting of the Welsh assembly's agriculture committee which accepted the recommendation of agency officials that the trench be lined with a protective covering.

An assembly spokeswoman said sheep already buried would be "shuffled" round the trench. "It is not an insurmountable problem and will not stop the cull," she added. But local protesters, who have maintained a picket outside the community centre in Trecastle, threatened court action, fearing pollution of the Usk and the Towy.

webTitle: Jeb asks brother George to let Florida ignore water rules

fields.headline: Jeb asks brother George to let Florida ignore water rules
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Governor Jeb Bush has written to his brother, President George Bush, asking him to suspend federal environmental regulations which ensure that Florida has safe drinking water.
fields.body:
Governor Jeb Bush has written to his brother, President George Bush, asking him to suspend federal environmental regulations which ensure that Florida has safe drinking water.

Rapid population growth in the low-lying state, which now has 16 million inhabitants and low levels of underground fresh water, will cause a serious risk of water shortages in Florida unless the restrictions are lifted, Governor Bush says.

State officials want to allow billions of gallons of untreated and partly contaminated rain and river water to be injected underground to help form underground reservoirs.

Such action would save Florida millions of dollars in water treatment costs, although officials say "extensive precautions" would be taken to avoid any health danger.

If the plan goes ahead, however, the federal government's environmental protection agency would have to waive rules which require that any water pumped into the ground must first be treated to meet drinking water standards.

In his letter, Jeb Bush called the requirement "nonsensical". He said the stored water would be treated before it was fed into the drinking water system and asked for "a willingness to abandon conventional processes as long as the environmental results are achieved".

Opponents say the governor's plan risks feeding untested water into private wells, where drinking water is not always treated and that the pumping process risks creating unforeseen hazards.

"This is something that really has not been studied yet with respect to the injection of untreated surface water. I think the state could be opening the door to a lot of problems," said John Vecchioli of the US geological service.

Florida's population is projected to reach more than 20m by 2020 and experts say that the state faces a water deficit of up to 30 per cent by then.

The state has suffered a succession of droughts, the worst in half a century.

Such action would save Florida millions of dollars in water treatment costs, although officials say "extensive precautions" would be taken to avoid any health danger. If the plan goes ahead, however, the federal government's environmental protection agency would have to waive rules which require that any water pumped into the ground must first be treated to meet drinking water standards. In his letter, Jeb Bush called the requirement "nonsensical". He said the stored water would be treated before it was fed into the drinking water system and asked for "a willingness to abandon conventional processes as long as the environmental results are achieved". Opponents say the governor's plan risks feeding untested water into private wells, where drinking water is not always treated and that the pumping process risks creating unforeseen hazards. "This is something that really has not been studied yet with respect to the injection of untreated surface water. I think the state could be opening the door to a lot of problems," said John Vecchioli of the US geological service. Florida's population is projected to reach more than 20m by 2020 and experts say that the state faces a water deficit of up to 30 per cent by then. The state has suffered a succession of droughts, the worst in half a century.

webTitle: Going bananas over fate of the metric martyr

fields.headline: Going bananas over fate of the metric martyr
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: The case of the metric martyr, as he has become known to Eurosceptics and Europhiles alike, is a wonderful metaphor for the whole European debate and its coverage in the national press.
fields.body:
The case of the metric martyr, as he has become known to Eurosceptics and Europhiles alike, is a wonderful metaphor for the whole European debate and its coverage in the national press.

This week's conviction of Steve Thoburn, the Sunderland market trader who insisted on weighing his bananas on a pounds-and-ounces-only scale, left every newspaper showing its true colours. Here we have the classic European issue: trivial, emotive, fundamental, inevitable, defining and ridiculous. It depends on where you come from.

Here we have sceptic papers giving the issue more importance than the single currency, and Europhile newspapers covering the story but avoiding comment because deep down they know it is an issue on which the great majority of the population agrees. Irrespective of your position on the euro, further European integration, or the rapid reaction force, it can hardly be sensible, or helpful in convincing the public of the merits of the EU, to bring court cases against a greengrocer for selling a pound of bananas.

The sceptic press did not, of course, treat the case as risible. Rather it was a symbol of all that was wrong with Europe, and the reason we should never join the single currency. No matter that we agreed long ago to join the single weights and measures. As is often the case with these high profile inconsequential euro-issues, there was saturation, confident, coverage in the sceptic press, slightly apologetic treatment in the euro-supportive press.

The Daily Mail was characteristically apocalyptic: the implications of the Sunderland court ruling were "so immense they may take a long time to sink in". The headline crystallised the immensity. "The day selling a pound of bananas became a crime like burglary or rape. The will of the people counts for nothing." It should be said, in view of the rape comparison, that Thoburn was not sentenced to life, or indeed any custodial term.

The Sun was no less enraged. "This is a sad day for Britain," it said. "We can now see that the wishes of the people and parliament come second best. What the EU wants, the EU gets. No one voted for pounds and ounces to be made illegal. Kilos and grammes have been imposed on us by Brussels bureaucrats. How they would love to do that with the euro too."

And the broadsheet third of the sceptic troika, the Daily Telegraph, was trembling with rage. The conviction was "outrageous on so many levels that it is difficult to know where to begin", it spluttered. We never asked for metric measures. Parliament never debated them.

But worse than anything was the "sheer nastiness" of the case. Sunderland has demonstrated a "peculiar blend of cowardice and viciousness that sometimes characterises municipal Britain in its dealings with the little man".

Even the Mirror, consistently loyal to the government and pro-European, had to argue the pointlessness of bringing an "always ridiculous" case. "It should never have been brought because it gave publicity to an absurd man fighting an absurd case. Eventually, most people will buy things in metric quantities because that is what children are taught in schools. There are really vital issues over Europe. How fruit is weighed is not one of them."

You had a sneaking feeling the Mirror readership might disagree. Which is why the prosecution was so unhelpful to those struggling to support the European cause.

The Express, which seldom mentions any aspect of Europe, made just this point. "Is this example of the bureaucratic mind run rampant really any way to win the British people round to the joys of European integration?" it asked rhetorically.

The Financial Times, measured and supportive over matters Europe, dismissed "metric martyr" as a tabloid term and then proceeded to use it twice itself. It emphasised the political dimension and remarked that Thoburn "could now find himself an icon of the forthcoming general election campaign".

The Conservatives were planning to use the "Sunderland one" in party political broadcasts, and Alan Duncan, the trade spokesman, had been to visit Thoburn. The FT quoted the leader of Labour's MEPs as saying Thoburn had been "used shamelessly" by the Conservatives to "stir up anti-European feeling".

The Times carried an article by its legal editor which demonstrated that this absurd case really did go to the heart of the sovereignty issue. The judge in the Sunderland case had said it would "destroy the concept of a union when member states could go off on legislative frolics on their own".

 Peter Cole is professor of journalism at Sheffield University

fields.headline: UK workforce attacks Amazon
fields.standfirst:
Biggest online store accused over wages and conditions

More internet news
fields.trailText: Biggest online store accused over wages and conditions.
fields.body:
Amazon.com was last night accused of operating the worst of old economy working practices at a giant warehouse dispatching books, music, DVDs and other goods bought over the internet across Britain.

Staff working for the world's biggest e-commerce trader at its Marston Gate depot near Milton Keynes have made a series of complaints to the Guardian about wages and conditions in the company.

The singer-songwriter Billy Bragg is threatening to organise a boycott of Amazon and the GPMU print and paper union, which has launched a recruitment drive at the site, will next week ask Acas, the advisory, conciliation and arbitration service, to intervene.

Union organiser Peter Lockhart said: "Behind the shiny facade of Amazon and the internet are poor pay, poor conditions, poor communications and poor management. It is anything but 'new age' inside that distribution centre."

The US firm, trading in Britain as Amazon.co.uk, yesterday strongly denied the allegations and said pay rates were comparable with those of other firms in the area.

"We are a hugely open and democratic company and we believe we do the very best for our employees," a spokeswoman said.

But GPMU officials believe the discontent explodes the myth of a groovier dot.com capitalism behind the technological slickness of online shopping with its discounts and home deliveries.

A number of workers who spoke on condition that their identities were not disclosed were highly critical of conditions in the giant green and white depot 200 yards from junction 13 on the M1.

According to employees, supervisors known as "leads" and managers continually clock-watch staff. One employee claimed that they shout at those who fail to meet demanding targets.

Staff say strict quotas are imposed with a "picker" forced to select three items a minute from the warehouse's shelves and a "packer" to parcel an average 2.5 orders a minute.

One employee claimed they were required to push a trolley for what felt like up to 20 miles in a night to fill it with books and CDs named on computer-printed lists. The company said the distance was "nowhere like that".

The 11-hour night shift stretching from 7.30pm to 6.30am includes an unpaid one-hour meal break at 1am and Marston Gate has no canteen, staff taking in their own food or using vending machines. Two shorter rest periods, however, are paid.

The union said a standard 23 days' holiday included bank holidays, and the pay rate is £5.50 an hour plus a £1 hourly bonus for night staff who are rostered four shifts a week.

"They offer the minimum needed to hire people around Milton Keynes and don't seem to care about the turnover," said Mr Lockhart.

An employee claimed that ethnic miniority staff felt they were frequently overlooked for promotion, an allegation denied particularly forcefully by Amazon which said in recent months two black or Asian employees had been appointed to management posts.

Managers recently took handwriting samples from staff after a note criticising the working conditions was sent out with an order by a disgruntled worker.

"They are looking at you all the time. It is not pleasant," said one employee.

Another said: "I need the job but I would not advise my friends to work there. It's not good. If they say I am valued, they have a funny way of showing it. They don't care about us."

Union leaders intend to make Amazon a test case to break into the unorganised dot.com sector and the GPMU, which had four members at Amazon last October, has signed up 92 out of an estimated workforce of 270 after a recruitment campaign.

The union said that last autumn Amazon rebuffed GPMU overtures to secure bargaining rights but Mr Lockhart said the union has since passed the 10% threshold in law to trigger a recognition ballot. The company said it had met the union but had received "no formal communication".

Another option the union is considering is to continue recruiting with the aim of enrolling 50% of the workforce plus at least one other since that would guarantee automatic recognition.

Amazon, which has its UK head office in Slough, said yesterday wages were competitive "within the bands" around Milton Keynes and staff were provided with private medical insurance and share options, although the options have plunged since the collapse in the value of internet firms.

The spokeswoman said: "There are obviously two sides to this. We really believe that we do the best for our workforce and the feedback that we have is positive."

Amazon has a company council, including representatives of the workforce, which the dot.com maintains allowed open debate and the GPMU insists is dominated by management.

Sales at the world's biggest online supplier are projected to reach £3bn this year but losses remain huge.

webTitle: Moscow's No 2 in Chechnya killed by bomb in TV studio

fields.headline: Moscow's No 2 in Chechnya killed by bomb in TV studio
fields.standfirst:
Special report: crisis in Chechnya
Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: The fragile pro-Kremlin administration in Chechnya suffered a new blow yesterday with the assassination of its deputy leader in a bomb attack on a local television studio.
fields.body:
The fragile pro-Kremlin administration in Chechnya suffered a new blow yesterday with the assassination of its deputy leader in a bomb attack on a local television studio.

Adam Deniyev was fatally injured when a bomb exploded in the studio where he was broadcasting a live reading from the Koran on Thursday evening. He died later from head injuries.

The attack took place in his home town of Avtury, in a region of Chechnya south-east of Grozny ostensibly under Russian control - demonstrating again the weakness of Russia's grip on the region.

Mr Deniyev is the most powerful pro-Moscow official in Chechnya to have been assassinated during the course of the war.

Chechen rebels claim to have compiled a death list containing all the names of officials in Chechnya appointed by the Russian government. Any Chechen who agrees to work for the Russian-imposed local government is viewed as a traitor by separatist fighters and is vulnerable to attack. Several have already been killed.

The murdered administrator was appointed by the Kremlin to help restore stability to the separatist republic, shattered by two devastating wars over the past decade. Akhmad Kadyrov, his direct superior and head of the pro-Moscow administration, immediately blamed the Chechen rebel leader Aslan Maskhadov for the killing.

Mr Kadyrov, who has survived several assassination attempts, claimed that both he and Mr Deniyev had received threats from Mr Maskhadov. "This is another act of terrorism. They have killed somebody who was trying by every means possible to restore normal life to Chechnya," he said.

This attempt to cast the dead official as a blameless agent for the future good of Chechnya was dismissed by Chechen experts in Moscow. Mr Deniyev had himself been accused of murder and was widely believed to be collaborating with the Russian security forces, the FSB.

He was named as a suspect in a 1999 US state department report in the murder of six Red Cross nurses. The nurses were discovered shot dead in their beds in Chechnya in 1996. At the time, Russian officials blamed the killings on Chechen rebels, but the murders remained unsolved.

Andrei Babitsky, the Radio Liberty reporter who disappeared for a month last year after Russian troops handed him over to Chechen rebels in a bizarre prisoner exchange, said after his release that he had not ended up in rebel hands but been imprisoned in Mr Deniyev's house.

The journalist, whose critical coverage of the conflict in Chechnya infuriated the Kremlin, said he was held by pro-Moscow Chechens under Mr Deniyev's orders until international pressure apparently prompted the Russian government to order his release.

Mr Maskhadov swiftly denied responsibility for the killing yesterday. "The Chechen leadership offers its condolences to the FSB, which has lost an important collaborator in Deniyev," a spokesman said.

fields.headline: New row about Elgin marbles
fields.standfirst:
British Museum is accused of stifling debate

Special report: the Elgin marbles
fields.trailText: British Museum is accused of stifling debate.
fields.body:
The British Museum has become involved in a fresh row with the Greeks and a leading British academic over the controversial damage done to the Elgin Marbles - kept secret by the museum for 60 years.

The new row broke out after the museum announced it was abandoning a public commitment to publish controversial academic papers submitted by contributors to an international symposium held at the British Museum to discuss the issue.

The symposium was meant to end the secrecy that surrounded the "cleaning" of the Elgin Marbles with wire brushes and chisels in the 1930s, which caused irreparable damage to them.

Greek academics and the historian, William St Clair - a prominent critic of the museum's handling of the issue - had been invited to debate with supporters of the museum in London in December 1999.

The museum said it would publish all the contributions from the symposium as part of wider dissemination of the issue. It also told Unesco the reports would be circulated. Unesco has taken a special interest in the future of the marbles and would like to see them returned to Athens.

Last month the museum abruptly cancelled publication of the contributions, blaming four Greek academics for failing to meet a year-long deadline to submit their papers. But in the meantime the museum had become embroiled in another row with Mr St Clair over his submission - which they claimed was "derogatory" towards the museum - and sought to change his paper before they would agree to publication.

Dyfri Williams, keeper of Greek and Roman antiquities at the museum, wrote to Mr St Clair accusing him of having "submitted a considerably expanded and reworked version of his address".

Dr Williams said: "Your submission is far too long... in many places throughout your text you employ what some might consider unsubstantiated innuendo or invective. Such writing is out of place in a scholarly publication."

The museum asked for the removal of sections of Mr St Clair's article, which accused the museum of covering up the scandal and acting illegally by keeping some of the papers in director's personal files, and refusing to disclose them until just before the conference.

Mr St Clair wrote back refusing to make the changes and defending his charges against the museum."

The museum then decided not to publish the papers at all, which led to a further protest from Mr St Clair.

He wrote back: "It is not open to you or the trustees to attempt to withdraw from the commitment which was given. As a public body, the British Museum is required to carry out its undertakings and much work has been done in the expectation that it would be honoured... I suggest that you withdraw it immediately."

The Greek embassy said its academics were sending their papers to the British Museum regardless of whether they were to be published.

"As for the censorship issue, we would have thought that it would be sine qua non that a contributors' work would be published without being changed," the embassy said.

The British Museum last night suggested that it might be having second thoughts. "Now the Greeks are threatening to send their papers we may well be prepared to publish it at a later date - though we have no date in mind at the moment.

"We would normally publish contributor's views but in his case he had extended his thoughts considerably."

fields.headline: New NTV boss claims control
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: The disputed takeover of Russia's leading independent television station, NTV, lurched forward yesterday when the man who was controversially made station director claimed to have seized control of its finances and programming.
fields.body:
The disputed takeover of Russia's leading independent television station, NTV, lurched forward yesterday when the man who was controversially made station director claimed to have seized control of its finances and programming.

Boris Jordan, who was installed as NTV's head last week during a state-controlled takeover by the natural gas giant, Gazprom, said he would begin work on Monday morning.

This may not be possible, however, since the station's staff do not recognise his appointment and have refused to allow him inside the building.

Mr Jordan warned that the staff's salaries could only be paid if he approved the payments. A Moscow court will hold hearings next month on the legitimacy of his appointment.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: • In a report headed How archbishop's voice thundered unexpectedly, page 5, March 31, we said there was "little love lost" between the Archbishops of Canterbury and York. We accept that that should not have been reported as fact but as an expression of opinion.
fields.body:
 In a report headed How archbishop's voice thundered unexpectedly, page 5, March 31, we said there was "little love lost" between the Archbishops of Canterbury and York. We accept that that should not have been reported as fact but as an expression of opinion.

 In an article headed Call to axe M&S chief's bonus, page 19 (Finance), yesterday, we quoted a spokesman who said that turning the chief executive's bonus from cash into shares "would send a powerful message to shareholders and employees". Marks & Spencer has asked us to point out that the spokesman was speaking on behalf of a City institution and not for Marks & Spencer.

webTitle: Comment: Bearing witness to the truth

fields.headline: Bearing witness to the truth
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: "I was born for this, I came into the world for this: to bear witness to the truth." "Truth? What is that?" These words, spoken between Jesus and Pilate, are part of a timeless dialogue. We can place ourselves within it, hearing the question echoing within us.
fields.body:
"I was born for this, I came into the world for this: to bear witness to the truth." "Truth? What is that?" These words, spoken between Jesus and Pilate, are part of a timeless dialogue. We can place ourselves within it, hearing the question echoing within us. Sometimes, though, it's easier to place others within the argument: the enthusiast and the bigot; the sceptic and the cynic.

No matter what emotional overtones we may bring to this dialogue, the search for truth is as keen today as ever. Or perhaps not. Some would argue that the great step we have taken, especially in modern Britain, is to say that the question posed by Pilate is essentially misleading, no more than a distraction. The freeing insight of the modern age is precisely this: there is no overarching truth at all. There is no blueprint, no definable commonality underlying our separate experiences. And certainly, it is said, there is no God from whom such a pattern or coherence could flow. This is true freedom: to realise that whatever I know is true; whatever I do, causing no obvious harm to another, is good.

This is the brave world into which we are invited to step. It demands huge courage and inner conviction, for ultimately each of us has to accept that we constitute our own meaning, and that it will endure, for certain, only as long as we endure. Then there is only extinction.

This is a stark response to the question "And what is truth?" It is the response of secular individualism and it is writ large in our contemporary British way of life. We know its fruit; it is all around us. I do not belittle this answer and all the individual endeavour, achievements and anguish that flow from it. But I do not believe it to be the truth. It is not the truth about ourselves; nor is it the truth about our shared, public life.

I have just returned to England from four days in the ancient capital of Spain: Valladolid. A walk through the streets and squares of that town contrasts sharply with a walk through London, Birmingham, Leeds or Manchester. In Valladolid the sense of a common view and purpose in life is tangible. People instinctively seem to belong together. They fill their plazas; they walk and talk together; the generations mix; the youngsters respect each other; they seem to share so much. Of course, the sunshine helps. But so does a light of a different sort.

My faith is that we all share a common humanity, a single human nature. From that belief can flow the quest for its essential values. These rest on the principles, the truth, which gives shape to human living, both for individuals and societies. Of course there are a myriad of expressions of human living. But pervading truths lie beneath that variety.

My faith is also that the God from whom all this life flows - its unsourced source - has cast a light on our human nature, illuminating its deepest truths, laying bare its puzzling patterns. That light is a person: Jesus, the Christ. "I was born for this, I came into the world for this: to bear witness to the truth." (John ch18 v37).

With these words our search for understanding changes. Now it can be conducted in that form of search which best fits our nature. The search for truth becomes a relationship. In faith we can know Christ. In that relationship the light he casts on human nature comes into my life. In that light I begin to untangle the mystery of my own being. I am led towards the very source of life.

The streets and the squares of Valladolid have been thronged with crowds every day this week as the drama of the passion, death and resurrection of Christ has been played out in great outdoor pageants. Jesus greeted by jubilant crowds waving palms; Peter denying Christ, and then meeting him again; Veronica wiping the face of Jesus; Mary brokenhearted at the foot of the cross; Jesus dying on the cross.

These pageants are carried out without words. They go beyond words. They are ancient and moving expressions of the story still written in the hearts and minds of the people. And the story tells the truth. It tells the truth about living and dying, about sin and forgiveness, about love and compassion. The truth holds the people together. And life is more wholesome.

Perhaps the story - the Easter story - is largely forgotten, or has never been heard, by many people in Britain today. Yet the need for its message is as plain as ever. Beneath the noise of much activity and many distractions, the rumbling need in many hearts can almost be heard. It echoes in an empty space that only God can fill. But for that to happen, so many myths and misunderstandings have to be cleared away. This is the purpose of the coming of Christ, the purpose of the climax of his life and of his death celebrated at Easter: that we might know the truth and, knowing it, rejoice.

 The Most Rev Vincent Nichols is Roman Catholic Archbishop of Birmingham

webTitle: Comment: The Middle East: The real deal

fields.headline: The real deal
fields.standfirst:
Israel's view that Arafat missed a chance for peace under Barak is dangerously deluded

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel's view that Arafat missed a chance for peace under Barak is dangerously deluded
fields.body:
On the edge of Jerusalem, in a hollow in the hills, is a sad sight, the ruins of an abandoned Arab village. It has been empty since 1948, a victim of the conflict between Arabs and Israelis. It is a quiet spot. The stone is old, and the columns and curves belong to a very different architectural tradition from the red-roofed modern Israeli houses that surround it.

Today, there are new ruins. This week, the Israeli army bulldozed 30 homes, adding to the many already destroyed elsewhere in the Gaza Strip and on the West Bank. The Palestinians are paying a heavy price for the uprising they began in September: more than 370 dead and an economy destroyed.

The response of most Israeli liberals is to agree that the Palestinians are suffering but that the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, is to blame: he should have accepted the peace proposals put to him by the then Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the then US president, Bill Clinton, at Camp David last year and at Taba earlier this year. It is a view widely shared internationally, and one that the Israeli government is happy to project: that a generous deal was put on the table for Arafat and he missed the historic opportunity. The reality is that it may turn out to be Israel's missed opportunity.

There are two basic Israeli views of how to deal with its neighbour, the future state of Palestine. There is the liberal version put forward by the Israeli foreign minister, Shimon Peres, of an economically healthy Israel co-existing alongside an equally economically healthy Palestinian state. Together they could be at the centre of a revitalised Middle East.

Unfortunately, it is the other Israeli view that has long been dominant and is prevalent today: to have a weak, malleable Palestinian neighbour. Thomas Friedman, the New York Times journalist, writes in his account of his 10 years in the Middle East, From Beirut To Jerusalem, about how the Israelis have never quite managed to give up hopes of controlling all of biblical Israel, which includes the West Bank. That is what motivates the movement of Jewish settlers out into the Palestinian Wild West, the source of most of today's conflict.

Friedman and a host of other journalists and academics have recorded how Israeli politicians since the founding of the state in 1948 have talked peace while grabbing land. While Barak put seemingly generous offers on the table, Jewish settlers continued to expand into the West Bank, which they call by the biblical name, Judea and Samaria.

Demographic maps of the Middle East since 1948, the year Israel was founded, show a steady expansion of the Jewish population eastwards. Arab East Jerusalem today is being gradually surrounded by Jewish homes. Even within Jerusalem's Old City, Israelis are spreading into Arab neighbourhoods.

A Palestinian this week, spotting for the first time new Jewish houses on the outskirts of Jerusalem, said: "It is like a magic wand. You go away for a few weeks and then suddenly there is a whole new place." The Israeli government, supposedly committed to no new settlements, announced this week a further 700 new houses. The Israeli government finds it easy to keep to its commitment to build no new settlements: because there are so many already on the West Bank, all it has to do is just keep expanding existing ones.

It is against this background that Barak's "generous" deal should be seen. The Israelis portrayed it as the Palestinians receiving 96% of the West Bank. But the figure is misleading. The Israelis did not include parts of the West Bank they had already appropriated.

The Palestine that would have emerged from such a settlement would not have been viable. It would have been in about half-a-dozen chunks, with huge Jewish settlements in between - a Middle East Bantustan. The Israeli army would also have retained the proposed Palestinian state's eastern border, the Jordan valley, for six to 10 years and, more significantly, another strip along the Dead Sea coast for an unspecified period: so much for being an independent state.

Israel could afford to be magnanimous in terms of territory, given the amount it has gained over the last century at the expense of the Palestinians, many of whom fled or abandoned their homes for Lebanon, Syria, Jordan and elsewhere.

Compromises were discussed at Camp David and Taba on the right of return of the 3.5m Palestinian refugees, but nothing that Arafat could take away to sell to his own people. In spite of the protestations of Israeli liberals such as Amos Oz that to allow back 3.5m Palestinians would be suicidal for Israel, a solution was possible. The Israeli view that 3.5m Palestinian refugees would flood into Israel is a nonsense. What the Palestinians are looking for is something akin to an apology from the Israelis for taking their land. Israel could allow a few hundred thousand back and pay - or get the US or Japan or Europe to pay - compensation to the remainder, most of whom would stay where they now live.

One proposal on the table was for a land swap: the Palestinians would get part of Israel proper next to the West Bank in return for Israel taking part of the West Bank. Arafat could have taken this deal to the refugees and said: "Look, you are going back to Israel, as I promised." Barak could just as easily have said: "Look, it is no longer Israel but the West Bank." Solutions were possible, but in the end Barak would not give on the right of return.

A genuinely generous offer by Barak might have secured peace. That was the missed historic opportunity. If Israel had been more magnanimous at Camp David, it could have had the greater prize of long-term stability.

There is a huge danger attached to the Israeli view that Arafat spurned a great offer. Accepting this version perpetuates the Israeli myth that the Palestinians will not be happy until the Jews are pushed back into the sea and that the West Bank and Gaza are full of gunmen and bombers intent on making that happen.

There are such people - but most Palestinians are interested less in the destruction of Israel than in establishing a proper Palestinian state. Most are as exercised about the poor quality of the leadership round Arafat and about the endemic corruption and lack of democracy in their own society as they are about Israel. What they want is for the Israeli army to go home and to take the Jewish settlers with them. There will be no peace until that happens.

Nothing in the career of the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, suggests he will do that. Instead, he will continue with the subjugation of the Palestinians and grabbing more of their land. The only safe bet is that there are going to be a lot more Palestinian ruins.

Ewen MacAskill is the Guardian's diplomatic editor
