webTitle: Capitalism takes a hit in the media

fields.headline: Capitalism takes a hit in the media
fields.standfirst:
The nature of the story changes when Marks & Spencer and Tesco headlines leap to the front page

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Hold the front page! Well run company makes big profits, shock! It is not often that corporate news finds its way on to the front pages of Britain's newspapers or into any part of its television bulletins.
fields.body:
Hold the front page! Well run company makes big profits, shock! It is not often that corporate news finds its way on to the front pages of Britain's newspapers or into any part of its television bulletins.

We should perhaps sit up and take notice then when the Guardian slaps the woes of Marks & Spencer on the front page, as it did in last Saturday's edition, and then follows up with a page three on Thursday devoted to Tesco's billion pounds of profits.

Neither day could be considered a slow news day, what with the very public stumblings and bunglings of Sophie Wessex and Maff.

Do not get me wrong, I am all for boosting the coverage of financial issues on the front of this and other broadsheets. And I am aware it is no easy task - market research showing that readership levels dip dramatically between the obituaries and sports pages.

It is, however, inevitable across the media that when City issues move up the news agenda the instinct is to dumb down. It is instinctive to give capitalism a bad press.

Tesco's profits did not make page one, but then presumably there was an absence of any provocative pictorial accompaniment to rival that of the prominently placed photo of the Paris branch of M&S with its sadomasochistic overtones. Tesco chief executive Terry Leahy will just have to try harder.

Big round numbers are certainly evocative. As Who Wants to be a Millionaire has been exported around the world, the top prize has not been flexed to reflect exchange rate or cost of living differences. So a US winner would bag £700,000, but probably be more than 70% as happy as a UK winner - all else being equal. I confess I have not checked out the Turkish or Indonesian shows, though.

Had Tesco scraped together only £999m of profits, Mr Leahy would have been spared the cringeworthy television interviews in which he claimed that the profits were all ploughed back into more stores, more jobs and lower prices.

Again, this does capitalism a disservice. Tesco does not recycle all of its profits. It pays a slug of them out in dividends to its shareholders - the owners of the business who have risked their capital to fund its success. Just as others have risked and lost on M&S. Tesco need not be ashamed of this. It is what commerce is all about.

Corporate profits tend to escape the finance pages when there is a bigger peg to hang them on. The crisis in agriculture focuses attention on food retailers, just as last autumn's fuel crisis did on BP and Shell, and every recession does on the banks.

It is as well for the media to remind consumers of the choices that they have and of the value that their custom creates for the businesses whose services they use. However, creating headlines from the scale of profits merely panders to an uncritical "big business is bad" mentality.

My closest brush with Tesco came in the studio of BBC Radio 4's Today programme last week. I was privileged to witness a ding-dong between representatives of the retailer and Levi Strauss about £25 pairs of 501 jeans. It was great entertainment - even John Humphries and James Naughtie displayed more than usual interest in the financial slot.

It was difficult to warm to either protagonist, Mr Levi spouting nonsense about a brand experience and Mr Tesco about championing the consumer.

But it was a great reminder of the power of supply and demand and of the efficiency of the economy. If - eventually - Tesco loses the case, you as the consumer will not be forced to buy more expensive jeans. Just choose a different brand experience.

The choice is yours

Similarly, you are not forced to shop at Tesco for your organic, free range eggs. But if you like the experience and the prices, do not be alarmed that it proves a profitable business for the retailer. Go and buy some of their shares instead.

M&S is a curious case. The media confers iconic status on this bruised business, but a sense of proportion can easily be lost. However close to our essential selves we may consider our underwear to be, we are only talking about a store chain here.

So the first British retailer to record a billion pounds of profit is now in apparently terminal decline. Welcome to the world of fashion retailing. Parisians will have to cross the Channel to restock their drawers and they are a little upset they were not consulted first. Well, that is one bit of good news for the British tourist industry.

M&S's woes are of its own making. They do not tell us anything about trends in the broader economy. And all they tell us about high street retailing is that shoppers are rational - spending their money where they perceive value and quality.

The decision to slap the company's troubles on the front page is all well and good, so long as it is not intended as a profound comment on societal change in Britain.

Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities

Tesco need not be ashamed of this. It is what commerce is all about. Corporate profits tend to escape the finance pages when there is a bigger peg to hang them on. The crisis in agriculture focuses attention on food retailers, just as last autumn's fuel crisis did on BP and Shell, and every recession does on the banks. It is as well for the media to remind consumers of the choices that they have and of the value that their custom creates for the businesses whose services they use. However, creating headlines from the scale of profits merely panders to an uncritical "big business is bad" mentality. My closest brush with Tesco came in the studio of BBC Radio 4's Today programme last week. I was privileged to witness a ding-dong between representatives of the retailer and Levi Strauss about £25 pairs of 501 jeans. It was great entertainment - even John Humphries and James Naughtie displayed more than usual interest in the financial slot. It was difficult to warm to either protagonist, Mr Levi spouting nonsense about a brand experience and Mr Tesco about championing the consumer. But it was a great reminder of the power of supply and demand and of the efficiency of the economy. If - eventually - Tesco loses the case, you as the consumer will not be forced to buy more expensive jeans. Just choose a different brand experience. The choice is yours Similarly, you are not forced to shop at Tesco for your organic, free range eggs. But if you like the experience and the prices, do not be alarmed that it proves a profitable business for the retailer. Go and buy some of their shares instead. M&S is a curious case. The media confers iconic status on this bruised business, but a sense of proportion can easily be lost. However close to our essential selves we may consider our underwear to be, we are only talking about a store chain here. So the first British retailer to record a billion pounds of profit is now in apparently terminal decline. Welcome to the world of fashion retailing. Parisians will have to cross the Channel to restock their drawers and they are a little upset they were not consulted first. Well, that is one bit of good news for the British tourist industry. M&S's woes are of its own making. They do not tell us anything about trends in the broader economy. And all they tell us about high street retailing is that shoppers are rational - spending their money where they perceive value and quality. The decision to slap the company's troubles on the front page is all well and good, so long as it is not intended as a profound comment on societal change in Britain. Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities edmondw@omsecurities.co.uk

webTitle: BT clinches £387m right to buy J-Phone stakes

fields.headline: BT clinches £387m right to buy J-Phone stakes
fields.trailText: Heavily indebted BT has obtained the right to buy stakes in each of Japan Telecom's three regional mobile phone companies for a total of $551m (£387m).
fields.body:
Heavily indebted BT has obtained the right to buy stakes in each of Japan Telecom's three regional mobile phone companies for a total of $551m (£387m).

The deal, struck yesterday, gives BT the option to acquire stakes of 5% in J-Phone East, J-Phone West and J-Phone Tokai - the operating units of Japan Telecom's wireless subsidiary by September 29. The news in effect means that BT has six months to decide whether to remain in Japan and battle against its bigger rival, Vodafone.

On Thursday Vodafone completed the purchase of a 15% stake in Japan Telecom and is in negotiations to buy a further 10% stake. BT already has a 20% holding in the company.

A BT spokesman tried to play down the significance of the options, saying it was a simple restructuring of the J-Phone operating companies.

At the moment, BT has a 20% stake in J-Phone, but only tiny holdings in the operating units. By contrast Vodafone has a 26% stake in J-Phone, and holdings ranging from 8.31% to 10.14% in three operating companies.

But the company refused to comment on whether it would exercise the options it has just bought or on whether it would sell its stake in Japan Telecom.

Most City analysts expect BT to sell the stake to Vodafone as part of efforts to cut its £30bn debt mountain by a third by its fiscal year-end in March.

Vodafone's recent deal to buy a further 10% stake in Japan Telecom from US group AT&T was widely interpreted as a fatal blow to BT's ambitions in the region. "We have said that we are committed to Japan, but at the same time in this business world it is mad for anything to be absolutely set in stone," a BT spokesman said.

Under the terms of the option agreement, were BT to sell its stake in Japan Telecom, it could sell the option as well. Analysts said this could increase the appeal of the stake.

Both Vodafone and BT are interested in Japan's wireless market because it will be the first to launch third generation mobile phone services. J-Phone is well-placed to exploit the demand.

It is Japan's third biggest mobile phone company, with around 10m subscribers.

Meanwhile, BT dismissed reports that it wants to delay a plan a sell its stake in Spanish mobile phone company Airtel via a stock market flotation.

BT has a 17.8% stake in Airtel, which is controlled by Vodafone.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Guinness back on tap
fields.body:
Guinness back on tap

Production of Guinness in Ireland began returning to normal yesterday after a strike that threatened supplies was suspended late on Thursday.

The stoppage, over plans to close the company's packaging plant in Dundalk, was lifted after 15 hours following a breakthrough in talks brokered by the republic's labour relations commission.

Fears that Irish pubs would run out of Guinness on one of their busiest weekends receded as lorries began rolling from the St James's Gate brewery.

Food firm calls in receivers

Naylor Foods, a Yorkshire firm specialising in cold storage and distribution services, has called in administrative receivers after falling victim to intense competition and cost pressures.

KPMG Corporate Recovery is hoping to find a buyer for the business, which operates from sites in Leeds and Knaresborough.

The 120-year-old company, formerly named Charles F Naylor, employs 80 staff and has annual sales of £25m.

Managers buy Freshbake

A management buyout team has purchased Freshbake Foods, one of the largest suppliers of savoury pastries and sausages to supermarkets.

The team, led by present boss Kelvyn Hale, has bought the business from Vlasic Foods International, with backing from venture capital firm WBS.

Freshbake has factories in Salford and Glasgow, with annual sales of £50m.

webTitle: Notebook:   M&S 'hello'  to Holmes makes sense

fields.headline: Don't make Holmes the villain
fields.standfirst: This M&S 'hello' makes sense
fields.trailText: Suppose a big British company needed to recruit a top flight executive to run an essential part of its business and become its chief executive in waiting. The man or woman it wanted was already toiling away at a rival firm, earning a basic salary of £350,000, and was locked into a share option package which would net a further £550,000 if that person stayed put.
fields.body:
Suppose a big British company needed to recruit a top flight executive to run an essential part of its business and become its chief executive in waiting. The man or woman it wanted was already toiling away at a rival firm, earning a basic salary of £350,000, and was locked into a share option package which would net a further £550,000 if that person stayed put.

So the company doing the hiring tables an offer: £425,000 basic salary, a £100,000 signing-on bonus and then a package of shares worth £550,000 if the executive stayed with the new employer for three years, compensating for the lost options package.

This is routine stuff in modern business. The market in top quality executives possessing both the flair and experience to make a big company truly successful is tight. The right person does not come cheap.

The example above is real. It refers to Roger Holmes - the Kingfisher man who was poached by Marks & Spencer in the autumn to run its British stores and, we assume, at some stage take over the reins of chief executive from Luc Vandevelde.

Yet Mr Holmes is being vilified in some sections of the media this weekend for supposedly taking a £550,000 "golden hello" for joining Marks. It is nothing of the sort - and the criticism stinks, betraying ignorance about what is acceptable in terms of corporate remuneration and what is not.

Mr Holmes has been dragged into the frame because his boss, Mr Vandevelde, is in line for a bonus which many of his senior colleagues and some of his biggest shareholders believe is unfair. He is due to trouser up to £810,000 simply for meeting undisclosed "strategic and qualitative" targets, while all his managers have seen their bonuses, tied to that old-fashioned thing called profits, axed.

Given the state of the Marks business, those strategic and qualitative targets must actually have been set at negative levels, and it is extraordinary that the man has not yet put up his hands and agreed to transfer his bonus into a long term, share-based plan.

Mr Holmes, on the other hand, has been compensated for money he would have lost in joining Marks, and even then the executive has been locked in until September 2003. He also has a big tranche of share options that will only pay out if the share price goes up - which is how it should be.

Railing against Big Pay per se is fruitless. Companies of all shapes and sizes are in business to make a profit; the shareholders who risk their money in these companies expect the best possible return and the best management.

What is unacceptable - damaging to customers and shareholders alike - is the sort of ludicrous non-performance-related bonus that still litters so many British boardrooms. Too often these simply amount to rewards for failure.

Pipeline jam

The technology sector is not short of shocks at the moment. But there is persistent talk in the industry of some real nasties still to come.

The reason is simple: suspect accounting policies.

There is a real worry that as orders for software in particular are curtailed when the general US economic slowdown spreads across the Atlantic, a number of well-known British companies will be found out.

The problem is known in techie circles as "stuffing the pipeline". For obvious reasons, we cannot use a real example here, but a fictional illustration might help.

Typically, a software company will have a product sold to big corporates which carries a list price of, say, £1m for a company-wide licence. The software firm will actually do most of its direct business, however, through a so-called value added reseller (VAR) who buys a number of licences wholesale from the software firm and then markets these to the end customer.

Against the headline price of £1m, the VAR might pay just £500,000 for 10 licences, which it then hawks around companies, ready to sell at a big discount to the list price but still at a very substantial profit to the middleman.

Some British software companies have a habit of booking these VAR sales as revenue through their profit and loss account as soon as they are struck, rather than waiting for a real customer to bite. Yet the VAR agreements often have little clauses in them that allow the middleman to return some or all of the licences if they cannot find a genuine buyer.

The risk here is clear. Hyped expectations of corporate spending on software over the past year have seen a large number of untenable VAR deals which are now likely to snap back in the face of certain British software firms.

In the US, this type of accounting ruse, which does not show when sales are still motoring ahead, is against the rules.

It should be over here, as well.

fields.headline: Wok coup
fields.standfirst: Chef's future with Yellow River Cafe in doubt
fields.trailText: Chef's future with Yellow River Cafe in doubt.
fields.body:
Celebrity chef Ken Hom is likely to fall victim to a "wok coup" at Yellow River Cafe following the Asian restaurant chain's takeover by leisure company Noble House.

The new owners of the eight-strong chain have questioned whether Mr Hom is worth his £50,000 salary as "consultant chef". One industry source said Mr Hom's involvement in menu planning was limited.

Mr Hom, the author of books such as Ken Hom's Hot Wok, has been a key element in Yellow River Cafe's marketing strategy. One restaurant features a row of chairman Mao-style portraits of Mr Hom along its wall, such as in the chain's Islington restaurant.

Yellow River Cafe's website boasts that many of the chain's recipes are "unique to Ken Hom", adding that families and children are welcome because "Ken Hom stresses his belief that children should learn healthy eating habits from an early age".

However, industry sources say Mr Hom's involvement extends to little more than guest appearances at Yellow River Cafes, usually in order to sign copies of his books.

Yellow River Cafes have been widely praised for their concept of middle-market Asian meals aimed at a casual crowd spending £12 to £15 a head.

The Yellow River chain is part of Oriental Restaurants Group, which was bought by Noble House at the end of last year for £14.4m. Noble House is run by Robert Breare, the venture capitalist who is preparing a £470m takeover of Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries.

Mr Hom's contract is to be reviewed - he will either be given a much wider role with clearly specified duties or be dropped entirely.

The American-Chinese chef is best known for his BBC series on Chinese cookery, "Ken Hom: Travels With a Hot Wok".

Mr Hom learnt to cook in his family's Chicago restaurant, where he worked from the age of 11.

webTitle: Wal-Mart feels the chill of US economic slowdown

fields.headline: Wal-Mart feels the chill of US economic slowdown
fields.trailText: Profit warnings from America's two biggest retailers, Wal-Mart and Sears Roebuck, have given a clear signal that shoppers are feeling the pinch from the slowing US economy.
fields.body:
Profit warnings from America's two biggest retailers, Wal-Mart and Sears Roebuck, have given a clear signal that shoppers are feeling the pinch from the slowing US economy.

Wal-Mart, the Arkansas-based retailing empire, blamed cold spring weather for poor sales in its garden furniture, sports goods and lawncare departments.

The group, which owns the British supermarket chain Asda, said its earnings would be short of expectations for the three months to April 30. Like for like sales in recent weeks have edged up 3.5%, well short of last year's increase of 5.5%.

Smaller rival Sears Roebuck felt significantly more pain. It predicted a 19% slump in its first-quarter earnings, citing plunging sales of warm weather clothes. More than 40% of Sears' revenue comes from clothes.

Sears chairman Alan Lacy said: "March retail sales fell below expectations, with the slowing economy and colder than anticipated weather having an impact.

"Weather-related seasonal apparel and lawn and garden merchandise accounted for over one third of the comparable store sales decline."

Analysts expressed little surprise that the weather had punished the two companies. Steven Kernkraut at Bear Stearns said: "People don't go to a store in the middle of March when it's snowing to buy shorts and tank tops. They know they'll need them, but they don't buy them."

There are fears among analysts that the slowdown reflects deeper economic problems. With consumer confidence declining, retailers face a tough job matching last year's figures.

On Thursday the Standard & Poor's retail index fell 1.6%. The industry has been knocked by disappointing figures from many second line players, such as childrenswear firm Gymboree, department store operators Dillard's and Federated Department Stores, the parent company of Macy's and Bloomingdale's.

fields.headline: Merrill sharpens jobs axe
fields.standfirst: 1,000 could go in London and New York
fields.trailText: 1,000 could go in London and New York.
fields.body:
Expectations of a wave of redundancies in the City of London hardened yesterday when Merrill Lynch, the US investment bank, disclosed in New York that it was considering a series of selective staff reductions across its businesses in the coming weeks.

At least 1,000 jobs in the company's 35,000 strong brokerage division - largely based in London and on Wall Street - are believed to be under threat, with further reductions across Merrill's research departments and institutional securities operations being considered, according to reports.

News of any job cuts could come on Wednesday when Merrill announces its first-quarter figures.

"Due to the continuing weak business environment affecting the entire industry, we continue to examine how we are allocating resources including staffing levels and all other expenses," a Merrill Lynch statement said.

"We expect there will be some selective staff reductions as well as other expense reductions based on strategic decisions by individual business."

A spokesman declined to comment on the likely numbers involved or on the proportion of cuts which might fall in London.

Leading investment banks on both sides of the Atlantic are under pressure to cut costs because lucrative revenues from advising on flotations and mergers and acquisitions have dried up. In the first quarter, the number of mergers and acquisitions in Europe halved from the level seen a year ago.

On Wall Street, Bear Stearns, Prudential Securities and Charles Schwab have already announced plans to lay off staff as difficult market conditions have started to bite. Last week Merrill was rumoured to have shown about 100 London broking staff the door.

Economic think-tank the CERB recently warned that as many as 20,000 City jobs could be lost if the economic slowdown continues.

webTitle: Curfew restores calm in Cincinnati but funeral could ignite new violence

fields.headline: Curfew restores calm in Cincinnati but funeral could ignite new violence
fields.standfirst: Special report: gun violence in America
fields.trailText: Cincinnati is braced for renewed protests and violence today when the funeral is held of the young man whose killing by police sparked days of rioting.
fields.body:
Cincinnati is braced for renewed protests and violence today when the funeral is held of the young man whose killing by police sparked days of rioting.

The rites for Timothy Thoma, 19, in the inner-city area of Over-the-Rhine will be a real test of efforts to restore order to the Ohio city, which is now under curfew from 8pm to 6am.

The introduction of the curfew on Thursday night restored some peace yesterday, putting a firebreak in place after three nights of violence and loot ing triggered by the shooting of Thomas a week ago.

More than 150 people were arrested overnight for curfew violations, with 63 arrests for other offences, but the streets remained calm.

The Cincinnati police chief, Thomas Streicher, whose force has been the focus of increasingly violent protests since the killing, said the city was returning to normal.

Thomas was the 15th black man to be shot dead by Cincinnati police since 1995 in a city where 40% of the population is black.

There was no attempt by city officials to claim that America's latest urban crisis was anywhere near over.

"It seems to be working, but it's a very tenuous circumstance," said the Cincinnati mayor, Charles Luken, who declared a state of emergency in his city on Thursday.

"I have lived in this city all of my life and I love it to death," Mr Luken said. "I never thought I would sign an emergency order because of civil unrest."

A move by some black citizens to defy the curfew was abandoned when the president of the National Associated for the Advance ment of Coloured People, Kweisi Mfume, used a megaphone to urge a reluctant crowd to go home.

The incident that sparked the week of upheaval came in the early hours of April 7 when two off-duty policemen spotted Thomas, who was wanted on 12 charges of driving without a licence. A chase ensued, joined by 12 other policemen. One of them, Steve Roach, spotted Thomas jumping over a fence and shot him dead. Thomas was unarmed.

Thomas had been stopped 11 separate times since March 2000 by police, mainly for suspected traffic offences. Critics believe that his case highlights repeated complaints that police target young black men such as Thomas simply because of their colour.

There appears to be wide spread recognition on both sides that police reform, especially in racial profiling, cannot be put off for long if this week's events are not be repeated.

"If it's not solved here, it won't be solved anywhere," Mr Mfume said.

"When police officers, particularly good officers, get tainted by those who take the law into their own hands, it's up to the police to break the blue wall of silence."

However, the head of the police union, Keith Fangman, said that the city of Cincinnati should not give in to the rioters.

The rites for Timothy Thoma, 19, in the inner-city area of Over-the-Rhine will be a real test of efforts to restore order to the Ohio city, which is now under curfew from 8pm to 6am. The introduction of the curfew on Thursday night restored some peace yesterday, putting a firebreak in place after three nights of violence and loot ing triggered by the shooting of Thomas a week ago. More than 150 people were arrested overnight for curfew violations, with 63 arrests for other offences, but the streets remained calm. The Cincinnati police chief, Thomas Streicher, whose force has been the focus of increasingly violent protests since the killing, said the city was returning to normal. Thomas was the 15th black man to be shot dead by Cincinnati police since 1995 in a city where 40% of the population is black. There was no attempt by city officials to claim that America's latest urban crisis was anywhere near over. "It seems to be working, but it's a very tenuous circumstance," said the Cincinnati mayor, Charles Luken, who declared a state of emergency in his city on Thursday. "I have lived in this city all of my life and I love it to death," Mr Luken said. "I never thought I would sign an emergency order because of civil unrest." A move by some black citizens to defy the curfew was abandoned when the president of the National Associated for the Advance ment of Coloured People, Kweisi Mfume, used a megaphone to urge a reluctant crowd to go home. The incident that sparked the week of upheaval came in the early hours of April 7 when two off-duty policemen spotted Thomas, who was wanted on 12 charges of driving without a licence. A chase ensued, joined by 12 other policemen. One of them, Steve Roach, spotted Thomas jumping over a fence and shot him dead. Thomas was unarmed. Thomas had been stopped 11 separate times since March 2000 by police, mainly for suspected traffic offences. Critics believe that his case highlights repeated complaints that police target young black men such as Thomas simply because of their colour. There appears to be wide spread recognition on both sides that police reform, especially in racial profiling, cannot be put off for long if this week's events are not be repeated. "If it's not solved here, it won't be solved anywhere," Mr Mfume said. "When police officers, particularly good officers, get tainted by those who take the law into their own hands, it's up to the police to break the blue wall of silence." However, the head of the police union, Keith Fangman, said that the city of Cincinnati should not give in to the rioters. webTitle: Laughter Choir reveals Berlin humour deficit

fields.headline: Laughter Choir reveals Berlin humour deficit
fields.trailText: Thomas Draeger was in his late fifties and out of work when it all began.
fields.body:
Thomas Draeger was in his late fifties and out of work when it all began.

"I had to think about my life and it struck me I had nothing to laugh at or about. So I put an ad in the newspaper looking for laughers," he says.

The results of his odd initiative were to be found last Wednesday evening in a bare room with brown lino and strip lighting in the Berlin district of Wilmersdorf. We were in a hideous building in the most uninspiring, nondescript part of the capital.

And eight Berliners were laughing their heads off.

They are members of what Mr Draeger, a film producer and director, believes is the world's first and only "laughter choir".

"We don't need a joke to start laughing," said Holger Wettingfeld. "We don't laugh at people or things, but for the sake of laughing."

"When you laugh without a reason, the mind is not involved," said Mr Draeger, a rather anxious, worried-looking man with a beard and glasses. "So you can forget all about your problems and your everyday life and that makes you feel happy."

His choir, which has already released a CD, starts by trying to render a known piece of music by going "ha, ha, ha" until the inanity of what they are doing strikes one of them who then dissolves into real laughter. Sooner or later, the rest follow suit as Mr Draeger attempts to "conduct" them and shape the laughter into something resembling music.

This is no easy task when your "choristers" are either doubled up and rolling around or making uncontrollable honking noises.

Mr Wettingfeld is a freelance journalist. His fellow choristers include a nurse, a teacher, a retired doctor - and a TV reporter who came to write a story on the Laughter Choir and ended up joining it.

Late for rehearsal, when she appeared at the door she looked around the assembled group and burst into guffaws, which they all returned. This appeared to be the accepted form of greeting among laughter choristers.

Some people would say the choir is not the sort of project you would expect of the Germans. And those people include its members: they are pitiless in their assessment of their compatriots' sense of humour.

"I think it's the German mentality", said Bärbel Ziplies-Diekman, a social worker with a particularly infectious chuckle. "Germans are hard-working. Everyone wants to have lots of money".

"Maybe we'll change that," said Monika Waack, who works as a school secretary.

Ten days earlier, the group had made its first attempt at proselytising. The members of the Laughter Choir travelled up and down the underground between the Zoo and Potsdamer Platz, trying to induce a chortle from the Berliners, notoriously Germany's sourest-faced commuters.

"Didn't they think you were mad ?"

"Yes," said Holger Wettingfeld enthusiastically. "They didn't realise we were a group. Some people were asking 'Why are you laughing?' There was no joke."

Then, barely able to control his mirth, he added: "That was the joke."

webTitle: Leader: Italians like it to smell sweet

fields.headline: Taking the political air
fields.standfirst: Italians like it to smell sweet
fields.trailText: A buzz of expectancy sounds in households from Messina to Milan: Silvio Berlusconi, the right-of-centre contender in Italy's forthcoming general election, is dispatching a photo album to every address in the country.
fields.body:
A buzz of expectancy sounds in households from Messina to Milan: Silvio Berlusconi, the right-of-centre contender in Italy's forthcoming general election, is dispatching a photo album to every address in the country. It contains snaps of Il Cavaliere with, among others, Sylvester Stallone and, in soft focus naturally, the candidate picking flowers in his garden in springtime. Perhaps Italian voters are impressionable, a man in a black shirt once having gone down well, at least in non-communist households. But since Mr Berlusconi carries a lot of media weight, with his various television channels and publishing interests, and within the past year or so sailed round the Italian coast in a liner drumming up votes, you might think Italians already know as much about him as they need.

It is hard to see the personal publicity ploy working here. Rupert Murdoch, wisely, sticks to back passages and side entrances. Even the brashest of Hague advisers would shrink from sending out unsolicited pictures of Willie in baseball cap, Willie sinking his seventh pint etc. As for the prime minister, the Labour party surely fear electors would punish it for abusing their letter boxes.

Mr Berlusconi is also reported to be giving his troops a pep talk on campaign manners. In the country of O Sole Mio, candidates should of course "carry the sun in your pocket". Any voters encountered in the piazza should be offered "sincere compliments" - in the case of men on their intelligence and on their beauty if they are women. (Don't expect many women in the Berlusconi cabinet unless they look like La Cicciolina.) Last year Forza told its people in the field always to carry a clean hankie and make sure their breath smelled sweet. Millbank may worry about facial hair and the general tidiness of candidates, but even in these regimented days, it is hard to imagine even New Labour aspirants taking instruction on how to avoid BO on the stump.

webTitle: Setting a common date for Easter is no piece of cake

fields.headline: Sweet dream
fields.standfirst:
Setting a common date for Easter is no piece of cake

Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Orthodox and other Christian denominations mark Easter Sunday tomorrow, the first time since 1990.
fields.body:
Orthodox and other Christian denominations mark Easter Sunday tomorrow, the first time since 1990.

But plans to make it an annual event have failed.

The churches have bickered for centuries overthe date of Easter, so in the spirit of the new millen nium the World Council of Churches held a conference in Aleppo, Syria, in 1997 to try to end the impasse. Four years later, no deal.

The dates of Easter were established in 325AD, at the Council of Nicaea, which said that Easter Sunday follows the full moon after the spring equinox.

But Orthodox churches adhere to a rule that Easter should not be held until after the Passover. And while some use the Julian calender, others employ the Gregorian.
Newsday

webTitle: Powell says Croat hardliners could return Bosnia to 'law of the jungle'

fields.headline: Powell says Croat hardliners could return Bosnia to 'law of the jungle'
fields.standfirst: S-For accused of botching security for raids on militants' funds
fields.trailText: The US secretary of state accused Bosnia's leading Croat party yesterday of inciting mob violence that could mean "a return to the law of the jungle" in the republic, just five years after the US-brokered Dayton accords ended the ethnic war in the republic.
fields.body:
The US secretary of state accused Bosnia's leading Croat party yesterday of inciting mob violence that could mean "a return to the law of the jungle" in the republic, just five years after the US-brokered Dayton accords ended the ethnic war in the republic.

Colin Powell flew to Sarajevo to meet international officials fighting an attempt led by a hardline Bosnian Croat party, the HDZ, to set up a breakaway state.

He tried to counter a local feeling that the US is going to reduce its engagement in the region, including a cut in its peacekeeping contingent, part of the S-For stabilisation force of roughly 20,000 in Bosnia.

"We will be engaged politically and economically and provide military assistance as appropriate," he said after meeting all the Balkan foreign ministers in Macedonia's capital, Skopje, on Thursday.

Mr Powell was to have visited the Yugoslav province of Kosovo but low cloud and bad weather made a helicopter trip impossible. Instead, several Kosovo Albanian leaders drove to Skopje to see him before he left by plane for Sarajevo.

In Bosnia, S-For officers, including the American general commanding the peacekeeping force, are currently the targets of scorn and anger among officials of the international administration in the republic.

Some officials are calling for a detailed inquiry, accusing S-For of bungling security during a crackdown earlier this month on a bank used by the Bosnian Croat militants to fund their drive to set up their own state.

Under the 1995 Dayton peace accord, Bosnia was split into a mini-state run by Serbs, and a federation of Muslims and Croats. The Croats feel they have been shortchanged by the Muslims, the largest ethnic group in Bosnia.

The violence around the bank happened on April 6 in the divided Croat-Muslim town of Mostar in southern Bosnia. The Austrian diplomat who serves as the international community's high representative in the republic, Wolfgang Petritsch, had ordered the seizure of Banka Hercegovacka's headquarters in the town, and about 10 branches there and around Bosnia, because of suspicions about the activities it was funding.

But when his auditors arrived at several of the branches, Bosnian Croat thugs went into action.

Senior S-For staff had been sent down to Mostar from Sarajevo, and Spanish and French troops were on hand at the headquarters bank - but too few to deal with the angry crowd, including schoolchildren, summoned by the hardline Croat war veterans who keep constant watch on the international community. Eggs and tomatoes were thrown, then stones. Finally shots were fired.

Bosnian Muslim and Croat financial police in the operation were seized by the thugs and forced to take off the masks hiding their identities. The Croats among those unmasked are in special danger, accused of treachery.

Meanwhile, one auditor was led into the streets by the thugs and threatened with execution, until a Franciscan priest intervened. Other officials, foreign and local, were held hostage in the bank.

An Irish policeman was severely beaten and Tobi Robinson, the woman from the US Agency for International Development sent in to supervise the bank, was struck.

Colin Munro, a British diplomat who is the senior foreign civil servant in Mostar, was trapped in his fifth-floor office in a hotel when armed men stormed upstairs. He had to ring S-For for reinforcements.

Lieutenant-General Michael Dodson, the American commander of K-For, has admitted that "had we known this was going to be a well orchestrated mob, we may have acted differently". He argued that greater force could "disrupt the whole city" and might have led to more damage.

Furious participants, speaking off the record for fear of losing their jobs, accuse S-For of a failure of basic intelligence. And they want to know why, when the crowds grew, it was left to civilians rather than the officers on the ground to call for more soldiers.

One man who took part in the raid said the few troops and police used were not briefed until around midnight, with only a few hours of sleep before the raids. He told the Guardian that some of the auditors from private companies had flown in from the US only two days before the investigation and had no idea their lives could be at risk.

In the sensitive town of Grude officials had to give back some of the files and computer hard drives they had seized under warrant, to get the thugs to release colleagues.

Mr Petritsch helped to co-ordinate the takeover of the bank, believed to be the main source of HDZ party funds.

His administration's intelligence, too, seems to have been impefect: in Mostar, officials thought Hercegovacka Banka had three branches. When a fourth was discovered, a small group of investigators had to rush there with even less protection than the main group.

The bank is controlled by supporters of the HDZ leader, Ante Jelavic, who was sacked by Mr Petritsch from the three-man state presidency of Bosnia a few weeks ago after an illegal "Croatian National Congress" was set up.

webTitle: Family olive groves fall to Israeli attacks

fields.headline: Family olive groves fall to Israeli attacks
fields.standfirst:
Army and settlers feed Palestinians' resentment Israel destroys groves in the West Bank and Gaza

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Army and settlers feed Palestinians' resentment Israel destroys groves in the West Bank and Gaza
fields.body:
Ahmed Kasem, a Palestinian olive-farmer, enjoys curling up for a nap in the shade of one of his trees. When he is not dozing, he wanders round the olive groves, as he has done for most of his 76 years, watering the trees or tucking a little more earth round their roots to protect them from the sun.

He lives in Huwwarah amid a pretty landscape of cypress, pine and olive trees a few miles south of Nablus, on the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

Olive trees have been cultivated in this part of the world since the Romans. On the hillsides above his home, there are olive trees that were planted 1,000 years ago that still produce olives. Closer to home, he can point to trees that were planted by his father 100 years ago.

He loves the olive tree. "For me, being with the trees is like being in heaven. I am not crazy but I open my heart to the trees. I think of the trees as I do my family. I speak to them when I have troubles."

He has had plenty of troubles to share with the trees in the past seven months. The olive branch, the universal symbol of peace, has fallen victim to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, as have Mr Kasem and his fellow villagers.

The Israeli army and Jewish settlers living nearby have been uprooting the olive trees. Mr Kasem lost 20 of them when an olive grove was bulldozed by the Israeli army in December.

"It was four in the morning. A neighbour knocked on the door. I rushed out almost naked. They had gone by the time I got there. The field was churned up, the trees lying all over the place," Mr Kasem said.

"I took the roots home. They are in the yard. I look at them every day. I say to them 'I spent half my life nurturing you'. I will keep the roots to remind my grandchildren what the Jews did to me and to them."

Although he has other olive trees, the loss was painful.

"Even if you have lots of kids, the death of one is going to hurt," he says. "I planted those trees when I was only 20. It was the start of the winter season. I bought them at a village near Tel Aviv and took them home in my brother's truck."

The destruction of the olive groves is continuing at Huwwarah. Sixty other olive-farmers in the village have suffered losses: they estimated 2,500 olive trees have been torn up by the Israeli army or Jewish settlers.

Two weeks ago the Palestinian Authority announced that in the past seven months 25,000 olive trees had been uprooted in the West Bank and Gaza.

Major Yarden Vatichai, an Israeli army spokesman, said: "We do it because there is a threat to our soldiers and civilians. They can be a hideout for Palestinian gunmen."

Most of the trees uprooted have been close to Jewish settlements, or beside roads used by Jewish settlers.

Israeli peace groups, some of whose members have been arrested trying to stop the destruction, dispute the army version and claim the real reason for the uprooting is to aid the further Israeli annexation of Palestinian land.

Palestinians, such Mr Kasem, see the loss of the olive trees as part of a deliberate policy by Israel to humiliate them, to sap their will.

The mayor of Huwwarah, Wajeeh Odeh, 44, admitted that Palestinian youths have thrown stones at Jewish settlers using the road but said the Israeli response had been disproportionate.

"The kids throw stones to demonstrate their opposition to the occupation," he said. "There have been no Palestinian snipers here. No soldier or settler has been killed or wounded."

One of the toughest parts of life under Israeli occupation is the curfew. The first and longest imposed by the army on Huwwarah lasted 38 days, beginning on October 6. It was a 24-hour curfew. There have been two others since.

"We were not allowed to leave our homes," one of Mr Kasem's neighbours, Mustapha Dawoud, said. "It was like being a pigeon in a cage."

Closure of the village to the outside world has been near constant. Israeli checkpoints at either side of the village ensure a safe passage for Jewish settlers but they cut off access for the Palestinians.

There are ways round, using desert by-pass roads, but locals use these at the risk of being shot. "I took a risk," Mr Kasem said. "I got a lorry and a driver and got some of the crop through."

He is confident that one day, God willing, there will be a Palestinian state and that the Israeli army and the settlers will be gone. He will safely replant new trees then.

"If not me," he says, "my children or grandchildren will."

There have been two others since. "We were not allowed to leave our homes," one of Mr Kasem's neighbours, Mustapha Dawoud, said. "It was like being a pigeon in a cage." Closure of the village to the outside world has been near constant. Israeli checkpoints at either side of the village ensure a safe passage for Jewish settlers but they cut off access for the Palestinians. There are ways round, using desert by-pass roads, but locals use these at the risk of being shot. "I took a risk," Mr Kasem said. "I got a lorry and a driver and got some of the crop through." He is confident that one day, God willing, there will be a Palestinian state and that the Israeli army and the settlers will be gone. He will safely replant new trees then. "If not me," he says, "my children or grandchildren will." fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Hostage freed in Philippines
fields.body:
Hostage freed in Philippines

Muslim separatists in the southern Philippines last year, was flown to a military hospital yesterday after being freed by the army a day before.

Mr Schilling, who said he had lost about seven stone during his ordeal, spoke haltingly and looked exhausted.
John Aglionby

Body found at rugby club

The body of a white man has been discovered in the ticket office of the Pietersburg rugby club in South Africa. Nine players there face murder charges in connection with a black teenager killed three weeks ago.

The police say the white man had complained to them the night before his death of being assaulted by four black men. Officials say the victim has no connection to the club. They do not know if his death, from head injuries apparently, is linked to the murder of Tshepo Matloga.
Chris McGreal, Johannesburg

Brando has pneumonia

Days after Marlon Brando was said to have agreed to make a cameo appearance in Scary Movie 2 - for a reported fee of $2m (£1.4m) - there was news yesterday that the actor, 77, has developed pneumonia.

In the opening scene of the film he is meant to play a priest performing an exorcism.

Milosevic put back in jail

Yugoslavia's former president, Slobodan Milosevic, was returned to prison in the capital, Belgrade, yesterday after two days in a military hospital where he was taken for heart tests.

fields.headline: Authorities seize rare fish cargo
fields.trailText: Australian and South African forces have seized a fishing boat for poaching 100 tonnes of a fish so valuable it is known as "White Gold".
fields.body:
Australian and South African forces have seized a fishing boat for poaching 100 tonnes of a fish so valuable it is known as "White Gold".

After a 10-day chase across thousands of miles of ocean the Togo-registered boat, South Tommy, was caught with its illegal cargo of rare Patagonian toothfish estimated to be worth about £500,000 if sold as a delicacy in Japan and the US.

Its 44 crew, believed to be Spanish, have been arrested.

Patagonian toothfish grow to be more than two metres long, live for nearly 50 years and breed extremely slowly.

Some have proteins that act as antifreeze to protect them in sub-zero waters.

Fishing the toothfish is restricted because it is close to extinction as a commercial fish and because of the impact on the environment.

The 150-foot South Tommy was first spotted by an Australian patrol boat nearly two weeks ago in Australian waters off Antarctica.

A 2,500-mile chase ensued with the patrol vessel at times within a few hundred yards of its quarry.

The Australians asked for South African help as the South Tommy approached the Cape of Good Hope.

Pretoria dispatched three vessels to join the pursuit.

The captain of the South Tommy allowed his vessel to be boarded on Thursday by 40 Australian troops on South African ships 250 miles off Cape Town.

Australia's fisheries minister, Wilson Tuckey, said his navy was determined not to allow the South Tommy to escape.

"Had we not intercepted it when we did, it would have gone on until the fish stopped biting, so it would have ended up with 200 or 300 tonnes, which would have been tragic," he said.

The captain faces a fine of up to £180,000 and the loss of the boat.

Environmentalists say plunder of the toothfish has had a devastating effect on Antarctica's fragile ecosystem.

The illegal trade in the fish is estimated to be worth about £70m a year.

webTitle: 250 'child slaves' to sail back to Benin

fields.headline: 250 'child slaves' to sail back to Benin
fields.trailText: UN officials gathered yesterday at Cotonou, Benin's main port, to receive a cargo of 250 suspected child slaves after the ship carrying them was turned back by two nearby west African countries.
fields.body:
UN officials gathered yesterday at Cotonou, Benin's main port, to receive a cargo of 250 suspected child slaves after the ship carrying them was turned back by two nearby west African countries.

The children are thought to be from Benin and Togo, and bound for the the coffee and rubber plantations of nearby Gabon, where slave labour is rife.

Estelle Guluman of the UN Children's Fund (Unicef) said the suspected slave ship was due in early this morning after a three-week round trip of 1,250 miles.

"There are centres which have been established in Benin to receive such children where they can be housed temporarily while we establish their identity," she said.

The ship was turned away from Libreville, in Gabon, and from Cameroon's main port of Douala on its journey.

Despite international efforts, child slavery persists in west and central Africa. Families are typically given as little as £10 for their child with the promise of a regular remittance. Invariably, that is the last they hear from the purchaser or their child.

Child slaves from countries such as Benin, Togo and Mali can fetch up to £300 each in the plantations of Gabon and the Ivory Coast.

Thousands of children aged nine to 12 are thought to be enslaved in Ivory Coast, the world's top cocoa producer. Anti-child labour campaigners say there they are forced to work 12-hour days, and are often subjected to physical and sexual abuse.

Every year border officials in Benin stop scores of children being transported to work abroad. But the full extent of the problem is hard to know.

"We don't have any accurate figures - the borders are very porous and the sea is not the only exit for these children," Ms Guluman said. "They are crossing all along the border with Nigeria."

webTitle: Monarchy: Going Dutch ensures the future is Orange

fields.headline: Going Dutch ensures the future is Orange
fields.standfirst:
Netherlands: Few scandals, hangers-on or hand-outs

Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Netherlands: Few scandals, hangers-on or hand-outs
fields.body:
Held up as a shining example of the kind of trendy slimmed-down bicycling monarchy to which Britain should aspire, the Dutch royal family could well have hit on a recipe for success which the Windsors might imitate.

It is not burdened by too many showy hangers-on, only five people get hand-outs from the public purse, and it has, by and large, avoided the type of scandals which have bedevilled its British counterpart.

The bicycling monarchy epithet is, however, a bit of a myth. Queen Beatrix, a mother of three, has been spotted on two wheels in the past - on her way to a market in the Hague or even cycling through the red light district in Amsterdam - but not that often.

"The queen has only got on her bike two or three times during her 21-year reign," one palace source said yesterday. Chauffeur-driven cars are more her thing.

And just because the Dutch royals are more low-profile than their British counterparts does not mean they are poor. Queen Beatrix is rumoured to be one of the wealthiest reigning monarchs in the world with a personal fortune estimated at a cool £3.25bn.

In general, the Dutch royals, are far more down to earth and closer to their subjects than the Windsors. Queen Beatrix, who has a sweet tooth, can often be spotted buying cakes in the Hague and the heir to the throne, Prince Willem-Alexander, 33, has often been seen strolling through the streets of Amsterdam arm in arm with his Argentine fiancee. Nobody bats an eyelid and they are not besieged by paparazzi.

Many of the royals hold conventional jobs and live "in obscurity", according to palace officials. Prince Johan Friso, 32, is a banker for Goldman Sachs in London, while his brother, Prince Constantijn, 31, has worked in Brussels for the European commission.

Nor do the royals cost the Dutch government a fortune. Queen Beatrix gets about £2.3m a year, while the total allowance for the house of Orange-Nassau comes to just over £4m a year, a figure which includes the hand-out to the queen. The cash is tax-free, although the family pays normal taxes otherwise.

Payments from the public purse are limited to five people: the queen and her German husband, Prince Claus, the queen mother and her husband, Prince Bernhard, and Crown Prince Willem-Alexander. Nor is the circle of minor royals too unwieldy. It numbers around 17, and the prime minister, Wim Kok, has announced his intention to slim that down, too.

Scandal does not seem to have reared its head. Prince Bernhard was accused of taking kickbacks from US defence firms in exchange for talking up their products. The claim was strongly denied by him and nothing came of it.

Prince Claus struggled to live down his German roots and his military service during the second world war but that has long since ceased to be an issue.

Prince Johan Friso was accused of being gay in much the same way that Prince Edward was but the claim has not stuck. And more recently there has been controversy about the father of Prince Willem-Alexander's bride-to-be, who served as agriculture minister in Argentina during the bloody reign of President Videla. The old man has agreed not to come to the wedding and the fuss has faded away.

"It works efficiently and Beatrix is what we sometimes call the perfect queen," says Dutch Labour MP Peter Rehwinkel, an expert in constitutional affairs. "More than 80% of the Dutch are in favour of the monarchy and support the way the queen does her job."

In contrast to the Windsors then, the house of Orange-Nassau is in rude health and the republican movement is weak and fragmented.

But that does not mean that the Netherlands has abandoned the pomp and circumstance so beloved by the Brits. Queen Beatrix has three palaces at her disposal - two in the Hague and one in Amsterdam - and every September, Queen Bee, as she is known, travels with her husband to parliament in a golden coach for its state opening.

All the trimmings remain in place - the military guard of honour, the brass bands and the obsequious courtiers. But analysts say she wields very little power in practice and is always careful to stay out of politics.

But some experts believe that hardcore support is falling away. "It used to be a magical thing a hundred years ago but it has lost its magic as it has become more and more democratic," argues journalist and author Harry van Wijnen.

"Queen Beatrix has a trace of old-fashioned monarchy about her. She has reintroduced phrases such as 'Your majesty'. The Dutch don't like that kind of thing."

webTitle: Monarchy: Populist style and an unwritten pact with the press

fields.headline: Populist style and an unwritten pact with the press
fields.standfirst:
Spain: 'Comeback' king likes spin on motorbike

Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Spain: 'Comeback' king likes spin on motorbike
fields.body:
Nothing sharpens the minds of monarchs as much as a period in exile. That is why Spain's royal family, which has twice been thrown out in favour of republics in the past 130 years, would never be caught by a Sophiegate.

King Juan Carlos was never guaranteed the popular support of Spaniards. He was foisted on them 25 years ago by decree of General Francisco Franco - even though Spain had not had a monarch for more than 40 years.

But Juan Carlos has made himself popular by leading a slimmed-down, unfussy royal family, and, crucially, by nurturing democracy. His high point was the day, 20 years ago, when he refused to back a military coup after Colonel Antonio Tejero had stormed parliament.

A lack of transparency about the royal household's finances and an unwritten "hands-off" pact with the press have helped keep royal life relatively scandal-free.

A trip to the king's Zarzuela Palace on the outskirts of Madrid turns up many surprises. It is a modest former hunting lodge with a modern extension. The royal family's living area is smaller than that enjoyed by some second-ranking Windsors. The dining room seats just 14 people.

The king himself is determinedly populist. Sometimes he takes off on his own motorbike, unrecognisable under his helmet and leathers.

But what about his son and heir, 33-year-old Prince Felipe? The salsa-loving prince is currently dating a Norwegian model, Eva Sannum, who is best known in Spain for her lingerie shots. She stands a serious chance of becoming queen.

Is Miss Sannum, the daughter of a Norwegian social security office bureaucrat, the Sophie Wessex, Duchess of York or Princess Diana of the Bourbons? Some worry she might be. "There must be maximum prudence when selecting those incorporated through marriage," trumpeted the royalist La Razon newspaper after Sophiegate broke.

King Juan Carlos receives £40m a year from Spanish taxpayers. Journalists who ask exactly what he spends it on are told, in polite words, that it is none of their business.

The family referred to appears to include just the five nuclear royals. But it is useless to ask, for example, how much taxpayers' money the king's daughters receive.

Only one of the king's three children, Princess Cristina, has a career. Her job, organising exhibitions for the cultural institute of La Caixa savings bank, is paid at the lowest rate for that particular scale.

Although the king's two sons-in-law get titles and feature as members of the royal family on the monarchy's own website, neither seems to be on the payroll.

Both have continued with their careers. Inaki Urdangarin, husband of Princess Cristina, recently retired from professional handball to study for an MBA. Jaime Marichalar, husband of Princess Elena, is a banker at Credit Suisse. He has been appointed to the board of a cement company and presides over an insurance company's cultural foundation.

Did Mr Marichalar's royal status get him these jobs? Spaniards did not seem to care.

In fact, Spaniards show remarkably little critical interest in their royals. Their love lives are not scrutinised as those of the British royals are. There is no Spanish equivalent to the News of the World.

The only time the king was criticised by the press was when he began spending a lot of time in Switzerland. Officials said he was going for medical treatment.

A minor scandal broke when a group of tourism millionaires bought a £12m, turbodiesel royal yacht for his use last year. This was patently a prize for holidaying on the Balearic islands, where the millionaires' companies were based, and where the king and his family have free use of a holiday palace.

By British standards the Spanish family is given an easy run. Perhaps this is because, uniquely in Europe, the constitutional monarchy which emerged after Franco's death was approved at the polls in a 1978 referendum on the constitution.

But that was 23 years ago. Would Spaniards vote the same way now? Yes - thanks to the exile-sharpened wits of their king, they probably would.

webTitle: Monarchy: See the queen by request or bump into her at a shop

fields.headline: See the queen by request or bump into her at a shop
fields.standfirst:
Denmark: Head of state can speak her mind on TV

Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Denmark: Head of state can speak her mind on TV
fields.body:
At first sight, the Danish royal family appears little different from ours. They change the guard outside the Amalienborg Palace in Copenhagen every morning for the tourists, just like in London except that the soldiers wear blue uniforms with their bearskins, not red ones.

The EU's second smallest member state has a queen married to a foreign husband. She has been on the throne for a long time - nearly 30 years - and has two sons, the older of whom has had difficulty finding a wife. She keeps dogs, dachshunds rather than corgis, and occasionally drives in an open-topped gold carriage.

But there any resemblance Queen Margrethe II has to her second cousin Elizabeth tends to falter. She can trace her lineage rather further back than the Windsors, being the 54th Danish sovereign (but only the second queen) in a direct line stretching back more than 1,000 years to King Grom the Old.

Margrethe, 60 years old, a chain-smoking (60-a-day) and striking six footer, educated at Cambridge, the LSE, the Sorbonne, and in Denmark, speaks five languages and is an accomplished stage and textile designer and book illustrator.

Any Dane can pop in to see her on request and they can even come across her in the local shops just down from the palace. It is said that she can be seen carrying her shopping bags back to the Amalienborg and her official car joins the Copenhagen rush hour most mornings to cross the city to her office in the Christiansborg Palace.

She and her French-born, former diplomat husband Henri, whose name has been transmogrified into Henrik in Danish, receive the equivalent of about £4.5m a year from the state, on which they pay no taxes, and the two royal princes, Crown Prince Frederik and Prince Joachim, receive an additional £1.3m.

These expenses help with the upkeep of the four royal palaces, though the royal yacht is maintained by the state. The family also has a chateau in Cahors, southern France, where Henrik can supervise his vineyard - whose product is marketed over the internet as Vin du Prince de Danemark.

In 1985 Henrik briefly went on strike, refusing to open any more buildings until he got paid for it - and he won.

Crown Prince Frederik's long search for a suitable wife (he is now 32) has been discreetly followed but a newspaper which dared to carry a photograph of him relaxing beside a swimming pool with a girlfriend three years ago was fined for its presumption. He was last reported to be squiring Bettina Odum, a Danish designer living in London.

"It is certainly easier to be a Prince of Denmark than a Prince of Wales," the queen told British correspondents last year. They certainly don't have the same media pressure - but then when did Queen Elizabeth II ever give an interview to any newspaper?

When his younger brother married Hong Kong-born Alexandra Manley, who has a half-Chinese father, an Austrian mother and a British passport, six years ago, there was rejoicing at Europe's first princess to have Asian blood.

The couple's popularity increased when she gave birth to a son two years ago. The queen has said that her sons must have marriages that will last. Frederik follows heir-to-the-throne type pursuits, gaining his frogman's diving diploma and training for long spells in Greenland with the armed forces, while Joachim farms.

Margrethe has similar powers to Elizabeth, except that she can theoretically delay legislation. When she makes her annual address to the nation - on New Year's Eve rather than Christmas Day - she is even allowed to be controversial: a few years ago she ticked off her fellow citizens for their growing racism and hostility to asylum seekers.

The Danes, who can be a stubborn lot, are famously protective of their queen. When the Swedish media had the temerity to criticise her smoking, Denmark's equivalent of the Sun thundered back: "Mind your own business, Swedes."

Opinion polls put support for the monarchy at over 90%. "Anti-monarchists have a hard time here," says the foreign minister, Niels Helveg-Petersen.

fields.bodyText: At first sight, the Danish royal family appears little different from ours. They change the guard outside the Amalienborg Palace in Copenhagen every morning for the tourists, just like in London except that the soldiers wear blue uniforms with their bearskins, not red ones. The EU's second smallest member state has a queen married to a foreign husband. She has been on the throne for a long time - nearly 30 years - and has two sons, the older of whom has had difficulty finding a wife. She keeps dogs, dachshunds rather than corgis, and occasionally drives in an open-topped gold carriage. But there any resemblance Queen Margrethe II has to her second cousin Elizabeth tends to falter. She can trace her lineage rather further back than the Windsors, being the 54th Danish sovereign (but only the second queen) in a direct line stretching back more than 1,000 years to King Grom the Old. Margrethe, 60 years old, a chain-smoking (60-a-day) and striking six footer, educated at Cambridge, the LSE, the Sorbonne, and in Denmark, speaks five languages and is an accomplished stage and textile designer and book illustrator. Any Dane can pop in to see her on request and they can even come across her in the local shops just down from the palace. It is said that she can be seen carrying her shopping bags back to the Amalienborg and her official car joins the Copenhagen rush hour most mornings to cross the city to her office in the Christiansborg Palace. These expenses help with the upkeep of the four royal palaces, though the royal yacht is maintained by the state. The family also has a chateau in Cahors, southern France, where Henrik can supervise his vineyard - whose product is marketed over the internet as Vin du Prince de Danemark. He was last reported to be squiring Bettina Odum, a Danish designer living in London. fields.headline: Mustard gas leak town evacuated
fields.trailText: About 15,000 people living around the British first world war battlefield of Vimy in Flanders were forced to leave their homes yesterday after a huge dump of Great War ammunition started leaking waves of deadly mustard gas.
fields.body:
About 15,000 people living around the British first world war battlefield of Vimy in Flanders were forced to leave their homes yesterday after a huge dump of Great War ammunition started leaking waves of deadly mustard gas.

British tourists visiting cemeteries and battlegrounds in the Pas de Calais were among families told to stay out of the area where 173 tonnes of recently uncovered explosive weapons, including 16,000 shells and bombs, were stored in the open waiting to be destroyed.

The evacuation of Vimy, with a population of 4,700, and the villages of Farbuf, Willerval, Acheville and Arleux-en-Gohelle, came only a day after 10,000 people were ferried out of the centre of Lorient following the discovery of a 500lb second world war British bomb. The boobytrapped missile was safely defused.

But the alert in the Atlantic port bore no comparison to the emergency around the Vimy dump where army engineers stock much of the 500 tonnes of rusting first and second world war ammunition recovered every year in France. The holding area on farmland is unguarded and protected only by a barbed wire fence.

Local people have repeatedly expressed concern over the dangers and the frequent thefts by souvenir hunters. Yesterday, about 3,500 firemen, police and soldiers, including 50 bomb disposal experts, were drafted into the area, which 500,000 people visit each year.

The emergency evacuation, in which 130 buses were sent from Lille, appears to have been precipitated by the extremely heavy rain in northern France which has caused widespread flooding in the Somme and Pas de Calais where hundreds of families have had to be rescued from flooded homes.

Several people, including farmers, said they would not obey a 6pm deadline to quit Vimy after security forces went from door to door to tell them of the danger. There was a flurry of panic when parents were told to take their children out of school and seek safety. "Everybody was running this way and that," a nursery school worker said. "People are leaving with their TVs and stereos because they are afraid of looting."

While evacuees were found emergency lodging in hotels, hospitals, holiday centres and schools, the army moved in with refrigerated lorries to take the unstable ammunition to an army depot in the Marne where it will be destroyed in an operation that could take up to 10 days.

Vimy was one of the most bitterly fought battlefields in the first world war . Commonwealth troops seized the town in April 1917, taking 10,000 prisoners.

fields.headline: Death becomes him
fields.standfirst: Five years after his murder, Tupac Shakur is bigger than ever.  Dom Phillips  investigates how a gun-loving criminal somehow became a role model
fields.trailText: Five years after his murder, Tupac Shakur is bigger than ever. Dom Phillips investigates how a gun-loving criminal somehow became a role model
fields.body:
Since his still unsolved murder in Las Vegas in 1996, the rapper and actor Tupac Shakur has assumed almost mythical status. Some grassroots Afro-American activists claim the FBI killed him. Public Enemy frontman Chuck D believes he's still alive. In west Africa, South Africa, Uganda and Zimbabwe, he is revered. "He was a phenomenon and his legacy lingers on," says Sierra Leone journalist Lansana Fofany. "He was so influential on youth in Africa."

This week another Tupac album shot to the top of the US album charts. Until the End of Time, a double album of unfinished recordings re-produced and completed with the help of guest stars such as TLC's Lisa "Left Eye" Lopez, follows last year's acclaimed The Rose That Grew From Concrete, a tribute album and book of lyrics. Even dead, Tupac can still shift units.

During Sierra Leone's civil war, teenage members of the West Side Boyz militia scrawled his "2PAC" logo on the butts of their AK47s and sported Tupac T-shirts. "It created so many problems that non-rebels could be arrested for wearing Tupac T-shirts," says Fofany. In West Side Boyz hideouts, they listened to Tupac's albums, focusing on his more violent lyrics.

But although Tupac prided himself on having the lifestyle of a "playa" (high roller), he is also claimed as a poet and prophet. "He's everyman," says Max Bankole Jarrett, a Liberian presenter with the BBC World Service's Network Africa show. "He's full of contradictions, and that's where his power comes from."

Tupac's lyrics were often misogynistic, and his reputation as a womaniser preceded him. In his book Got Your Back, his former bodyguard Frank Alexander claimed Janet Jackson insisted he take an Aids test before kissing her for the movie Poetic Justice. But in many of his lyrics he demonstrated a sensitivity and imagination that widened his appeal way beyond the "THUG LIFE" tattooed across his chest. "Tupac represented the complexity of young black males in America," claims London-based music journalist and broadcaster Fusion. He refers to the searing social comment found on tracks such as Brenda's Got a Baby, from 2Pacalypse Now - about a pregnant 12-year-old: "She didn't know what to throw away and what to keep/She wrapped the baby up and threw him in the trash heap/I guess she thought she'd get away/Wouldn't hear the cries/She didn't realise/How much that little baby had her eyes."

Both hero and villain, Tupac epitomises the conflict between playa and poet that defines so many rappers. "He was a study in contradiction - which I think most of us are if we're real," says Nayaba Arinde, an editor at New York's black daily newspaper The Daily Challenge. "I wasn't crazy about how he spoke about women, and he knew better. But he was a product of his environment, and he told us that time and time again."

Tupac was born Lesane Parish Crooks in Brooklyn in 1971. His mother, Afeni, renamed him Tupac Amaru (Shining Servant) Shakur (Thankful to God) when he was a small child. There are two candidates for the role of biological father: his stepfather, Mutulu Shakur, was a Black Panther, jailed in 1984 for an armoured car robbery. Afeni had been involved with the Panthers in New York and was also friends with "Geronimo" Pratt, a Panther who later spent 25 years in jail after being wrongly convicted of murder.

At the age of 12, Tupac joined a Harlem theatre group and studied ballet and acting. But crime and the politics of oppression dominated his youth - especially when his mother moved him in 1988 to Marin City, California, where he began to run with the wrong crowd. His mother struggled with crack addiction. None the less, Tupac became chairman of a youth group called the New Afrikan Panthers, performing plays at community centres. His first manager, Leila Steinberg, met him while reading Winnie Mandela's book Part of My Soul Went With Him in a park; Tupac appeared and announced: "I love that book." He joined the group Digital Underground as a dancer, then rapper.

Controversy stalked Tupac from the minute he released his explicit solo debut album 2Pacalypse Now in 1991. Vice-president Dan Quayle declared there was "no place for 2Pacalypse Now in our society". Tupac was arrested in 1992 after a fight that left a six-year-old bystander dead from a stray bullet (the charges were later dismissed). He was sentenced to 15 days in jail for assaulting director Allen Hughes during the filming of Menace II Society. In 1993 he was charged with shooting two off-duty police officers in Atlanta, but the charges were dropped. He starred in a string of successful movies such as Juice and Gridlock'd with actors such as James Belushi and Tim Roth, and his albums - Strictly 4 My N.I.G.G.A.Z, Me Against the World - kept selling. Platinum, double platinum, with lyrics that flipped from gangsta bragging to social comment to frequent predictions of his death.

In 1995 Tupac was shot five times and robbed of $40,000 worth of jewellery in New York during an east coast-west coast feud that involved Tupac and New York producer Puff Daddy and rapper Biggie Smalls, whom Tupac then accused of being involved in the hit. Jailed for four and a half years for sexually abusing a fan, Tupac was released when LA rap mogul Suge Knight, who had controversial links to LA's Bloods gangs, posted a $1.4m bond. In return, Tupac signed to Knight's Death Row label, home to Snoop Doggy Dogg, who himself had faced a murder charge, and released the album All Eyes on Me.

Tupac stoked the feud, claiming to have slept with Faith Evans, wife of Biggie Smalls, who threatened to get his own back. In 1996 Tupac was murdered after a Mike Tyson fight in Las Vegas; Suge Knight, in the car with him, was barely touched by the bullets. Weeks later Biggie Smalls was killed in LA. Since then, the only suspect for Tupac's murder, Orlando Anderson, has himself been murdered.

Yet, for many, Tupac remains an inspirational figure. "There's an African proverb that goes, 'It's better to light a candle than curse the darkness'," says Jarrett. "Tupac started out cursing the darkness, and then lit a very bright candle."

Tupac was certainly aware of hip-hop's wider cultural heritage. "From ancient African civilisation, poets went from village to village and that's how stories and messages were taught," he once said. Nayaba Arinde believes this political awareness may have led to Tupac's murder. "The government understands the power of the potential and someone like Tupac has the ear of the youth," she says. "I wouldn't rule it out. You have to remember that this is still an unsolved murder."

Afenki Shakur is now the driving force behind her son's career. Tupac wrote prolifically during his prison,term and there's more to come, including an album named after his final, and revealing, choice of alter-ego: Makavelli. And with a film in development, the myth shows no sign of losing its potency.

 Until the End of Time is out now on Interscope.
