fields.headline: South Yorkshire
fields.trailText: A Country Diary
fields.body:
It is amazing what you learn when you start rummaging around in the local archive office. Reading through the enclosure award for Kimberworth of 1800, I found details of just how well Earl Fitzwilliam had done out of the process. When it came to fencing the outer limits of the earl's new estates, the local residents found themselves financing his lordship's needs. They gave some of their land to the earl in lieu of tithes foregone. They would have little choice, as land allotted under the enclosure award would probably be the only capital asset they had and the only way to buy out their future obligations.

Having given up some of their future livelihood, the villagers then found an extra hurdle. The commissioners decreed that they, not the earl, should plant the hawthorn hedge and protective fence to mark off the earl's land, around the outer perimeter. It was at no small cost, either. The award specifies "good and substantial oak posts and double rails with such ditches on each side thereof as the said commissioners should direct and appoint and also with good and substantial gates to be made where necessary in the said fences..."

This particular parcel of enclosed land, the subject of my research, lies between the village of Thorpe Hesley and the tiny settlement of Scholes, a ribbon of houses and farms along a twisting, winding road which snakes its way towards the earl's then home at Wentworth.

In four weeks' time, the present villagers are off to a public inquiry which will decide whether a housing development of 1,200 homes should meld the two villages together. They will be using skylarks, partridges, brown hares, newts and orchids as their arguments. The developer will fund its costs through the profits it makes here or elsewhere. The local council will pay its costs via the taxes that villagers pay to it. Local residents will pay their modest bills for the inquiry via collections and donations. Although the landscape has changed significantly in the last 200 years, some things have hardly changed at all.

fields.headline: The trouble with hope
fields.trailText: Smallweed
fields.body:
Consider this: "While the hemlock was being prepared, Socrates was learning a melody on the flute. 'What use will that be to you?' he was asked. 'At least,' he replied, 'I will learn this melody before I die.'" (Quoted in Italo Calvino, Why Read the Classics?) When I read this, I thought at first: how poignant, how profound. But a moment later I thought: how utterly pointless. I still cannot decide which of these responses makes better sense.

Consider this also: according to Lord Lytton's Tales of Miletus, Sisyphus, who was, as ever, engaged in pushing a rock up a mountain only to have it roll down again, was asked by Orpheus how he could endure so ceaseless and vain an employment. Sisyphus replied that he hoped to accomplish the task. "Never," exclaimed Orpheus. "It can never be done." "Well then," said Sisyphus, "the worst fate I can have is to have everlasting hope." Which leaves me with much the same problem.

As I constantly warn the young, it is always risky in journalism to describe anything as a first. Dare to aver that someone or other is the first left-handed Australian to attempt the pole vault while munching a Mars bar and playing a ukelele and an angry note will arrive from Lostwithiel claiming a precedent. The point was neatly illustrated this week in the Daily Telegraph (of which Charles Moore is editor). On its news pages, it reported that Nina Skorupska, 39, had been appointed the first woman manager at Didcot power station. "She is also the first woman to be appointed manager by the power group Innogy or its predecessor, National Power, from which it demerged in October 2000," the paper dared to aver.

Nothing wrong there. The facts are easily verifiable, and should the story prove to be wrong, that can be blamed on some hapless PR person. But what is this on the obituaries page? The late Dillon Ripley, for 20 years head of the Smithsonian Institute, is described as "the first ornithologist in a century to see a spiny babbler". He did so in Nepal, which was then closed to the west. Is this not a demonstration of the incurable colonialist tendencies of the Telegraph (of which Charles Moore is still editor)? Were there no Nepalese ornithologists to disturb the babbler's privacy - or do they not count? Altogether more sensible is the caption beneath a picture of Lt Col Anthony Jervis, who is also obituarised. "Among the last beaglers to hunt in shorts," it announces. How I admire that "among"! Some gnarled old pro has spotted the danger. He doesn't want the Telegraph's offices picketed by hundreds of ancient beaglers wearing shorts.

And so, as spring shoots its first shy tendrils into a waiting, expectant world, to Smallweed's intermittent series on places to visit this summer, foot and mouth or no foot and mouth. Today it's the turn of East Anglia, and specifically Orford, some 20 miles eastnorth-east of Ipswich. Though he has sojourned in Southwold, wandered in Walberswick, dabbled in Dunwich, ambled through Aldeburgh and blundered through Blythburgh, Smallweed has never set foot in Orford, but is lured there by the Shell Guide's description:

"A disfranchised pocket-borough, with a dissolved corporation, an empty market-place, a great 12th-century royal castle of which the keep alone is standing, a church of which the Romanesque aisled chancel is abandoned to the weather and great 14th-century tower truncated, an Austin friary of which fragmentary walls remain, a quay filled in and built over, two ancient hospitals vanished, and town lanes like those at Blythburgh, represented now by tracks though vegetable gardens, but perpetuating their former character by the pungency of their recorded names."

My kind of place exactly. The church, writes Norman Scarfe, is unforgettably associated with the first performances of Britten's Noye's Fludde and Curlew River: "As you cross the large porch think of (George) Crabbe's wild father as a young man using it as a schoolroom for Orford children." There is also a nearby bird sanctuary, famous for its avocets. Sir Robert Walpole, prime minister for 21 years till he fell, let it not be forgotten, on a vote on the representation of Chippenham, was first earl of Orford. I have checked with the English Heritage website, which says the castle is open. And it's nearer and cheaper this Easter, I dare to aver, than Tuscany.

I'll tell you what: it is not only the BBC's Match of the Day where the resident team of spiny babblers keeps repeating this worn-out formula. I counted five outbreaks in the ITV commentary last weekend on the match between mighty Liverpool and not quite so mighty Wycombe Wanderers.

Les Gillett, "regarded as the black sheep of English bowls", is number five on the English Indoor Bowls Association's rankings but cannot get into the national squad of 26. "An incident amounting to horseplay in the team hotel at Bournemouth when he made his international debut two years ago is thought to have coloured the selectors' opinions," a news report says. My advice to this Gillett is to forget about conventional bowls and take up a now neglected game which neatly combines that staid old sport with horseplay. Believe it or not (and I wouldn't if I were you), this game was invented by accident. While out hunting one day in the 1930s after several too many snifters, the legendary polo enthusiast Lt Col Anthony ("Snuffles") Threekingham sailed over a small picket fence and into the midst of a bowls match between Eastbourne Old Irascibles and Bexhill-on-Sea Reserves.

He was, as ever, equipped with his polo mallet, and seeing a bowl on the green mistook it for the kind of ball which is used in polo. (I dare say it has some name like pukka or chukka, but I'm not that well up on bowls terminology nowadays). Anyway: hanging out of his saddle, he thwacked this object with such monstrous force that it bounced off the jack, shot away through the air and landed in a neighbouring county, where horrified residents, thinking it came out of space, hurriedly summoned the rural police. Thus was the sport of mounted bowls ushered into existence. I am told there are still a few mounted bowls clubs in places such as Cowdenbeath and Lostwithiel. Given the average age of surviving players, I would guess that Gillett has an excellent chance of making it into the British team.
fields.bodyText: Consider this: "While the hemlock was being prepared, Socrates was learning a melody on the flute. 'What use will that be to you?' he was asked. 'At least,' he replied, 'I will learn this melody before I die.'" (Quoted in Italo Calvino, Why Read the Classics?) When I read this, I thought at first: how poignant, how profound. But a moment later I thought: how utterly pointless. I still cannot decide which of these responses makes better sense. Consider this also: according to Lord Lytton's Tales of Miletus, Sisyphus, who was, as ever, engaged in pushing a rock up a mountain only to have it roll down again, was asked by Orpheus how he could endure so ceaseless and vain an employment. Sisyphus replied that he hoped to accomplish the task. "Never," exclaimed Orpheus. "It can never be done." "Well then," said Sisyphus, "the worst fate I can have is to have everlasting hope." Which leaves me with much the same problem. As I constantly warn the young, it is always risky in journalism to describe anything as a first. Dare to aver that someone or other is the first left-handed Australian to attempt the pole vault while munching a Mars bar and playing a ukelele and an angry note will arrive from Lostwithiel claiming a precedent. The point was neatly illustrated this week in the Daily Telegraph (of which Charles Moore is editor). On its news pages, it reported that Nina Skorupska, 39, had been appointed the first woman manager at Didcot power station. "She is also the first woman to be appointed manager by the power group Innogy or its predecessor, National Power, from which it demerged in October 2000," the paper dared to aver. Nothing wrong there. The facts are easily verifiable, and should the story prove to be wrong, that can be blamed on some hapless PR person. But what is this on the obituaries page? The late Dillon Ripley, for 20 years head of the Smithsonian Institute, is described as "the first ornithologist in a century to see a spiny babbler". He did so in Nepal, which was then closed to the west. Is this not a demonstration of the incurable colonialist tendencies of the Telegraph (of which Charles Moore is still editor)? Were there no Nepalese ornithologists to disturb the babbler's privacy - or do they not count? Altogether more sensible is the caption beneath a picture of Lt Col Anthony Jervis, who is also obituarised. "Among the last beaglers to hunt in shorts," it announces. How I admire that "among"! Some gnarled old pro has spotted the danger. He doesn't want the Telegraph's offices picketed by hundreds of ancient beaglers wearing shorts. And so, as spring shoots its first shy tendrils into a waiting, expectant world, to Smallweed's intermittent series on places to visit this summer, foot and mouth or no foot and mouth. Today it's the turn of East Anglia, and specifically Orford, some 20 miles eastnorth-east of Ipswich. Though he has sojourned in Southwold, wandered in Walberswick, dabbled in Dunwich, ambled through Aldeburgh and blundered through Blythburgh, Smallweed has never set foot in Orford, but is lured there by the Shell Guide's description: "A disfranchised pocket-borough, with a dissolved corporation, an empty market-place, a great 12th-century royal castle of which the keep alone is standing, a church of which the Romanesque aisled chancel is abandoned to the weather and great 14th-century tower truncated, an Austin friary of which fragmentary walls remain, a quay filled in and built over, two ancient hospitals vanished, and town lanes like those at Blythburgh, represented now by tracks though vegetable gardens, but perpetuating their former character by the pungency of their recorded names." My kind of place exactly. The church, writes Norman Scarfe, is unforgettably associated with the first performances of Britten's Noye's Fludde and Curlew River: "As you cross the large porch think of (George) Crabbe's wild father as a young man using it as a schoolroom for Orford children." There is also a nearby bird sanctuary, famous for its avocets. Sir Robert Walpole, prime minister for 21 years till he fell, let it not be forgotten, on a vote on the representation of Chippenham, was first earl of Orford. I have checked with the English Heritage website, which says the castle is open. And it's nearer and cheaper this Easter, I dare to aver, than Tuscany. I'll tell you what: it is not only the BBC's Match of the Day where the resident team of spiny babblers keeps repeating this worn-out formula. I counted five outbreaks in the ITV commentary last weekend on the match between mighty Liverpool and not quite so mighty Wycombe Wanderers. fields.headline: Piccoli's progress
fields.standfirst: Michael Billington  in Sicily catches the best of European theatre
fields.trailText: Michael Billington in Sicily catches the best of European theatre
fields.body:
Each spring the great and the good of theatre gather in Taormina, Sicily, for the annual European Theatre Prize. In the past, the palm has gone to great directors and theatre-makers such as Peter Brook, Giorgio Strehler, Robert Wilson and Lev Dodin. This year, refreshingly, the prize - 60,000 euros (around £37,000) - went to the 75-year-old French actor Michel Piccoli, whose career is an object lesson in balancing stage and film.

In Britain, Piccoli is best known for his work in movies by directors such as Luis Bunuel, Louis Malle, Jean-Luc Godard and Claude Chabrol, and for what Pauline Kael called his "nuanced control". But in France he is equally renowned as a stage actor. In recent years, he has played Gaev in Brook's Cherry Orchard, Leontes in The Winter's Tale and the title role in Ibsen's John Gabriel Borkman, as well as appearing in Marguerite Duras's La Maladie de la Mort for Robert Wilson. He is a classic example of how an actor can bring the same iron technique to two media without compromising himself in either.

In Sicily we got only a tantalising glimpse of Piccoli's theatrical art. In Catania's handsomely baroque Bellini Theatre, he played the mysterious illusionist, Cotrone, in an hour-long reduction of Pirandello's The Mountain Giants. Cotrone, who has withdrawn from audiences and life, welcomes to his fantastic villa a group of travelling actors, here played by students and children. The staging, by Klaus- Michael Gruber,was rudimentary. But, roaming round the stage like a weary dancer in a black beret, Piccoli beautifully articulated Cotrone's solitude, sadness and Pirandellian belief in the deadening effect of reason - a far cry, it struck me, from Piccoli's own amiability and political radicalism.

Piccoli represents the strength of a great acting tradition. But European theatre is rapidly changing, as shown by the work of the joint winners of Taormina's New Realities prize for more experimental work: Alain Platel and Heiner Goebbels. Last week I saw Platel's extraordinary choral spectacle, Because I Sing, at London's Roundhouse. In Taormina, his Ghent-based company staged Iets Op Bach, which blends dance, drama and music in a way that looks playfully anarchic but I suspect is rigorously controlled. Eight musicians and three singers present formally strict Bach pieces; meanwhile, nine acrobatic dancers offer a physical interpretation studded with violent Catholic imagery and harping on loss of childhood innocence. There are times when I resent the physical interference with the purity of Bach's music but, having seen two Platel shows in quick succession, I cannot doubt his visual wizardry.

What Taormina confirmed, however, is that the theatrical barriers between text, mime, music, dance and video are crumbling fast. Goebbels presented a piece called The Left Hand of Glenn Gould, which used texts by Proust and Kafka, music from a variety of sources and close-up camerawork to explore the human face. It was totally unclassifiable, sometimes nerve-grating, but always intriguing.

In Edinburgh this year Goebbels will be offering a musical spectacular based on Gertrude Stein. And, in Taormina, it struck me that while great texts will always require great actors like Piccoli, European theatre is entering a phase of formal eclecticism that could either produce something startlingly new - or lead us up a chaotic cul-de-sac.

fields.headline: A legend in his lunchtime
fields.standfirst: As an impoverished schoolboy in Leeds, he sold his first piece of comic writing. He went on to a dazzling career in Fleet Street and his plays and novels have won global acclaim. For this prolific, misanthropic wit, writing is a compulsion, reports Nicholas Wroe
fields.trailText: As an impoverished schoolboy in Leeds, he sold his first piece of comic writing. He went on to a dazzling career in Fleet Street and his plays and novels have won global acclaim. For this prolific, misanthropic wit, writing is a compulsion, reports Nicholas Wroe
fields.body:
It was 50 years ago that Keith Waterhouse first set foot in Fleet Street. He had travelled from his home in Leeds to be interviewed for a job as a reporter on the now defunct News Chronicle. It simply hadn't occurred to the 21-year-old that he might be rejected, but he realised something had gone wrong when the interview ended and he was told not to forget to send an invoice for his travel expenses. Before beginning the long journey back home, he walked down to Ludgate Circus to pay his respects at the plaque there commemorating Edgar Wallace, his hero. Wallace had sold newspapers on that spot as a boy before going on to be a journalist, Boer war correspondent, novelist, playwright and Hollywood script writer. This was the future the dejected Waterhouse thought he had just been excluded from. However, as he noted in his memoirs, in reality it was all just around the corner.

"How was I to know then that within months I should be established on Fleet Street," he wrote, "that within three years I should be more familiar with New York, Washington, Moscow and Leningrad than I now was with London, that within four I should be turning down the post of the New Chronicle's chief reporter, that within five I should be publishing my first novel, and within 10 I should see my name in lights on Shaftesbury Avenue and on the cinema posters of Leicester Square?"

That catalogue of achievement takes him up to 1961, and since then there has been a great deal more of the same. He says the only thing Wallace did that he hasn't, is to own racehorses. Late last year Waterhouse was given a What the Papers Say lifetime achievement award. "A bit unnerving," he recalls, before asking: "Where to from there?" But this is a rhetorical question. He has no intention of going anywhere. As far back as 1994, just before his 65th birthday, one observer noted that he had already passed through the stages of being a survivor, an anachronism, a dinosaur and a monument. Whatever his status, he just keeps chugging on and the novels, plays and journalism continue to pile up.

His twice-weekly column in the Daily Mail, with its occasional cast of Dickensian-named bureaucrats, politicians, illiterates and the rest, is not to everyone's taste. Julie Burchill recently launched into him. "There are many irritating things about the Daily Mail, but surely a contender for most irritating item is Keith Waterhouse's recurrent Sharon and Tracy column, in which two monumentally thick working-class shopgirls demonstrate that they have the IQ of a sock. From time to time, highly qualified young Sharons and Tracys write in to the paper and request that Waterhouse desists. But the tired old routine drags on and on. Can we imagine Waterhouse being allowed regularly to spoof two stupid, idle West Indians or Irishmen in his column, even in the Daily Mail? Of course not."

Another attack came after he called William Hague a wimp for consulting Ffion. But none of this has stopped Waterhouse's lucid combination of fierce topicality and an encyclopaedic memory ensuring that he is still one of the best-read and best-paid columnists around. A good example was provided earlier this week when the travails of Sophie Wessex and Marks & Spencer were thrown into the pot, along with flashbacks of 30s Leeds.

Leading humorist and columnist Craig Brown shares many reservations about Waterhouse's approach, but notes that while, "the Mail can swamp even the best writer because its own voice is so strong, nevertheless, at least once a month, Waterhouse does have an original idea which is more than most columnists can manage. I think the main thing is that he is quite a hero really. No one else has done a humorous column for such a long time, and so skilfully and with such an ease of style."

Waterhouse's work in other mediums is similarly respected. As a novelist from the late 50s, his fiction, of which Billy Liar is still the best known, was seen as part of the revolt of the angry young men. He has now written 14 novels and academic and critic Richard Hoggart says: "I very much admire his work. He's very talented and witty, quirky and outspoken."

Ned Sherrin has directed five of Waterhouse's 20 plays, including the hugely successful Jeffrey Bernard is Unwell. He says that, "there'll always be a place in the theatre for Billy Liar, and Celebration [his 1961 play written, like Billy Liar, with Willis Hall] will always be worth reviving. He has an instinctive stage craft. God knows where he picked it up."

The best guess is somewhere in a working-class Leeds childhood that, Waterhouse perceptively notes, although packed with escapism, was in fact an escape into realism. He was transfixed by the nitty gritty of Leeds life, and his recollection of his adventures around the city invest the place with the same lyrical nostalgia that Woody Allen does to his childhood New York. Fellow Leeds boy Gerald Kaufman said Waterhouse's 1994 memoir, City Lights, gave back to him, "the Leeds that I loved, the Leeds that time and change had taken away". (Waterhouse had already complimented Kaufman with the sublimely backhanded observation that his book, My Life in the Silver Screen, was, "the best volume of film-going memoirs ever written by a politician".)

Waterhouse was born in 1929 in a back-to-back house in the Hunslet area of the city. He was the youngest of four boys and a girl. His father, Ernest, was a heavy-drinking costermonger who sold vegetables from a cart in South Leeds and died when Waterhouse was aged three. His total estate was a brown suit and a ha'penny left in the pocket, which was given to the young Keith. These were the hungry 30s and the family was visited by bailiffs who took all the furniture except the mattresses and a stool for his mother, Elsie, to sit on. "But we were richer than the poorest because my mother had a thing about shoes," he recalls. "She thought shoes were respectable and boots were not - and clogs positively not. She got the shoes from the public benefit shoe company, so we were a shoe-wearing family, which was quite important."

He says his mother was ambitious for her children, "within her knowledge and limitations". She once bought a book in French for his sister - "I suppose she thought she would assimilate this language somehow" - and when she found Keith wanted to write, she bought him notebooks. "But with the greatest respect to my mother," he says, "she had no idea who I was or what I was about. I was a bit of a cuckoo in the nest, and she was like the mother bird bringing worms home and not really knowing if cuckoos ate worms. She knew I was different, and she encouraged this difference without quite knowing what it was. For instance, she got me into school a year early, aged four, because I wouldn't stop reading."

Despite this early academic promise, Waterhouse failed the 11- plus but, perversely, this put him in some pretty good company. The Leeds-born critic Richard Hoggart had failed the same exam, and so did Waterhouse's eventual writing partner, Willis Hall. However, at 13, Waterhouse won a scholarship to the local college of commerce where he came under the influence of a science teacher who had to teach English because of the wartime shortage of teachers. "He would just chuck a book like Huckleberry Finn at me and say 'you might like this'." Although Waterhouse's mother had expected him to leave school at 14 to bring some money into the house, she allowed him to stay an extra 18 months. "She wanted me 'to get on', as the phrase was," he says, but he was already contributing financially at home. "I had at least five paper rounds, I sold firewood and I had a window-cleaning round, ground floor only because I didn't have a ladder. As a schoolboy, I was in fact earning at my height more than I earned in my first job."

When he left school, he became a clerk in an undertakers-cum-surveyors, auctioneers and estate agents, who also hired out limousines. Years later it provided the setting for Billy Liar, but at this stage he says he was writing "sub Wodehouse stories set in Mayfair. The idea of using a Leeds undertakers' parlour didn't cross my mind."

Waterhouse's career as a writer was sealed when at 15 he sent a humorous piece about a conversation in a music shop to Punch. The editor wrote back saying "not quite" - "which was as good as an acceptance from any other magazine". So Waterhouse pressed his only copy of the typed manuscript under a damp towel with a flat iron, as he had been taught by the Writer magazine, and sent it off to a magazine called London Opinion. They paid him two guineas for it.

His career as a journalist was put on hold when was called up for National Service in the RAF, but as soon as he was demobbed he fulfilled his ambition to be a reporter on the Yorkshire Evening Post. He says, looking back, his ambition was "crazily optimistic", but when he told his mother, "she just accepted that I would be and I believed it totally as well. It was more arrogance than confidence, but I was the driven one of the family, although at the time I didn't know I was driving."

A colleague on the paper was Barbara Taylor, now better known as the bestselling novelist Barbara Taylor Bradford. She remembers Waterhouse with, "flaming red unruly hair rising up from his head", kicking against the paper's owners, the Leeds Conservative Newspaper Company, by going round the corridors singing the Red Flag. He helped her with her copy and taught her how to manufacture an expense account.

"He'd say, 'Barbara, you're going to shame us with your two-and-six expenses and we've all put in for five quid'," she recalls. "He also used to borrow 10 shillings off me - which he always paid back - and take me to lunch in the Kardomah, where he'd regale me about how he was going to go to Fleet Street and going to write plays." In a neat illustration of how far they have both since travelled, the last time Waterhouse and Taylor met was at the Dorchester where they were chatting to the then prime minister, John Major.

While all of his career ambitions were fulfilled long ago, Waterhouse still continues the routine he's had for the past 40 years: churning out the pages on an ancient Adler portable typewriter from the cluttered study he calls "the word factory" in his Earl's Court mansion flat home. He is not exactly taciturn, but there is a stillness and quietness, although friends insist that he is not in the least melancholy or lonely. He invariably answers questions in a single, neat sentence and says that writing is not something he likes doing, it is something he likes having done. "It's what I do, it's what I am for. Whether I like it or not doesn't really come into it."

Ned Sherrin says Waterhouse, "gets up when the cock crows and does his work and so he is free for lunch. He doesn't eat a great deal but it is very celebratory. There's always that salad left untouched which he reckons he imbibes by osmosis." He likes to have a drink on the go most of the afternoon and evening, but says he never gets a hangover, nor missed a morning's work because of it. His first Fleet Street job was on the Daily Mirror in 1951. He joined within a few weeks of the legendary editor, Hugh Cudlipp, who "kind of adopted me", says Waterhouse. "I learned a hell of a lot from him. It was a bit in the manner of my old English teacher throwing Huckleberry Finn at me, but he would throw assignments. He'd say 'go to the south of France and write about having a good time'. He was a great believer in bread and circuses. He would do the heavy politics and then say, 'that's enough of politics, let's have some fun in the paper', and I was involved in both sides."

As a newsman, Waterhouse was a correspondent in America, Russia and Cyprus. With the close links between the Labour party high command and the Mirror, Waterhouse found himself drafting articles and speeches for Hugh Gaitskill and Harold Wilson. "I never belonged to the Labour Party but I did dabble," he says. "But I really go with my friend Richard Littlejohn on this. He says it's the task of the columnist to sit at the back throwing bottles, and I rather believe that."

This approach seems calculated to bait a certain sort of politician. When Harriet Harman, as secretary of state for social security, was promoting after-school clubs for children, the example she gave of opposition to her ideas was a Waterhouse column. His view was that children should be, "falling into ponds, eating poisonous berries, contracting stomach-ache from under-ripe stolen apples, getting lost, being bitten by dogs, fighting and starting fires, sitting in cowpats and acquiring bumps the size of a duck-egg on their heads". Despite this flippancy, he has contributed to government education policy as a member of the Kingman Committee on teaching English in the mid 80s.

Friends say that, while he can deliver the occasional stunning one-liners, he is more prone to a sort of surreal schoolboy humour. There are lots of stories of him behaving badly at party conferences. At one Blackpool Labour conference in the mid 70s, via a series of complicated bets, he won the trousers of a fellow reporter and then went round the bars introducing the trousers to various members of the Callaghan cabinet. Once in Venice he bought the entire stock of clockwork soldiers from a stall and marched them into the Grand Canal because he had seen a similar thing in a New Yorker cartoon.

The distinguished former industrial editor of the Mirror, Geoffrey Goodman, says that while Waterhouse was often great fun to be with, he wasn't a regular in the Mirror pub, known as the Stab in the Back. "He sought out his own territory and was much more inclined to hang around theatreland. He's only really at home with journalists if they are his mates."

Wherever he hung around, it was for long enough to precipitate the end of his first marriage. He had met Joan Foster in Leeds when they were both 16, and they married at 21. Almost the first thing they did was move to London for the Mirror job and their three children were all born there. He says the marriage was not untypical of Fleet Street marriages of the time in that he didn't see his family for days on end.

When the marriage finished in the mid 60s, he actually began to see more of his children with regular weekend and midweek dates, which continued well after they became adults. His son, Bob, is now the artistic director of a theatre in Buffalo, New York, and has staged a successful production of Jeffrey Bernard is Unwell. His daughter Sarah runs a picture-framing business in Barnes. His other daughter, Penny, died of heart disease two years ago at 43, after a prolonged illness. It is a measure of how private a man Waterhouse is that even when he told close friends about it, they didn't feel able to ask him about what had happened.

Friends reinforce his aversion to the personal. "The worst thing you can do to Keith," says one, "is to either tell him a joke - he doesn't mind listening to an anecdote, but a look of fear and pain comes over him when someone starts to tell a joke - or tell him you have a personal problem that you'd like to talk about." Jaci Stephen, the journalist, has been a friend of Waterhouse since she gave one of his many sitcoms a terrible review about 10 years ago. She says that while, "he absolutely understands how people work, you never talk about things like that with him. He's terrific company but he's an extremely private person who is much happier talking about people in the business and what's going on in Fleet Street."

Waterhouse married for a second time in 1984, to the journalist Stella Bingham. They divorced in 1989, but still see each other regularly. "Marriage didn't suit either of us," he explains. "We got on well enough before, and we get on well now." In 1994, his former secretary and mistress, Jean Leyland, referred to in his columns as his "flame-haired factotum", threatened to take him to an industrial tribunal for unfair dismissal. Leyland gave an interview in which she claimed, "at 1pm he would expect smoked salmon sandwiches and a bottle of champagne, and I had to put on my black basque, suspenders and stripogram gear". The case was settled out of court, and when asked about it he just waves his hand and mutters, "an interlude time. I've forgotten about that."

Although he was a star of Cudlipp's Mirror, and said he enjoyed work as a news and features reporter, he also wanted to do, "something less ephemeral. I wanted to expand." He always thought he had lived between two stools as far as writing was concerned. "Down in Nottingham there was DH Lawrence writing out of muck heaps and pits, and in London there was PG Wodehouse and the Drones club. But I was stuck in a council estate in Leeds: who would want to read about that? Then I read Dylan Thomas's stories about his adolescence, Portrait of an Artist as a Young Dog, which was a real eye-opener. It came as a blaze that you could write about anything, and it was up to you to bring the society you were writing about alive."

A newspaper strike in 1956 gave him the time, and he wrote his first novel, There Is a Happy Land, which was set on a Leeds housing estate. Four years later he left the Mirror staff but was given £1,000 a year by Hugh Cudlipp not to write for any other paper. He maintained contact with the paper as a freelance and started his twice-weekly column there in 1970. He eventually left after the paper was bought by Robert Maxwell. "I am rather in favour of larger than life newspaper bosses," he says, "but he was a bit too large." Former Mirror editor, Mike Molloy, says Waterhouse's presence in its pages gave the paper a lift. "He mostly worked at home, but when he did come in to the office it was good for the paper because people were genuinely proud to have someone of his stature knocking around."

Waterhouse's first act after leaving the staff was to write Billy Liar, the story of the daydreaming Billy Fisher planning his escape from his job in the Leeds undertakers. He left 10,000 words of it in a taxi and had to start again. "The best thing that happened to me; it was pretentious twaddle." He says it was a life changing event, but by then it wasn't really rags to riches. "It was more suede shoes to Gucci shoes, not that I ever wore Gucci shoes, but I could if I wanted to."

The phrase Billy Liar has entered the culture, and he has in his study framed front pages of it as headlines. Two recent examples are from the New York Post about Bill Clinton in relation to Monica Lewinsky, and in the Sun about William Hague's claims to have drunk 14 pints of beers a day. The novel has never been out of print, the stage version was chosen as one of the 100 best plays of the last century by the National Theatre, and the classic 1963 film starring Tom Courtney and Julie Christie was recently revived to critical acclaim in New York.

Of his other fiction, he says his favourite is the 1981 novel, Maggie Muggins, a first person account of the life of a young alcoholic woman living in Earl's Court, which received widespread acclaim. His 14th and latest novel, Soho, is published next week. It tells the contemporary story of a young Leeds boy searching for his girlfriend. Waterhouse says he's always had a fixation on the place. "It is a conurbation of truants, which is what I like about it. Jeffrey Bernard was the Huckleberry Finn of Soho. The rest of us were going home and paying mortgages and educating children, but Jeff was paddling his raft up and down Old Compton Street."

The novel is, of course, funny and picaresque, with some wonderful lines and observations. It also has a slightly melancholy air, with several deaths of characters as well as the death of the old Soho. "But part of Soho is always dying as another part is renewing itself," he explains.

It was Willis Hall, who first wrote with Waterhouse on a youth club magazine when they were both 14, who encouraged Waterhouse's move in to the theatre, suggesting that Billy Liar would make a good play. "And this was the 60s," recalls Waterhouse, "when you couldn't move on the slag heaps of the north for film and television crews. We were caught up in all that."

The pair scripted two more key British films, Whistle Down the Wind and A Kind of Loving, and in Hollywood they worked, un-credited, on Hitchcock's Torn Curtain. Back in London they took an office in Bond Street above Vidal Sassoon's salon. Willis Hall describes their routine. "We'd start work at about nine in the morning and work until lunchtime. Then we seemed to go off and piss it up for God knows how many hours, but we'd always be back in the office at nine."

As well as films they also worked in television. Starting with sketches for the likes of TW3 and the Frost Report, they went on to write scripts for a huge variety of programmes, including Budgie, Queenie's Castle and Worzel Gummidge. Who now remembers The Upchat Line, in which John Alderton played a freeloading newspaper hack who lived out of a locker in Marylebone station?

But it was the theatre and theatrical life that was Waterhouse's greatest love. As a boy in Leeds, he would take girls to the cinema but not to the theatre, even though it was cheaper, because he would prefer to watch the play. "There is a wonderful ephemeral family feeling of being in rehearsal and then playing out of town for a couple of weeks. Perhaps the greatest critical acclaim he has received in the theatre was for his and Willis Hall's National Theatre adaptation of the Italian dramatist de Filippo's Saturday, Sunday, Monday, and Filumena, which won the 1978 Olivier award for best comedy. Ned Sherrin says the recent translation of de Filippo's work, put on by Peter Hall, "didn't compare to the one Keith and Willis did". In 1986, Sherrin directed Waterhouse's Mr and Mrs Pooter, starring Judi Dench and Michael Williams, and went on to direct another four Waterhouse plays, including his hugely successful 1989 adaptation of Jeffrey Bernard's Spectator columns, Jeffrey Bernard is Unwell. Waterhouse says that he expected the play to last for the few weeks that Peter O'Toole was able to star in it. But Sherrin says: "I think Keith always felt it would work. Waterhouse's next play was Bookends in 1990, which was adapted from Craig Brown's book, The Marsh-Marlowe Letters. "The book was a kind of satire on two crusty old men," explains Brown, "but somehow on stage the crusty old men were kind of being applauded. I think he was over sympathetic to these characters that I was sending up."

A similar complaint is made about Waterhouse's treatment of Jeffrey Bernard. Brown says: "I thought Bernard was a pretty unpleasant man. I didn't find his alcoholism and misogyny amusing, but somehow, for people who liked the play, he was made to seem a bit cuddly. I think if Waterhouse has a failing, it's that sort of slight misanthropy."

However, a propensity to the crusty and the reactionary is something of an occupational hazard for a popular newspaper columnist. But that said, Waterhouse has never been an entirely predictable creature of the Mail's world view. Although he recently supported the grocer charged after insisting on selling his bananas in pounds, not kilos, and is an enthusiastic Brussels basher, there are still traces of the Red Flag-singing radical of his youth, and in his recent column on the Wessex debacle, a few bottles were thrown at the house of Windsor in general.

It is widely assumed that because he is so productive, Waterhouse can churn out copy on demand. Even his former editor, Mike Molloy, who had never actually seen him write, thought so until they were once in a New York hotel. "We were due to meet for dinner so I knocked on his door and there was a voice as if from 10 fathoms deep saying 'come in'. I went in and his column was lying on the bed looking like a map of the Ypres Salient. It was covered with all these lines and crosses and stabs marks from his fountain pen. 'It's coming a bit slowly,' he grunted, and we agreed to meet a bit later. After an hour or so, Keith turned up at the restaurant whistling, and had I not seen him earlier, I'd never have known what he had gone through."

Whatever the pains of the process, Waterhouse continues to do what he has always done and has another novel and a new play in progress. Despite a persistent wheezy cough, which he has had since he gave up smoking 30 years ago, he says he is in good health and has never missed a day's work. He doesn't intend to start now. While he says he does look back fondly on the old Fleet Street, in what he calls its anecdotage, to his credit he doesn't overdo the reminiscences about the good old days of hot metal and drinking in El Vino's.

"The only time anyone is in El Vino's now is after a memorial service, with people bellowing 'it's what he would have wanted'." Waterhouse genuinely prefers to look to the future where, for him, there is always the next book, play or column. "I'll always have something else to do. If I write everything that's in my head, I've got five years' work and during the course of that five years other things will crop up and I'll die and that will be about it. I suppose I must actually like sitting here in this room, with some silly detective play on the radio, banging away on that machine." Life at a glance: Keith Spencer Waterhouse

Born: 6 February 1929, Leeds

Family: Married Joan Foster 1950, divorced, one son, two daughters; married Stella Bingham 1984, divorced.

Career: journalist 1950-present; columnist with Daily Mirror 70-86; Daily Mail 86-present.

Some films with Willis Hall: Billy Liar 60; Whistle Down the Wind 61; A Kind of Loving 62

Some plays with Willis Hall: Billy Liar 60; Celebration 61; The Card (musical) 73

Some solo plays: Mr and Mrs Nobody 86; Jeffrey Bernard is Unwell 89; Bookends 90

Some TV series: Budgie 71-72; Billy Liar 73; Andy Capp 88

Some books: There is a Happy Land 57; Billy Liar 59; Jubb 63; Maggie Muggins 81; Our Song 88; Bimbo 1990; Daily Mirror Style 80; Mrs Pooter's Diary 83; City Lights (memoir) 94

Awards: CBE 1991

 Soho is published by Sceptre, price £16.99
fields.bodyText: It was 50 years ago that Keith Waterhouse first set foot in Fleet Street. He had travelled from his home in Leeds to be interviewed for a job as a reporter on the now defunct News Chronicle. It simply hadn't occurred to the 21-year-old that he might be rejected, but he realised something had gone wrong when the interview ended and he was told not to forget to send an invoice for his travel expenses. Before beginning the long journey back home, he walked down to Ludgate Circus to pay his respects at the plaque there commemorating Edgar Wallace, his hero. Wallace had sold newspapers on that spot as a boy before going on to be a journalist, Boer war correspondent, novelist, playwright and Hollywood script writer. This was the future the dejected Waterhouse thought he had just been excluded from. However, as he noted in his memoirs, in reality it was all just around the corner. "How was I to know then that within months I should be established on Fleet Street," he wrote, "that within three years I should be more familiar with New York, Washington, Moscow and Leningrad than I now was with London, that within four I should be turning down the post of the New Chronicle's chief reporter, that within five I should be publishing my first novel, and within 10 I should see my name in lights on Shaftesbury Avenue and on the cinema posters of Leicester Square?" That catalogue of achievement takes him up to 1961, and since then there has been a great deal more of the same. He says the only thing Wallace did that he hasn't, is to own racehorses. Late last year Waterhouse was given a What the Papers Say lifetime achievement award. "A bit unnerving," he recalls, before asking: "Where to from there?" But this is a rhetorical question. He has no intention of going anywhere. As far back as 1994, just before his 65th birthday, one observer noted that he had already passed through the stages of being a survivor, an anachronism, a dinosaur and a monument. Whatever his status, he just keeps chugging on and the novels, plays and journalism continue to pile up. His twice-weekly column in the Daily Mail, with its occasional cast of Dickensian-named bureaucrats, politicians, illiterates and the rest, is not to everyone's taste. Julie Burchill recently launched into him. "There are many irritating things about the Daily Mail, but surely a contender for most irritating item is Keith Waterhouse's recurrent Sharon and Tracy column, in which two monumentally thick working-class shopgirls demonstrate that they have the IQ of a sock. From time to time, highly qualified young Sharons and Tracys write in to the paper and request that Waterhouse desists. But the tired old routine drags on and on. Can we imagine Waterhouse being allowed regularly to spoof two stupid, idle West Indians or Irishmen in his column, even in the Daily Mail? Of course not." Another attack came after he called William Hague a wimp for consulting Ffion. But none of this has stopped Waterhouse's lucid combination of fierce topicality and an encyclopaedic memory ensuring that he is still one of the best-read and best-paid columnists around. A good example was provided earlier this week when the travails of Sophie Wessex and Marks & Spencer were thrown into the pot, along with flashbacks of 30s Leeds. Leading humorist and columnist Craig Brown shares many reservations about Waterhouse's approach, but notes that while, "the Mail can swamp even the best writer because its own voice is so strong, nevertheless, at least once a month, Waterhouse does have an original idea which is more than most columnists can manage. I think the main thing is that he is quite a hero really. No one else has done a humorous column for such a long time, and so skilfully and with such an ease of style." Waterhouse's work in other mediums is similarly respected. As a novelist from the late 50s, his fiction, of which Billy Liar is still the best known, was seen as part of the revolt of the angry young men. He has now written 14 novels and academic and critic Richard Hoggart says: "I very much admire his work. He's very talented and witty, quirky and outspoken." Ned Sherrin has directed five of Waterhouse's 20 plays, including the hugely successful Jeffrey Bernard is Unwell. He says that, "there'll always be a place in the theatre for Billy Liar, and Celebration [his 1961 play written, like Billy Liar, with Willis Hall] will always be worth reviving. He has an instinctive stage craft. God knows where he picked it up." The best guess is somewhere in a working-class Leeds childhood that, Waterhouse perceptively notes, although packed with escapism, was in fact an escape into realism. He was transfixed by the nitty gritty of Leeds life, and his recollection of his adventures around the city invest the place with the same lyrical nostalgia that Woody Allen does to his childhood New York. Fellow Leeds boy Gerald Kaufman said Waterhouse's 1994 memoir, City Lights, gave back to him, "the Leeds that I loved, the Leeds that time and change had taken away". (Waterhouse had already complimented Kaufman with the sublimely backhanded observation that his book, My Life in the Silver Screen, was, "the best volume of film-going memoirs ever written by a politician".) Waterhouse was born in 1929 in a back-to-back house in the Hunslet area of the city. He was the youngest of four boys and a girl. His father, Ernest, was a heavy-drinking costermonger who sold vegetables from a cart in South Leeds and died when Waterhouse was aged three. His total estate was a brown suit and a ha'penny left in the pocket, which was given to the young Keith. These were the hungry 30s and the family was visited by bailiffs who took all the furniture except the mattresses and a stool for his mother, Elsie, to sit on. "But we were richer than the poorest because my mother had a thing about shoes," he recalls. "She thought shoes were respectable and boots were not - and clogs positively not. She got the shoes from the public benefit shoe company, so we were a shoe-wearing family, which was quite important." He says his mother was ambitious for her children, "within her knowledge and limitations". She once bought a book in French for his sister - "I suppose she thought she would assimilate this language somehow" - and when she found Keith wanted to write, she bought him notebooks. "But with the greatest respect to my mother," he says, "she had no idea who I was or what I was about. I was a bit of a cuckoo in the nest, and she was like the mother bird bringing worms home and not really knowing if cuckoos ate worms. She knew I was different, and she encouraged this difference without quite knowing what it was. For instance, she got me into school a year early, aged four, because I wouldn't stop reading." Despite this early academic promise, Waterhouse failed the 11- plus but, perversely, this put him in some pretty good company. The Leeds-born critic Richard Hoggart had failed the same exam, and so did Waterhouse's eventual writing partner, Willis Hall. However, at 13, Waterhouse won a scholarship to the local college of commerce where he came under the influence of a science teacher who had to teach English because of the wartime shortage of teachers. "He would just chuck a book like Huckleberry Finn at me and say 'you might like this'." Although Waterhouse's mother had expected him to leave school at 14 to bring some money into the house, she allowed him to stay an extra 18 months. "She wanted me 'to get on', as the phrase was," he says, but he was already contributing financially at home. "I had at least five paper rounds, I sold firewood and I had a window-cleaning round, ground floor only because I didn't have a ladder. As a schoolboy, I was in fact earning at my height more than I earned in my first job." When he left school, he became a clerk in an undertakers-cum-surveyors, auctioneers and estate agents, who also hired out limousines. Years later it provided the setting for Billy Liar, but at this stage he says he was writing "sub Wodehouse stories set in Mayfair. The idea of using a Leeds undertakers' parlour didn't cross my mind." Waterhouse's career as a writer was sealed when at 15 he sent a humorous piece about a conversation in a music shop to Punch. The editor wrote back saying "not quite" - "which was as good as an acceptance from any other magazine". So Waterhouse pressed his only copy of the typed manuscript under a damp towel with a flat iron, as he had been taught by the Writer magazine, and sent it off to a magazine called London Opinion. They paid him two guineas for it. His career as a journalist was put on hold when was called up for National Service in the RAF, but as soon as he was demobbed he fulfilled his ambition to be a reporter on the Yorkshire Evening Post. He says, looking back, his ambition was "crazily optimistic", but when he told his mother, "she just accepted that I would be and I believed it totally as well. It was more arrogance than confidence, but I was the driven one of the family, although at the time I didn't know I was driving." A colleague on the paper was Barbara Taylor, now better known as the bestselling novelist Barbara Taylor Bradford. She remembers Waterhouse with, "flaming red unruly hair rising up from his head", kicking against the paper's owners, the Leeds Conservative Newspaper Company, by going round the corridors singing the Red Flag. He helped her with her copy and taught her how to manufacture an expense account. "He'd say, 'Barbara, you're going to shame us with your two-and-six expenses and we've all put in for five quid'," she recalls. "He also used to borrow 10 shillings off me - which he always paid back - and take me to lunch in the Kardomah, where he'd regale me about how he was going to go to Fleet Street and going to write plays." In a neat illustration of how far they have both since travelled, the last time Waterhouse and Taylor met was at the Dorchester where they were chatting to the then prime minister, John Major. While all of his career ambitions were fulfilled long ago, Waterhouse still continues the routine he's had for the past 40 years: churning out the pages on an ancient Adler portable typewriter from the cluttered study he calls "the word factory" in his Earl's Court mansion flat home. He is not exactly taciturn, but there is a stillness and quietness, although friends insist that he is not in the least melancholy or lonely. He invariably answers questions in a single, neat sentence and says that writing is not something he likes doing, it is something he likes having done. "It's what I do, it's what I am for. Whether I like it or not doesn't really come into it." Ned Sherrin says Waterhouse, "gets up when the cock crows and does his work and so he is free for lunch. He doesn't eat a great deal but it is very celebratory. There's always that salad left untouched which he reckons he imbibes by osmosis." He likes to have a drink on the go most of the afternoon and evening, but says he never gets a hangover, nor missed a morning's work because of it. His first Fleet Street job was on the Daily Mirror in 1951. He joined within a few weeks of the legendary editor, Hugh Cudlipp, who "kind of adopted me", says Waterhouse. "I learned a hell of a lot from him. It was a bit in the manner of my old English teacher throwing Huckleberry Finn at me, but he would throw assignments. He'd say 'go to the south of France and write about having a good time'. He was a great believer in bread and circuses. He would do the heavy politics and then say, 'that's enough of politics, let's have some fun in the paper', and I was involved in both sides." As a newsman, Waterhouse was a correspondent in America, Russia and Cyprus. With the close links between the Labour party high command and the Mirror, Waterhouse found himself drafting articles and speeches for Hugh Gaitskill and Harold Wilson. "I never belonged to the Labour Party but I did dabble," he says. "But I really go with my friend Richard Littlejohn on this. When Harriet Harman, as secretary of state for social security, was promoting after-school clubs for children, the example she gave of opposition to her ideas was a Waterhouse column. His view was that children should be, "falling into ponds, eating poisonous berries, contracting stomach-ache from under-ripe stolen apples, getting lost, being bitten by dogs, fighting and starting fires, sitting in cowpats and acquiring bumps the size of a duck-egg on their heads". His daughter Sarah runs a picture-framing business in Barnes. His other daughter, Penny, died of heart disease two years ago at 43, after a prolonged illness. Jaci Stephen, the journalist, has been a friend of Waterhouse since she gave one of his many sitcoms a terrible review about 10 years ago. Leyland gave an interview in which she claimed, "at 1pm he would expect smoked salmon sandwiches and a bottle of champagne, and I had to put on my black basque, suspenders and stripogram gear". The case was settled out of court, and when asked about it he just waves his hand and mutters, "an interlude time. I've forgotten about that." He always thought he had lived between two stools as far as writing was concerned. Waterhouse genuinely prefers to look to the future where, for him, there is always the next book, play or column. "I'll always have something else to do. If I write everything that's in my head, I've got five years' work and during the course of that five years other things will crop up and I'll die and that will be about it. I suppose I must actually like sitting here in this room, with some silly detective play on the radio, banging away on that machine." fields.headline: Infamy! Infamy!
fields.standfirst: Patronising, cynical... how did the British Museum get its Cleopatra exhibition so wrong, asks  Jonathan Jones
fields.trailText: Patronising, cynical... how did the British Museum get its Cleopatra exhibition so wrong, asks Jonathan Jones
fields.body:
The story of Antony and Cleopatra is a rare instance in which the losers are remembered as more glamorous than the winners. Cleopatra, Queen of Egypt, seduced not one but two of history's most famous politicians, first living with and having a son by Julius Caesar; then, after Caesar's death, having an even more public affair with Mark Antony. Antony and Cleopatra were eventually defeated and driven to suicide by Caesar's great-nephew, Octavian; but even though he went on to transform the Roman Empire, no artist or writer was ever inspired by his story as they were by Cleopatra and her Antony.

The British Museum's exhibition Cleopatra of Egypt: From History to Myth takes this magical story and pulverises it. It makes Cleo-patra, who has seemed like our contemporary from the time of Shakespeare's England to Liz Taylor's Hollywood, a figure as remote as Shelley's Ozymandias. It achieves this despite containing works of art that, under normal circumstances, would take your breath away. There are Roman paintings from Pompeii lent by the Naples Archaeological Museum, a statue of Cleopatra from the Hermitage, and even the colossal head thought to be of Caesarion, Cleopatra's son by Caesar - recently raised from Alexandria harbour by French archaeologists, and a star find from the most dramatic development in Egyptian archaeology in decades. "Wonderful things," as Howard Carter said when he first peeped into the tomb of Tutankhamen - yet even the most wonderful things can be sterilised by a badly conceived exhibition.

The degree to which this show makes a sow's ear out of one of history's finest silk purses is spectacular. You walk up the spiral staircase to the Joseph Hotung Gallery with anticipation, the Egyptian statuary displayed on the way up looking gorgeous in the light and space of Norman Foster's Great Court. You've read the press coverage about the British Museum finally revealing the real face of Cleopatra. This is going to be a sensation. Then there's a surreal change of scale from the generous expanse of the Great Court to this pocket-sized gallery, which would be perfect for prints or gems, but is obviously too small for a show of this scope. Inside, the treasures of Egypt and Rome have been squashed together in what are supposed to be separate sec tions exploring aspects of Cleopatra's life and legend, but their close proximity and the utterly confusing plan make it a headache just working out which bit you're in. Within minutes, excitement gives way to bafflement, followed by boredom. Is this a bust of Julius Caesar, or Mark Antony? Who's on that coin? Where's the shop?

This is an oppressive and cynical exercise, an unholy alliance of marketing and scholarship. The marketing department's contribution is felt not just in the spurious advance publicity - you no more see the true face of Cleopatra in her variously idealised statues and coins than you see the real Christ on the telly - but in the patronising layout of the show. There are big picture boards everywhere, as if this were a corporate presentation. Above is a frieze of images of Cleopatra from the movies. It's all so desperate, I wouldn't have been surprised if, on the way out, there was an animatronic statue of Kenneth Williams in his toga saying "Infamy, Infamy, they've all got it in for me." It's like the same museum's Gladiators and Caesars exhibition last year, which lamely gestured towards the movie Gladiator without reflecting any of the true love of ancient Rome visible in Ridley Scott's film.

But what kills this exhibition stone dead is its lack of any coherent point. The fact that it fails to tell the story of Antony and Cleopatra in a lucid, informative manner is bad enough. But what it does instead is bewildering. The argument seems to be, broadly, that there was a real Cleopatra, and there is a mythic one. This exhibition juxtaposes the two, setting the queen in her time and place, and also following her reinvention in art from Rome through Renaissance and the Baroque up to Cecil B DeMille's 1934 film Cleopatra. This sounds fine, but it is misconceived. The attempt to bring us close to the "real" Cleo-patra turns out to be doomed: the more artefacts you look at, the further away you get. There are also few contemporary representations of Cleopatra - and some of those are questionable.

What you get instead are approaches to and flirtations with facts, the promised revelation endlessly deferred. So there's a section that brings together artefacts from Cleopatra's capital, Alexandria, several of them recently discovered. There's a lovely mosaic of a dog excavated in 1993 on the site of the new Alexandrian library - a witty, crisp work of art, but nothing to do with Cleopatra; indeed, it dates from a century before her time. Context is great, yes, but how do we get from the dog to the queen? The collection of drinking vessels from Alexandria won't do it. Perhaps that bust is Cleopatra? Oh no, it's just a noblewoman. And that guy who looks like Caesar? He's not Caesar. Nothing in the ancient art seems to get us close to the "real" people in the story - and why would we expect it to ?

It's the Roman images of Egypt, full of nutty stereotype and fantasy, that kick a little life into the proceedings: a painted plaster panel from Pompeii purportedly depicting life on the Nile has pygmies riding crocodiles and fighting hippos in a graphic manifestation of the west's image of Egypt as the strangest place on earth. It was this sense of Egypt as exotic that gave the story of Cleopatra such resonance. Then we're on to the image of Cleopatra in later art, and this is where you get the juicy iconography whose absence in antiquity is proved here in such tedious detail. At last, Cleopatra lifts the asp to her bare breast in Guercino's sultry Baroque drawing in red chalk, done in the 1630s. These images are fascinating, but again there's a patchiness that stops you getting absorbed: to cover such a great theme in art history in 10 or so drawings, paintings and porcelain statuettes is pathetic.

The British Museum has a problem with exhibitions. It seems insecure and confused about why it puts them on, and for whom. This is an appalling manifestation of that problem. It seems to be aimed at two publics the museum imagines to be completely separate. One is a mass audience who need something crude to draw them in, and don't need to take anything away except having seen the face of Cleopatra; the other is the academic community - the catalogue preface enthuses most about "the exciting elements of the research programme" prompted by this show. But a national museum has a duty to create and cultivate an intelligent public. The amount of marketing flannel surrounding this show - from "a beautiful gift book, Cleopatra's Face" to a talk by Tracey Emin, who recently visited Cairo - suggests the British Museum has a poor opinion of our ability to engage with the art of the past. The only decent exhibitions here nowadays are in the remote Prints and Drawings Gallery, where, safe from PR nonsense, curators can get away with putting on shows of passion and beauty. Otherwise it's all hysterical tat.

Despite the Great Court, there's something missing at the British Museum: a sense of purpose. The great French curator and historian Pierre Rosenberg is about to retire as director of the Louvre - perhaps he might have time for some charity work?

 Cleopatra of Egypt: From History to Myth is at the British Museum, London WC1 (020-7323 8000), until August 26.

fields.headline: Who let the men out?
fields.trailText: Last night's TV
fields.body:
When in doubt, have two guys come through the doors with guns - Raymond Chandler

Wobbling with worry over the newly invigorated EastEnders, which has seen Phil Mitchell metamorphose into Darth Vader, Coronation Street (ITV) has come over all blokey. This feels a bit odd.

In an intrinsically female genre, the only soap to have a robust masculinity at its heart is EastEnders. From Elsie Tanner to Sarah-Lou Platt, Coronation Street has remained centred on hale, hearty and often Herculean women. Men in Manchester are either dull (Ken, Dev, Kev), comic (Jack, Roy, Fred) or as queer as folk (Norris). Little wonder that Hayley got her menbits lopped off when she could.

But in its Friday 13th hour-long special, Coronation Street was firmly focused on Weatherfield's male residents. Even with a hen night in The Rovers and the initiation of a major storyline centred on a female character, the cobbles were awash with testosterone.

First, there was Kevin, or rather the Kevin-shaped hole where he should have been. Kevin had vanished on the eve of Sally's wedding to the nice-but-dim Danny.

Instead of worrying about the bridesmaids (the gurlz), or the catering for the reception (scampi nuggets, beans and chips), the earlobeless one spent most of her time wondering if Kevin had gone off and done "something silly". Given his track record - marrying Sally, having it off with Natalie, growing preternaturally creepy beards - her concern seemed justified.

Thus it was quite understandable for Sally to smack him when he returned. Understandable, yes. Advisable, probably not. Last seen drinking whisky in his car, a crisis of masculinity in repose, could Kev spill the beans to Danny about his recent saucy shenanigans with Sally? And if he did, would Danny understand if Kevin used words of two syllables or more?

Over at the Rovers, the lads were playing poker. More obnoxious than usual, they spoke some of the most realistic dialogue ever heard down Corrie way. What with Les's vulgarity, Peter Barlow's vile desperation and Duggie's general abhorrence, here were the men of Weatherfield conversing in the secret language of heterosexual blokes: misogny-speak. And, after Duggie's brush with the Mulder and Scully of Weatherfield Trading Standards, his threat to Toyah ("You'll get what's coming to you") was moist with intent.

Even Fred, who can't have seen his genitals without the aid of a mirror for years, is getting in on the act, with two women on the go. (one of them is Audrey, but still...) Of course, all of this - Fred aside - was a deliberate diversion to provide motive and opportunity in the mystery of Who Attacked Toyah Battersby. That it was done isn't so surprising; that it was done so well is. Writer David Lane combined slowly boiling tension with vintage comic lines from Jack, Vera and Audrey, including the delightful tale of Vera's Auntie May tripping on a chamberpot and going headfirst - and fatally - into her dressing table mirror. Lane's is a considerable feat. Writing of this quality has been sadly lacking down the Street recently.

I hope that standards will remain high. Georgia Taylor, who plays Toyah, is a gifted young actress, and it would be a scandal to weigh her down with duff dialogue, especially in such a meaty storyline. While the usual suspects will be lined up and the obviously guilty party will be singled out to no one's great surprise, it is in Toyah's reaction to her situation that there will be most dramatic mileage. Not so much the whodunnit but the what-Toyah-does-now. Taylor has a prime opportunity to cement Toyah as a landmark in Coronation Street, another memorable Weatherfield woman.

Perversely, what the special blokeish Coronation Street has demonstrated is that, when in doubt, men with guns aren't what you need at all. It's women with guts.

fields.headline: Shoreham Walk
fields.trailText:
We walked

up through the wood

nettles and oak

a dark green
fields.body:
We walked

up through the wood

nettles and oak

a dark green

fall of light

leading us

past soft

erect wheat

then the white

potato flowers

and flints, a few

rusty can tops

it is the shining

June day, warm

as seldom

in our country

on our skin

a south wind

silver barley ears

are swaying

swaying us

and a lark

less visible than

the flower, blue

big, no bigger

than your pupil

under crusty

oaks again, ferns

they smell of salt

curved seawaves

& a place

we found

called the kingdom

of children

you said, because

nobody frowns

as you climbed

vanishing up

a giant beech, red

as old blood

tall as the sky,

so many strong

branches it

was easy

webTitle: When a silent screen goes beyond words

fields.headline: When a silent screen goes beyond words
fields.trailText: Diary
fields.body:
Cast and crew showings of films produce an atmosphere that can be seductive. The air is charged with affection and goodwill which are not conducive to objectivity. This week I was invited to Captain Corelli's Mandolin at the Empire, Leicester Square with a full house of the partisan. I hadn't liked the book, so my expectations were modest. It is a fine film - moving, wonderfully acted, and superbly directed by John Madden.

I reflected on the question of books and films. It is a cliche that it is difficult to make a good film out of a good book. The reason for this is said to be that a good book gives the individual imagination an outing, where the bad book merely rearranges the familiar.

But I think there is more to it. The experience of watching a movie has been described as the experience of watching two giant faces which will eventually come together. These faces bring to the film something that was never - for better or for worse - in the book. Penelope Cruz in Corelli is mesmerising, and Madden has the confidence to allow her and Nicolas Cage to remain silent at key moments. You see here the power of the mute human face, in all its intimacy and vulnerability, a fact that great painters have known for a thousand years.

There is some fear among the producers that the complexities of the German- Italian axis might mystify Americans. It seems to be accepted that almost anything mystifies Americans. I wonder if this is really the case. Publishers, TV companies and film producers are terrified of losing one moron in Podunk, Ohio, so all history and culture must be made relevant or TV-friendly or contemporary. The fact that the Germans massacred their Italian allies in Cephalonia when they wanted to pull out of the war cannot be trivialised; it also leads to the most moving moment of the film, when the German officer played by David Morrissey turns away in utter anguish from what his colleagues have done. I don't believe it will put off American audiences.

For those of us who admire Saul Bellow, Pierre Thaxter in Humboldt's Gift is one of his finest creations. He is the urbane but unreliable co-editor, with the narrator, Charlie Citrine, of a literary magazine, which stumbles from one financial crisis to the next. Although indigent, he is a man of extravagance and bravura: he has houses in Mexico, a special place in Chicago where he buys fishknives, and children all over the world. And he is always taking poor Citrine for money.

Thaxter has long been reputed to be based on Keith Botsford, Bellow's co-editor of the Republic of Letters. In the latest edition, Botsford admits with some glee to being the model for Thaxter. He defends on artistic grounds any writer of fiction who uses his friends and acquaintances.

I wondered if it is true that a writer has licence to use whoever he likes in his fiction. In my most recent book, I have a character who is based on Tony Blair. I know nothing about Blair that any diligent reader of newspapers doesn't. At one point I had even contemplated using his real name; perhaps naively, I imagined it would lend verisimilitude. But I realise that I thought of Tony Blair as part of the folklore, almost as a natural event. Celebrity on this scale creates an alternative persona, just as real to us as the original, perhaps more so. This independent form of life, with consequences in the real world, is the most fascinating aspect of celebrity. It has always intrigued me that the public should be so interested in celebrity. I believe that this preoccupation is something to do with the desire to be free of the toils and preoccupations of daily life: celebrities are seen to have escaped. In this way they offer intimations of immortality. They are the household gods.

On Sunday night a television film which I have been involved with, The Quest for the True Cross, was shown on Channel 4. It is a film about a piece of wood in Rome bearing some of the words said to be on Christ's cross. Professor Carsten Thiede, a German historian, believes that the writing can only have been done at the time of Christ and that it is the real thing. During filming we were able to take it out of the glass case in which it is housed; according to the seals on the case, this was only the fourth time in 600 years that it has been removed.

The overwhelming and slightly disorienting impression I have been left with, after weeks of work in Rome and Jerusalem tracing the origins of this piece of wood, is that the early Christian era wasn't as long ago as I had imagined. I had somehow thought of it as being as remote as Greek antiquity, but to see the orantes, the early Christian praying figures in the British Museum, to see the Christian catacombs of Rome, to see a stone with Pilate's name on it, and to see Jerusalem itself, was to find my whole sense of history disoriented. Jerusalem in Christ's time was a sophisticated place, and the Jewish temple destroyed by the Romans 30 years after his death was magnificent. My Sunday school image of a few simple folk in tea towels caring for sheep has been revised.

Once it was cordon bleu courses or chalet cooking for the girls with posh voices and elusive A levels. Now it's PR. PR is populated by girls called Caroline who can't spell and are hoping to marry somebody who shoots pheasants. Why the semi-literate should be attracted to this business is a mystery, as it involves a form of writing, but the truth is, I have never yet seen a press release from a PR agency that is free of solecism.

I have noticed over the last 10 years or so that more and more children of the middle class are turning their backs on traditional educational achievement. Where a familiarity with books was considered the minimum qualification for culture, now there's a preference for computers, video, DVDs, crafts, graphics, organics, sound engineering and media studies: skills that owe nothing to old-world educational values. They may serve the purpose of the army in the old days, as a refuge for the unacademic. But literature and grammar are part of the antique landscape - as important as Thaxter's fishknives.
