Publishers, TV companies and film producers are terrified of losing one moron in Podunk, Ohio, so all history and culture must be made relevant or TV-friendly or contemporary. The fact that the Germans massacred their Italian allies in Cephalonia when they wanted to pull out of the war cannot be trivialised; it also leads to the most moving moment of the film, when the German officer played by David Morrissey turns away in utter anguish from what his colleagues have done. I don't believe it will put off American audiences. For those of us who admire Saul Bellow, Pierre Thaxter in Humboldt's Gift is one of his finest creations. He is the urbane but unreliable co-editor, with the narrator, Charlie Citrine, of a literary magazine, which stumbles from one financial crisis to the next. Although indigent, he is a man of extravagance and bravura: he has houses in Mexico, a special place in Chicago where he buys fishknives, and children all over the world. And he is always taking poor Citrine for money. Thaxter has long been reputed to be based on Keith Botsford, Bellow's co-editor of the Republic of Letters. In the latest edition, Botsford admits with some glee to being the model for Thaxter. He defends on artistic grounds any writer of fiction who uses his friends and acquaintances. I wondered if it is true that a writer has licence to use whoever he likes in his fiction. In my most recent book, I have a character who is based on Tony Blair. I know nothing about Blair that any diligent reader of newspapers doesn't. At one point I had even contemplated using his real name; perhaps naively, I imagined it would lend verisimilitude. But I realise that I thought of Tony Blair as part of the folklore, almost as a natural event. Celebrity on this scale creates an alternative persona, just as real to us as the original, perhaps more so. This independent form of life, with consequences in the real world, is the most fascinating aspect of celebrity. It has always intrigued me that the public should be so interested in celebrity. I believe that this preoccupation is something to do with the desire to be free of the toils and preoccupations of daily life: celebrities are seen to have escaped. In this way they offer intimations of immortality. They are the household gods. On Sunday night a television film which I have been involved with, The Quest for the True Cross, was shown on Channel 4. It is a film about a piece of wood in Rome bearing some of the words said to be on Christ's cross. Professor Carsten Thiede, a German historian, believes that the writing can only have been done at the time of Christ and that it is the real thing. During filming we were able to take it out of the glass case in which it is housed; according to the seals on the case, this was only the fourth time in 600 years that it has been removed. The overwhelming and slightly disorienting impression I have been left with, after weeks of work in Rome and Jerusalem tracing the origins of this piece of wood, is that the early Christian era wasn't as long ago as I had imagined. I had somehow thought of it as being as remote as Greek antiquity, but to see the orantes, the early Christian praying figures in the British Museum, to see the Christian catacombs of Rome, to see a stone with Pilate's name on it, and to see Jerusalem itself, was to find my whole sense of history disoriented. Jerusalem in Christ's time was a sophisticated place, and the Jewish temple destroyed by the Romans 30 years after his death was magnificent. My Sunday school image of a few simple folk in tea towels caring for sheep has been revised. Once it was cordon bleu courses or chalet cooking for the girls with posh voices and elusive A levels. Now it's PR. PR is populated by girls called Caroline who can't spell and are hoping to marry somebody who shoots pheasants. Why the semi-literate should be attracted to this business is a mystery, as it involves a form of writing, but the truth is, I have never yet seen a press release from a PR agency that is free of solecism. I have noticed over the last 10 years or so that more and more children of the middle class are turning their backs on traditional educational achievement. Where a familiarity with books was considered the minimum qualification for culture, now there's a preference for computers, video, DVDs, crafts, graphics, organics, sound engineering and media studies: skills that owe nothing to old-world educational values. They may serve the purpose of the army in the old days, as a refuge for the unacademic. But literature and grammar are part of the antique landscape - as important as Thaxter's fishknives.

fields.headline: The last word on   Deceit
fields.standfirst: He who digs a hole for another may fall in himself -  Russian proverb
fields.trailText: He who digs a hole for another may fall in himself - Russian proverb
fields.body:
If there is anything surprising about the furore surrounding the "indiscretions" - banal and commonplace from one source, mere braggadocio and immaturity from another: what on earth was the fuss about? - reported by a tabloid last Sunday, it is the fact that the nation has not risen up as one and asked: why is the gutter press allowed to get away with using lies, deceit, trickery and entrapment to get its stories? What price the future of public debate in this country if, in addition, the front pages of serious newspapers report the outcome of the gutter press's unscrupulous tricks?

The use of deceit to eavesdrop on the private opinions of individuals, with a view to damaging them, is supposedly justified by considerations of public interest. But tabloid newspapers have never distinguished between what interests the public and what is in the public interest. They have their own interest: profit, and because there are several million people out there who relish gossip, snooping and the humiliation of celebrities, the tabloids gleefully do whatever it takes to make money by satisfying them.

Citing public interest as a justification of subterfuge is acceptable if a public interest really exists. Where harm is threatened to society or its members, for example by terrorist plots, or if public trust is betrayed, for example by misuse of public funds, then undercover investigations are means amply justified by their ends. But where there is no public interest, only public curiosity, and tabloid newspapers send employees to lie and misrepresent themselves in the hope of getting secretly recorded confidences in order to slake that curiosity - and to pique it by causing harm to individuals - an important line has been unacceptably crossed.

It seems odd that it should be legal for any organisation to make money by acknow-ledged acts of deception aimed at causing individual harm. What the tabloids do in this line is a form of fraud; it relies on false identities, deception, and systematic dishonesty; it involves breaching the implicit confidence of those who take themselves to be having a private conversation; it is invasion of privacy, resulting in damage to the reputation and careers of the parties concerned. Whether or not one cares about the parties, one should care about the standard of probity observed by the newspapers: and without question, such cheap and nasty methods raise serious worries.

Deceit is a member of an unappealing family which includes deception, hypocrisy, falsehood, imposture, chicanery, entrapment, swindle, fraud and cheating. The family of virtues to which it is contrasted includes honesty, truth, frankness, candour and scrupulousness. The tabloids take great satisfaction in making a living by avowedly embracing the former. What they love best is, by means of deception, imposture, falsehood, etc, to show that someone who professes honesty, candour, truth, etc, is really just like them in being dishonest, fraudulent, hypocritical, etc. By the alchemy of their readers' insatiable desire to see people humiliated and dragged down to the level of their favourite gossip sheet, the tabloids thus coin money out of slime.

The problem is that public debate is thereby debased. Most of what really matters is ignored in the distraction offered by these trivial and morally degraded proceedings. A national newspaper with a large readership has a platform to raise and discuss many things that make a difference in the world; the tabloids rarely use that privilege, restricting themselves to simplistic propagandising on behalf of their owners' views when it comes to serious issues, and otherwise devoting themselves to the titillation of what they cheerfully identify as their readers' baser instincts.

There is no satisfaction in stating these obvious facts, for this is a leading feature of our country, and it happens because we all either actively or supinely connive at it, the former by buying and reading the ordure in question, the latter by ignoring it - even if in contempt. Perhaps, as Carlyle observed, deceit only thrives where there is self-deceit; and we deceive ourselves if we think that openly avowed sharp practice in our biggest-circulation newspapers is tolerable.

webTitle: Leader: Easter offers secular inspiration, too

fields.headline: Passion play
fields.standfirst:
Easter offers secular inspiration, too

Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: For many, all that distinguishes this weekend from any other is a lot of chocolate, a couple of bank holidays, queues at the gardening centre and a huge number of ads on television for compost. The truth is that in this country, for the vast majority, this weekend has no religious or spiritual significance.
fields.body:
For many, all that distinguishes this weekend from any other is a lot of chocolate, a couple of bank holidays, queues at the gardening centre and a huge number of ads on television for compost. The truth is that in this country, for the vast majority, this weekend has no religious or spiritual significance. A recent Mori poll revealed that only 43% knew the meaning of Easter, a stark indication of how far we have slipped the moorings of western Christian tradition. This is not just a question of how many people still attend Christian services, but more importantly the extent to which we are still conversant with the tenets of a faith that represents so much of our history and culture. How can you understand Shakespeare, Bach, John Tavener or Stanley Spencer without a working knowledge of Easter? Curiously, it is at Easter that the vacuum left by Christianity is most apparent - we are left with nothing to celebrate but a miserably chilly English spring. At least Christmas has again found its pagan roots in feasting in the dark midwinter.

Easter's neglect owes much to the way an increasingly secular society finds the Christian beliefs it celebrates simply fantastical. More and more of us do not believe in the resurrection or that by this event Christ, as the only son of God, conquered death and sin and promised eternal life to the saved. Strip out these huge theological claims and what you are left with is the torture and brutal death of a gentle Galilean carpenter. That is not something many people want to spend a bank holiday weekend thinking about, because it challenges two of our most powerful contemporary taboos, death and suffering. In a competitive, capitalist culture, success is the preoccupation and happiness the great dream. Death and suffering have no place in either. We are fascinated by death, but only death that has been glamorised or turned into whodunnit drama. Meanwhile we tidy away the reality of everyday death into crematoria and hospitals. Equally, our culture sees little meaning or purpose in suffering when Easter is above all else a celebration of the redemptive power of suffering.

Even worse, the crucifixion harshly confronts us with some of the most painful questions of the human conditions: even the innocent and the virtuous are brutally killed. Christianity's dilemma is close to that of Amnesty, as it struggles to publicise the abuse of human rights among good and innocent people. From Gandhi and Martin Luther King to families such as the Taylors and the Dickinsons, we struggle to understand what justice is when the great and the innocent can be killed with such wanton indifference.

For thousands of years, the passion has been the central inspiration for the Christian tradition, which now has a following of billions across the planet. Its appeal lies in the story's telling detail, which encompasses in one narrative thread so much of human experience. So we witness the ephemeral nature of fame with Christ's triumphal entry into Jerusalem and, a few days later, the mob demanding his death; we hear of two kinds of betrayal in Judas Iscariot and Peter; we hear of Christ's non-violence and forgiveness. And throughout there are cameo parts, such as Pontius Pilate the weak, good man, or the compassion of the bystander in Veronica as she wiped Christ's forehead. Underpinning Easter is a set of beliefs about power, evil, suffering, forgiveness and justice: we may no longer believe in all of them, but they can still give us insight into some of human nature's most persistent dilemmas.

webTitle: Decline in churchgoing hits CoE hardest

fields.headline: Decline in churchgoing hits CoE hardest
fields.standfirst:
Only 54% of young adults believe Jesus lived

Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: The decline in churchgoing in Britain has been highlighted in a survey that gives fresh cause for concern for the Church of England, whose membership is haemorrhaging fast.
fields.body:
The decline in churchgoing in Britain has been highlighted in a survey that gives fresh cause for concern for the Church of England, whose membership is haemorrhaging fast.

The poll, for the Catholic weekly magazine The Tablet, shows that although there is still a strong vestigial belief in Christianity, the established churches are neither attracting nor benefiting from it.

More worrying for the churches' future is the level of religious belief among the young. While 80% of those aged over 65 still believe that Jesus lived, only 54% of those aged 18-24 do so.

Politicians entering the general election promising a greater role for church schools and religious charities in welfare provision, can take some consolation from the poll which found that voters seem to agree with them - 63% of Labour supporters, 60% of Conservatives, and 51% of Liberal Democrats said they thought these bodies should have a more prominent role.

The findings show that Muslims and Hindus, despite representing only 3% of the population, now make up 9% of all those attending religious ceremonies regularly. More Muslims may be attending a mosque each week than Anglicans attending church. If only half of Britain's 2m Muslims take part in regular worship, that already exceeds the proportion of worshippers in the so-called 'national' church.

Although 43% of the population claim to be Anglicans, they make up only 24% of those attending services as often as once a month and nearly half of those who never go to church. The Church of Scotland, the equivalent north of the border, represents 5% of the population and 6% of regular churchgoers there.

Even though Roman Catholics form only 11% of the population, they make up 26% of all those who regularly attend a religious service more than once a month, making them effectively the largest denominational churchgoing population.

Some in the Church of England, including the Archbishop of York, David Hope, have expressed concern that the leadership's concentration on management structures in recent years has not helped it to preach its message. The church has even resorted to focus groups to find out how it might appeal better to the uncommitted, and was alarmed to discover that the people most associated with it in the public mind were the actor Dame Thora Hird, 90, and the pop star Sir Cliff Richard, who is 60.

The church has claimed that although surveys have shown snapshots of Sunday attendances sinking below 1m for the first time three years ago - a statistic so controversial that the church tried to bury it - such figures pay little attention to changing patterns of churchgoing, such as more people attending services in their work lunch hours.

Nevertheless, since 1980 the Church of England has suffered a 27% decline in membership, a similar figure to that in the Catholic Church.

In a Gallup poll last year however, only 38% of those questioned said they believed Jesus was the Son of God. When the same question was asked in 1957, the comparable figure was 71%.

The latest poll, carried out by Opinion Research Business, indicates the extent to which the main churches are failing to capture the imagination of the young or to capitalise on what remains a latent belief in God.

The findings will be discussed on BBC Radio 4's Sunday programme at 7.10am tomorrow.

The Tablet's editor, John Wilkins, said: "The findings are really surprising in showing that the image of Britain as a secular society is not completely true. The picture is more complicated than that... there is a widespread residual belief."

The Anglican bishop of Southwark, Thomas Butler, said: "I think it shows that the British are daylight atheists. When things get difficult in their lives they discover that they believe more than they thought they did, and that is when they seek out the churches."

The research was conducted last month by telephone poll across Britain with 1,001 respondents.

fields.headline: John Clinch
fields.standfirst: Sculptor whose acute humour was reflected in his unashamedly populist work
fields.trailText: Sculptor whose acute humour was reflected in his unashamedly populist work.
fields.body:
The style of the sculptor and teacher John Clinch, who has died aged 66, was instantly recognisable. His Wish You Were Here (1983), for Merseyside Development Corporation, depicts three relaxed seasiders: a man enjoying a beer, and two girls waving and pointing at the sights.

Clinch was a calm, often reserved man, with an acute humour that was delivered with an absolutely straight face. His personality was reflected in his sculptures. Accessible and populist - his own description - his work has an inherent wit.

Head of sculpture and principal lecturer from 1970 to 1987 at Nottingham school of art (now Nottingham Trent University), Clinch retired early to concentrate on his own work. A visit to Spain's Figueres toy museum in the early 1980s began his huge collection of tin toys, which began to influence work such as The Great Blondinis (1985), commissioned by Thamesdown borough council.

Other commissions included Vox Pop (The Family) (1984) for Milton Keynes Development Corporation, Diana Dors: Filmstar (1992) for MGM Cinemas and The Winchers (1995) for Strathclyde Regional Transport. He also created works for Royal Caribbean, the cruise liner company, and, in the Vale of Glamorgan, there was Beside the Seaside... Beside the Sea.

Born in Folkestone, Kent, he was the son of a milliners' representative. In his early career he had trained to be an accountant in the City of London, and it was during this time that he discovered his love and talent for the arts at evening classes. In 1951 he began to learn his craft at Kingston school of art, gaining his National Diploma in 1955. From 1955 to 1957 he saw national service as a military policeman, including a stint at Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers Europe in Paris.

He then spent four years at the Royal College of Art's school of sculpture under the tutelage of John Skeaping and, later, Bernard Meadows. In 1958, while at the RCA, he married Christine Newstead, and by the time he graduated in 1961 they had celebrated the birth of their first child.

Contemporaries from that time remember his lyrical skill in modelling and drawing - and his taking turns at babysitting. In his graduation year he won the RCA Silver Medal and a drawing prize that gave him the opportunity to travel to Italy and France. He was later to return to Italy for a summer residency at the British School in Rome in 1989, and travelled to Valencia, Spain, with an Arts Council Travel Award in 1993.

On his return to England in 1962 he took up part-time teaching posts at Camberwell, Colchester and Hammersmith art schools until 1964, when he and his family (by this time he had two of his three children) moved to Nottingham. There he worked in the school of art's sculpture department, taking time out in 1969 to teach for a year at Canada's Calgary University.

Clinch exhibited widely in Britain and Europe from the 1960s to the present, taking in Madrid, Barcelona, Stockholm, London's Institute of Contemporary Arts, Serpentine and Graffiti galleries, Winchester Cathedral and Ebbw Vale.

He lived and worked in Tregaron from 1988 until his death. It was an area which fulfilled his need for space to work and his love of fishing. He was unable to complete his last commission, a figure of the footballer Bobby Moore to be sited near West Ham United Football Club, due to illness.

Elected as an associate of the Royal Society of British Sculptors in 1992 and a fellow in 1994, he was greatly respected and will be much missed by his peers. He is survived by his wife, Christine, two sons and one daughter.

 John Ian Howard Clinch, sculptor and teacher, born November 23 1934; died April 3 2001

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: We do not yet have a Somerfield wing of the National Gallery or a Lord Somerfield in the upper house, but in spite of these unfortunate lacunae, Somerfield competes with Sainsbury's.
fields.body:
We do not yet have a Somerfield wing of the National Gallery or a Lord Somerfield in the upper house, but in spite of these unfortunate lacunae, Somerfield competes with Sainsbury's (whose eponyms have endowed museums and collected peerages) and, where certain wines are concerned, is more than holding its own.

How do their wines compare? We shall see in a moment. But first let me get an interloper out of the way. This is a wine from Unwins (and Chile), and this time I hope to avoid upsetting any reader - unlike the last time I featured a great Unwins red, when the local branch denied all knowledge of it. If wine shops are to compete with supermarkets, then the advantage they have is surely the people who work in them, but not if those servers are either kept in the dark or wilfully live in it.

The Chilean red is Gracia Reserva Lo Mejor Ocasion Merlot 1997. The name is horrifically twee, I grant you, and is enough to make one wince, but the liquid itself produces more sublime emotions as the drinker revels in the dry, dark and faintly exotic fruit, all meaty and deep. There is a dextrous touch of spice to these savoury overtones and a layered finish of considerable oomph.

A red to enhance the poshest of dinners - celebrating Lord Sainsbury handing over a Breugel to the nation, perhaps - this is a consummately classy food wine that, though not suited to scrambled or addled branch managers, may find itself in this situation (if so, please make use of the email details at the foot of this column). It rates 16.5 points (out of 20) and costs £7.49.

At Sainsbury's, there is nothing so grand (this week). But how does a non-vintage South African Chenin Blanc at £13.99 grab you? A lot of money, yes, but until April 28 it has been reduced to £10.99. This is not your big, rich, OTT chenin, but a good, dry mouthful of solid fruitiness that never tires or goes flabby. Helpfully, Sainsbury's does not require you to own a corkscrew to access this charming little drop, because it comes in a three-litre box with a tap. At its offer price, this is everyday quaffing at 45p a glass, and it rates 15 points at that level of pocketability.

There are three further Sainsbury's wines on offer for the same period. Goiya Glaan 1999 (16 points, down to £2.99) is very ripe and rich, firmly textured, with plums, blackcurrants and spice in its make-up. It really gushes with flavour, while retaining some degree of structure. The South African Reserve Selection Pinotage 2000 (16 points, down to £4.49) is unusually dry and a serious-sided pinotage with more pinot character than age. Okay, so it is young and vibrant, but the plums and meaty blackberries are handsomely rigged. Heritage du Rhne 1999 (15 points, on offer at £3.79) is beefy, country bumpkin-style glugging. It has dry, earthy touches to its plums and blackberries, but not every branch has it (call 0800 636262 for details).

Over at Somerfield, there are no special offers (this week), and so you will have to dig deeper than normal where this retailer is concerned. South African Cabernet Sauvignon 2000 (16.5 points, £4.49) is superbly woody, with feisty tannins that add loads of character to the dry fruit. It is a bitingly bonny mouthful of liquefied hedgerows.

Vacqueyras Domaine de la Soleiade 1999 (16.5 points, £4.99) is the essence of what French country red is all about: characterful, soft, gently tannic, beautifully herby, finely textured. Chilean Cabernet Sauvignon Vina La Rosa 1999 (16.5 points, £4.49, also at Kwik Save) is vivaciously fruity, wonderfully quaffable and has a glorious texture. Espiral Tempranillo Barrique 1999 (16 points, £5.99, not all branches; call 0117 935 6669 for details), from Spain, has loads of spicy plums with great tannins. Very urgent fruit here, keen to please.

Beaumes de Venise Ctes du Rhne Villages Rouge 1998 (16 points, £5.49) is a stunning blend of grenache, syrah, mourvèdre and cinsault, which opens demurely, then goes combative and rich, then calms itself, then goes warm and deep.

For the latest wine news, and to email Malcolm Gluck, visit superplonk.com

fields.headline: Jose Greco
fields.standfirst: Strikingly handsome Spanish-Italian dancer also renowned for his film and television appearances
fields.trailText: Strikingly handsome Spanish-Italian dancer also renowned for his film and television appearances.
fields.body:
Jose Greco, who has died of a heart attack aged 81, was one of the most brilliant and internationally famous Spanish dancers of his generation. He was also well known for his film and American television appearances.

Born in Montorio-nei-Frontani in Italy of Spanish-Italian parentage, he studied in New York, notably with the celebrated La Argentinita, with whose company he danced in 1944-45. After her death, he joined the company of her sister, Pilar Lopez, and for two years toured with her in Europe and America. In 1949 he founded his own Spanish Ballet company, again touring widely in Europe and America.

He first appeared in London with members of his company at a special lecture-demonstration matinee organised by Dona Dolores de Pedroso on behalf of the Royal Academy of Dancing's Production Club, at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, in 1950. This was followed by his first London season, at Sadler's Wells, in 1951, which featured his first wife, Nila Amparo, and also the great La Quica, one of the foremost teachers (and performers) of both classical Spanish dance and flamenco.

Greco, a strikingly hand some man, in addition to touring and dancing with his own company, made several film appearances (his best in Around the World in 80 Days) and was a frequent guest on such television shows as those of Ed Sullivan, Perry Como and Bob Hope.

Towards the end of his dancing career he tended to place more emphasis on his looks, and sometimes glitzy costumes, than on the original purity of his dance style. But at the height of his career he was an undoubted star.

After his retirement, he settled in Lancaster, Pennsylvania, and served as an adjunct professor of dance at Franklin and Marshall College there.

 (Constanzo) Jose Greco, dancer, born December 23 1919; died December 26 2000

fields.headline: Akvavit
fields.trailText: An Aalborg Jubilaeums Akvavit for preference. If you feel daunted at rolling that round your tongue (the correct pronunciation is oolberg you-bill-ow-ums), steel yourself. It's the best drink bar none to down with the mountains of cut-price smoked salmon the supermarkets are flogging this weekend.
fields.body:
An Aalborg Jubilaeums Akvavit for preference. If you feel daunted at rolling that round your tongue (the correct pronunciation is oolberg you-bill-ow-ums), steel yourself. It's the best drink bar none to down with the mountains of cut-price smoked salmon the supermarkets are flogging this weekend.

Akvavit, as of course you know, derives from the Latin aqua vitae (water of life), Aalborg is Denmark's best known distillery, and Jubilaeums is a special bottling made to mark its centenary in 1946. It is flavoured with coriander and dill, which makes it taste rather aniseedy, and it should always be served ice-cold in shot glasses with cheery cries of 'Skal' (looking intently into your drinking companion's eyes as you do so, which might possibly be misconstrued this side of the North Sea).

Who drinks it? Traditionally, Danish farmers and sailors who were knocking back a litre of akvavit a day in the early 1900s, until the government slapped a 300% price increase on it and spoiled all the fun. Here, it costs £17.99 from Unwins.

fields.headline: Roll with it: sushi
fields.trailText:
The subject
Raw fish and/or vegetables on or inside vinegared rice. One of the most popular food items in this country at the moment, and one of the most debased.
fields.body:
The subject
Raw fish and/or vegetables on or inside vinegared rice. One of the most popular food items in this country at the moment, and one of the most debased.

The basics
Sushi is big business: Tesco alone claims to sell £7m-worth a week. And where big business leads, then we consumers must tread carefully. Meaning, in this case: supermarket sushi is junk. Making your own: now that's another matter. Easy-peasy. And as satisfying as the sight of a V-reg Mercedes getting clamped. Principal types: makizushi, the rolled variety, and nigirizushi, slices of fish or omelette on lozenges of rice.

The details
Making sushi is easy if you have three things: the right ingredients, a single item of hardware, and a bit of experience.

Ingredients, Japanese division: rice, vinegar, seaweed sheets (nori), wasabi (horseradish paste), soy sauce (Kikkoman by preference), and pickled ginger. Ingredients, any old division: top-grade fish, veg, sesame seeds. Or just veggies (you choose) if fish is off the menu. There's ample scope for messing around here, as long as you're not a stickler for (boo!) authenticity.

Hardware: a makisu, the bamboo mat used for rolling makizushi.

Experience: aka trial and error. Making the rice is the trickiest part (and one that has never been cracked by mass-market purveyors), but it, too, is simply a matter of practice.

Where to buy Japanese goods: easiest-peasiest in London (try Natural House, 020-7434 4218), or check out www.mountfuji.co.uk (01743 741169) for mail order or online buying. The expert knowledge: Easy Sushi, by Emi Kazuko (£8.99, Ryland Peters & Small), a marvellous manual for bumbling beginners.

The easy way out
Get that stuff out of your trolley now. Once you've eaten the real thing, supermarket sushi will look about as appealing as a long car journey with a flatulent dachshund.

fields.headline: Christopher Lloyd
fields.standfirst: All the months of ultra-wet weather mean even more heavy-duty tasks, says Christopher Lloyd
fields.trailText: All the months of ultra-wet weather mean even more heavy-duty tasks, says Christopher Lloyd.
fields.body:
Jobs in a garden divide themselves into two camps: those that occur routinely and predictably, year after year, and those that are one-offs. Of the latter, no one will be surprised that draining water away looms large. Over the past six months, the climate has been persistently wet. Given our clay soil, we need to do something about this.

One bad area is next to our front path, which is meadow and should be full of bulbs. But many of these - crocuses and wild daffodils, notably - have drowned. It is easier to dig drains if your trenches do not fill with water as you dig them, but we cannot wait. The grass will be lengthening, which makes the job far more difficult. Fergus seems resigned to getting on with it. We shall dig out the top layer of earth to the depth of a spade - otherwise known as a spit. This layer still has many wild orchids in it, including Orchis morio (green-winged) and Dactylorhiza fuchsii (spotted), so we set it on one side.

There is no point in going deep to lay the perforated draining pipe. Instead we will lay that in the next spit, at a depth of 40cm, and surround it with shingle. The drains will be laid in the usual herringbone pattern. The turf will stand proud of the overall meadow level, but it will sink in due course.

Another big, one-off job, is the cutting back of our yew trees. We have a big cubic buttress of clipped yew which, at one corner, had seriously encroached on a flagstone path where it turns a right-angled bend. The result of this was that the public cut this corner, walking on the grass which, naturally, became worn out with repeated treading.

As the four yews that comprise the cube were planted some 90 years ago, we can hardly complain about their bulk (says he, thinking of his own bulk after only 80 years). It is customary to spread a hatchet job of this kind over two or three years, so as to lessen shock to the plants. Well, we have broken with custom and done the whole job in one go. The bushes were healthy enough with signs of growth at the centre, and we shall feed them.

I feel pretty confident they'll be okay, especially as they seem unlikely to run into an immediate drought. But we've certainly made them skeletal. It is important in such cases to go right back to the central trunks, from which pretty even regrowth can be expected, and not to leave lateral branches from which regrowth would be uneven at best, with many failing entirely.

Yew is one of your best friends when this kind of reducing becomes necessary. You would kill a Lawson or Leyland cypress hedge entirely (hurrah!). Thuja, on the other hand, "breaks" well, as do hawthorn and hornbeam. Beech is more hesitant, but also gets there in the end.

Among the routine jobs to be completed will be cleaning up around fairly recently planted trees - where they are in turf - because turf is highly competitive for water and nutrients. Keeping the turf and weeds clear for a metre radius around the tree stem is not over-doing it, and this area is then mulched with garden compost. Likewise, yew hedges that abut on meadow should be cleared at the base. Unless hedge roots are exposed here, we do not automatically mulch, but we do apply a slow-release fertiliser that will give them a feed during their growing season.

All our larger bamboos are grown as specimens, and it makes a great difference to their appearance and presentation if they are annually thinned, which is done by removing all the older, tired canes and accumulated debris within a colony so that you can see right through it and beyond. This makes such a difference. If the bamboo is one of the very flexible kinds, wherein the canes need to support one another, thinning may result in the collapse of remaining ones.

That is a nuisance if the bamboo is sited in a mixed border, for instance, but there are many more informal places where splaying outwards will do no harm. A particularly upright and proud-looking bamboo, easily kept within a narrow space, is Semiarundinaria fastuosa. I can enjoy it from where I am writing. But even this spreads a little. Most bamboos spread quite a lot more, and this is the best moment for reducing their circumference. We pot up the detached pieces and grow them for sale. With bamboos active again, from now till August is right for messing around with them if you need to - splitting, replanting, potting or whatever. Even so, some grasses such as molinias and miscanthus may sulk for a season after wholesale disturbance.

If it is simply a need to reduce the size of a clump, it's often best to chop it away on one side or at the circumference, so that what remains isn't disturbed. This can be a tough job, requiring a sharp spade, a good aim and a lot of muscle. Fergus loves it.

We have quite a lot of bedding, sown last autumn, to plant out now, notably cornflowers, nigellas and Dianthus 'Rainbow Loveliness', which has a swooning airborne scent, so I like a large area of that and room has been left for it. These bedders, sown in September, were potted individually and have been overwintering in a cold frame. They are rather lusher than I should like. It is always tempting, because it is less trouble, to leave the lights on when they could be off. Ammi majus is ready to go out, too. That won't flower till June; the others will start up before May is out.

fields.headline: Spadework
fields.trailText: Liquid asset
fields.body:
Liquid asset

This garden sprinkler has to be seen in action when it flings arcs of water in all directions (above). It's as much for playing in as watering the plants. Made of brass, and measuring 112cm high and 38cm diameter, it costs £195 from the Conran Shop, 81 Fulham Road, London SW3 (020-7589 7401).

Break for the borders

If you want to take a look at what other gardeners are up to, check out the 2001 edition of Gardens In England And Wales Open For Charity, known as the Yellow Book. It gives details of more than 3,000 private gardens across the country, open to the public between now and November, as part of the National Gardens Scheme. Gardens with moats, follies, outrageous plants, picnic spots as well as secret gardens are among the selection. All money raised goes to a multitude of charities. The Yellow Book, published by the National Gardens Scheme, costs £5 and is available in bookshops everywhere.

Plant of the week

'Whirligig' is the name of this osteospermum (above) - a daisy-like flower that does well in dry, sunny conditions and is ideal for container plantings. There are about 70 other varieties, some with crimped petals much like the 'Whirligig', others more plain, and coming in a range of colours, from buttermilk to purple. fields.headline: Junk in charge
fields.standfirst: Leave all that trendy garden design behind and let a bit of chaos into your life. Fill yoghurt pots with tumbling busy lizzies, let begonias run wild in old tin cans... a bright and broken objet trouvé, overflowing with a happy plant, is a thing of beauty, says Celia Woolfrey
fields.trailText: Leave all that trendy garden design behind and let a bit of chaos into your life. Fill yoghurt pots with tumbling busy lizzies, let begonias run wild in old tin cans... a bright and broken objet trouvé, overflowing with a happy plant, is a thing of beauty, says Celia Woolfrey.
fields.body:
Container counsel

Drainage
Drill holes in the bottom of containers, or place the plant in a smaller pot inside the larger, more decorative one. In the event of heavy rain, pour out excess water - after all, you don't want your pots to get waterlogged.

Fragile pots
These need to be kept frost-free. In winter, empty them and store upside down, or keep them dry and undercover.

Feeding
Plants in containers need regular watering and feeding: use liquid feed every couple of weeks during the growing season, or slow release granules. If a pot dries out so that the soil shrinks away from the sides, dunk it in a sink full of water to rehydrate.

Slugs and snails
To deter these pests, smear Vaseline just below the rim of the container or use anti-slug and snail barrier tape, available from garden stores. Surround the plant with a ring of grit, broken egg shells or bran, which slugs find difficult to cross.

Vine weevils
If a container plant goes into sudden collapse, vine weevils might well be the cause. Bin the lot, disinfect the pot and use fresh compost.

Small pots
Keep these for alpines, herbs and compact bedding plants - larger plants need larger containers to spread their roots.

Think of an ultra-modern garden, and what comes to mind? Tasteful rows of box balls, or great swathes of concrete set off by a copper screen or two. Sometimes, it's tempting to ask, "Where have all the flowers gone?" Which is why, after the recent brutality of minimalist design, it might be time to loosen up and think of a garden full of junk. Not junk in the sense of abandoned mattresses and old shopping trolleys, mind. Rather, junk that can be turned into containers for plants or hard landscaping: salvaged ceramics, troughs, planters, timber, slates, bricks, bed edging and so on; the stuff of everyday life that might otherwise have been thrown away.

For the concept, think of an Italian-style garden, where a pergola, say, has been knocked up next to the house and industrial-sized tins that once held olive oil or tomatoes now spill over with grapevines and geraniums. Junk style is beyond fashion. You can grow the lowliest of plants in such containers - pansies, begonias, busy lizzies - and not give a damn whether they are "architectural".

Expert recyclers Moira and Nicholas Hankinson say their greatest triumphs have been things "that have crept up on them". One of their best buys was a job lot of timber, including cart shafts and late 18th-century architraving, for £2 at an auction .They got it so cheaply because most other people were interested in the smarter stuff.

Fellow enthusiast Adam Caplin warns that you have to know when to say no, however. He went through a phase of piling every knick-knack he fell in love with into his garden, which wasn't a success, and led to him pruning and weeding back to just a few of his favourite items. Certain materials need restraint, he explains: for example, with plastics, there is "less of a margin between attractive and ugly. What's good is great, what's bad is awful."

The mark of junk success is when an imaginatively chosen plant transforms your find into something new. Yorkshire gardener Jill Pattenden and her organic-minded pal Marian Softley stuffed an old armchair with compost and covered it in turf, then held the ensemble in place with tent pegs and pea wire. The next year, they planted it with lobelia and marigolds for a flowering version before it fell apart the following winter.

That impermanence is itself an attraction. Cardboard fruit boxes disintegrate after a few summer storms, tins rust and yoghurt pots fade - but by that time the chances are that you will be on to a new junk enthusiasm anyway. Junk style develops organically and, like the garden, is always changing

 Salvage Style In Your Garden, by Moira and Nicholas Hankinson, is published by Kyle Cathie, at £19.99. Planted Junk, by Adam Caplin, is published by Ryland, Peters & Small, at £18.99. To order copies for the special prices of £15.99 and £16.99, respectively, plus £1.99 p&p, freephone CultureShop on 0800 316 6102.

Sources for scrap

Skips
Pick out drainpipe hoppers to turn into wall-mounted planters; water pipes and tanks can serve the same function; cable holders can form makeshift tables; you can even plant-up chairs.

Scrap yards
For fencing, piping for irrigation systems, thin sheet steel and zinc for making planters, and butler's sinks to use as plant troughs.

Architectural reclamation
These companies trade in materials and fixtures with antique status, so prices are higher. Salvo is the umbrella organisation for around 1,000 architectural reclamation firms - directory from PO Box 333, Cornhill-on-Tweed, Northumberland, 01890 820333 www.salvoweb.com

Government surplus dealers
Army ammunition boxes for storing tools, latrine buckets for planters, and tent poles for making an arbour. Try Harpers Bazaar, 263 Worcester Road, Malvern (01684 568723) or, for an outlet near you, look under Army & Navy Surplus or Government Surplus and Camping in the phone book.

Antiques and collectibles fairs
The fairs at the Newark and Nottinghamshire showground, Newark, are some of the largest in the country. For information (the next fairs are on June 4-5), visit www.dmgworldmedia.com.

The usual suspects
Jumble sales, car boot sales, charity shops, etc.

Getting started
You could do a lot worse than kick off with this herb set (left), created by Moira and Nicholas Hankinson, with accompanying slate markers. To order an organic herb and marker set for £22.95 (plus £2 first-class p&p), call 0870 066 7966, or send your order, with a UK cheque for £24.95 payable to Somerset Creative Products, to Guardian Herb Offer, Laurel Farm, Westham, Wedmore, Somerset BS28 4UZ. Orders will be sent out within 28 days of receipt. The set contains thyme, basil, parsley, marjoram and mint, packed in a recycled plastic 'mini' propagator, and five robust engraved markers.

fields.headline: Julie Burchill
fields.standfirst: Things may not be as nice as they could be, but when you start comparing Britain with other countries, suddenly it's not quite so grim
fields.trailText: Things may not be as nice as they could be, but when you start comparing Britain with other countries, suddenly it's not quite so grim.
fields.body:
I like most things about young, working-class women - even the stuff that other people, theoretically workerists, sneer at under cover of "good taste". I like white bread more than brown. Instant coffee more than that stinking, bitter, overpriced slop. I like the names Sharon and Tracey - say them to yourself without prejudice, just listening to the sounds they make, and you'll see how much more attractive they are than lumpy old handles such as Emily and Elizabeth. And how much more honest and human are those young mothers who, pushed beyond endurance at the supermarket check-out, finally give their grizzling brat a light slap and crow triumphantly, "There! Now you've got something to cry about!"

And before all you Horrifieds of Hampstead write in and accuse me of sanctioning child abuse, save your energy and your manky recycled notepaper; if you really believe that a spontaneous slap in a public place inevitably leads to methodical torture and murder by a tattooed stepfather, you're only revealing your own anti-prole prejudices. Anyway, better a swift smack in a supermarket any day than, say, the creepy, middle-class hot-housing that forces so many over-examed teenagers to top themselves, or the enforced beatings and buggery "enjoyed" at any of our major public schools.

I can't help but think of this earthy mother's cry whenever I pick up a newspaper these days. Ever since this country lost the Empire, it has been beating itself up in some way, shape or form. Oooh, we can't do sex like the French! (Despite the fact that recently surveyed Frenchwomen claimed that two out of three of them would rather shop than shtup.) Oooh, our food's the worst in Europe! (Ever tried eating in Germany?) Oooh, our education system stinks! (Excuse me, we're not the country that's made a deity out of Jerry Lewis.) And the ultimate obscenity: who really won the war? (Said with wry, knowing smirk.)

This was particularly rich coming from the sort of soft, self-adoring cosmopolitan type who invariably finds a way to weasel out of any conflict more taxing than beating up his wife, but who would very probably have been the first to feel the difference if the other side had won. Then there were the milksops posing as sophisticates who would bang on about how our continental cousins were so good at enjoying themselves with sex, wine and food - and then start tut-tutting whenever those surveys came out with us Brits topping the polls for drink, drugs and divorce! Just because we cut straight to the chase and don't piss around with finger-bowls and foreplay! If joie de frigging vivre is what you're looking for, Johnny Englishman's your man!

Can anyone beat themselves up as good as the English can? Start the day with an apology to the colonies, take a grovelling lunch of humble pie with a visiting dignitary, and we'll still have time to get that hair shirt on before a supper of bread and gruel. No wonder they call masochism le vice Anglais. For example, it's a stone fact that the economies of Germany and Japan have been in a hell of a state for a good half-decade, yet I know many otherwise intelligent people who refer to the German and Japanese economic miracles as if they're still present and correct, just so as not to spoil the perfect line of their own self-loathing.

Even Cool Britannia, though it might have seemed like we were showing off, was just part of our bipolar condition - the manic babble to the usual depressive whinge. By banging on about how good we were at fashion, food and pop music - kid's stuff - we were actually damning ourselves with faint praise; we still aren't the meat of the matter, our subtext went, just the silly little cherry on top of the Fondant Fancy.

And now we really do have something to cry about. Cattle with foot and mouth, royals with foot-in-mouth, floods, a third-world rail system, crime up and, despite copious state handouts to our film industry, you've got more chance of seeing a good Iranian flick these days than an English one. Worse, something has happened which surely indicates that British morale is at an all-time low - we've started to think that the French are actually really, really good at pop music!

It may well be that things are not as nice as they could be, but the idea of Britain being the most beleaguered cesspool on the planet only stands up in a vacuum. Everything is relative, and when you compare us to other countries, suddenly things aren't quite so grim. (As the refugees from countries far and near who have made this country the Number One destination on their various itineraries will vouchsafe.) Where else, exactly, is there? The third world? No cheers! America? I'd rather live in a toilet than in the evil empire. Russia? Used to be good, but since the end of communism, the life expectancy has dropped by 10 years, productivity has been cut in half and they pay you in dog food. "Newly-free eastern Europe"? Yeah, it's so great there that they're all coming over here. Corrupt France, racist Germany, boring Belgium? Keep 'em!

A bit of perspective never goes amiss, and in the midst of all this doom and gloom it's worth remembering what we've got that others haven't. A sense of humour. A love of the underdog. The idea that a corrupt politician is still worth getting upset about. That inbuilt bullshit detector that makes mincemeat of philosophers, politicians and Martin Amis. "They" used to talk about the people of England who had not spoken yet; but that might be because "their" heirs, the chatterers, haven't shut up long enough to give them a chance. And everything they say is such a downer. I can't help but think that the disgusting behaviour of young Brits abroad might just have something to do with the nonstop disapproval of their "betters".

It's strange; the liberal establishment can see that it might be counter-productive to tell people they're bad all the time, individually - look at the coochy-coo treatment given to the murderers of James Bulger - but it doesn't seem to occur to them that if you tell a people how crap they are constantly, they might think, well, may as well be hung for a sheep as a lamb.

More and more, when it appears to me that this country is rather overcrowded, I long to deport not the mild immigrants but the bellicose natives who have a good word to say for every country but their own. Oi, Mortimer, eff off back to Tuscany. Nigella, Provence for you, luv. And as for Louis de Bernières, with his ignorant comments about the "anti-education, anti-culture attitude of the white working class" (yeah, and the black working class are queueing up for the opera), it's off to Cephalonia he goes, and let the communists deal with him. With that lot gone, who knows, dear old Blighty might well enjoy a reversal of fortune.

fields.headline: Kim Wilde
fields.trailText: Though she had a staggering 14 top 20 chart entries during a 15-year pop career, it is Kim Wilde's first single, 1981's Kids In America, for which she is perhaps best remembered.
fields.body:
Though she had a staggering 14 top 20 chart entries during a 15-year pop career, it is Kim Wilde's first single, 1981's Kids In America, for which she is perhaps best remembered. Having left the music world five years ago, Wilde says today, 'I couldn't imagine still singing that song when I was 50. There comes a time when it's best to bow out.'

Much of the impetus behind the decision was meeting her husband-to-be while on the set of the West End show, Tommy. 'I'd met this man, we wanted to have babies, and I just thought, "I'm going to give this my best shot",' she says. She now has two children, Harry, three, and Rose, one.

Shortly after getting married, Wilde started studying gardening at Capel Manor, Enfield, obtaining a general certificate in horticulture. She is now taking a two-year City & Guilds course in planting design.

Against her expectations, this career change has helped put Wilde back in front of the camera: she is set to appear in Garden Invaders, BBC1's forthcoming morning gardening programme. 'I'm offered interesting jobs and projects because of my name, I think, but that makes me work twice as hard,' she says. 'I know that I have much to learn, and that I must live up to the high standards of other gardeners around me.'

fields.headline: Alexander Chancellor
fields.standfirst: It's astonishing after all the publicity that anyone should still be taken in by Mahmood. But the Arab disguise seems to be foolproof
fields.trailText: It's astonishing after all the publicity that anyone should still be taken in by Mahmood. But the Arab disguise seems to be foolproof.
fields.body:
If evidence were needed of anti-Arab prejudice in Britain, one need not look beyond the astonishing career of Mazher Mahmood, the "investigations editor" of the News Of The World. Mahmood is the paper's great sting artist. Time and again, he manages to lure minor British celebrities into damaging indiscretions by posing as a depraved Arab sheikh. It is clear that this disguise is crucial to his success. For if Mahmood posed as a French, German or American, let alone a British millionaire wanting drugs or sex or both, their suspicions would almost certainly be aroused.

As it is, they consider it quite normal for a gentleman in a flowing Arab robe and occupying an expensive suite in a West End hotel to be openly on the look-out for such things. It is not even clear from the extracts published last Sunday whether Mahmood - posing this time as the personal assistant of a sheikh, rather than as the sheikh himself - actually asked for the gay sex he was so enthusiastically offered by the Countess of Wessex's business partner, Murray Harkin. One suspects that the tapes were edited to cover up Mahmood's contemptible role in soliciting these confidences. But Harkin's boastful advice that the Banyan Tree Hotel in Phuket, Thailand, would be the perfect discreet spot for homosexual encounters with young boys not only helped cost him and Sophie their jobs, but also lost R-JH, their PR firm, its contract with the hotel. It seems astonishing, after all the publicity given to Mahmood's past entrapment activities, that people should still be so easily taken in by him. But the Arab disguise seems to be foolproof.

So what is one to make of this grubby little affair that dominated all the newspapers for more than a week? For me, it has added to the general impression of a nation that is rudderless at sea. The past few months have been reminiscent of the Winter of Discontent of 1978/9. On the surface, everything is far better this time. The economy (for now) is strong. There is low inflation and low unemployment. There are no IMF officials banging at the Treasury door. There are no mounds of uncollected rubbish on the streets. There are no dead bodies waiting around to be buried (unless, of course, you count the bodies of cows, sheep and pigs).

But, as in 1979, there is the same sense that the country is feckless, leaderless and out of control. The railways don't work, roads are clogged, agriculture is ruined, tourism is dying, education is a shambles, the health service is in crisis, and yet nobody seems willing or able to do anything about it. The people remain content only because the economy remains able to satisfy their material greed.

In addition, nearly all our national institutions are tainted in some way by sleaze and cronyism. Even the tabloid press has reverted to the bad old ways it seemed to be giving up after the death of Princess Diana. Its self-regulatory body, the Press Complaints Commission, meanwhile brought discredit upon itself with its self-serving, celebrity-studded 10th anniversary party in February. Prince Charles and Prince William attended that event, upholding the image of the monarchy as a threatened institution helplessly thrashing around in search of salvation. Saying "thank you" to the PCC for having curbed press harassment of William was a pretty pathetic admission of the media's power over him and his public image. Now, the News Of The World's exposure of the avarice and foolishness of one very minor royal has deepened existing doubts about the value of the monarchy itself.

Should it have had this effect? Probably not, since the Sophie affair has little relevance to the central constitutional question. But the media has ensured that it has, thus putting Buckingham Palace into one of its periodic panics. In this fraught situation, the country cries out for the sort of political leadership offered by Stanley Baldwin during the abdication crisis of 1936.

But what do we hear on the subject from the prime minister? Absolutely nothing, except for his lukewarm mantra that the monarchy seems to be for the moment preferable to any alternative system for selecting a head of state. This is neither a ringing endorsement of our existing constitutional arrangements, nor a call for their reform. Instead of receiving support and guidance from her elected government, the Queen is left floundering about, trying to control her unruly family, without help from anyone outside her immediate circle.

I don't know what Tony Blair really thinks of the monarchy, though the Sun's well-informed political editor, Trevor Kavanagh, says he is neutral, despite "wife Cherie's vehement anti-monarchist influence". This suggests that even if Blair were an enthusiastic monarchist, he would not risk his wife's wrath by saying so. Then there is his spokesman, Alastair Campbell, who as a journalist was once almost as vehemently against the monarchy as Mrs Blair is reported to be.

Blair may feel inhibited about speaking his mind, but it is his duty as the country's political leader to do so.

webTitle: 'Door slams with a horribly final clang. Turn to discover there's no handle'

fields.headline: 'Door slams with a horribly final clang. Turn to discover there's no handle'
fields.trailText: "Black Saturday" Death. That's why I've always hated Easter. And this one's the worst yet.
fields.body:
"Black Saturday" Death. That's why I've always hated Easter. And this one's the worst yet. Offer tea and hot-cross buns to aunt and Harriet, sighing over sacrificial lambs. Can I transform this annus horribilis into a vita nova? Where's my philosopher's stone?

"Fancy a day in Oxford, Harriet?" I propose. "We can see the snake's head fritillaries! Magdalen Tower! And the place where Latimer and Ridley were burnt to death!" What larks. We shall go by train, as Gordon has borrowed the car to drive Elaine to a bespoke bathroom specialist. She's found an elegant little Georgian town house and she's nesting.

"What I hate," Harriet growls as we walk to the station, "is that when Dad left us the first time, at least he was in love with Elaine. Now he's just after her money." Harriet is so disgusted, she hasn't spoken to her father for 10 days. But he hasn't noticed. And, anyway, ignoring Gordon is not a punishment. To him, it's a prize.

Must distract my dejected daughter. It may be a spring of slaughter, and her father may be leaving us again, but we must try to convert our songs of woe. Why should Elaine have all the hey nonny nonny? Youth, beauty and money aren't everything. There's always, er - er - er . . . I know! There's always education. "We'll travel, Harriet," I promise her as we buy our rail tickets. "One day, we'll go to Urbino, the perfect Renaissance palace, where life was a work of art, and walk up a neo-platonic staircase. Hang on a tick - I must just go to the loo, first."

Pass through ladies' waiting room: empty, cold and falling rather short of the neo-platonic architectural ideal, and dash into the loo at the far end. Door slams behind me with a horribly final clang, and I turn to discover there is no door handle. Trapped! Push and pull in vain. Wait for someone to come. Nobody does. I'm going to have to make a loud noise in public.

"Harriet!" I shout quietly. No reply. I'm going to have to roar. "Harriet!" A Harriet-shaped figure appears on the other side of the frosted glass. Will it be like this, trying to haunt her from the Beyond? "I'm locked in the loo!"

"Shut up, Mum!"

"Go and get help!"

"All right, all right! No need for stress!"

No need for stress? The train is due in three minutes. Oxford awaits with its Latin, stones and philosophy, and here I am locked in the lav. I insert a Biro into the hole where, in any civilised country, there would be a doorknob. They would never have put up with this in 15th-century Urbino. I twist the Biro. It splinters. It's just not true that the pen is mightier than the sword. Where is Domum when I need him? Scrutinising a better class of sanitaryware with a younger woman. Somehow, I had thought he would stick around this time, providing grumbling companionship and solidarity in old age. We both like silence and fresh air. And cricket and history. If we were ever 80 together, I could turn to the miserable old bastard and say, "Remember that custard tart we had in Stowmarket?" But Joan must grow old alone, because Darby is off chasing skirt.

"Mum? There's a man with a thing who thinks he can help." Something metallic is inserted into the hole and turned briskly, and the door is opened by a man resembling John Major. "Abracadabra!" I cry theatrically. He looks startled.

"Never say Abracadabra again!" hisses Harriet, embarrassed, as the train arrives.

Oxford is full of Latin, stones and philosophy. We walk for hours. "I wouldn't mind coming here," says Harriet. "But I'd have to have a nose job first."

Return home to find Gordon and Elaine returned, and I can see by his face that he has been reduced to suicidal despair by the contemplation of gold taps. But he'd rather suffer a life sentence of designer trash than laugh at old age with me.

Adjourn to my room, where I listen to Schubert's songs of loss and departure. Go to bed without checking my emails. The words of Mercury are harsh after the songs of Apollo. You that way: we this way.

This is the final Dulcie Domum in the Guardian. You can follow her further adventures online at www.suelimb.com
