They are registering disabled people to vote and demanding that the voting process be made more accessible. They are protesting about a piece of legislation that, they feel, would give parents and carers too much control over their lives. In December, People First went to Nice for the European Council summit to present a series of measures it would like to see added to the human rights charter.

The group has the ear of the Labour government, at least indirectly. One People First member is on the advisory group for the government's National Learning Disability Strategy. Another activist is on the Disability Rights Commission (DRC). "It shows people with learning difficulties that we can be involved in the decisions that get made about our lives," says Eve Rank-Petruzziello, the only DRC member with a learning difficulty. "There can be no more excuses about not involving us in the issues which affect us."

But the London office is hardly typical of the 300 or so self-advocacy groups scattered around Britain. Most struggle with far more mundane tasks, such as paying the bills,making sure that all their members, many of whom cannot drive and have difficulty with public transportation, can get to meetings. Although many share the People First name, most operate independently, and they don't always get along. A few attempts have been made to bring the groups together into a national coalition, but each has succumbed to internal bickering. And the movement has yet to convince the general public, including major funders, that people with learning difficulties are capable of leading and managing sizeable organisations. Stack up their budgets next to that of, say, Mencap, the country's largest learning disability charity, which last year spent just over £100m, and even the wealthiest of Britain's People First groups are paupers in comparison.

And while its brethren movements of the 60s and 70s stepped into the international spotlight long ago, self-advocacy has remained in obscurity, a continued low profile that raises questions about its long-term potential. Is it simply yet another sign of society's unwillingness to broaden its notion of what the learning disabled can achieve, or is it rather a sign of an inherent weakness of the movement? To put it more baldly, does the nature of the disability place inevitable limits on what those whom it affects can achieve? "Fifty years from now, people will either look back on this as a time when the pendulum swung too far and people had ridiculous hopes and expectations," says Walmsley, "or they will look back on it and say, 'How could they have been so limited in their thinking?' "

Sitting in the centre of the front row of the council chambers at Camden Town hall one day last year was John Atkinson. Atkinson had an unusual lifestyle compared with most people with learning difficulties. By the age of 34, he had a wife, a six-year-old son and a house. As basic as those things sound, for people with learning difficulties they are rare and highly prized commodities. For Atkinson, each one entailed a battle against public perception. Volunteers at the leisure centre where he and his wife spent time placed wagers on whether his marriage would last, he said. Social services put a care order on his son before he was born, so that they could take the baby away at the first sign of trouble.

He was in London that day because he had been elected to represent the Darlington area on Mencap's National Assembly. Sadly, since then John Atkinson has died - but he lived long enough to see some of the things he worked for come to fruition.

Three years ago, Britain's oldest and largest learning disabled charity tore up its old constitution, which put most power in the hands of the parents, and began the complex task of writing a new one. The culmination of that effort is the National Assembly, a membership-elected governing body that convened its first full meeting in Camden's council chambers, which had been donated as a venue. The constitution requires that at least one-third of the elected members must have learning difficulties. Not long after the meeting started, Atkinson suggested that an audio version of the board of trustees' report should be made available for people who were seeing impaired.

Behind Atkinson was Thomas Menear, who was elected from Cornwall and whose 45-year-old son has Down's syndrome. Menear is 73 and has been a member of Mencap for 35 years. You need look no further than his first name to work out his attitude to Mencap's constitutional changes. "My first name is Thomas," he says. "And, remember, in the Bible Thomas was a doubter." The problem with self-advocacy, he argues, is that sometimes it caters to the interests of those with milder disabilities, who usually occupy leadership positions, and ignore the needs of those with more severe disabilities. (Lee and Rank-Petruzziello have disabilities so mild they are not apparent on first meeting them.)

"What you see in London at the National Assembly, it's not true to life," adds Menear. "The aspirations are marvellous, but most of it can't be achieved except by a very small number of people." During the meeting, he complained that a report they had been given was oversimplified.

Both Atkinson's and Menear's comments bring the challenges facing Mencap's new assembly sharply into focus - one was concerned that the materials are not accessible enough for people with learning disabilities; the other was concerned they are not informative enough for people without suchdisabilities. It is the job of Fred Heddell, chief executive of Mencap, to turn a group of people with both viewpoints into a functioning governing body. The charity now accepts the idea that people with learning difficulties should have more power in the organisation, but two questions still remain - how, and how much?

The "how?" part is relatively easy to answer. The representatives arrive at the meeting carrying materials that they hope will allow people with disabilities and people without to work on an equal footing. As they settle into their seats in the chamber, they pull out multicoloured agenda sheets printed with large fonts and helpful illustrations. Each member has red, green, yellow and white "traffic light" cards. If a member wants to vote against a motion or to stop the meeting because she doesn't understand something, she holds up the red card. If the meeting is moving too fast, she holds up the yellow card to slow it down. Green is to vote for a motion. White is to ask a question.

The trickier question, however, is "how much?". Mencap was launched in 1946 by a group of parents whose children had learning difficulties. Since then, its parent members have led the charge for better education, better services, more leisure and vocational activities, better housing, and some of those parents now feel that, after all their years of hard work, they are being shoved aside in an organisation they created.

Heddell crosses his arms across his chest. He's sitting in an office that he is using temporarily while Mencap's headquarters, just a stone's throw from the City of London, are being refurbished. He feels confident that, together, people with learning difficulties and their parents will represent a more powerful force than they do separately. "I think the great danger is to focus too heavily on the differences and not recognise that, in fact, in terms of the service, the provision, the support and things that people with learning disability need, the vast majority is in common with all of the other stakeholders and vested interests in the area. That gives us in terms of, say, our campaigning role much better leverage."

It's a position that Atkinson supported. "I think people with learning difficulties are getting a fair crack of the whip," he said. The learning disabled "learn from those who have been in the job the longest. The new people with the learning difficulties who are coming in, they're showing [the non-disabled] how to do things so that people can understand it. It's a learning thing for both of us."

But the desire to incorporate both the disabled and non-disabled leaves Mencap with an intractable dilemma. The structure of the charity, whose mission statement says it aims to be "the principal pressure group for people with a learning disability", would be absurd if applied to any similar organisation. Most social movements hold as a core belief the idea that people who are the target of discrimination have to be in control of the efforts to fight it. Otherwise, you are left with an impossible situation in which the oppressor is both doling out the injustice and dictating the terms on which it is fought. So, parents may have a personal connection to disability, but, ultimately, they rank among the oppressor class - that is, the non- disabled. Imagine if two-thirds of the control of the Scottish National Party was in the hands of the English. Or if Stonewall was two-thirds run by parents of gays and lesbians.

But Heddell makes clear that Mencap has no intention of becoming a self-advocacy group. "Let's start from the beginning," he says. "Intellectual disability is intellectual disability. And the more complex and so on issues become, the more you're going to need other people to do it. Animal welfare groups are not run by animals. Now I don't want to create any kind of parallel with people with learning disability. Children's groups are not run by children. Perhaps that's a better example."

Even People First can't entirely escape a dependence on the non-disabled. In movement lingo, they are called "supporters". Their job is to help people with disabilities, many of whom have been told all their lives they are incapable of making up their own minds, determining what they want and how they can get it. Their tasks can range from writing letters to translating official documents into plain English, to explaining legal and political strategy, to chauffeuring disabled people around.

"The supporter is so important," explains Walmsley. "The supporter has to be somebody who allows people to make mistakes and not be on a power trip. They're seen as wheelchairs or sign-language interpreters, but they're not because they perform a much more complex task."

For a self-advocacy group to succeed, good support is critical. But there are no national networks, no standardised training, no regulations for supporters. Although some are paid staff, many are volunteers. The uneven quality of support available is one of the movement's greatest vulnerabilities. "I see it at times as a very difficult role, because it's very easy to allow yourself to be influencing heavily the decisions they reach," says Chris Lock, a supporter and trustee with the self-advocacy group, My Life My Choice. "The watchword is to listen carefully to what they are saying and to act on it, rather than acting on your own decisions, even if you disagree with them. That's the hardest of all."

But the line between drawing ideas from people and telling them what to think is thin and hard to locate. Take a glance at the work of a group of people with learning difficulties in Croydon that the NHS has recruited to assess the quality of its residential services, and you'll see an impressive effort by people who have spent months interviewing residents and tallying their findings. Then look again, this time more closely, at a meeting with the group and the programme co-ordinators from the NHS: in one corner you will see a non-disabled woman, one of the co-ordinators, lean over to whisper to a disabled man who has just suggested that staff in these homes should do a better job of asking residents what they want.

"Do you think that people [with disabilities] should learn to ask for themselves?" she says.

"Yeah," he responds.

"Good point. Say that then."

When he is called on to speak, she has to talk him through it. "Should people . . ." she coaxes.

"People."

"Ask . . ."

"Ask."

"For themselves?"

"For themselves?"

Lock says that, sometimes, he has no choice but to take charge in this way. With only a few supporters for 11 disabled trustees, they simply do not have the resources to help each person keep up with everything. For example, two members sign the cheques. Lock would like them to have a better understanding of how the budget works, but they would need individual support to do that. "Sometimes it's necessary to make decisions because there isn't time to check and go back and listen," he says.

The weakness of groups run entirely by people with learning difficulties, argues Craig Dearden, project manager of Speaking Up!, the organisation that hosted Express 2000, is that they are attaching more importance to the process than the outcome. For this reason, Speaking Up! describes itself as an advocacy group, not a self-advocacy group, to acknowledge the fact that, although most of its leaders have learning difficulties, some do not. "We believe that a partnership between people with and without learning difficulties is far more effective than a situation in which people with learning difficulties are left to do everything on their own," says Dearden, who is not learning disabled. "In my experience, those types of organisations often struggle to deliver, and hit problems in the medium and long term . . . I think that is an incredibly slow approach in a competitive charity environment."

But what if the problem isn't that people with learning difficulties move too slowly? What if the problem is that people without learning difficulties assume that there is value in moving quickly? If the achievements of the self-advocacy movement do not appear to measure up to those of other social move-ments, perhaps all we need to do is change the yardstick by which we measure its success.

During the lunch break of Express 2000, a middle-aged man with round, plastic glasses and a jacket over his arm approaches Lee and introduces himself. His name is John. Immediately, Lee is back in evangelist mode. He begins telling John about some of People First's political goals: "What we'd like to see is, when people are interviewed for jobs to work in residential care, people with learning difficulties are on the panels."

John, it turns out, is very agreeable. He says little, nods a lot and, when Lee pauses, replies simply, "That's nice." He wanders off again and it's not clear that he's understood anything Lee has just said. Lee recognises that bringing people such as John on board will be a slow process. "There is nothing wrong with an organisation going at the speed that people with learning difficulties want it to," he says. "If an organisation is not controlled by people with learning difficulties, then it is bound to go too quickly for them. And then how can they make an informed decision about what the organisation is achieving?"

So you change the yardstick: rather than viewing Lee's conversation with John as a failure, see it as a tiny step in a very long, very gradual, but very vital process. And, as far as Lee is concerned, there is no debate to be had over whether people with learning difficulties can lead a movement; there are no paradoxes, no contradictions and confusions. It may take time, he says, but we are slowly, inexorably headed for a different future.

Walmsley provides her own answer to the question she posed earlier - whether in 50 years' time people will look back and say we went too far or not far enough. "I think we will get further. I'm sure we will get further than we are now. I suppose 50 years from now, we'll be saying that they were very naive, that they could have done this better."

In 50 years' time, self advocates imagine a world in which people with learning difficulties live independently, earn money, get married, have children. A world in which they are free from harassment and abuse. They can see a future in which People First will be Britain's "principal pressure group for people with a learning disability". When the government's minister for disabled people will have learning difficulties.

They imagine a day when we will look back at this time and see not a movement that had reached its zenith, but a movement that had only just begun.

"The aspirations are marvellous, but most of it can't be achieved except by a very small number of people." During the meeting, he complained that a report they had been given was oversimplified. Both Atkinson's and Menear's comments bring the challenges facing Mencap's new assembly sharply into focus - one was concerned that the materials are not accessible enough for people with learning disabilities; the other was concerned they are not informative enough for people without suchdisabilities. It is the job of Fred Heddell, chief executive of Mencap, to turn a group of people with both viewpoints into a functioning governing body. The charity now accepts the idea that people with learning difficulties should have more power in the organisation, but two questions still remain - how, and how much? The "how?" part is relatively easy to answer. The representatives arrive at the meeting carrying materials that they hope will allow people with disabilities and people without to work on an equal footing. As they settle into their seats in the chamber, they pull out multicoloured agenda sheets printed with large fonts and helpful illustrations. Each member has red, green, yellow and white "traffic light" cards. If a member wants to vote against a motion or to stop the meeting because she doesn't understand something, she holds up the red card. If the meeting is moving too fast, she holds up the yellow card to slow it down. Green is to vote for a motion. White is to ask a question. The trickier question, however, is "how much?". Mencap was launched in 1946 by a group of parents whose children had learning difficulties. Since then, its parent members have led the charge for better education, better services, more leisure and vocational activities, better housing, and some of those parents now feel that, after all their years of hard work, they are being shoved aside in an organisation they created. Heddell crosses his arms across his chest. He's sitting in an office that he is using temporarily while Mencap's headquarters, just a stone's throw from the City of London, are being refurbished. He feels confident that, together, people with learning difficulties and their parents will represent a more powerful force than they do separately. "I think the great danger is to focus too heavily on the differences and not recognise that, in fact, in terms of the service, the provision, the support and things that people with learning disability need, the vast majority is in common with all of the other stakeholders and vested interests in the area. That gives us in terms of, say, our campaigning role much better leverage." It's a position that Atkinson supported. "I think people with learning difficulties are getting a fair crack of the whip," he said. The learning disabled "learn from those who have been in the job the longest. The new people with the learning difficulties who are coming in, they're showing [the non-disabled] how to do things so that people can understand it. It's a learning thing for both of us." But the desire to incorporate both the disabled and non-disabled leaves Mencap with an intractable dilemma. The structure of the charity, whose mission statement says it aims to be "the principal pressure group for people with a learning disability", would be absurd if applied to any similar organisation. Most social movements hold as a core belief the idea that people who are the target of discrimination have to be in control of the efforts to fight it. Otherwise, you are left with an impossible situation in which the oppressor is both doling out the injustice and dictating the terms on which it is fought. So, parents may have a personal connection to disability, but, ultimately, they rank among the oppressor class - that is, the non- disabled. Imagine if two-thirds of the control of the Scottish National Party was in the hands of the English. Or if Stonewall was two-thirds run by parents of gays and lesbians. But Heddell makes clear that Mencap has no intention of becoming a self-advocacy group. "Let's start from the beginning," he says. "Intellectual disability is intellectual disability. And the more complex and so on issues become, the more you're going to need other people to do it. Animal welfare groups are not run by animals. Now I don't want to create any kind of parallel with people with learning disability. Children's groups are not run by children. Perhaps that's a better example." Even People First can't entirely escape a dependence on the non-disabled. In movement lingo, they are called "supporters". Their job is to help people with disabilities, many of whom have been told all their lives they are incapable of making up their own minds, determining what they want and how they can get it. Their tasks can range from writing letters to translating official documents into plain English, to explaining legal and political strategy, to chauffeuring disabled people around. "The supporter is so important," explains Walmsley. "The supporter has to be somebody who allows people to make mistakes and not be on a power trip. They're seen as wheelchairs or sign-language interpreters, but they're not because they perform a much more complex task." For a self-advocacy group to succeed, good support is critical. But there are no national networks, no standardised training, no regulations for supporters. Although some are paid staff, many are volunteers. The uneven quality of support available is one of the movement's greatest vulnerabilities. "I see it at times as a very difficult role, because it's very easy to allow yourself to be influencing heavily the decisions they reach," says Chris Lock, a supporter and trustee with the self-advocacy group, My Life My Choice. "The watchword is to listen carefully to what they are saying and to act on it, rather than acting on your own decisions, even if you disagree with them. That's the hardest of all." But the line between drawing ideas from people and telling them what to think is thin and hard to locate. Take a glance at the work of a group of people with learning difficulties in Croydon that the NHS has recruited to assess the quality of its residential services, and you'll see an impressive effort by people who have spent months interviewing residents and tallying their findings. Then look again, this time more closely, at a meeting with the group and the programme co-ordinators from the NHS: in one corner you will see a non-disabled woman, one of the co-ordinators, lean over to whisper to a disabled man who has just suggested that staff in these homes should do a better job of asking residents what they want. "Do you think that people [with disabilities] should learn to ask for themselves?" she says. "Yeah," he responds. "Good point. Say that then." When he is called on to speak, she has to talk him through it. "Should people . . ." she coaxes. "People." "Ask . . ." "Ask." "For themselves?" "For themselves?" Lock says that, sometimes, he has no choice but to take charge in this way. With only a few supporters for 11 disabled trustees, they simply do not have the resources to help each person keep up with everything. For example, two members sign the cheques. Lock would like them to have a better understanding of how the budget works, but they would need individual support to do that. "Sometimes it's necessary to make decisions because there isn't time to check and go back and listen," he says. The weakness of groups run entirely by people with learning difficulties, argues Craig Dearden, project manager of Speaking Up!, the organisation that hosted Express 2000, is that they are attaching more importance to the process than the outcome. For this reason, Speaking Up! describes itself as an advocacy group, not a self-advocacy group, to acknowledge the fact that, although most of its leaders have learning difficulties, some do not. "We believe that a partnership between people with and without learning difficulties is far more effective than a situation in which people with learning difficulties are left to do everything on their own," says Dearden, who is not learning disabled. "In my experience, those types of organisations often struggle to deliver, and hit problems in the medium and long term . . . I think that is an incredibly slow approach in a competitive charity environment." But what if the problem isn't that people with learning difficulties move too slowly? What if the problem is that people without learning difficulties assume that there is value in moving quickly? If the achievements of the self-advocacy movement do not appear to measure up to those of other social move-ments, perhaps all we need to do is change the yardstick by which we measure its success. During the lunch break of Express 2000, a middle-aged man with round, plastic glasses and a jacket over his arm approaches Lee and introduces himself. His name is John. Immediately, Lee is back in evangelist mode. He begins telling John about some of People First's political goals: "What we'd like to see is, when people are interviewed for jobs to work in residential care, people with learning difficulties are on the panels." John, it turns out, is very agreeable. He says little, nods a lot and, when Lee pauses, replies simply, "That's nice." He wanders off again and it's not clear that he's understood anything Lee has just said. Lee recognises that bringing people such as John on board will be a slow process. "There is nothing wrong with an organisation going at the speed that people with learning difficulties want it to," he says. "If an organisation is not controlled by people with learning difficulties, then it is bound to go too quickly for them. And then how can they make an informed decision about what the organisation is achieving?" So you change the yardstick: rather than viewing Lee's conversation with John as a failure, see it as a tiny step in a very long, very gradual, but very vital process. And, as far as Lee is concerned, there is no debate to be had over whether people with learning difficulties can lead a movement; there are no paradoxes, no contradictions and confusions. It may take time, he says, but we are slowly, inexorably headed for a different future. Walmsley provides her own answer to the question she posed earlier - whether in 50 years' time people will look back and say we went too far or not far enough. "I think we will get further. I'm sure we will get further than we are now. I suppose 50 years from now, we'll be saying that they were very naive, that they could have done this better." In 50 years' time, self advocates imagine a world in which people with learning difficulties live independently, earn money, get married, have children. A world in which they are free from harassment and abuse. They can see a future in which People First will be Britain's "principal pressure group for people with a learning disability". When the government's minister for disabled people will have learning difficulties. They imagine a day when we will look back at this time and see not a movement that had reached its zenith, but a movement that had only just begun.

fields.headline: Dolphin danger
fields.standfirst: Net deaths put species at risk
fields.trailText: Species of dolphin and porpoise are in danger of extinction because so many are killed in fishing nets around the British coast, according to the UN and North sea governments.
fields.body:
Species of dolphin and porpoise are in danger of extinction because so many are killed in fishing nets around the British coast, according to the UN and North sea governments.

Conservation measures were needed to save bottlenosed dolphins in the Murray Firth in Scotland, Cardigan Bay in Wales and in the waters around the Cornwall and Devon, as well as harbour porpoise all round the coasts.

The European commission is being pressed to adopt measures that will restrict the death rate from entanglement in nets to less that 1.7% of their populations a year, a mortality rate which will allow species to recover. Up to 6% are estimated to die each year.

Ascobans, the Agreement on Small Cetaceans of the Baltic and North seas, of which the UK and most states bordering the north Atlantic are members, is urging the EC to include marine mammal conservation in its review of the common fisheries policy due to be completed by December 2002. Klaus Toepfer, the executive director of UN environment programmes, said: "More than 2,000 harbour porpoises die annually in the Celtic sea alone." The fisheries review offered a "golden opportunity" to address the threat.

webTitle: Solo walk into dangers of the Arctic

fields.headline: Solo walk into dangers of the Arctic
fields.standfirst: Explorer's trek to the North Pole challenges 'risk-averse' philosophy
fields.trailText: Explorer's trek to the North Pole challenges 'risk-averse' philosophy.
fields.body:
As holidaymakers flew abroad for their Easter breaks this week, Dave Mill set out on a rather more challenging journey. For the next 50 days, the 33-year-old Scot will battle alone to reach the North Pole in temperatures as low as minus 60C.

To most people, it sounds like seven weeks of sheer hell. He will drag his sledge of provisions for 450 miles across the Arctic, facing moving ice floes and struggling over 100m ice ridges, with no human contact save via a radio and emergency back-up system to pinpoint his position.

Last year Sir Ranulph Fiennes abandoned an attempt on the route due to frostbite and Mr Mill, who had been following him, had to give up his own mission after 35 days, draining the last vestiges of power from his batteries as he frantically radioed for assistance.

But this time the adventurer from Kenmore, Perthshire, is confident that he will face down the dangers and become the first man to walk solo and unaided to the Pole from the Canadian side.

"I'm going to make it because I know that local people in Aberfeldy have had faith in me and have supported me," he said this week.

"Knowing that they are all with me every step of the way will give me strength and belief to keep going when things get tough."

Mr Mill is one of that strange band of adventurers: loners who seem ecstatic at the prospect of spending weeks in gruelling conditions, with no company and a substantial risk of losing their lives.

"People are interested in risk in what appears to be a risk-averse society," said Shane Winser, head of the expeditions advisory centre at the Royal Geographical Society.

"For many people, testing yourself and surviving is an important growth experience. It gives you a focus and quality of being alive that you don't get sitting on the underground," suggested Mike Money, a psychologist at Liverpool's John Moores University.

"But we are keener and keener to protect people - look at the sort of risks we protect children from, for example. It is very understandable, but people often have a reaction to that. They want to get out of the cotton wool and live life on their own terms."

Adventurers often seem to be escaping from otherwise humdrum lives. Jim Shekhdar, the 54-year-old Briton who last month became the first person to row unaided across the Pacific, is a former civil servant and businessman who tired of being a "corporate animal".

Brian Jones, the British half of the first team to go round the world in a balloon, took up the sport after becoming bored with his furniture business.

Dr Money said one explanation for the dissatisfaction was that we face an evolutionary conflict.

"There's a sudden mismatch between our bodies and what we use them for," he suggested. "The sort of bodies you and I have are designed for hunter-gathering and narrow escapes from danger, such as running away from sabre-toothed tigers. Now we spend seven hours a day sitting in front of a VDU."

Mr Jones's Swiss co-pilot, Bertrand Piccard, a psychiatrist, believes that people can only get in touch with their true selves by confronting their greatest fears.

Mr Jones suggests that facing great risks paradoxically brings humans a sense of security. "'The parachute regiment has a motto 'knowledge dispels fear', and it is absolutely true," he said of his voyage.

"If you can bring it out of the unknown into something more tangible, something you may be able to cope with, it does dispel fear." While few of us want to test such theories ourselves, we are eager to explore them vicariously - and that, in turn, may drive explorers on.

"Go into bookshops and you will see countless titles on the subject," said Felix Driver of Royal Holloway, the University of London, whose book Geography Militant: Cultures of Exploration, examines our fascination with adventurers.

"I'm amazed by how significant the market is. People love the idea of these heroic and slightly deranged individuals - the eccentric loners. And some explorers seem to cultivate that quite consciously."

Dave Mill may be unaccompanied on his gruelling solo mission, but he has the admiration and moral support of armchair adventurers across the world.

Where to find Britain's other adventurers

 The Arctic

Mike and Fiona Thornewill, from Nottinghamshire, are just under halfway through their 480-mile trek to the North Pole, which will make them the first married couple to reach both poles on foot. Mrs Thornewill and their companion, Catherine Hartley, from London, will become the first women in the world to walk both poles. They crossed Antarctica last year.

 Cairns, Australia

Jason Lewis is about to embark on a 100-day mountain biking trip across the continent, following his 7,000-mile pedalboat voyage from the United States to Australia. The 32-year-old from Dorset has already spent six years attempting to circumnavigate the globe under human power alone. His friend Steve Smith abandoned the project in 1999.

 Alaska, United States

Two weeks ago, Briton Steve Brooks and his team halted their attempt to cross the 56-mile Bering strait to Siberia in a hovering car. The Ice Challenger team hopes to mount a second attempt on the ice bridge next year after strengthening the vehicle, before driving right around the world.

 Cape Town, South Africa

Robert Garside, a former psychology student from Stockport, has crossed Europe, Asia, Australia and the Americas in his attempt to become the first person to run around the world. He is now beginning his assault on Africa and plans to cross Antarctica in 2002. But in February he admitted fabricating part of his account of the journey and missing thousands of miles from his original route by taking a flight.

 Queensland, Australia

On March 30 rower Jim Shekhdar, 54, became the first man to row unassisted across the Pacific ocean, from Ilo in Peru to North Stradbroke island off the Queensland coast. His boat was swamped in sight of land and the Londoner was forced to swim ashore.

webTitle: Live rap by DJ at radio chief's order to play Eminem

fields.headline: Live rap by DJ at radio chief's order to play Eminem
fields.trailText: Love him, loathe him, Eminem rouses emotions - as witnessed by a spontaneous on-air exchange between a Birmingham DJ and his programme controller yesterday.
fields.body:
Love him, loathe him, Eminem rouses emotions - as witnessed by a spontaneous on-air exchange between a Birmingham DJ and his programme controller yesterday.

BRMB's breakfast presenter Graham Mack walked out of the studio after an order to play Eminem's Stan. Listeners heard him call the track "rubbish" and argue live with the controller, Adam Bridge.

Mack began by saying: "I'm supposed to play Stan by Eminem. He's a bigot, he's a criminal, and he's on probation." (The US rapper was this week convicted of carrying a concealed weapon.)

"Here we are playing this song, making him rich... The countryside's in a mess, and it's not looking good for people at places like Marconi - so I'm going to play Keeping the Dream Alive instead."

Mack went on to tell listeners that he did not get on with the controller, and then the phone rang. Mr Bridge came on air: "Maybe I'm stupid, but I selected Eminem. I don't pay you for your opinion - just play the bloody song."

Mack told him the conversation was going out live before saying: "I'm out of here - if you want it played, you bloody play it."

The show's remaining half hour was taken by another DJ.

webTitle: Palace serves up history of chocolate

fields.headline: Palace serves up history of chocolate
fields.trailText: Chocolate, that well known hangover cure and aphrodisiac, will once again be served at Hampton Court this weekend.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Chocolate, that well known hangover cure and aphrodisiac, will once again be served at Hampton Court this weekend.

Hampton Court palace was one of the first places in England where chocolate was regularly served. Some royals took a fortifying cup before joining their mistresses. Others, including William III, took it as a pick-me-up after a night of gambling and drinking.

The food historian Richard Fitch has studied the archives and discovered that the Oscar-nominated film Chocolat, where the confectioner seduces an entire French village into transports of erotic delight, is not so far of the mark.

William may have acquired the habit in the Low Countries, one of the first places in Europe to import cocoa beans. He clearly took to it in a big way and it became a life long habit, in defiance of the medical advice of his personal physician, Dr Mulligan.

"Throughout the 17th century the argument rages backwards and forwards - is chocolate a food, a drug, a medicine? Is it good for you or very bad, should it be given only to invalids or never given to them?" said Mr Fitch, who will be cooking 17th century chocolate recipes at Hampton Court for the next nine days.

Small samples of the drink, made from hand ground roast cocoa beans, mixed with sugar, water, cinnamon and vanilla, will be offered to visitors.

London had its first chocolate house by 1657, and by the 1590s the habit was well enough established at Hampton Court for a special kitchen to be built, just for chocolate.

Mr Fitch said: "In England, unlike the continent, anyone could drink chocolate who could afford it, anyone could go into a chocolate shop, but it was expensive... In 17th century France the crown chocolatier is recorded as having 8lb of chocolate in his personal stores, when there were only 22lb in the country."

The chocolate kitchen at Hampton Court still survives, in Fountain Court. It was the domain of Mr Nice, the chocolate cook. There are two tantalising references to Mr Nice in the archives - that the kitchen is being created for him, and that lodgings are being built for him - an indication that he was above the status of other servants.

It is not known where he learned his trade, or whether he outlived the king, who died in 1702.

In Mr Fitch's own household the question of whether it is good or bad for you has been resolved: his two children do not get chocolate Easter eggs. "Lord no, they get mental, speed around the house and wreck the place. Not a good idea."

fields.bylineHtml: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Nuclear deal resumes | Music hall legend dies | TB check on health workers | Finishing line, 41 days later
fields.body:
Nuclear deal resumes

Nuclear fuel shipments from Germany to Sellafield in Cumbria, are to be resumed after being suspended three years ago when high levels of radioactivity were found on flasks and rail wagons. The spent fuel is reprocessed into plutonium and uranium at the controversial Thorp works which is currently closed because of high level waste safety problems. The first shipment is due later this month.

Music hall legend dies

Scottish music hall legend Jimmy Logan died early yesterday in hospital after losing his battle with cancer of the oesophagus. Scottish First Minister Henry McLeish said Logan, 73, whose range covered serious drama, comedy and song, "was loved by generations of Scots and by people with Scottish connections all over the world".
Obituary: Jimmy Logan

TB check on health workers

Health workers in Solihull are being tested after a community nurse in her 30s was diagnosed with tuberculosis. Solihull health authority has also written to the GPs of about 100 patients who have been in contact with the nurse.

Finishing line, 41 days later

webTitle: Needless battle caused by uncommon language

fields.headline: Needless battle caused by uncommon language
fields.standfirst: How a misunderstanding between a British brigadier and US general led to disaster on a Korean battlefield
fields.trailText: How a misunderstanding between a British brigadier and US general led to disaster on a Korean battlefield
fields.body:
His men were outnumbered eight to one, stranded on every side by human waves of Chinese Communist infantry attackers at the height of the Korean war.

But when the British brigadier reported the position to his American superior in the United Nations joint command, he did so with classic and -as it turned out - lethal British understatement.

"Things are a bit sticky, sir," Brig Tom Brodie of the Gloucestershire Regiment told General Robert H Soule, intending to convey that they were in extreme difficulty.

But Gen Soule understood this to mean "We're having a bit of rough and tumble but we're holding the line". Oh good, the general decided, no need to reinforce or withdraw them, not yet anyway.

The upshot was one of the most famous, heroic and - according to a BBC2 documentary on April 20 - unnecessary last stands in military history: the ordeal of 600 men of the "Glorious Gloucesters" at the Imjin river almost exactly 50 years ago.

With no extra support promised, the colonel in charge of the Gloucesters fell back to a hill overlooking the river, where they made their stand. For four days, mostly without sleep, they held off 30,000 Chinese troops trying to surge across the river, killing 10,000 of them with Bren gun fire.

When they tried to withdraw, they were too late. More than 500 of them were captured and spent years in Chinese camps. Fifty-nine were killed or missing. Only 39 escaped. Two soldiers were awarded Victoria crosses for bravery.

Their feat was credited with saving Seoul, the south Korean capital, from capture. But yesterday the official historian of the war, General Sir Anthony Farrar-Hockley, said Seoul probably would not have been endangered if the men had been withdrawn earlier, and they would not have been cut off or captured.

Sir Anthony, now 77, a former Nato commander-in-chief, was himself captured at Imjin as a young adjutant to the Gloucesters. He said a US officer - unlike Brig Brodie - would have known how to make Gen Soule understand, by using the phrase "Sir, there is all hell breaking loose here".

Sir Anthony said: "The two nations spoke military [language] in a slightly different way. It's certainly a good example of the old saying about Britain and the US as two nations divided by a common language."

He discloses the episode in Forgotten Heroes: Korea Remembered, a programme of interviews with veterans to mark the 50th anniversary of Imjin.

The programme says: "Any hopes of relief were dashed by an American misunderstanding of British understatement."

Sir Anthony said he learned of the conversation from a number of sources while researching An Honourable Discharge, the second volume of his Cabinet Office history of the Korean war, published in 1995.

He said: "I don't think anyone should be hard on the brigadier. He was talking in battle, when they were clinging on by their fingertips. Nobody had time to think of the nuances of what they were saying."

The British 29th brigade, of which the Gloucesters were part, saw 400 die at Imjin. The horror of the slaughter, which began on April 22 1951, is caught in the survivors' stories. John Dyer of Twyford, Berkshire, then a 20-year-old national serviceman with the Royal Ulster Rifles, says in the documentary: "I had never seen so many soldiers in my life. The hillside was literally covered in them. If you've ever seen on a film when lemmings go over a cliff, it was just like that.

"Then we realised that we were into trouble. We wouldn't be human if we hadn't got scared - a mass of people rushing at you, bayonets fixed, grenades being thrown, shouting, screaming, because they used it as a fear tactic."

Geoff Costello of Ashtead, Surrey, who was fighting with a platoon, says: "Several of their assaults just broke up because you can imagine the force of five Bren guns, with one loose on the side. That's 150 rounds all in one spurt in the space of seconds. I saw an awful lot of dead Chinese."

Dennis Whybro of Chelmsford, Essex, who was with the King's Irish Royal Hussars, describes racing by tank uphill to try to rescue the Gloucesters. "It was more or less a death or glory sort of stunt."

Mr Dyer said the courageous Chinese foot soldiers fought almost suicidally when they saw survivors escaping on tanks.

"The tanks were going straight through them. And that's all I could hear, these people screaming, being crushed by the tanks as they went through them. Quite a horrible experience."

Only when the tank carrying him reached safety did Mr Dyer see the full horror of what had happened.

"It was a mess, just a mess. The sides of the tanks were covered in blood. All the tracks were full of limbs, it was a mess. It was a mess. So much so that we were taken off into the tents so that we wouldn't see any more of it. But it was a horrible mess."

When the survivors and ex-prisoners finally returned home, it was to a Britain still sick of the 1939-45 war and uninterested in their experiences.

One of them says: "It's unfair that so many men should be killed and so many men should go [to Korea] and fight and put their lives on the line fighting for the principles of the United Nations.

"But you can't help human nature, can you?"

webTitle: Mystery of Indian rope trick unravelled

fields.headline: Mystery of Indian rope trick unravelled
fields.trailText: Can you keep a secret? You know that centuries-old trick where an Indian fakir coaxes a rope from a basket and a small boy clambers to the top? It's a pole.
fields.body:
Can you keep a secret? You know that centuries-old trick where an Indian fakir coaxes a rope from a basket and a small boy clambers to the top? It's a pole.

This earthly explanation of the famous illusion is just one of the myths of magic debunked by magician-turned-academic Peter Lamont at the Edinburgh International Science Festival last night.

In a talk on the magic of India, Dr Lamont, a former president of the Magic Circle in Edinburgh, unravelled some of the secrets of the east. But only up to a point. Anxious not to blow the cover or incur the wrath of his fellow magicians, Dr Lamont offered a scientific explanation for feats that appear to challenge modern science - without giving away the exact mechanics of the tricks themselves.

The rope trick, he said, was one of the simplest to explain. "The rope trick itself never used a rope. The legend is that the rope goes up and a boy shins up it and disappears at the top. What seems to be the case is that first-hand accounts of this were exaggerated over time from what was a pole-balancing trick. Then there were hoax photos and the myth was perpetuated."

Dr Lamont also cast a sceptical eye over levitation, sword swallowing and body piercing, and demonstrated by stabbing a spike through his own tongue. "You can fake that or you can do it for real," he said. "I'm a magician so you can guess what I do."

He said there was an enduring fascination with India among westerners. "Interest in the paranormal and supernatural has been around for a long time. In the mundane world we have, and especially the less spiritual world, we hanker after something that tells us there is a bit more to life. We have an interest in something that gives some sense of spirituality. Every second traveller I have met in India is on a quest for spirituality. They don't go to Shepherd's Bush to find it. They go to India."

Meanwhile, plans to allow the public to walk on hot coals as part of Dr Lamont's festival project have been scuppered by insurance firms.

The organisers had hoped to allow visitors to today's event to try walking on red hot coals themselves to show that there is nothing mystical or supernatural about the activity. But the spectacle being held at West Princes Street Gardens is to go ahead purely as a demonstration event after insurance companies got cold feet and refused to offer cover.

webTitle: Battle for the skies hots up

fields.headline: Battle for the skies hots up
fields.trailText: Airbus, the European aircraft manufacturer, is ready to ratchet up its war with US giant Boeing for global supremacy by building a rival "sonic cruiser" to that planned by the American group, senior executives indicated yesterday.
fields.body:
Airbus, the European aircraft manufacturer, is ready to ratchet up its war with US giant Boeing for global supremacy by building a rival "sonic cruiser" to that planned by the American group, senior executives indicated yesterday.

Boeing recently pulled out of the race to build new superjumbo aircraft, abandoning plans to develop a 520-seater 747X to compete with Airbus's 555-seater A380 on non-stop long haul flights such as London to Sydney.

Instead the group set out plans to develop a "sonic cruiser", a delta-winged plane that would cut 90 minutes off the journey time from London to New York by flying at just under the speed of sound.

Boeing, which has consistently belittled the potential market for superjumbos, says it has attracted considerable interest from its traditional airline customers in the new plane. But Airbus executives cast serious doubt on the project, suggesting the plane might not be aerodynamically sound, let alone economically viable.

However, in a new twist, executives from Airbus's majority shareholder, the European Aeronautical Defence and Space company (EADS), said they would talk to airlines about the prospects for building a rival sonic cruiser - a project that would take up to 10 years to deliver.

In a further development, Boeing was yesterday reported to be considering plans for a bigger, longer range version of its jumbo, the 747, after all. These moves are viewed by Airbus executives as "spoilers" designed to deter customers from buying its A380, which has already secured 66 orders.

webTitle: Against all odds, the Russians and Zulus

fields.headline: Against all odds, the Russians and Zulus
fields.standfirst: The most famous example of tangled communications leading to military disaster is the Charge of the Light Brigade in 1854, during the Crimean war, writes Vikram Dodd.
fields.trailText: The most famous example of tangled communications leading to military disaster is the Charge of the Light Brigade in 1854, during the Crimean war,  writes Vikram Dodd.
fields.body:
An order to attack a Russian position was misinterpreted and led to the wrong - heavily defended - position being rushed, with calamitous consequences.

Immortalised in verse by Tennyson, the charge of the 630 horses and men of the light brigade left 110 men dead, 196 wounded and 57 captured.

It happened because Lord Raglan, situated on high ground, saw Russian troops beginning to remove guns captured from Turkish forces fighting with the British.

Cavalry commander Lord Lucan was handed an order to stop the enemy taking the guns. But Lucan (nicknamed Lord Look-on) could only see the main Russian position and directed the Light Brigade to charge it. They rode into the "valley of death" held on three sides by the Russians.

In another last stand incident, at Rorke's drift in 1879, 125 British soldiers held off at least 4,000 Zulus for more than a day.

There could have been 450 British soldiers at Rorke's drift but a lieutenant and his mounted men rode up to the post and shouted to an officer that they refused to stand, and galloped off.

Another officer, seeing this, leapt over a mealie bag wall and fled, followed by his entire company.

webTitle: Letters: A cross we bear proudly

fields.headline: A cross we bear proudly
fields.trailText: Once again we have an anti-faith tirade from Polly Toynbee (Our lost religion, April 13).
fields.body:
Once again we have an anti-faith tirade from Polly Toynbee (Our lost religion, April 13). She rightly deplores the ignorance of many regarding the importance of religion in our history. She then comments that "the convictions that fired the [Labour] party's founders were quite enough to sustain their sense of purpose and their moral impetus". Is she not aware how fundamental were Christian values to the likes of Keir Hardie, the McMillan sisters, George Lansbury and Arthur Henderson?

Many older members of the Labour Party - including David Blunkett - know very well how important Christian values have been to the wider Labour movement, and still are. The determination of Gordon Brown, Clare Short and others to tackle child poverty is a further example, though it needs more focus and wider support, including from the faith communities.

She suggests government plans to ban religious discrimination will stifle free speech and extend blasphemy laws. But many in the faith communities agree that blasphemy laws are better abolished. She complains about the Budget's VAT relief for repairs to church buildings (omitting to mention it is only listed ones). That would leave church congregations to raise even more money to help maintain the nation's heritage, which apparently even Ms Toynbee is in favour of. Where does Ms Toynbee stand? At least we Christian Socialists are not afraid to wear our hearts on our sleeves.
Rev David Haslam
Chair, Christian Socialist Movement
davidhaslam@easynet.co.uk

 Contrary to Polly Toynbee's assertion that the Labour party's founders were not inspired by the supernatural, figures from RH Tawney to John Smith drew their "sense of purpose and moral impetus" from their Christian beliefs. Rather than pursuing the faith communities in search of a few easy votes, Tony Blair is simply continuing a long and distinguished line.
Pete Moorey
Beckenham, Kent
pete@themooreys.com

 We believers, it seems, just can never get it right! If we keep our religion to ourselves we are accused of disappearing into a holy huddle, concentrating on arcane rituals and counting angels on the head of a pin. If, on the other hand, we engage in more constructive activities, such as education, we stand accused of forcing otherwise honest unbelievers into the pews by providing the only decent schools for miles around. Does it not occur to our critics that, if we can run good schools, there might actually be something to be said for our beliefs and disciplines?

Could not our critics, instead of instantly complaining, take time to sit back and think out carefully why church schools seem to perform so well? Perhaps also they could look at educational success in the Judaic and Islamic communities, and among those of strong secular convictions.
Humphrey Reader
Weston-super-Mare, Somerset

 Polly Toynbee's fears of the loss of common cultural references is tellingly illustrated in the preface to Peter and Linda Murray's Oxford Companion to Christian Art and Architecture, where they record the comments of an English couple in front of Leonard da Vinci's Last Supper: "I don't know what they are doing, but they seem to be having some sort of a meal."
Stuart Walsh
Swinton, Lancs

 In your front-page picture (April 13), why is the Rev Dr John Roden wearing a white stole when it's still Lent? Ignorance of our religious heritage is even worse than Polly Toynbee fears.
Paul Hartmann
Otley, W Yorks

fields.headline: Romans and countryman
fields.trailText: We have just endured the wettest winter on record, the weather is still abysmal and much of the countryside is a sea of mud.
fields.body:
We have just endured the wettest winter on record, the weather is still abysmal and much of the countryside is a sea of mud. How many potential tourists would choose to holiday in such circumstances, even if foot and mouth wasn't present (Easter in Britain, April 13)?
Mike Henning
Shepton Mallet, Somerset

 Your idealistic photograph of a cyclist mingling with deer, with no signs of a car, in Richmond Park (Where to go if you stay at home, April 13) distorts the reality. Through traffic, which accounts for 98% of the total park movements, is now back polluting this unique haven.
Philippa Edmunds
East Twickenham, Middx

 You missed one of Britain's greatest gems. Bolsover castle, near Chesterfield, remains open throughout and indeed will be invaded by the Romans during the Easter break.
Brian Holland
Artist in residence, Bolsover castle

 Your picture (French make their excuses over the Widdecombe visit, April 13) suggests a fail-safe method of deterring illegal immigrants: each lorry should be equipped with a life-size cutout of Ann Widdecombe in a leaning-forward-to-attack-Jack-Straw position, accompanied by a recording of the verbal assault.
John Sheeran
Cheltenham, Glos

 When are we going to follow the excellent example of the International Red Cross and ban Ann Widdecombe?
Paul Patrick
Burnley, Lancs

 Reading of the musical chairs being played out in Downing Street (PM rounds on the BBC over Campbell story, April 13) reminds me of Gibbon's line in Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire: "A weak prince will always be governed by his domestics."
David Powell
Lewes, E Sussex

webTitle: Letters: Maybe the joke's on us

fields.headline: Maybe the joke's on us
fields.trailText: It's always enjoyable to laugh at our American cousins and their paranoias (Is that the one where you have to burn your shoes? April 13). But on this occasion perhaps their fears of contracting "hoof and mouth" are not entirely ridiculous.
fields.body:
It's always enjoyable to laugh at our American cousins and their paranoias (Is that the one where you have to burn your shoes? April 13). But on this occasion perhaps their fears of contracting "hoof and mouth" are not entirely ridiculous. Remember, it wasn't so very long ago that Selwyn Gummer was publicly force-feeding beefburgers to his children in an attempt to persuade us mad cow disease was no danger to humans.

A degree of scepticism when presented with "irrefutable" scientific evidence is no bad thing, especially when so many scientists are in the pay of the agricultural and chemical industries. Those US tourists who believe that when taking their dogs for a walk they should stick to one side of the street to avoid contracting foot and mouth may be taking sensible precautions. These enlightened visitors may in fact be teaching us Brits a lesson - it's OK to stroke a cow's rump but not to tickle its toes. They may have the last laugh whilst we hurtle towards an ignominious fate. Or, of course, they could be barking mad septic tanks who are sent here by divine providence to amuse and entertain us.
Anton Moctonian
London

 Miranda Sawyer writes (Travel, April 7): "It's weird because in America it's quite hard to find people to get on with - people are either incredibly straight, or they are a heroin addict. It's hard to find people in between." I emailed this quote to all my Americans friends. So far I have had two replies: one from a friend who is training to be a priest and the other from a friend who hasn't been in touch for a while because he recently "did more drugs than God, almost died". Mmm, how right you are, Miranda.
Sarah Dean
York

webTitle: Letters: The terms of global trade

fields.headline: The terms of global trade
fields.trailText: You claim Wal-Mart was one of a number of retail companies using a Bangladeshi supplier, Islam Garments, where workers looked "barely 10 or 11 years old" (British workers build solidarity, April 9).
fields.body:
You claim Wal-Mart was one of a number of retail companies using a Bangladeshi supplier, Islam Garments, where workers looked "barely 10 or 11 years old" (British workers build solidarity, April 9). We were concerned to see this allegation as it conflicts with the findings of our own rigorous inspection programme.

Islam Garments was inspected by Wal-Mart in April 2000 - no child labour was being used then. Nevertheless, we took your article seriously and are conducting additional inspections to make sure local labour laws and our high standards for suppliers are still being met.

Wal-Mart has a zero-tolerance policy towards child, slave and forced labour, and any other unethical treatment of workers. It requires suppliers to meet written commitments to the basic principles of human rights, reasonable hours of labour and a safe, clean, healthy and productive working environment. This is backed up by regular and rigorous inspections of all factories from which it sources directly - actions which are improving working conditions for people around the world.
Christine Watts
Corporate affairs director, Asda
cwatts@asda.co.uk

 Hugo Young highlights the EU's role in reducing the power of MPs (Comment, April 12), but a greater threat comes from the unelected World Trade Organisation. If the government accepts the Gats agreement, our public services will be up for grabs by transnational corporations. That really will leave MPs "tinkering at the margins".
Dominic Kelly
Carnforth, Lancs

fields.headline: All the right choices
fields.trailText: Patrick Berry, founder of England's first black radio station, Choice FM.
fields.body:
As a small boy in Port Antonio, Jamaica, Patrick Berry found himself inexorably linked with Hollywood's greatest swashbuckler Errol Flynn. The boy's father sometimes worked on a farm owned by Flynn's family and dreamed of buying some land and setting up on his own. But he was frustrated when the family, apparently no Robin Hoods, gazumped him.

The move made him so mad that he sold his one asset, the family cow, and bought a passage to England. This, years later, was what the boy, who is now a man and founder of England's first black radio station, Choice FM, reckons was his first break.

Landing up in Lewisham, south London, Patrick did "quite well" at Catford Boys comprehensive. "My parents pushed me. They were big on education," he says.

He gained four O levels and dreamt of becoming a policeman. His first job was a clerical one, for £14 a week, but he left for a job at Cable & Wireless when the boss reneged on a £2 rise. "But," he says, "my father kept after me to get an education."

He signed up for a course at Middlesex University and "scraped through" with a degree in social science. "My dad was chuffed, as you can imagine". It was 1975 when he took his new degree and started at the bottom, as he remembers, at a community centre in New Cross, London. "The job had really little prospect," he recalls, "but remember there was a lot of unemployment among young black boys."

A real challenge opened up when he was taken on by the Minority Arts Advisory Services to help put out a publication reviewing fringe theatre and coming events in the arts world.

"It was a kind of landmark for me," he says, "the magazine was what I found I enjoyed." Then he got another break when his boss went away and he was left in charge. "I had to get the thing out and I enjoyed it. I liked the feeling." This is when his dream of launching a black Time Out began to take shape. He bumped into an acquaintance, Neil Kenlott, and discussed the idea. "Neil said 'what about the money' and I said that I'd use freelancers and go from there".

Mr Kenlott was just about to cover the 1977 Festec, a huge festival of art and artists in Nigeria and he came back brimming with ideas for a magazine. But Kenlott wanted to go the Ebony magazine glossy route while Berry wanted the listings route.

In the end they compromised and so Root was born, looking for a circulation of around 30,000. "Our investor, Godfrey Hope, enabled us to get out the first issue." After that, a lucky break came in the form of a cheque from the distributors for the whole contract instead of a month's money. "That £11,000 and a friendly manager at the Midland bank, a real Christian, kept us going for eight years."

But by 1987, a coup in Nigeria put paid to healthy sales in that country and so, not making money, the partners sold out to an ethnic publisher and found themselves "back to square one".

Then came rescue in the unlikely form of Leon Brittain, who was getting ready to hand out 300 radio station licences. "We wanted one of them," says Mr Berry. Looking for a consortium of the "good and the brave" and bolstered by a couple of friends employed at Chiltern Radio in Luton, they prepared their application. Suddenly, though, the project was cancelled.

The consortium decided to stay together and wait for the project to be revived. In 1988, the IBA offered 21 licences and the group spent £90 on submitting an application for an Afro-Caribbean station based in London's Brixton area and rooted in research conducted in the street.

The Brixton bank knew nothing about black radio, according to Mr Berry, so back they went to Luton. "This was my real breakthrough," he says, "when we beat out five other groups for the 40-watt station. It was good and felt fine after all those years of campaigning."

Choice opened an offshoot in Birmingham which it sold in 1998 to Chrysalis for £6m. With the Chrysalis money, Choice FM moved into new quarters near London Bridge and applied for the last licence for a 100-watt station in London. Holding public meetings around the boroughs and drumming up support, they beat off 20 rivals.

"I was in the car when I heard the news," he says. "We had been knocking on the door for 10 years - and now, with the coming of digital radio, the future looks bright."

fields.headline: Capital letters:  Phone rates
fields.trailText: At the end of last month, the Office of Fair Trading issued the latest pronouncement in its battle against package tour operators' cancellation charges,  writes Richard Colbey.
fields.body:
At the end of last month, the Office of Fair Trading issued the latest pronouncement in its battle against package tour operators' cancellation charges, writes Richard Colbey.

It said that if Thomson's, Airtours, JMC and First Choice failed to provide the information that supposedly justifies these charges by the end of this week it would definitely take legal action.

In January the OFT was "considering its position" after 15 months of fruitless negotiations with the industry over this matter. In response to a number of complaints from the public, the OFT had earlier decided it was probably unfair for holiday companies to rely on the small print that enables them to charge the full cost of the holiday when a customer cancels. Most companies reserve the right to cancel holidays with little or no compensation.

The OFT's research shows that charges here are higher than those levied in other countries. Swedish operators typically charge 50% for last minute cancellations, Danish ones 60%. The British industry's response has been that its charges less for holidays and that relatively high cancellation charges are one of the factors that enable it to do so.

Even so, the Unfair Contract Terms Regulations, which the OFT enforces, do not suggest that commercial considerations need be taken into account when considering fairness. The OFT might also argue that it has to balance the interests of business and consumers before taking enforcement action.

The industry has defended cancellation charges on the basis that holiday insurance usually covers them. This is one of the reasons why tour operators are so insistent on customers taking out, often needless, insurance.

The OFT is concerned about the lack of information from the industry. It could seek an injunction preventing companies relying on the terms until the matter can be fully resolved by a court. That relatively simple procedure would end cancellation charges within weeks.

Since John Vickers was appointed director-general last October, the OFT has appeared to be taking a tougher line on abuses. Most encouragingly, a £3.2m fine was imposed last week on Napp Pharmaceuticals. In breach of the Competition Act it had grossly over-charged for drugs supplied in the community, while undercharging hospitals to cut out competitors. This was the biggest penalty imposed by the OFT, and its level could prove controversial.

While the issues are very different to those involved in consumer protection, it shows that the OFT need not be held back by the caution that appears to afflict its dealings with unfair terms.


Richard Colbey is a barrister

fields.headline: Better homes, poorer loans
fields.trailText: Thousands of house-proud Brits will take advantage of the Easter break and embark on home improvement projects. Abbey National is already reporting an increase of 7% in the number of applications for people taking out loans to renovate their properties.
fields.body:
Thousands of house-proud Brits will take advantage of the Easter break and embark on home improvement projects. Abbey National is already reporting an increase of 7% in the number of applications for people taking out loans to renovate their properties.

But apathy rules when it comes to finding the best personal loans, according to a MORI poll. When asked what factors should be considered when taking out a personal loan, 55% of those interviewed said they would head for the bank where they run their basic current account. Only one in five respondents, 21% based their decision on the level of interest rates. This results in the high street banks Lloyds TSB, Barclays, NatWest and HSBC, taking an estimated 45% of the unsecured personal loan market.

This apathy also means that consumers are overpaying millions of pounds of interest through taking out costly personal loans. Examples of APRs charged by the major high street banks stretch from 12.9 to 15.9. Anyone borrowing £5,000 through Barclayloan Direct with an APR of 15.9 would repay the loan over three years at £201.07 per month. The repayments on the same advance from Northern Rock, which charges APR 9.1, would cost £158.41 a month.

Elsewhere, American Express Bank has cut its interest rates on personal loans across the board by up to 1.3%. On a personal loan of £10,000 over five years at the new typical APR of 9.2 payments will be £238.17 per month. What's more, American Express card members are eligible for an additional 1% discount on these rates. For loan application procedures tel 0808 1002265.

On solid foundations

In a separate move improveline.com, has set up an online rating service that vets building contractors and other tradesmen for quality and professionalism. The facility will enable users to find out whether a company has had any county court judgments against them or whether they offer guarantees on the work carried out. It will also check that the contractor is holding suitable insurance cover. For full details of the scheme visit www.improveline.com

Net some cover with Tesco

Tesco Motor Insurance is offering a 5% reduction for customers who buy their motor insurance policy on line. Log on to www.tesco.com/finance for a quote and instant cover. Key features include a facility to handle claims over the phone, with no lengthy forms to fill in. It also offers a 24-hour accident recovery helpline plus windscreen repair service.

Halifax kicks off rugby card ...

Halifax has launched a new credit card that will inject cash directly into the coffers of local rugby clubs. Clubs who persuade their members to sign up for its Rugby Round-up credit card will get £10 for each card issued plus it will trigger a commission of 20p per £100 spent on the plastic. A club that converts 500 members or fans to the new plastic would receive a £5,000 windfall plus an estimated £2,000-£3000 per year in commission.

The Halifax card, with a typical APR of 17.9, offers an initial rate of 3.9% for the first five months to cardholders switching their existing debt.

... And MBNA joins the scrum

Picking up the rugby ball MBNA is also trying to reach rugby fans through its deal with the Rugby Football Union in England. It is offering Visa cards with an APR of 15.9 and an initial rate of 2.9 fixed for five months to anyone who transfers their exsting balance from another card issuer. Application forms for The England Rugby Visa Card are available from its helpline on 0800 776 262.

webTitle: You don't have to be rich

fields.headline: You don't have to be rich
fields.standfirst: Parents can still find buy-to-let bargains, says Sandra Steed who last week bought a three-bed home near Manchester University for her daughter who is on a four-year law course
fields.trailText: Parents can still find buy-to-let bargains, says Sandra Steed who last week bought a three-bed home near Manchester University for her daughter who is on a four-year law course.
fields.body:
Ms Steed also proves that you don't have to be a rich landlord. She is a social worker from Stoke on Trent who earns around £21,000 a year, and bought the £50,000 house in Chorlton upon Medlock with a £10,000 deposit and a £40,000 loan from Mortgage Express, arranged by brokers Charcol. The mortgage, to be paid off over 10 years, will cost Ms Steed £448 a month, but the rent from her daughter's three flatmates will total £600 per month.

"Every other parent I spoke to said that, with hindsight, they wished they had bought a place while their children were at university," she says.

"I was horrified by some of the houses I saw in very dodgy areas, but I think I have found something in an up and coming area. I thought it would be a lot of hassle with the mortgage but Charcol took all the fuss out of it."

Her plan is to keep the house after her daughter has graduated: "If I keep it after she leaves then it will be a good pension fund. I'm 48 and I'll have paid off the mortgage by the time I'm 58. I think it's a damn good investment."

webTitle: How to transcend a stressful lifestyle

fields.headline: How to transcend a stressful lifestyle
fields.standfirst: Meditation is helping more and more bosses, says Susie Tempest
fields.trailText: Meditation is helping more and more bosses, says Susie Tempest.
fields.body:
Thank God for the Holy Week and the first long weekend of the year. There are still three more days to go before our noses will be back to the grindstone on Tuesday morning.

Yet many of us find it hard to completely take time out - and rarely do we return to work fully refreshed.

Laptops, mobile phones, palmtops and other gizmos were supposed to liberate us from the tyranny of the workplace, but instead all this office technology is blurring the boundaries between work and the rest of our lives.

For many hard-pressed executives this workstyle is ruling their lifestyle: laptops feature in bedrooms and mobiles interrupt Sunday lunch. But many business leaders have begun to search for a less stressful way of working that does not adversely affect their managerial competence.

Several executives are taking the teachings of Indian mystic the late Maharishi Mahesh Yogi (pictured right) to their hearts and mind. The guru made famous by The Beatles in the 60s advocated transcendental meditation (TM) as a foolproof method that tackles stress at the cause.

The effectiveness of the TM program is no longer in doubt, validated by more than 500 scientific studies at more than 200 independent research institutions in 30 countries. The TM technique requires no belief or lifestyle change, is not time-consuming, and can be learned by anyone regardless of age or level of education.

Practitioners say the results are impressive. TM is said to reduce stress, increase alertness, creativity, intelligence, well-being and motivation; heighten deci sion making and job satisfaction; improve relationships with colleagues and customers and generally increase efficiency at work.

Among its many boardroom followers are broadcaster and business guru, Sir John Harvey-Jones. He believes that TM has helped him and many others find clarity at work, and has contributed to greater efficiency. He says: "Practising TM certainly helps to put business problems into perspective. I think every businessman would benefit from taking time out to meditate."

Martin Creese, managing director of London-based Creese Communications, discovered TM in 1969 whilst at university. Martin puts much of his business success down to TM and he especially com mends TM for the energy and clarity of thought that it gives him. For him TM is "both a management tool and a personal development programme".

Nigel Barlow, another TM enthusiast, runs his own management consultancy, Service Legends. In his book, Batteries Included, about customer service and creativity at work, he shares how he believes TM can help resolve stressful business situations.

Nigel regularly addresses conferences around the world and finds that TM helps to soothe his pre-public speaking nerves. "TM gives me a feeling of inner invincibility which means I can't be fazed," he says. What's more, he adds: "TM is invaluable for getting over the jet lag after a long haul flight."

Nigel encourages his staff to take up meditation and within eight to 10 weeks, people notice a difference in their approach to work. They seem a lot calmer and more energised.

TM is practised for 15 or 20 minutes twice a day, just sitting quietly and comfortably. It could be at home in a chair or on a busy commuter train to work.

During the sitting the individual's awareness settles down and they experience a unique state of restful alertness. As the body becomes deeply relaxed, the mind transcends all mental activity to experience the simplest form of awareness, transcendental consciousness.

The more sceptical executives swear by tennis, jogging, fishing, golf, gardening, reading and listening to soothing music as their antidote to being stressed out. These are all relaxing, enjoyable activities, and provide a welcome change of pace, a break in the routine.

The difference is that TM draws the mind back to its own source, a reservoir of energy, creativity, and intelligence.

There are an estimated 5m practitioners of TM worldwide. Roughly 200,000 of these are based in the UK and this number is growing rapidly. And so is the belief that it works - especially in business.

Moreover, the benefits of TM are cumulative so the longer you do it, the more rewards you reap.
