fields.bodyText: Thank God for the Holy Week and the first long weekend of the year. There are still three more days to go before our noses will be back to the grindstone on Tuesday morning. Yet many of us find it hard to completely take time out - and rarely do we return to work fully refreshed. Laptops, mobile phones, palmtops and other gizmos were supposed to liberate us from the tyranny of the workplace, but instead all this office technology is blurring the boundaries between work and the rest of our lives. For many hard-pressed executives this workstyle is ruling their lifestyle: laptops feature in bedrooms and mobiles interrupt Sunday lunch. But many business leaders have begun to search for a less stressful way of working that does not adversely affect their managerial competence. Several executives are taking the teachings of Indian mystic the late Maharishi Mahesh Yogi (pictured right) to their hearts and mind. The guru made famous by The Beatles in the 60s advocated transcendental meditation (TM) as a foolproof method that tackles stress at the cause. The effectiveness of the TM program is no longer in doubt, validated by more than 500 scientific studies at more than 200 independent research institutions in 30 countries. The TM technique requires no belief or lifestyle change, is not time-consuming, and can be learned by anyone regardless of age or level of education. Practitioners say the results are impressive. TM is said to reduce stress, increase alertness, creativity, intelligence, well-being and motivation; heighten deci sion making and job satisfaction; improve relationships with colleagues and customers and generally increase efficiency at work. Among its many boardroom followers are broadcaster and business guru, Sir John Harvey-Jones. He believes that TM has helped him and many others find clarity at work, and has contributed to greater efficiency. He says: "Practising TM certainly helps to put business problems into perspective. I think every businessman would benefit from taking time out to meditate." Martin Creese, managing director of London-based Creese Communications, discovered TM in 1969 whilst at university. Martin puts much of his business success down to TM and he especially com mends TM for the energy and clarity of thought that it gives him. For him TM is "both a management tool and a personal development programme". Nigel Barlow, another TM enthusiast, runs his own management consultancy, Service Legends. In his book, Batteries Included, about customer service and creativity at work, he shares how he believes TM can help resolve stressful business situations. Nigel regularly addresses conferences around the world and finds that TM helps to soothe his pre-public speaking nerves. "TM gives me a feeling of inner invincibility which means I can't be fazed," he says. What's more, he adds: "TM is invaluable for getting over the jet lag after a long haul flight." Nigel encourages his staff to take up meditation and within eight to 10 weeks, people notice a difference in their approach to work. They seem a lot calmer and more energised. TM is practised for 15 or 20 minutes twice a day, just sitting quietly and comfortably. It could be at home in a chair or on a busy commuter train to work. During the sitting the individual's awareness settles down and they experience a unique state of restful alertness. As the body becomes deeply relaxed, the mind transcends all mental activity to experience the simplest form of awareness, transcendental consciousness. The more sceptical executives swear by tennis, jogging, fishing, golf, gardening, reading and listening to soothing music as their antidote to being stressed out. These are all relaxing, enjoyable activities, and provide a welcome change of pace, a break in the routine. The difference is that TM draws the mind back to its own source, a reservoir of energy, creativity, and intelligence. There are an estimated 5m practitioners of TM worldwide. fields.headline: From the top
fields.trailText: Crocodile Dundee may still leap to mind when we think of Australia, but the island continent is an emerging - and potentially world-class - laboratory for triple bottom line thinking.
fields.body:
Crocodile Dundee may still leap to mind when we think of Australia, but the island continent is an emerging - and potentially world-class - laboratory for triple bottom line thinking.

Wherever you go, in government, business or the fi nancial world, growing numbers of Australians are busy on one aspect or another of the sustainability agenda.

The original focus on ecologically sustainable development is expanding to embrace economic and social dimensions of business and market performance. But times are changing - and early commitments are about to be put to the test.

Recessionary pressures will be the most immediate test, but a controversy has also been raging around the implications for Australian greenhouse emissions policy of President Bush's recent decision to "kill Kyoto", distancing the US from the 1997 greenhouse protocol.

Some Australians unreservedly welcomed news of the US turnaround. "Listen to Europeans and you could be forgiven for thinking George Bush has just sent the world to the gas chamber - the greenhouse gas chamber," was how the economics editor of The Australian newspaper kicked off a no-holds-barred attack on the whole Kyoto process.

Europe's commitment to Kyoto, he argued, has been driven by "quasi-religious green fundamentalism and cynical calculation of commercial advantage".

Well no one's perfect, but maybe Europeans are playing the role that canaries used to have in mines? Travelling around Australia and New Zealand, I have argued we may even be better off with a Republican president who clearly doesn't believe in cli mate change than with a Democrat, or anyone else, who believes in the problem - but can't deliver solutions.

Indeed, there's a strong sense of déjà vu. Companies taking advantage of the Bush announcement to throttle back on their own climate change initiatives should recall what happened to previous Republican presidents.

Peter Kinder of US social investment analysts Kinder Lydenberg Domini & Co (KLD) has a theory. "Each Republican administration since Eisenhower's has entered office determined to 'do something' about the environment," he says.

"Within 18 months, in each case, their industry-centred approach led to a public relations disaster that perma nently strengthened their opponents. With Richard Nixon, it was the Santa Barbara Channel oil well blowout; with Ronald Reagan, it was his political appointees; and with George Bush (the First) it was the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil disaster."

So why have they failed to learn? And what happens next? The second question is easier to answer. NGOs and public interest networks will switch tactics and re-target high profile corporations. These days they have much better intelligence on the corporate sector.

And anyone who has worked with corporations knows that, whichever way their presidential campaign funding may flow, business leaders are much more sensi tive to NGO pressure than they were in the BC (before Clinton) era.

Couple these dynamics with growing corporate transparency - did George Bush the First even know what the internet was when President? - and within 18 months George the Second can expect massive pressure from the corporate sector to do something, anything, to get the NGOs to turn off the political heat.

With the second Earth Summit due in 2002, history may be about to repeat itself for the Republicans.

 John Elkington is chairman of SustainAbility (www.sustainability.co.uk) and co-author of The Global Reporters: The first international survey of corporate sustainability reporting.

fields.headline: Jerry Roest Head of NTL, Broadband Internet
fields.trailText: What was your first career aspiration?
fields.body:
What was your first career aspiration?

To become a great salesman.

What has been your best moment in management?

Launching the UK's first mainstream unmetered internet service in March 2000.

And your greatest mistake?

Taking on the managing directorship of an innovative, but underfunded, online property information business in 1989; then came the property crash.

How would you describe your management style?

An adrenalin fix for those I manage.

Which deal would you most like to have done?

The one done by John Pluthero (Freeserve) in 1998 bringing subscription-free internet to the world.

What do you find most annoying in your staff?

Apathy.

Does your organisation have a glass ceiling?

Not that I am aware of.

What management wisdom is most over-rated?

Be cautious my son, be cautious.

What is the biggest challenge facing your industry?

Educating the world about the benefits of broadband.

What single lesson would you pass on to budding managers?

Learn to be interested in people... I mean really be interested - not an act.

Which management guru do you believe in?

I have met several managers whom I admire enormously. People like David Bell at Pearson combine the talent for big company management with a wonderful gentlemanly style... And Barclay Knapp for his ability to enthuse others to aspire to greatness.

Who is your management hero?

Winston Churchill - great leader, great organiser and a winner.

Who is your favourite politician?

Michael Foot for his oratory, Edward Heath for winning the Admiral's Cup in 1971.

If you could change one aspect of British business, what would it be?

Make it more exciting.

Do you have a view on British membership of the EMU?

We need to do it, but only when the time is propitious to the UK.

What phrase or saying do you most over-use?

Life isn't fair, it is what you make of it.

Apart from quality time with your family, what else makes you happiest in life?

Being effective and recognised for it.

What annoys you most?

Lack of commitment.

How do you relax?

Sailing a 40ft ketch in the Solent.

What is your favourite city?

Boston, USA.

What is your greatest regret?

That my illness three years ago (brain haemorrhage) left me slightly disabled and unable to do some of the physical things that I used to take for granted, though I can still sail!

What is your biggest fear?

Being ignored...

What would you really like to have been?

A great footballer playing along- side Best, Charlton and Law.
